DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Dec. 1, or the 17th day of the 10th month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1640: Portugal becomes independent again after the Portuguese under the leadership of John IV drive out the Spaniards.
1887: Portugal secures the secession of Macau from China's Ching court.
1918: The Danish parliament passes an act giving independence to Iceland.
1921: With the United States and Britain as mediators, representatives of China and Japan hold negotiations on the issue of the Shantung dispute on the sidelines of a meeting in Washington.
1922: Henry Pu Yi, the last emperor of the Manchu dynasty, and Wan Yung, daughter of Yung Yuan, a former minister in the Ching court, hold their wedding ceremony in Beijing's Forbidden City.
1927: The Republic of China's Chiang Kai-shek and Soong Mayling hold a wedding ceremony witnessed by Tsai Yuan-pei in Shanghai.
1932: The government of the Republic of China, which was moved to Loyang on Jan. 30 due to the Japanese invasion, moves back to Nanjing.
1935: Chiang Kai-shek is elected chairman of the Kuomintang, the ruling party of China.
1936: Chinese Communist Party leaders, including Mao Tse-tung, Chu Teh, and Chou En-lai, send a letter to Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek asking him to allow the CCP to join the war against Japan to save the country.
1951: Communist Chinese troops enter Lhasa, Tibet.
1956: Chiang Kai-shek finishes his book titled "Soviet Russia in China."
1959: Twelve members of the United Nations, including the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain, Japan, and France, sign a treaty in Washington stipulating that the South Pole region will be used for peaceful purposes such as scientific exploration and that no military bases will be allowed.
1961: The first nuclear reactor in the Republic of China, installed by scientists from the National Tsinghua University campus in Hsinchu, is put into operation.
1962: India rejects mainland Chinese proposals for a cease-fire and negotiations over disputed territory.
1969: The ROC government sets up the Armed Forces University, with Yu Po-chuen serving as commandant and Chiang Wei-kuo as vice commandant.
1971: A total of 43 miners of the Keelung Coalmine Company are killed in an accident at the Chisingkeng mine in northern Taiwan.
1972: The ROC and Ivory Coast sign a trade agreement.
1973: A total of 14 seamen go missing when the Tatung, a freighter plying the route between the southern Taiwan city of Kaohsiung and Makung, in the Penghu archipelago, sinks.
1973: The Kuomintang selects 45 candidates for the Taipei City Council election. Sixty-three candidates fight for 49 seats.
1976: A metalworking trade mission representing leading U.S. companies arrives in Taipei for an eight-day visit.
1979: Jurisdiction of the Central Bank of China is moved from the Presidential Office to the Executive Yuan.
1987: Eight people are killed in a fire blamed on arson at a job-training center on the ROC-controlled Green Island.
1987: The Ministry of Education announces that National Chungcheng University will be established in Minhsiung Village, Chiayi County and will begin admitting students in the 1989 academic year.
1988: Benazir Bhutto is nominated to be prime minister of Pakistan, becoming the first woman elected to govern a Muslim nation.
1988: The Executive Yuan announces guidelines governing unofficial participation in international academic conferences and cultural and athletic activities held in mainland China, as well as regulations governing visits to Taiwan by overseas mainland Chinese scholars and students.
1989: Mikhail Gorbachev becomes the first Soviet leader to visit the Vatican and meet the Pope, ending 70 years of mutual hostility between the USSR and the Vatican.
1999: The first batch of the two-in-one lottery tickets issued by the Central Bank of China go on sale, causing a buying spree around the island.
Motse's lesson of the day: "There are many rulers in the world but few are magnanimous. For everybody to imitate the ruler is to imitate the unmagnanimous. Imitating the unmagnanimous cannot be taken as following the right standard."

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY (DEC. 2)

TEXT.P: Today is Sunday, Dec. 2, or the 18th day of the 10th month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1804: Monarchy returns to France when Napoleon Bonaparte crowns himself Emperor Napoleon I at Notre Dame, 11 years after King Louis XVI was guillotined.
1815: The Rajah of Nepal signs peace treaty with Britain.
1823: U.S. President James Monroe, introducing his "Monroe Doctrine," warns Europe to keep its hands off both American continents.
1901: King Camp Gillette markets a safety razor with a double-edged disposable blade in the United States.
1908: Henry Pu Yi, the last emperor of the Ching dynasty, is crowned emperor of China at the age of three.
1911: Chinese revolutionaries capture Nanjing.
1923: The Young China Party sets up in Paris, France.
1942: A nuclear chain reaction is demonstrated for the first time by American scientists working on a secret project in Chicago.
1954: Republic of China Foreign Minister George K.C. Yeh signs the Sino-American Mutual Defense Treaty with U.S. Secretary of State John Foster Dulles in Washington.
1965: The World Health Organization formally recognizes Taiwan as free of malaria.
1968: The Taiwan Power Company signs an agreement with the World Bank for a loan of US$50 million for construction of the Dachien Dam.
1971: Soviet Union spaceship "Mars III" lands on Mars.
1974: The Fifth Asian Congress of Pharmaceutical Sciences opens a four-day meeting in Taipei.
1974: The Young China Party celebrates its 51st anniversary.
1976: The Fourth Asian Composers' League Conference holds its closing ceremony, with more than 100 delegates and observers from 20 countries attending.
1976: The ROC's "Hai Kung" research vessel leaves Keelung for an expedition to Antarctica.
1988: A cyclone packing winds in excess of 177 kph hits Bangladesh, killing thousands and leaving more than 5 million homeless.
1986: The Chunghwa (ROC) Blues and the Chunghwa Whites win 1st and 2nd places, respectively in the Third International Baseball Tournament.
1989: V.P. Singh, leader of the Janata Dal Party, replaces Rajiv Gandhi as prime minister of India.
1989: Elections are held for the Legislative Yuan, Taiwan Provincial Assembly, Taipei and Kaohsiung municipal councils, county magistrates, and provincial-level city mayors.
1990: Chancellor Helmut Kohl's center-right coalition wins re-election in the first elections since 1932 involving all of Germany.
1994: A ferry carrying more than 600 people collides with a freighter and sinks in Manila Bay, the Philippines. Sixty bodies are recovered, and 85 people remain missing.
1995: The ROC elects 164 lawmakers to the Third Legislative Yuan.
1995: A Singapore court sentences former Barings Bank trader Nick Leeson to six-and-a-half years in prison for his part in the crash of Britain's oldest merchant bank.
1996: ROC Foreign Minister John Chang departs for South Africa.
1997: After a bitter power struggle with Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif, President Farooq Leghari of Pakistan resigns.
1999: The Republic of China signs a formal aviation agreement with Palau as part of its efforts to facilitate exchanges between the two countries.

Motse's lesson of the day: "Heaven is all-inclusive and impartial in its activities, abundant and unceasing in its blessings, and lasting and untiring in its guidance. And so, when the sage-kings had accepted heaven as their standard, they measured every action and enterprise by heaven. What heaven desired they would carry out, what heaven abominated they refrained from."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HOLDS LEGISLATIVE, LOCAL ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: Taiwan held legislative and local elections Saturday to elect 225 legislators and 23 magistrates and mayors, the first since the Democratic Progressive Party took power in May 2000.
Voting began at 8 a.m. and was to last through 4 p.m., with vote counting to start shortly after the end of the polling.
The Central Election Commission (CEC) said it expected vote counting to be completed by 9:30 p.m.
The CEC urged the public not to sell their votes, saying that candidates caught buying votes will face a maximum jail term of five years and a fine of between NT$400,000 and NT$6 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: MINOR, SPORADIC INCIDENTS REPORTED ON ELECTION DAY

TEXT.P: Although Saturday's legislative and local elections were going smoothly nationwide, some small, sporadic electoral incidents occurred in some polling stations.
A young woman surnamed Yang in the southern port city of Kaohsiung tore up her ballot sheet in a fit of petulance after she was accused of making too much noise in the polling station.

She was brought to a nearby police station for questioning and is likely to face a fine ranging from NT$5,000 to NT$50,000 for violating the Public Officials Election and Recall Law, according to Kaohsiung election officials.
A male voter in Taipei's Chungshan district tore up his ballot sheet after he found he had mistakenly used his personal chop rather than the designated polling chop.
He was also questioned by police for violating the election and recall law and was facing a fine.

A similar incident occurred in the central city of Changhua, while in the eastern city of Hualien, law enforcement authorities were undecided on what to do after a man reportedly cast two ballots instead of one.
According to polling station officials, they were too late to stop him casting the second ballot and were puzzled as to how the man had two ballot sheets instead of one.

Polling was taking place in 13,511 polling stations set up around Taiwan and on the offshore counties of Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu for the election of legislators, city mayors and county magistrates during an eight-hour period between 8 a.m. and 4 p.m.
In the hotly contested legislative elections, 455 hopefuls were competing for 176 seats up for grabs, giving each candidate, 140 of whom are seeking re-election, a 38.68 percent chance.
In the elections for mayors and county chiefs, 88 candidates were battling for 23 seats up for grabs islandwide in an even more severe competition with an election rate of 26 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN GOES TO POLLS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian went to the polls Saturday to cast his votes in the legislative and local elections.
Chen and his wife were accompanied by Chairman Huang Shi-cheng of the Central Election Commission and Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou.
Asked who he voted for, Chen replied only that he had "voted for the ones that should be voted for" and he urged the country's voters to get out and cast their ballots.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEC URGES VOTERS TO POLLING STATIONS IN FACE OF POOR INITIAL TURNOUT

TEXT.P: Polling at more than 13,000 polling stations nationwide for legislative and local elections was lukewarm as of noon Saturday, prompting the Central Election Commission (CEC) to urge voters to get out and vote.
CEC authorities urged them to take advantage of the election to choose "ideal and capable" lawmakers and public officials to serve the people and the country.
Despite the poor turnout in the morning, CEC officials were confident that the total voting rate nationwide would reach at least 72 percent by 4 p.m. when polling ends.

The officials said they expected vote counting at the 13,511 polling stations set up around Taiwan and on the offshore counties of Penghu, Kinman and Matsu to conclude before 9:30 p.m. at the latest and that the election results would be released almost simultaneously, thanks to the computerized tallying system.
Some 15.82 million voters were eligible to cast their votes to directly elect 176 legislators from among 584 candidates, 140 of whom were seeking re-election -- an election rate of 38.68 percent.

Of the 584 legislative candidates, 434 hopefuls were competing for 168 seats up for grabs in various constituencies, while 21 aboriginal candidates were vying for eight seats reserved exclusively for aborigines.

In the elections for mayors and county chiefs, 88 candidates were battling for 23 seats up for grabs nationwide in an even more severe competition, with an election rate of 26 percent. Some 12.835 million voters were eligible to vote in these elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Saturday are as follows:

DOC.HEADLINE: HOPEFUL FOR TAIPEI COUNTY MAGISTRATE MULLING SOLVING FLOODING ISSUE
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei County, northern Taiwan, Dec. 1 (CNA) (By David Hsu)

TEXT.P: A candidate for the post of Taipei county magistrate said Saturday after casting his votes in Taiwan's legislative and local government chief elections that he had "already begun" mulling county administrative affairs.

Wang Chien-shien, a candidate of the opposition "pan-blue alliance" made up of the Kuomintang, the People First Party and the New Party, expressed confidence in his chances and added that his main priority if elected will be solving the county's perennial flooding problems.

DOC.HEADLINE: VOTING ENDS IN TAIWAN'S LEGISLATIVE, LOCAL ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: Voting in Taiwan's hard-fought legislative and local government chief elections ended at 4 p.m. Saturday, with initial results expected to come out within the hour.
A record 584 candidates were contesting 225 legislative seats while 88 hopefuls vied for five mayoral and 18 county magistrate posts. Competition was extremely fierce.

The elections came 18 months after the island's first-ever peaceful transition of power between different political parties and the poll results are expected to shake up Taiwan's political landscape if the former ruling and now opposition Kuomintang (KMT) loses its absolute majority in the new legislature as is widely anticipated.

None of the parties were expected to emerge from the legislative elections with an absolute majority, but the KMT still had a good chance of winning the largest number of seats in the new legislature.

On the eve of the polls, the KMT predicted it would win 90 parliamentary seats, down from the 110 it held prior to the voting. The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), which controls barely one-third of the seats at present, was expecting to win at least 85 seats.
Voting proceeded smoothly overall, with only minor isolated incidents reported in a few constituencies.

The number of eligible voters in the legislative elections reached more than 15.82 million, while the number of eligible voters in the local-level elections exceeded 12.83 million. Voter turnout was not expected to be as high as in last year's presidential elections, which was between 77 percent and 78 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER TO LEAD CABINET RESIGNATION AFTER NEW LEGISLATURE FORMS

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Saturday that he will lead the Cabinet in an en masse resignation before the new legislature opens its inaugural session Feb. 1, 2002 as stipulated in the Republic of China Constitution.
Chang made the statement in the southern port city of Kaohsiung, where he cast his votes for the elections of legislators and local government chiefs.

Quoting former Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Huang Hsin-chieh, who once said that elections are a happy occasion worthy of celebration, Chang urged the nation's eligible voters to choose the right candidates.
He also called for the candidates to compete "like gentlemen" and to accept the election results that represent the decision of the voters.
Earlier in the day, both Chang and President Chen Shui-bian attended a ceremony to open the 2001 Taiwan Information Technology Month in Taipei.

Addressing the opening ceremony, Chen said elections are transient and temporary, but the progress of national development, including the evolution of the information technology industry, is "forever and fundamental."

Chang, who also spoke at the ceremony, said that the conclusion of Saturday's elections "would also signal the end of all mudslinging and off-message days" and he called for all concerned to accept the voters' decision.
He urged the people of Taiwan to "replace confrontation with cooperation" and strive with the "Taiwan spirit" to enable the country to surpass its challenges and difficulties.

He added that the administration will try even harder in the face of the recession, but noted that the administration has made "noticeable achievements" over the past one-and-a-half years, including enabling the 91.6 percent completion of the country's public construction projects and initiating sweeping financial reforms.

On the development of cross-Taiwan Strait relations, Chang noted that Taiwan has decided to open its tourism market to mainland Chinese visitors and has lifted a ban on 122 computer hardware-related industries relocating their manufacturing operations to the Chinese mainland, in the hope that the long-imposed "no haste, be patient" policy will be replaced by a more open, pragmatic approach.

Chang continued that soon after Taiwan becomes a formal member of the World Trade Organization (WTO) early next year, it will have to open its markets -- worth between US$6 billion and US$8 billion -- to foreign companies, while other WTO members are expected to open their markets -- with a total value of about US$200 billion -- to Taiwan companies.

DOC.HEADLINE: THREE CANDIDATES DECLARE THEMSELVES ELECTED COUNTY HEADS

TEXT.P: People First Party Secretary-General Chung Jung-chi declared early Saturday evening that the party's candidate for Lienchiang county magistrate is expected to win according to a preliminary vote tally.
Chung said Chen Hsueh-sheng had already won more than 56 percent of the ballot as of 5:30 p.m.
The prediction was not confirmed by the Central Election Commission, which is in charge of vote-counting.
A few minutes earlier, New Party candidate for Kinmen county magistrate Lee Chu-feng had declared himself winner, just one hour and 20 minutes after the polling stations closed.
Lee thanked the voters, saying that they made a wise choice.
Lai Feng-wei, the incumbent Kuomintang magistrate of Penghu County who was running for re-election, also declared himself winner before the official outcome was announced.
Lai said he had already garnered more than half of the ballots cast.

DOC.HEADLINE: INCUMBENT TAICHUNG CITY MAYOR CONCEDES DEFEAT

TEXT.P: Incumbent Taichung City Mayor Chang Wen-ying conceded defeat in her re-election bid at around 6 p.m. Saturday.

Chang delivered a concession speech at her campaign headquarters two hours after vote counting began, by which time she had garnered only slightly more than 27,000 ballots, far behind the two front-runners.

The outgoing mayor quit the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to run as an independent in the central Taiwan city after the party nominated Tsai Ming-hsien as its standard-bearer in the mayoral race.
Saying she had yet to decide her future career plan, Chang added her hope that her successor would continue the city government's various development plans.
A factional split in the DPP enabled Kuomintang candidate Jason Hu, a former Republic of China minister of foreign affairs, to win the mayorship with a comfortable majority.

DOC.HEADLINE: KUOMINTANG WINS TAOYUAN COUNTY

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang-nominated Chu Li-lun announced Saturday evening that he had won the election of Taoyuan county mayor, which had previously been governed by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).
The 41-year-old scholar-turned-legislator said that he would seek the cooperation of all political parties for the "construction" of the county.
Chu beat the DPP nominee, Perng Shaw-jin, also a legislator, and independent candidate Chuan Chih-chuan.
In the last local elections in 1997, the KMT candidate lost to Vice President Annette Lu, who got 56.2 percent of the vote.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT ACCUSES DPP OF LIBEL IN ELECTION DAY AD

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) accused the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) of libel Saturday for describing the KMT in a newspaper ad that day as a "blue monster that gobbles up votes today and will gobble up banknotes tomorrow."

The KMT filed a lawsuit against the DPP at the Taipei Prosecutors' Office and charged that the DPP also violated the Public Officials Election and Recall Law by carrying out campaign activities on election day.
In response, DPP Secretary-General Wu Nai-jen said that it is up to the Central Election Commission (CEC) to decide whether or not the ad was a campaign activity.

CEC Chairman Huang Shih-cheng said that the ad did indeed violate the election law, but that the CEC is powerless to mete out punishment in the form of a fine because the law only allows the imposition of such fines if the violating party continues its illegal action in spite of a CEC warning.

Huang added that a draft amendment bill currently awaiting ratification in the Legislative Yuan will plug the legal loophole and raise the maximum allowable fine for such violations from the current NT$100,000 (US$2,900) to NT$5 million (US$145,000).

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT WINS TAICHUNG MAYORSHIP

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang candidate Jason Hu announced his victory in the hotly contested Taichung City mayoral election Saturday.

Hu, a former minister of foreign affairs and Republic of China representative to the United States, made the announcement after he garnered a total of 200,000 ballots in the first two hours of vote counting.
His two rivals -- incumbent Mayor Chang Wen-ying and Tsai Ming-hsien, an incumbent legislator who represented the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) in the race -- conceded defeat.

Hu thanked the citizens of the central Taiwan city for their support and praised his rivals for their sportsmanship. He also expressed his pleasure with the improvements in the city's election culture, noting that the race was generally free of the "contamination" of vote-buying, violence and mud-slinging.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE SELF-DECLARED WINNERS IN RACE FOR LOCAL GOVERNMENT POSTS

TEXT.P: Ilan County Magistrate Liu Shou-cheng, a Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) candidate running for re-election, declared himself winner in the race Saturday.
Lin Tsung-nan, a DPP candidate in Nantou County, also claimed victory, while Weng Chin-chu, also a DPP member, declared herself winner in Changhua County.
Su Huan-chih, also a DPP candidate, declared himself winner in Tainan County, while Yang Chiu-hsing, the DPP candidate for Kaohsiung County, also declared himself winner.
Another DPP candidate, Su Chia-chuan, declared victory in Pingtung County.
Meanwhile, Kuomintang candidate for Keelung city mayor Hsu Tsai-li declared victory over his DPP rival, incumbent Mayor Lee Chin-yung.

DOC.HEADLINE: INCUMBENTS IN MIAOLI, PINGTUNG COUNTIES RE-ELECTED

TEXT.P: Incumbent Miaoli County Magistrate Fu Hsueh-peng, an independent candidate, and Pingtung County Magistrate Su Jia-quan of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) were both re-elected Saturday.
Fu, with more than 130,000 votes, had already beaten his opponents -- Kuomintang (KMT) nominee Hsu Shiang-kueen and DPP nominee Wei Chao-ping.
Su established an early lead when vote counting began and at 6:30 p.m. announced victory over Wang Chi-shih of the KMT and independent candidate Li chin-wei.
In Hualien County meanwhile, KMT candidate Chang Fu-hsing beat DPP candidate Yu Yin-lun and People First Party candidate Lai Cheng-hsiang.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI COUNTY MAGISTRATE WINS RE-ELECTION BID

TEXT.P: Taipei County Magistrate Su Tsen-chang announced at around 7 p.m. Saturday success in his bid to win a second term in office after taking a moderate lead over his closest rival.

Su, a standard-bearer of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), beat Wang Chien-hsien, who ran on behalf of the tripartite opposition alliance of the Kuomintang (KMT), the People First Party (PFP) and the New Party (NP).
By the time he made his victory announcement, Su had garnered slightly more than half of the ballots cast in the hard-fought race in what is, demographically speaking, the island's largest county.
Su said his win marks recognition of his administrative credentials over the past four years and he expressed deep gratitude for the voter support.
Wang, a founder of the tiny NP, said that despite his defeat, he appreciated the voter support as well as the enormous assistance extended to him by the two other opposition parties.
"The election has set a model for the integration of the KMT and its two splinter groups," Wang said.

The heated one-on-one duel had been widely seen as a test of strength between the DPP and the opposition alliance. Some analysts also said it gave the electorate a foretaste of the next presidential election in 2004, in which President Chen Shui-bian is certain to be pitted against a tripartite standard bearer.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. APPLICANTS FOR ROC VISAS TO BE CHARGED US$45
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Nov. 30 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: Officials of the Republic of China representative office in San Francisco have been busy processing a last rush of ROC visa applications since the ROC Foreign Ministry announced five months ago that the visas would no longer be free.
From Dec. 1, the ministry will charge US$45 for each ROC visa application for U.S. passport hlders, basing its measure on equality and reciprocity.
Until now, the ROC Foreign Ministry has not charged any fees for ROC visa applications for U.S. passport holders, while the U.S. side has collected fees for U.S. visa applications.
The average number of ROC visa applications in the past three days had increased to 90 from the usual 50, according to officials at the representative office.

The officials noted that U.S. passport-holders intending to stay in Taiwan for more than 14 days can also apply for an ROC landing visa upon arrival in the ROC but will face an additional US$24 handling fee.
U.S. passport-holders who stay in the ROC for less than 14 days do not need a visa.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRO-UNIFICATION NEW PARTY WINS KINMEN COUNTY CHIEF ELECTION

TEXT.P: The pro-unification opposition New Party claimed its first county chief election victory Saturday in the tiny county of Kinmen, only a stone's throw away from the southeastern coast of mainland China.

With all the votes counted and the party's victory all but official, awaiting only a formal announcement from the Central Election Commission, County Magistrate-elect Lee Chu-feng said that he will establish Kinmen as a bridge in cross-Taiwan Strait relations and a starting point for cross-strait integration.
An incumbent legislator, Lee emerged victorious on a campaign platform that included a pledge to improve transportation infrastructure and boost tourism on the island.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP WINS CHIAYI MAGISTRATESHIP; KMT CAPTURES TAICHUNG COUNTY

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) won the magistrateship of the southern county of Chiayi for the first time Saturday, while the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) captured Taichung County.
DPP candidate Chen Ming-wen announced his victory over KMT rival Weng Chung-chun at 6:30 p.m., by which time he was leading Weng by 8,435 ballots.

Chen, who campaigned on a platform of "ending factional strife and `black gold' politics" in the rural southern county, said his success is an indication of county residents' distaste for vote-buying and for the links between politics and organized crime.
In the central county of Taichung, KMT candidate Huang chung-sheng beat incumbent DPP Magistrate Liao Yung-lai by a comfortable margin.
An intraparty factional split resulted in the KMT's loss of the magistrateship to Liao in the last local elections in 1997.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIST OF NEW HEADS OF CITIES AND COUNTIES IN TAIWAN AREA

TEXT.P: According to preliminary results of Saturday's local elections, the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), which controlled 12 of the country's 23 counties and cities before the election, won only nine to tie with its arch-rival the Kuomintang (KMT), which controlled only eight counties before the elections.
The People First Party (PFP) won Lienchiang and Taitung counties, while the tiny New Party won Kinmen County.
Independents won Miaoli County and Chiayi City.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER CALLS FOR RESPECT FOR ELECTION OUTCOME

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung called Saturday for respect for the outcome of the elections of lawmakers and local government heads.
The premier inspected the vote-counting center of the Central Election Commission Saturday evening, just hours after the close of polling stations around the island.
He thanked the election officials for the calm balloting, saying that they helped the government stage fair and clean elections.
The premier also encouraged losing candidates to devote their energy to serving the country in other ways.

Lienchiang County, Chen Hsueh-sheng (PFP)

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP PERFORMS WELL IN TAIPEI, KAOHSIUNG LEGISLATIVE RACES

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) performed better than expected in Taiwan's two largest cities -- Taipei and Kaohsiung -- in Saturday's legislative elections.

On the eve of the polls, DPP Chairman Frank Hsieh said the party had to win at least 13 seats in the metropolitan Taipei and Kaohsiung constituencies if it wants to emerge as the largest party in the new Legislative Yuan.
In the event, the party won a total of 14 legislative seats in the two constituencies, with all six candidates fielded by the party in the southern port city of Kaohsiung managing to win.
In Taipei, the DPP fielded a total of 10 candidates for the city's two precincts, eight of whom emerged victorious.
Also in Taipei, the opposition People First Party (PFP) won six of the 20 legislative seats up for grabs.

The opposition Kuomintang (KMT), which ruled the island for 55 years prior to the 2000 presidential election, captured only four parliamentary seats in Taipei. Although the party lost the presidency last year, it still controls a majority in the current legislature.
None of the tiny opposition New Party candidates managed to win in the hard-fought Taipei and Kaohsiung races.

In contrast, the newly formed Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) managed won a seat in Taipei, with the city's remaining legislative seat going to independent candidate Sisy Chen, a former DPP spokeswoman.
The TSU, with former President Lee Teng-hui as its "spiritual leader," also managed to win two seats in Kaohsiung.
The KMT won only two seats in Kaohsiung and the PFP managed to capture one.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT WINS IN SIX PREVIOUSLY DPP-RULED COUNTIES AND CITIES

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) candidates won the city and county magistrate elections in six cities and counties previously governed by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), but lost Changhwa and Chiayi counties to the DPP.
KMT candidates beat the DPP incumbents in Taichung City, Hsinchu City, Keelung City, Taichung County, Hsinchu County, and Taoyuan County.

In Taiwan's local government chief elections Saturday, KMT and DPP candidates each won nine of the 23 positions and the People First Party (PFP) won Taitung County in eastern Taiwan and Lienchiang County, while the New Party managed to win Kinmen County.
In the 1977 local elections, the DPP won 12 of the 23 positions, the KMT got eight and independent candidates won three.
The KMT failed to beat their opponents in central Taiwan and the traditionally DPP-dominated southern Taiwan.

Even KMT heavyweight former Justice Minister Yeh Chin-fong was unable to prevent DPP candidate Wong Chin-chu, a legislator, from taking over in Changhwa County. A similar setback for the KMT occurred in Chiayi County when DPP candidate Chen Ming-wen, a legislator, beat KMT candidate Wong Chung-chun, also a legislator.

Newly elected Taoyuan County Magistrate Chu Li-lun, Hsinchu County Magistrate Cheng Yung-chin, Hsinchu City Mayor Lin Jung-jzer and Hualien County Magistrate Chang Fu-hsing are also incumbent legislators.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PRESIDENT `SATISFIED' WITH TSU'S PERFORMANCE: TSU CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui is "very satisfied" with the performance of the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) in its first legislative elections, TSU Chairman Huang Chu-wen said Saturday.
Huang said that his party "fought a good battle" by claiming 13 of the 225 legislative seats.

Predicting that the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) will splinter again after the elections, with the possibility that some KMT legislators may defect to the TSU, Huang said that the poll results show that voters have "abandoned" the KMT.
He added that the election results also show that the TSU did not take away votes from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party.
The TSU was formed in August by Lee supporters and considers the former KMT chairman -- who was expelled from the KMT in September -- to be its "spiritual leader."

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE CHIEF TO RUN FOR RE-ELECTION

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng said Saturday he will seek another term as parliament speaker in the next legislature.
Wang, who entered the Legislative Yuan in 1976, was re-elected with the second highest number of votes among the candidates in Kaohsiung County.
Brushing aside speculation about his future, the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) stalwart said that he will not make contact with other political parties or groups.

Regarding a "National Stabilization Alliance" proposed by President Chen Shui-bian and a "Political Affairs Advisory Group" proposed by former President Lee Teng-hui, Wang said negotiations will be conducted on a party to party basis and that he will not betray the KMT.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW PARTY CABINET OFFICIAL LAMENTS PARTY'S LEGISLATIVE DEFEAT

TEXT.P: Environmental Protection Administrator Hau Lung-bin, the only opposition New Party member in the Cabinet, said Saturday that he was surprised that a number of "outstanding" legislators were not re-elected that day.

Hau expressed regret over the election defeat of New Party lawmakers such as Hsieh Chi-ta and Lai Shyh-bao, as well as opposition Kuomintang legislator Ting Shou-chung and independent legislator Shih Ming-te.
The pro-unification New Party won only one out of 225 seats -- down from its previous nine seats in the current Legislative Yuan.
The sole New Party legislative victory was in Kinmen County, which lies only kilometers from the southeastern coast of mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CREDITS ITS ELECTION SUCCESS TO VOTE-DISTRIBUTING STRATEGY

TEXT.P: The Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) credits its better-than-expected Taipei City results in Saturday's legislative elections to its last-minute strategy of distributing its supporters' votes among its candidates, according to a DPP official.

The strategy -- designed to optimize the party's support base in Taipei City -- entailed asking DPP followers to vote for a DPP candidate according to the last number of their National Identification Card.

The party fielded 10 candidates in the two Taipei City constituencies, so it designated two single-digit numbers for each and asked voters to vote according to the last digit on their ID cards, thereby ensuring that each candidate would get an equal number of votes from DPP supporters.
The plan succeeded in returning four lawmakers each in Taipei's two constituencies in Saturday's elections.
Even the two DPP losers -- one in each district -- were defeated by only small margins, with one of them only 600 ballots shy of winning a seat at the legislature.

A DPP official in Shilin, a suburb of Taipei City, said his party was both surprised and pleased with the results, because many DPP rank-and-file members were skeptical of the vote distribution strategy.
However, the official went on, DPP supporters were spurred into following the plan when a newspaper survey predicted that only four of the 10 candidates would be elected.

Lan Shih-chung, the sole DPP loser in Taipei's First Electoral District was only 1,000 to 2,000 votes behind his closest rival and Chou Po-ya, the sole DPP loser in the Second Electoral District was just 600 votes short of winning.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT HEAD LAUDS TAIWAN ELECTIONS
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 1 (CNA) (By Herman Pan & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: The just-concluded elections in Taiwan underline the dynamic democracy on the island, American Institute in Taiwan Chairman Richard Bush said late Saturday.

Noting that democracy is a reinforcing factor in the relations between Washington and Taipei, Bush said the elections illustrate the thriving democracy in Taiwan and added that the biggest winners in the elections are the Taiwan people themselves.

Bush said he did not expect any dramatic changes in bilateral ties with the emergence of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party as the majority party in the legislature, pointing out that the party has already been in power for 18 months.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT SUFFERS GREAT SETBACK IN LEGISLATIVE ELECTION

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) lost its position as the largest party in the Legislative Yuan Saturday, winning only 68 seats as compared with the 87 seats won by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

KMT Chairman Lien Chan said that the party will make a "thorough review" of the unsatisfactory results and that as the biggest opposition party in the legislature, will try to achieve consensus among all political parties through negotiation.

Saturday's election saw the DPP attain the legislative majority with 87 seats, followed by the KMT with 68 seats. The People First Party (PFP) won 46 seats and the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) got 13 seats. The New Party (NP) had the biggest setback of all, winning just one seat.
Until the election, the KMT held 115 seats in the Legislative Yuan, followed by the DPP with 67 seats, the PFP with 17 seats, the NP with nine seats and independents with 12 seats.
Nearly 30 KMT legislators failed to obtain re-election, including some who had led in pre-election opinion surveys.
Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou expressed deep regret that most KMT legislators from Taipei seeking re-election had failed. Among the eight KMT nominees in Taipei, only four were elected.

The mayor, who is concurrently a member of the KMT's Central Standing Committee, said that the results signify a transition of political generations, as new faces and more media-savvy candidates are now able to garner more voter support.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP EMERGES AS LARGEST PARTY IN LEGISLATURE

TEXT.P: Despite Taiwan's lingering recession, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) managed to score a landslide win in Saturday's legislative elections.
"We have officially become the largest party in the Legislative Yuan," DPP Chairman Frank Hsieh told a news conference at the party's headquarters. "We have won a total of 87 legislative seats."
Hsieh said the DPP had garnered 69 of the 176 directly elected legislative seats and 18 proportional representation seats.

"The electoral outcome provides a solid foundation for President Chen Shui-bian's plan to form a broad-based, cross-party alliance to end the parliamentary gridlock and maintain domestic political stability," Hsieh said.
He said that although the general economic environment is unfavorable to the ruling party, the DPP managed nevertheless to win in the parliamentary elections.
"This result signifies the electorate's desire for political stability," Hsieh said, adding that the outcome also reflects the popular expectation of further domestic reform.

The DPP took control the presidency last year, but its first 17 months in power have been characterized by legislative gridlock and bickering. Saturday's parliamentary electoral victory gives the DPP the clout it needs to smooth its rule, Hsieh said.
"We deeply appreciate the voter support and will redouble our efforts to push for economic recovery and sweeping domestic reforms," he pledged.
Hsieh further said the elections mark a victory for all the people of Taiwan as the nation has taken yet another stride toward becoming a mature democracy.

According to Hsieh, the increase in the number of legislative seats controlled by the DPP and the newly formed Taiwan Solidarity Union's (TSU's) capture of 13 seats indicate that middle-of-the-road, mainstream values have received widespread recognition.

In the run-up to Saturday's polls, the DPP and the TSU, with former President Lee Teng-hui as its "spiritual leader," were dubbed the "pan green" alliance as they share similar ideals of stressing Taiwan's separate identity and keeping mainland China at arm's length.
Hsieh said the electoral outcome also proves that the DPP's efforts to move toward the middle-of-the-road from its original pro-independence platform have been the right choice.

Commenting on the tiny opposition New Party's failure to garner the 5 percent of the vote it needed to qualify for proportional representation legislative seats, Hsieh said the result indicates that the party's support for the Beijing-proposed "one country, two systems" scheme for the unification of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait runs against the popular will of the people of Taiwan.

Hsieh also hailed the fact that several candidates with links to organized crime lost their electoral bids. "This indicates that the government's crackdown on vote-buying and `black gold' politics has paid off and that Taiwan has made further progress in democratic development," he noted.

In future, Hsieh went on, Taiwan's party politics will be characterized by competition among two large parties -- the DPP and the Kuomintang, which won 68 seats in the latest polls -- and a medium-sized party -- the People First Party, which garnered 46 seats.
Turning to the local government chief elections that also took place Saturday, Hsieh noted that the party captured only nine mayoral and magistrate posts.

Nevertheless, he said, the DPP still managed to control the administration of cities and counties in central and southern Taiwan, with the exception of Yunlin County. "The population of the DPP-controlled cities and counties account for 54 percent of the total," he said, but he admitted that the party should step up its efforts to increase its strength in the eastern part of the island.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR OPTIMISTIC ABOUT CONSOLIDATION OF POLITICAL PARTIES

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said Saturday that the joint nomination of Wang Chien-shien by three parties as candidate for Taipei county magistrate "proves the feasibility" of consolidating the strength of the Kuomintang (KMT), the People First Party (PFP) and the New Party (NP).

Despite Wang's defeat to incumbent Taipei County Magistrate Su Tseng-chang of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) in Saturday's election, it was significant that Wang was able to rally the efforts of supporters of the three political parties, according to Ma.
Ma stressed in particular the importance for the KMT and PFP to cooperate in the future.

While admitting that DPP's campaign tactics achieved good results in the legislative election, Ma noted that KMT managed to take some populous counties and cities away from the DPP in the local elections.
The KMT won nine of the 23 seats in the county and city magistrate elections.

KMT Chairman Lien Chan also spoke of the significance of the KMT's winning several cities and counties currently under DPP rule and said that the party will seek more cooperation with the PFP and the NP.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP REPLACES KMT AS LARGEST PARTY IN LEGISLATURE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian has obtained what he wanted of the parliamentary elections -- his Democratic Progressives Party replacing the Kuomintang as the largest party in the Legislative Yuan -- but whether that electoral victory can be translated into swift government action to tackle daunting problems facing Taiwan remains to be seen.

The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) won 87 of the 225 seats in the unicameral legislature Saturday. The Kuomintang, the largest party with 110 seats going into the elections, managed to get only 68 candidates elected.

With the help of the 13 Taiwan Solidary Union (TSU) freshmen lawmakers, President Chen's DPP is ready to assume parliamentary leadership, which the administration badly needs to end the paralyzing grip the Kuomintang has on the outgoing legislature.
The parliamentary leadership alone is not enough to get things going for the Chen administration, according to a majority view of political observers.

There will be no parliamentary majority, observers said after the results of the elections were published. The DPP will still confront the opposition with nine independents controlling a majority of legislative seats. The People First Party (PFP), the third largest in the Legilative Yuan closely behind the Kuomintang with 46 seats, will continue to oppose the DPP.

Without that majority, the DPP is likely to be thwarted in much of parliamentary legislation it has to enact to remedy the economic and financial woes Taiwan has been suffering since President Chen assumed office in May last year.

Unemployment has hit a record high 5.33 percent. Gross domestic product is expected to post an unprecedented negative growth for 2000. Financial institutions have been saddled with bad debts topping NT$1 trillion. The terrorist attacks on the United States on Sept. 11 have dealt a crippling blow to the already ailing economy.

The ruling party will continue to experience a parliamentary stand-off, although much mitigated, unless it will be able to lure a sufficient number of Kuomintang defectors and independents into its fold.
That is exactly what President Chen hopes to do by proposing a "national stabilization alliance," which, however, has been rejected by the Kuomintang and its splinter group, the PFP.
The PFP was a clear victor in the heated parliamentary race. It won the 46 legislative seats, plus two county magistrateships in Taitung and on the offshore island of Matsu.

James Soong, PFP chairman, was not elected to the Legislative Yuan. He had ranked himself 11th on the PFP candidate list for proportional representation, and narrowly lost because the party failed to win two million votes or over 21 percent of the total cast. Nontheless, he has boosted his chance of bearing the standard in the 2004 presidential election.
Soong founded the PFP after he had lost last year's presidential race.

He spared no effort to campaign for PFP candidates, and for Wang Chien-shien who, even with the support of the Kuomintang, and the New Party, failed to beat incumbent DPP Magistrate Su Cheng-chang of Taipei County.

The Taipei county race was touted as a proving ground for the next presidential election, in which President Chen is certain to be pitted against a candidate with united opposition support like Wang, who was not able to consolidate his tripartite alliance against Su.

While suffering a near disaster in the legislative elections, the Kuomintang could take comfort in adding two to the number of its seven outgoing county magistrates and city mayors. It now occupies nine such offices.

Like the Kuomintang, the DPP collected nine local government posts, including the one in Taipei County, while the tiny opposition New Party won the magistrateship of Kinmen. Independents earned the remaining two of the 23 offices at stake.

The TSU, a new party former President Lee Teng-hui helped found only three months before the elections, made an spectacle showing. Its 13 candidates, all of them political new faces, rode in the "coattail" of Lee, who, though not running himself, tirelessly stumped for them.
The biggest loser was the New Party. Reduced to only one seat, it lost the right to elect any lawmaker in accordance with proportional representation. END.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN HOPES POLITICAL PARTIES WILL COOPERATE CLOSELY

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Saturday evening the end of elections should be "the beginning of cooperation" between the ruling party and the opposition in tackling problems facing the nation.

In a news release, issued after the elections, President Chen said that all political parties should leave behind their differences and pool their wisdom to revive the economy, reform the legislative branch of government, promote relations across the Taiwan strait, and improve social welfare.
All parties should bury the hatchet, Chen said. "No matter what the election results might be," he pointed out, "emotional conflict should now give way to rational thinking."

"Let us make the end of elections the beginning of cooperation," President Chen urged. "We should all work closely together for the enhancement of national security, stability, and prosperity in the common interest of all the people on Taiwan," he added.
His ruling Democratic Progressive Party won 87 of the 225 seats in the Legislative Yuan in the heated elections.

After learning of the DPP emerging as the biggest party in the legislature, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said the electoral victory is a clear indication that the electorate has accepted President Chen's proposals for the establishment of a "National Stabilization Alliance" and for the enhancement of inter-party cooperation.
"The proposals reflect the mainstream values of our society," Chang said, promising to carrying them all out as soon as practicable.

The administration will also put into effect the plans brought forth by President Chen before the elections to safeguard national sovereignty, promote legislative reform, improve social welfare, and revive the economy, Chang added. (Ed)

DOC.HEADLINE: JAMES SOONG SHOWS NO INTEREST IN JOINING POLITICAL ALLIANCES

TEXT.P: James Soong, chairman of the People First Party (PFP) said Saturday evening at a press conference that he is not interested in joining any political alliance, but his party will do its best to fulfill its obligation as a dutiful opposition party.
In Saturday's elections, the PFP secured 46 seats in the 225-seat Legislative Yuan and won victory in the race for two county magistrateships.
Soong said President Chen Shui-bian and KMT Chairman Lien Chan called him earlier in the evening, expressing their desire to exchange views on national affairs with him.

He said he will meet with other leaders of the party for exchanges of views on the party's policy guidelines, adding that the PFP will do its best to serve the people and the country. The result of Saturday's elections clearly indicate that the people long for political stability.
Soong said he told Chen and Lien that the PFP will honor its promises to the people and that the party will also put national interests and people's welfare ahead of its party interests.

He stressed that the PFP will help stabilize the political situation. "We hope that the KMT will stabilize and that the political situation will stabilize," he said, adding: "We are not going to do anything that may sow seeds of discord between the ruling and opposition parties."
"We will increase communications with the KMT in the spirit of goodwill," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PEOPLE FIRST PARTY CONGRATULATED BY RIVALS FOR ELECTION VICTORY

TEXT.P: James Soong, chairman of the People First Party (PFP) said Saturday evening that he received congratulatory greetings from President Chen Shui-bian and Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan after the election results were announced.

The party -- a little over a year old -- won 46 seats in Saturday's legislative election and as well as taking the county magistrateships of Taitung and Lienchiang in the simultaneous local government chief elections.

Soong said that both Chen and Lien expressed a wish to meet with him in the near future. However, he said he has no plans to arrange such meetings in the next few days because, he said, he must first meet with the newly elected legislators of his party.
Soong said that the PFP will fulfill its obligation as an opposition party and will give priority to meeting its commitments to the people.

With 46 seats in the Legislative Yuan, the PFP will be an important factor in determining the power structure of the new legislature. None of Taiwan's parties were able to win an absolute majority in the 225-seat Legislative Yuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ELECTIONS WILL NOT AFFECT ROC-U.S. RELATIONS: ROC OFFICIAL
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 1 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's representative to the United States said Saturday that the legislative, county chief and mayoral elections in Taiwan that day will not affect U.S. policy toward the island.

Chen Chien-jen said as he followed the results of the elections in his office at the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in the United States that the overseas Chinese in America and Taiwan's U.S. friends have all been watching the elections carefully.

"Regardless of the election results, everyone recognizes that Taiwan's democracy has once again been realized," Chen said. "Our democratic system will only be more solid and mature after these elections."
Chen added that the people of Taiwan will work together toward a gradual economic recovery after the elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING POLITICAL OBSERVERS SURPRISED BY TAIWAN'S ELECTION RESULTS
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Dec. 1 (CNA) (By Tzeng Chun-liang and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: Political observers in Beijing said Saturday that they were surprised by the election results in Taiwan whereby the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) replaced the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) as the largest party in the Legislative Yuan.

Xu Bodong, director of the Taiwan Research Institute at Beijing Union University, said that the DPP's victory can be attributed to its successful ballot distribution strategy while it demonstrates that its supporters' identification with the party is more stable.

Xu predicted that Taiwan's political quagmire will continue after the elections, and he believes that even if the independence-leaning "pan-green" parties, which includes the DPP, had won an overall majority, the "pan-blues" would have probably become even more united after the elections to fight against the "pan-greens."

Because the KMT lost the largest number of seats, Xu continued, it remains to be seen whether the party will split again. He said that the KMT is still the biggest variable affecting Taiwan's political situation and that the key is whether a faction within the party that favors native Taiwanese over those of mainland Chinese descent will leave at the urging of former President Lee Teng-hui.
A former KMT chairman who was expelled from the party in September, Lee is the "spiritual leader" of the fledgling Taiwan Solidarity Union, which is a member of the so-called "pan-green" parties.

Xu said that although a period of uneasy peace can still be maintained in the Taiwan Strait as long as Chen does not publicly announce Taiwan independence, bilateral relations remain unstable and full of danger.

Guo Zhenyuan, a senior fellow at the China Institute of International Studies, a Beijing government think tank, said that the DPP's surprising victory will not change Beijing's policy of continuing to observe Chen, especially as some of the things he said during the campaign have deepened Beijing's distrust toward him.
Therefore, Guo predicted, it is difficult to see any concrete development in cross-Taiwan Strait relations after the elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN, LOCAL COMMERCE LEADERS URGE LEGISLATORS TO FOCUS ON ECONOMY

TEXT.P: Foreign trade and industry offices and domestic industry leaders in Taiwan urged the newly elected Legislative Yuan to focus on economic issues after Saturday's legislative, county chief and mayoral elections.

Noting that he has been in Taiwan for eight years and has witnessed several elections, American Chamber of Commerce in Taipei (AmCham) President Richard Henson urged Taiwan's political parties to forgo their differences and concentrate on the economy instead of continuing to "play the economy like politics."

European Chamber of Commerce Taipei (ECCT) Chairman Fabrice de Murat also urged the government to focus on the economy because foreign businesses consider the local political situation this year to have been "unstable."

AmCham Executive Director Richard Vuylsteke said that Taiwan is still politicking while mainland China is already devoting itself fully to its economy. He added that foreign businessmen want to see the "beef" in the government's policies, not campaign mudslinging.

Henson said that as the power and influence of the Legislative Yuan grows, Taiwan politicians should realize that partisan cooperation is important, particularly in order to achieve consensus on economic issues.
He added that AmCham has begun to realize that foreign businesses must turn more of their lobbying efforts toward the Legislative Yuan as Taiwan's democratization continues.

Agreeing with his foreign counterparts, Taiwan Chamber of Commerce President Chuang Lung-chang said that he hopes the legislators can focus on response measures to Taiwan's imminent World Trade Organization entry.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW PARTY LEADER ATTRIBUTES SETBACK TO TAIWAN'S ELECTORAL CULTURE

TEXT.P: Hau Lung-bin, former convener of the New Party's (NP's) National Campaign and Development Committee, said Saturday evening that his party failed to appeal to Taiwan's voters "because they did not cast their votes rationally."
He called on party supporters to "deal rationally" with the election results. The NP won only one legislative seat and one county magistrate position in the Saturday elections.

The party, which was founded in 1993 by a group of young Kuomintang (KMT) members who broke away from the KMT to seek a new path to balance the then-ruling party, held nine seat in the previous legislature.

Hau claimed that the election results reflect the irrationality of Taiwan's voters, who he said tend to choose a party for whom to vote instead of taking into consideration the professionalism or image of individual candidates.

DOC.HEADLINE: ELECTION OUTCOMES WILL LEAD TO MORE POLITICAL STABILITY

TEXT.P: The seats won by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) in Saturday's elections show the voters' desire for political stability, according to several scholars interviewed by CNA Saturday night.

The scholars predicted that political stability will result from the elections, given that President Chen Shui-bian's power to name a premier is solidified by his party's legislative gains, while the leading opposition Kuomintang (KMT) is paying the price of deviating from mainstream public opinion.

They said they expect a "National Stabilization Alliance" advocated by Chen before the election will take shape among lawmakers of the DPP, the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), some KMT lawmakers and some independent lawmakers.

Wu Yan-chun, a professor at National Chengchi University, said that although Taiwan's recession is caused by the international economic slowdown and the DPP government's inexperience in governing, the voters chose to give the DPP dominance in both the executive and legislative branches in Saturday's elections.
He warned that the KMT should beware of the risk of being marginalized because of its departure from mainstream public opinion.
Meanwhile, the TSU's 13-seat gains on its political debut shows that its emphasis on Taiwan's identity is appealing to many voters.

Lee You-tan, another professor at National Chengchi University, said he takes comfort from the public confirmation of the DPP as it signifies that they did not buy the opposition's claims that the ruling party should be blamed for the flagging economy.

He predicted that Chen will be "more humble" in the remaining years of his term in light of the fact that his party failed to gain control of the legislature, but that he will not be dictated to by the KMT and its allies at the legislature.
He forecast that the elections will usher in a more stable period in politics and added that the prospects for Chen's "National Stabilization Alliance" are more real than ever.
The DPP's legislative victory might harden its stance toward Beijing, said Chang Lin-chen, a professor at National Taiwan University.

The DPP had to soften its position somewhat when the KMT still dominated the legislature, but now that its policy toward Beijing has won a new mandate, the party will have more leeway in dealing with Beijing. It is hard to predict whether this bodes ill or good for the country's ties with Beijing, she said.

But she said she expects the Taipei authorities to get tough on controversial issues such as the so-called "1992 consensus" on "one China" and on direct postal and transport links with mainland China.
Hsieh Cheng-yu, a professor at Soochow University, attributed the KMT's loss in the elections to the split of its traditional voters between the party and its breakaway, the People First Party.

National Taiwan University Professor Alexander Lu said the TSU's better-than-expected performance results from a shift toward a more pro-independence stance among DPP voters worried about Beijing's increasing international profile.

DOC.HEADLINE: END OF POLLS MARKS BEGINNING OF INTER-PARTY COOPERATION: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Saturday that the conclusion of the legislative and local government chief elections marks "the beginning of an era of cooperation."

In a press release issued following the announcement of the election results, Chen said all political parties should leave behind their differences and pool their wisdom to revive the economy, reform the legislature, promote relations across the Taiwan Strait and improve social welfare.
"Emotional conflict should now give way to rational thinking," Chen said.

According to official results, Chen has obtained what he wanted of the parliamentary polls -- his Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has replaced the Kuomintang (KMT) as the largest party in the Legislative Yuan.

The DPP, which until Saturday had barely one-third of the seats in the 225-member legislature, increased its presence to 87 seats -- an increase of about 40 percent. The main opposition KMT, with 110 seats going into the elections, managed to get only 68 candidates elected.

Two new parties formed by disgruntled KMT mavericks did well in their first legislative elections. The People First Party (PFP) won 46 seats and the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), with former KMT Chairman and ex-ROC President Lee Teng-hui as its "spiritual leader," got 13, with the remaining seats won by independents and fringe parties.

After learning of the DPP's emergence as the biggest party in the legislature, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said the victory is a clear indication that the electorate agrees with Chen's proposal for the establishment of a "national stabilization alliance" and for the enhancement of inter-party cooperation.
"The proposal reflects the mainstream values of our society," Chang said, promising to carry it out as soon as possible.

The DPP garnered 36.57 percent of total votes cast in the legislative elections, compared to the KMT's 31.28 percent, the PFP's 20.34 percent, the TSU's 8.5 percent and the New Party's 2.86 percent. The average voter turnout in the legislative polls was 66.16 percent.

The pro-unification New Party won just one seat in the new legislature, down from the nine it held prior to the election. The party failed to win the minimum 5 percent of the vote it needed to qualify for proportional representation seats. It also managed to win only one local government position -- the magistrateship of the frontline island of Kinmen, which lies closer to mainland China than to Taiwan.
New Party convener Hsieh Chi-ta, an incumbent legislator who lost her re-election bid, said the party will not fade away, but will "continue to flourish."
Noting that many of incumbent New Party legislators have topped the best-performing lawmakers list, she lamented that "their defeats were great losses to the nation."
Both Lee and TSU Chairman Huang Chu-wen said they were satisfied with the party's showing in the polls. "The results also show that the TSU did not win seats at the DPP's expense," said Huang.

He further said the outcome indicates that the New Party's "one country, two systems" unification advocacy and the KMT's insistence on the existence of the "1992 consensus" (one China, with each side free to interpret the notion as they see fit) do not enjoy popular support.
Huang, a former KMT member, predicted that the KMT will suffer another split in the wake of the elections.

KMT Chairman Lien Chan conceded the party's poor showing in the legislative polls. He said as the KMT remains the largest opposition party, it will do its utmost to help maintain domestic political stability and promote inter-party cooperation after the elections.

PFP Chairman James Soong said he was satisfied with the party's showing. Soong, who lost his presidential bid last year by a narrow margin, said he has no interest in joining any political alliances but stressed that the PFP will endeavor to be a dutiful, responsible opposition party.

In the local elections that also took place Saturday, the KMT managed to win mayorships and magistrateships in six previously DPP-ruled cities and counties -- Taichung City, Keelung City, Taichung County, Taoyuan County, Hsinchu City and Hsinchu County.

The DPP also won nine local government chief posts, while the PFP won in Taitung County and the outlying Lienchiang County, which covers the island of Matsu and lies closer to the mainland than to Taiwan. (By sofia Wu) (To be continued)

DOC.HEADLINE: END OF POLLS (II)

TEXT.P: The people of Taiwan made history last year by electing Chen Shui-bian, the first president from an opposition party. But Chen's inexperienced minority government has struggled to work with the legislature and has been unable to thaw relations with mainland China.

Analysts said that mainland China viewed Chen to be a weak, bungling president who wouldn't be re-elected and could be ignored. But his party's victory Saturday might convince Beijing that Chen could win another term. By continuing to ignore him, Chinese leaders could cause Taiwan to drift further toward independence.
Some of these analysts said the electoral outcome might prompt mainaldn leaders to take a second thought on their strategy toward Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Sunday are as follows:
The China Times:
DPP becomes leading party in Legislative Yuan by getting 87 seats.
The United Daily News:
DPP becomes leading party in a hung legislature.
The Liberty Times:
DPP becomes leading party in Legislative Yuan while KMT gains in race for county heads.
The Taiwan Daily:
DPP becomes biggest party in legislature.
The Central Daily News:
Legislature shakes up in elections and "Pan-blue Army" gains the upper hand in race for county heads.
The China Post:
DPP claims major victory.
The Taiwan News:
DPP slamdunks KMT.
The Taipei Times:
Voters deal KMT a second blow.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINESE SCHOLARS SEE CHANGES AFTER TAIWAN ELECTIONS
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 1 (CNA) (By Sherman Wu, Neil Lu, Jennifer J. Huang, Herman Pan, and Maubo Chang )

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP) victory in elections for lawmakers has cast a shadow on Taiwan's ties with mainland China, said some mainland Chinese scholars, but U.S. scholars said Beijing may reconsider turning a cold-shoulder to the Taipei government in the wake of Saturday's power shift.

Singapore's Chinese-language Lianhe Zhaobao daily quoted Beijing officials as saying Sunday that they are alarmed and disappointed by the DPP victory and the Kuomintang's (KMT) apparent failure in the elections.

In a story from Beijing, the paper quoted Yan Xuetung, a professor at Tsinghua University in Beijing, as saying that he was surprised that the economic sluggishness in Taiwan did not reduce the popularity of the DPP, but instead boosted the pro-independence party.
Encouraged by the election victory, Yan said he believes President Chen Shui-bian will be more confident in his pursuit of a second term and will stick to his policy of seeking Taiwan independence.

The outcome of Saturday's elections in Taiwan bore out the fact that economic factors have little, if any, impact on ties between Taiwan and mainland China, and closer commercial exchanges between the two sides doesn't necessary improve their political ties, Yan said.
Beijing should work out new ways to discourage the pro-independence force in Taiwan, rather than move toward closer economic interactions, Yan said.

The paper quoted another Tsinhua University professor, Chu Shulung, as pointing out that the results of the elections will inevitably harden President Chen denial of the so-called "1992 consensus" between Taiwan and mainland China on "one China," perhaps even emboldening him to go further on the path toward Taiwan independence.
But Chu said the results of the elections are unlikely to prompt Beijing to change its approach regarding Chen: "Listen to his words, watch his deeds."

Yu Keli, deputy director of the Institute of Taiwan Studies under the Chinese Academy of Social Science in Beijing told the Lianhe Zhaobao that he doesn't think Chen will move recklessly when it comes to ties with Beijing, even with the new mandate from the people.

Although the KMT has lost its leading place in the legislature, it is still a force to be reckoned with given the majority of seats controlled by it and its political allies, and the DPP should know that it cannot independently set mainland China policy, Yu said.
Meanwhile, Robert Scalapino, a Chinese affairs expert in the United States, said in Los Angels Saturday that Beijing should reconsider its approach toward Taiwan in light of the DPP's victory.

The former professor at the University of California in Berkeley, California said the results of the elections suggest that Beijing might be wrong to think that the DPP has its hands tied by Taiwan's opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan, and time is on Beijing's side in dealing with Taipei.
With DPP's power base solidified and it's time for Beijing to review its current no-contact policy toward Taipei, Scalapino said.

Another significant development from the elections is the People First Party's dramatic gain to 46 seats -- a shot in the arm for the party and its chairman, James Soong, Scalapino said, adding that the party will now become a power broker in the Legislative Yuan.
Ramon Myers, a researcher at the Hoover Institution, said that the DPP has more leeway in crafting its mainland China policy after the elections.
It is unrealistic for Beijing to wait and deal with Taiwan until after a non-DPP government emerges on the island some time in the future, Myers said.
Instead, he said, Beijing should open dialogue with the DPP under the framework of a confederation and treat Taiwan as a equal partner under it.

Former U.S. Ambassador to Beijing James Lilley said in Washington Saturday that Beijing should not consider the results of Saturday's elections as a spurn to its offer of reunion with Taiwan; rather, it should be seen as a further step by Taiwan toward "the middle way" and developing a responsive democracy.
Beijing should wake up to the fact that it simply cannot impose its will on Taiwan, and its ties with Taiwan will not improve when it targets Taiwan with missiles, Lilley said.

Larry Wortzel, a researcher at the Heritage Foundation in Washington said Saturday that the elections have further shown the benefits of the development of a multi-party democracy and a vibrant civil society in Taiwan.

The Legislative Yuan has been reshaped and President Chen will have a better chance to break political deadlocks by working to build political coalitions and consensuses on specific issues, Wortzel said.
The results of the elections also validated Presdient Chen's policies of economic engagement and a political rejection of Beijing's "one-China" formula, he said.
The KMT's failure in the elections, on the other hand, means that their platform is less attractive to many Taiwanese and the party should reconsider its platform, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO SUBSTANTIVE CHANGES IN CROSS-STRAIT TIES AFTER ELECTIONS: ANALYSTS

TEXT.P: No significant changes are expected in relations across the Taiwan Strait following the Dec. 1 elections in Taiwan, analysts attending a symposium Sunday in Taipei said.

Taiwan's first elections of the century saw the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) replace the Kuomintang as the largest party in the legislature by securing 87 seats, compared to the KMT's 68, the People First Party's (PFP) 46 and the Taiwan Solidarity Union's (TSU) 13.

The symposium, which focused on future political realignments after the elections and the prospects of cross-strait relations, was sponsored by Taiwan's Central News Agency and was held at its Taipei headquarters.

Stephen Chen, deputy head of the National Policy Foundation, a think tank of the opposition Kuomintang, said that due to the huge gap between the DPP and KMT in their national identification, it would be impossible for the KMT to join the "National Stabilization Alliance" that President Chen Shui-bian proposed before the elections.
However, he said that there is room for cooperation between the KMT and the PFP, one of the splinter groups of the KMT.
Chin Chin-sheng, PFP deputy secretary-general, said that the PFP will only come to a decision on a possible alliance with other parties after comprehensive discussions within the party.
He said that the PFP, formed only after last year's presidential election, is an independent party and "will not move towards either the KMT or the DPP."

Professor Ming Chu-cheng of National Taiwan University said that it would not be difficult for the DPP to form a cross-party alliance if it can get the participation from some of the KMT legislators-elect who have some leanings toward the pro-independence stance of the ruling party since the DPP, along with the pro-independence TSU, now controls 100 legislative seats.

On future relations with the mainland, Chen, who once served as Taiwan's top representative to the United States, said that the DPP-led administration will maintain is current policy toward the mainland, and ties will not undergo any big changes in the short term.
Chin said that for the sake of Taiwan's stability, the DPP government must adopt a steady and clear mainland policy.

Tien Hsin, director of the DPP's International Affairs Department, said that the ruling party has made it clear in its "Resolution on the Future of Taiwan" that it will respect the choice of the Taiwan people to become independent or unify with the mainland.
Tien stressed, however, that Taiwan should not mention the so-called "1992 consensus" that was alleged by the opposition to have been reached between Taipei and Beijing in 1992.

The consensus refers to an alleged tacit understanding that was reached between the two sides that they would accept a "one China" principle with each side being free to have its own definition of "one China."
The DPP administration has repeatedly denied that any consensus was reached; rather, it says that the only thing achieved was a "spirit of 1992."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN GIVEN REAL MANDATE TO GOVERN: FORMER DPP CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: The results of Saturday's elections for legislators and city and county chiefs have proven that the people will give President Chen Shui-bian a real chance to govern, former Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Shih Ming-teh said Sunday.

The results of the election prove that the people agree with President Chen's political programs, Shih said. He hoped that President Chen would now take full responsibility for resolving the unemployment issue, upgrade the nation's competitiveness and stabilize the political situation.
Shih lost his re-election race for a legislative seat as an independent. He said that he was somewhat surprised by the loss and that he would have to take some time to consider his political future.

Meanwhile, Parris Chang of the DPP, who was re-elected as a legislator, said that Beijing must be very disappointed with the legislative election results. The DPP victory shows that Beijing's strategy to press the Chen administration to accept the "1992 consensus" and "one China" principle through opposition pressure was a complete failure.
He hoped that Beijing will reassess and reevaluate its cross-strait strategy.
Chang made the remarks while attending a seminar on post-election Taiwan political developments sponsored by the Vanguard Policy Research Center.
Chang attributed the DPP wins to the DPP's insistence on the nation's sovereignty and highlighting the opposition's appeasement toward Beijing.
Prof. Ke Yung-kuang of National Taiwan University said that how to deal with the "one China" issue is still a sticky issue. He said, however, that the ruling DPP should embrace the "1992 consensus."

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT SAYS IT WILL NOT JOIN PRESIDENT CHEN'S ALLIANCE

TEXT.P: The leading opposition Kuomintang (KMT) will not join the "National Stabilization Alliance" that President Chen Shui-bian proposed last week, a party spokesman said Sunday.
The KMT made the decision after a review of its election results, according to KMT spokesman Wang Chih-kang.

The number of seats in the Legislature held by the KMT plummeted to 68 from 123 before the Dec. 1 elections. The party was also soundly defeated in the 2000 presidential election when its candidate, now-KMT Chairman Lien Chan, came in a distant third.

Wang said that the KMT, however, is more than willing to hold party-to-party negotiations with the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and that Lien is also willing to meet President Chen to exchange views on the domestic political situation.

Lien presided over the election result review meeting along with the participation of the vice-chairmen of the party, Wu Poh-hsiung, Chiang Chun-ling, Vincent Siew, Wang Jyn-ping and Lin Cheng-chih. KMT Secretary-General Lin Fong-cheng was also in attendance with other ranking party officials.
The KMT will seek to expand cooperation with the People First Party (PFP) in the legislature, Wang said.
The PFP, formed by former KMT Secretary-General James Soong after last year's presidential election, obtained 46 seats in addition to two county magistrateships.
He said that the KMT will field Vice Chairman Wang Jyn-ping, the incumbent Legislative Yuan president, to run for a second term as head of the lawmaking body.

The KMT, however, said that in spite of its disappointing showing in the legislative elections, it still managed to do relatively well in the elections for local government heads by winning nine of the 23 seats up for grabs, increasing its numbers by one.
Wang said that Lien will continue to be the leader of the party with firm support from the five vice chairmen and party leaders.
Chao Shou-po, head of the KMT Organizational Affairs Department, attributed the party's failure in the elections to several factors:
-- Strong campaign activities by President Chen and effective publicity by the DPP;
-- Ceaseless mudslinging from the DPP against the KMT;
-- Former President and former KMT Chairman Lee Teng-hui's stumping for candidates of the Taiwan Solidarity Union, and its veiled cooperation with the DPP; and
