-- A lack of solidarity among KMT candidates.
KMT Secretary-General Lin said that he has tendered his resignation to Chairman Lien to take responsibility for the setbacks. It is still unknown, however, whether Lien will allow him to leave.

DOC.HEADLINE: ELECTIONS HELP CONVERGE OPINIONS ON NATIONAL IDENTITY: DPP LAWMAKER

TEXT.P: The collapse of the pro-unification New Party in Saturday's elections will help converge public opinion on Taiwan's national identity, Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislator Lin Cho-shui said Sunday.

In a symposium sponsored by the Taiwan Research Institute on the elections of lawmakers, Lin said the sudden demise of the New Party, which succeeded in returning only one lawmaker, signifies a shift of public opinion toward acknowledging Taiwan's separate identity.

The sudden emergence in politics of the pro-independence Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), which snapped up 13 seats on its political debut, is more evidence of the political appeal of Taiwan's sovereignty and political stability.

The DPP's sweep of counties in the south of the country in the races for magistrates and mayors suggested that voters didn't blame the ruling party for the economic slowdown despite these counties suffering the most in the island's recession and accounting for the bulk of Taiwan's unemployment population, Lin said.

After the 2000 presidential election and Saturday's elections, Lin said, Beijing should shed its unrealistic expectations for Taiwan and try to establish new working relations with the island's officials.

Another message that emerged from the elections is the strong party-orientation among local voters, which is contrary to the widely accepted conception that they are attracted more by candidates' personal merits than by their political affiliation, Lin said.

Meanwhile, Fan Xitsou, director of the Institute of Taiwan Studies at Xiamen University in Xiamen, Fujian province, said Sunday by phone that Saturday's elections are nothing but a political shake-up among Taiwan's political parties and will not bear on its ties with mainland China.

This is why Beijing didn't bother to comment on the elections before or after Saturday, he said. The results of the elections will certainly not change Beijing's basic principles in dealing with Taiwan, that is "separating economic affairs from political affairs," and engaging with Taiwan on the basis of "one China," Fan said.

However, Fan said, Beijing did take note of the strong anti-Beijing sentiments during the campaign and will continue applying pressure on Taiwan to stop such activities. Officials in Beijing, however, do not consider that the DPP's new mandate will strengthen its hand in dealing with Beijing, Fan said.

The Taiwan affairs expert said the failure of the Kuomintang (KMT) was because it had fielded too many candidates and had to contend with the division of its traditional supporters between itself and its breakaway party, the People First Party (PFP).

He predicted the KMT will have trouble making a political comeback if it cannot transform itself into a party more attractive to grassroots voters. With a successful transformation, Fan said, the KMT might cooperate with the emerging PFP, but if not, the party could be replaced by the PFP.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI REMOVES OVER 50,000 ELECTION CAMPAIGN BANNERS OVERNIGHT

TEXT.P: Over 800 street sweepers worked overnight to remove more than 50,000 campaign flags across Taipei City after Saturday's parliamentary elections.

Shen Shih-hung, Taipei environmental protection director, declared Sunday the city streets were completely cleared of the banners and streamers the parliamentary candidates had put up in the run-up to the elections.

The cleaning operation started at 10 p.m., immediately after the votes had been tallied, Shen said, adding: "We got rid of a total of 52,810 flags, banners and streamers from the streets before sunrise," he added.
Sweepers did not remove the banners and streamers in the campaign offices of candidates, Shen said. "Those have to be cleared by the candidates," he added.
"Gone are those in all 214 public advertising squares," said Lin Cheng-hsin, Taipei civil affairs director. He added large campaign billboards will be torn down as soon as possible.

DOC.HEADLINE: SCHOLARS POSITIVE ON TAIWAN'S DEMOCRACY, BUT SAY CHALLENGES AHEAD

TEXT.P: Scholars gathered at a symposium Sunday were generally positive about the result of the elections and the democratic development in Taiwan, but also said that many challenges lie ahead for the nation.

An international symposium on democratic consolidation, peace and security was jointly sponsored by National Chengchi University (NCCU) and the Government Information Office. Scholars and experts from 10 countries were invited to discuss the significance on Asia and the Pacific region of Taiwan's democratic progress and their observations regarding Saturday's elections.
The scholars praised Taiwan for achieving a high level of democratization without serious conflicts or violence.

On the possibility of an upcoming political realignment, they said that the next few months will be crucial for Taiwan. The key is to observe whether the executive and legislative branches can work smoother now that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has become the largest party in the legislature.

The DPP increased its seats from 65 before the elections to 87, while the original dominant force in the lawmaking body, the Kuomintang (KMT), faltered after shedding 42 seats to take just 68, far below what the party had expected.

Shelley Rigger, a long-time observer of Taiwan's elections and associate professor of Davidson College in North Caroline, believed that the success of the DPP could be attributed to its "early preparation of its candidate list, conscientious devotion to party unity through the campaign," and its vote rationing strategy, a point NCCU professor Liu I-chou, also director of Election Study Center, had made earlier.

The success of the DPP, Rigger said, may not be solely interpreted as "a referendum on President Chen Shui-bian's performance," which has been marred by political squabbling over the past 17 months, but to a greater extent to the party's mastery of the media. The KMT failed to "manage the campaign in a way that a party must do," she said.

Robert Sutter, a professor at Georgetown University, cautioned that Taiwan's democracy has yet been consolidated, saying that although the mandate of the minority government will be strengthened, it will be limited. He said that Taiwan will face many challenges in the next few years, noting that consultation with the opposition camp will be difficult as will be implementing political reforms.
Meanwhile, Taiwan's "greatest challenge will be to keep its economy competitive," while the other side of the Taiwan Strait continues its military buildup, Sutter said.

Thomas Gold, an associate professor at the University of California-Berkeley, noted the Taiwan will face economic problems as part of the global economic downturn, and ethnic problems within the nation, and power has yet to be consolidated with the gaining of seats in the legislature by the DPP.
However, Gold said that it was a positive sign that the election was conducted without serious physical violence, proving that democracy in Taiwan was not fake as some commentators had claimed.
Alan Wachman, an assistant professor at Tufts University, said that Taiwan's democracy is marching in a peaceful and gradual way, and will stimulate mainland China to some extent.
Democracy, however, is not the solution to all problems, he cautioned, and what counts will be the improvement of the quality of democracy.

Tim Trampedach, a professor at Berlin Free University, agreed, noting that cross-strait economies may move closer, but that tensions will remain, judging from the fact that there is a lack of unity among candidates on national security issues.
The future of the KMT has also became a focal point, Wachman said, noting that the KMT had taken quite a blow and wondered how seriously the KMT is taking its losses.
Rigger said that the KMT is no more prepared to face defeat than it was in last year's presidential election, saying that it made bitter, angry-sounding statements after Saturday's elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO CHANGE ON CROSS-STRAIT POLICY AFTER ELECTION: MAC HEAD

TEXT.P: Cross-strait policy will not undergo major changes after the elections which saw the ruling Democratic Progressive Party increased its seats dramatically in the legislature to become the largest party in the lawmaking body, the nation's top planner in charting the mainland policy said Sunday.

Tsai Eng-wen, chairwoman of the Mainland Affairs Council, made the remarks when she delivered a keynote speech at an international symposium on democratic consolidation, peace and security across the Taiwan Strait held at the Grand Hotel in Taipei.
Tsai told scholars and experts participating in the symposium that the theme of cross-strait relations will remain peace, stability and non-provocation.

One day after the mandate of the DPP was strengthened by increasing its seats in the 225-seat legislature to 87, she said that the major task of the government now will be to continue to carry on political reforms and speed up the globalization of Taiwan's economy.

On cross-strait relations, she said the maintenance of peace will be of top priority, stressing that cross-strait policy will not change because of the results of the elections despite Beijing's misgivings about the pro-independence stance of the DPP.

Tsai said that the government's cross-strait policy is unequivocal -- on the one hand, it will continue to seek consensus within domestic parties, and on the other it hopes both sides of the Taiwan Strait will be able to sit down to talk. This she said would be the best way to ease misunderstandings.
She noted that the government has adjusted its financial policy toward the mainland, adding that there will be further and gradual adjustments over time.

On President Chen Shui-bian's mainland policy, she stressed that there has been no change, citing the president's "five noes" as spelled out in his inauguration speech -- meaning no declaration of independence if Beijing does not use force against the island, no change of the nation's official name, no adoption of the "state-to-state" theory into the Constitution, no referendum on the fate of the nation, and no abrogation of the Guidelines of National Unification. Chen also spoke of the cultural and economic integration between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait before the establishment of a mechanism of political integration.

Tsai noted that the mainland has so far not made a major response to the result of the elections, but she believed the mainland will realize that maintaining the peace and stability across the Taiwan Strait will be of common interests to both sides.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR OPTIMISTIC ABOUT CONSOLIDATION OF POLITICAL PARTIES

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said Saturday that the joint nomination of Wang Chien-shien by three parties as candidate for Taipei county magistrate "proves the feasibility" of consolidating the strength of the Kuomintang (KMT), the People First Party (PFP) and the New Party (NP).

Despite Wang's defeat to incumbent Taipei County Magistrate Su Tseng-chang of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) in Saturday's election, it was significant that Wang was able to rally the efforts of supporters of the three political parties, according to Ma.
Ma stressed in particular the importance for the KMT and PFP to cooperate in the future.

While admitting that DPP's campaign tactics achieved good results in the legislative election, Ma noted that KMT managed to take some populous counties and cities away from the DPP in the local elections.
The KMT won nine of the 23 seats in the county and city magistrate elections.

KMT Chairman Lien Chan also spoke of the significance of the KMT's winning several cities and counties currently under DPP rule and said that the party will seek more cooperation with the PFP and the NP.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP REPLACES KMT AS LARGEST PARTY IN LEGISLATURE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian has obtained what he wanted of the parliamentary elections -- his Democratic Progressives Party replacing the Kuomintang as the largest party in the Legislative Yuan -- but whether that electoral victory can be translated into swift government action to tackle daunting problems facing Taiwan remains to be seen.

The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) won 87 of the 225 seats in the unicameral legislature Saturday. The Kuomintang, the largest party with 110 seats going into the elections, managed to get only 68 candidates elected.

With the help of the 13 Taiwan Solidary Union (TSU) freshmen lawmakers, President Chen's DPP is ready to assume parliamentary leadership, which the administration badly needs to end the paralyzing grip the Kuomintang has on the outgoing legislature.
The parliamentary leadership alone is not enough to get things going for the Chen administration, according to a majority view of political observers.

There will be no parliamentary majority, observers said after the results of the elections were published. The DPP will still confront the opposition with nine independents controlling a majority of legislative seats. The People First Party (PFP), the third largest in the Legilative Yuan closely behind the Kuomintang with 46 seats, will continue to oppose the DPP.

Without that majority, the DPP is likely to be thwarted in much of parliamentary legislation it has to enact to remedy the economic and financial woes Taiwan has been suffering since President Chen assumed office in May last year.

Unemployment has hit a record high 5.33 percent. Gross domestic product is expected to post an unprecedented negative growth for 2000. Financial institutions have been saddled with bad debts topping NT$1 trillion. The terrorist attacks on the United States on Sept. 11 have dealt a crippling blow to the already ailing economy.

The ruling party will continue to experience a parliamentary stand-off, although much mitigated, unless it will be able to lure a sufficient number of Kuomintang defectors and independents into its fold.
That is exactly what President Chen hopes to do by proposing a "national stabilization alliance," which, however, has been rejected by the Kuomintang and its splinter group, the PFP.
The PFP was a clear victor in the heated parliamentary race. It won the 46 legislative seats, plus two county magistrateships in Taitung and on the offshore island of Matsu.

James Soong, PFP chairman, was not elected to the Legislative Yuan. He had ranked himself 11th on the PFP candidate list for proportional representation, and narrowly lost because the party failed to win two million votes or over 21 percent of the total cast. Nontheless, he has boosted his chance of bearing the standard in the 2004 presidential election.
Soong founded the PFP after he had lost last year's presidential race.

He spared no effort to campaign for PFP candidates, and for Wang Chien-shien who, even with the support of the Kuomintang, and the New Party, failed to beat incumbent DPP Magistrate Su Cheng-chang of Taipei County.

The Taipei county race was touted as a proving ground for the next presidential election, in which President Chen is certain to be pitted against a candidate with united opposition support like Wang, who was not able to consolidate his tripartite alliance against Su.

While suffering a near disaster in the legislative elections, the Kuomintang could take comfort in adding two to the number of its seven outgoing county magistrates and city mayors. It now occupies nine such offices.

Like the Kuomintang, the DPP collected nine local government posts, including the one in Taipei County, while the tiny opposition New Party won the magistrateship of Kinmen. Independents earned the remaining two of the 23 offices at stake.

The TSU, a new party former President Lee Teng-hui helped found only three months before the elections, made an spectacle showing. Its 13 candidates, all of them political new faces, rode in the "coattail" of Lee, who, though not running himself, tirelessly stumped for them.
The biggest loser was the New Party. Reduced to only one seat, it lost the right to elect any lawmaker in accordance with proportional representation.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN HOPES POLITICAL PARTIES WILL COOPERATE CLOSELY

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Saturday evening the end of elections should be "the beginning of cooperation" between the ruling party and the opposition in tackling problems facing the nation.

In a news release, issued after the elections, President Chen said that all political parties should leave behind their differences and pool their wisdom to revive the economy, reform the legislative branch of government, promote relations across the Taiwan strait, and improve social welfare.
All parties should bury the hatchet, Chen said. "No matter what the election results might be," he pointed out, "emotional conflict should now give way to rational thinking."

"Let us make the end of elections the beginning of cooperation," President Chen urged. "We should all work closely together for the enhancement of national security, stability, and prosperity in the common interest of all the people on Taiwan," he added.
His ruling Democratic Progressive Party won 87 of the 225 seats in the Legislative Yuan in the heated elections.

After learning of the DPP emerging as the biggest party in the legislature, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said the electoral victory is a clear indication that the electorate has accepted President Chen's proposals for the establishment of a "National Stabilization Alliance" and for the enhancement of inter-party cooperation.
"The proposals reflect the mainstream values of our society," Chang said, promising to carrying them all out as soon as practicable.

The administration will also put into effect the plans brought forth by President Chen before the elections to safeguard national sovereignty, promote legislative reform, improve social welfare, and revive the economy, Chang added. (Ed)

DOC.HEADLINE: JAMES SOONG SHOWS NO INTEREST IN JOINING POLITICAL ALLIANCES

TEXT.P: James Soong, chairman of the People First Party (PFP) said Saturday evening at a press conference that he is not interested in joining any political alliance, but his party will do its best to fulfill its obligation as a dutiful opposition party.
In Saturday's elections, the PFP secured 46 seats in the 225-seat Legislative Yuan and won victory in the race for two county magistrateships.
Soong said President Chen Shui-bian and KMT Chairman Lien Chan called him earlier in the evening, expressing their desire to exchange views on national affairs with him.

He said he will meet with other leaders of the party for exchanges of views on the party's policy guidelines, adding that the PFP will do its best to serve the people and the country. The result of Saturday's elections clearly indicate that the people long for political stability.
Soong said he told Chen and Lien that the PFP will honor its promises to the people and that the party will also put national interests and people's welfare ahead of its party interests.

He stressed that the PFP will help stabilize the political situation. "We hope that the KMT will stabilize and that the political situation will stabilize," he said, adding: "We are not going to do anything that may sow seeds of discord between the ruling and opposition parties."
"We will increase communications with the KMT in the spirit of goodwill," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PEOPLE FIRST PARTY CONGRATULATED BY RIVALS FOR ELECTION VICTORY

TEXT.P: James Soong, chairman of the People First Party (PFP) said Saturday evening that he received congratulatory greetings from President Chen Shui-bian and Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan after the election results were announced.

The party -- a little over a year old -- won 46 seats in Saturday's legislative election and as well as taking the county magistrateships of Taitung and Lienchiang in the simultaneous local government chief elections.

Soong said that both Chen and Lien expressed a wish to meet with him in the near future. However, he said he has no plans to arrange such meetings in the next few days because, he said, he must first meet with the newly elected legislators of his party.
Soong said that the PFP will fulfill its obligation as an opposition party and will give priority to meeting its commitments to the people.

With 46 seats in the Legislative Yuan, the PFP will be an important factor in determining the power structure of the new legislature. None of Taiwan's parties were able to win an absolute majority in the 225-seat Legislative Yuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ELECTIONS WILL NOT AFFECT ROC-U.S. RELATIONS: ROC OFFICIAL
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 1 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's representative to the United States said Saturday that the legislative, county chief and mayoral elections in Taiwan that day will not affect U.S. policy toward the island.

Chen Chien-jen said as he followed the results of the elections in his office at the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in the United States that the overseas Chinese in America and Taiwan's U.S. friends have all been watching the elections carefully.

"Regardless of the election results, everyone recognizes that Taiwan's democracy has once again been realized," Chen said. "Our democratic system will only be more solid and mature after these elections."
Chen added that the people of Taiwan will work together toward a gradual economic recovery after the elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING POLITICAL OBSERVERS SURPRISED BY TAIWAN'S ELECTION RESULTS
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Dec. 1 (CNA) (By Tzeng Chun-liang and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: Political observers in Beijing said Saturday that they were surprised by the election results in Taiwan whereby the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) replaced the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) as the largest party in the Legislative Yuan.

Xu Bodong, director of the Taiwan Research Institute at Beijing Union University, said that the DPP's victory can be attributed to its successful ballot distribution strategy while it demonstrates that its supporters' identification with the party is more stable.

Xu predicted that Taiwan's political quagmire will continue after the elections, and he believes that even if the independence-leaning "pan-green" parties, which includes the DPP, had won an overall majority, the "pan-blues" would have probably become even more united after the elections to fight against the "pan-greens."

Because the KMT lost the largest number of seats, Xu continued, it remains to be seen whether the party will split again. He said that the KMT is still the biggest variable affecting Taiwan's political situation and that the key is whether a faction within the party that favors native Taiwanese over those of mainland Chinese descent will leave at the urging of former President Lee Teng-hui.
A former KMT chairman who was expelled from the party in September, Lee is the "spiritual leader" of the fledgling Taiwan Solidarity Union, which is a member of the so-called "pan-green" parties.

Xu said that although a period of uneasy peace can still be maintained in the Taiwan Strait as long as Chen does not publicly announce Taiwan independence, bilateral relations remain unstable and full of danger.

Guo Zhenyuan, a senior fellow at the China Institute of International Studies, a Beijing government think tank, said that the DPP's surprising victory will not change Beijing's policy of continuing to observe Chen, especially as some of the things he said during the campaign have deepened Beijing's distrust toward him.
Therefore, Guo predicted, it is difficult to see any concrete development in cross-Taiwan Strait relations after the elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN, LOCAL COMMERCE LEADERS URGE LEGISLATORS TO FOCUS ON ECONOMY

TEXT.P: Foreign trade and industry offices and domestic industry leaders in Taiwan urged the newly elected Legislative Yuan to focus on economic issues after Saturday's legislative, county chief and mayoral elections.

Noting that he has been in Taiwan for eight years and has witnessed several elections, American Chamber of Commerce in Taipei (AmCham) President Richard Henson urged Taiwan's political parties to forgo their differences and concentrate on the economy instead of continuing to "play the economy like politics."

European Chamber of Commerce Taipei (ECCT) Chairman Fabrice de Murat also urged the government to focus on the economy because foreign businesses consider the local political situation this year to have been "unstable."

AmCham Executive Director Richard Vuylsteke said that Taiwan is still politicking while mainland China is already devoting itself fully to its economy. He added that foreign businessmen want to see the "beef" in the government's policies, not campaign mudslinging.

Henson said that as the power and influence of the Legislative Yuan grows, Taiwan politicians should realize that partisan cooperation is important, particularly in order to achieve consensus on economic issues.
He added that AmCham has begun to realize that foreign businesses must turn more of their lobbying efforts toward the Legislative Yuan as Taiwan's democratization continues.

Agreeing with his foreign counterparts, Taiwan Chamber of Commerce President Chuang Lung-chang said that he hopes the legislators can focus on response measures to Taiwan's imminent World Trade Organization entry.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW PARTY LEADER ATTRIBUTES SETBACK TO TAIWAN'S ELECTORAL CULTURE

TEXT.P: Hau Lung-bin, former convener of the New Party's (NP's) National Campaign and Development Committee, said Saturday evening that his party failed to appeal to Taiwan's voters "because they did not cast their votes rationally."
He called on party supporters to "deal rationally" with the election results. The NP won only one legislative seat and one county magistrate position in the Saturday elections.

The party, which was founded in 1993 by a group of young Kuomintang (KMT) members who broke away from the KMT to seek a new path to balance the then-ruling party, held nine seat in the previous legislature.

Hau claimed that the election results reflect the irrationality of Taiwan's voters, who he said tend to choose a party for whom to vote instead of taking into consideration the professionalism or image of individual candidates.

DOC.HEADLINE: ELECTION OUTCOMES WILL LEAD TO MORE POLITICAL STABILITY

TEXT.P: The seats won by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) in Saturday's elections show the voters' desire for political stability, according to several scholars interviewed by CNA Saturday night.

The scholars predicted that political stability will result from the elections, given that President Chen Shui-bian's power to name a premier is solidified by his party's legislative gains, while the leading opposition Kuomintang (KMT) is paying the price of deviating from mainstream public opinion.

They said they expect a "National Stabilization Alliance" advocated by Chen before the election will take shape among lawmakers of the DPP, the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), some KMT lawmakers and some independent lawmakers.

Wu Yan-chun, a professor at National Chengchi University, said that although Taiwan's recession is caused by the international economic slowdown and the DPP government's inexperience in governing, the voters chose to give the DPP dominance in both the executive and legislative branches in Saturday's elections.
He warned that the KMT should beware of the risk of being marginalized because of its departure from mainstream public opinion.
Meanwhile, the TSU's 13-seat gains on its political debut shows that its emphasis on Taiwan's identity is appealing to many voters.

Lee You-tan, another professor at National Chengchi University, said he takes comfort from the public confirmation of the DPP as it signifies that they did not buy the opposition's claims that the ruling party should be blamed for the flagging economy.

He predicted that Chen will be "more humble" in the remaining years of his term in light of the fact that his party failed to gain control of the legislature, but that he will not be dictated to by the KMT and its allies at the legislature.
He forecast that the elections will usher in a more stable period in politics and added that the prospects for Chen's "National Stabilization Alliance" are more real than ever.
The DPP's legislative victory might harden its stance toward Beijing, said Chang Lin-chen, a professor at National Taiwan University.

The DPP had to soften its position somewhat when the KMT still dominated the legislature, but now that its policy toward Beijing has won a new mandate, the party will have more leeway in dealing with Beijing. It is hard to predict whether this bodes ill or good for the country's ties with Beijing, she said.

But she said she expects the Taipei authorities to get tough on controversial issues such as the so-called "1992 consensus" on "one China" and on direct postal and transport links with mainland China.
Hsieh Cheng-yu, a professor at Soochow University, attributed the KMT's loss in the elections to the split of its traditional voters between the party and its breakaway, the People First Party.

National Taiwan University Professor Alexander Lu said the TSU's better-than-expected performance results from a shift toward a more pro-independence stance among DPP voters worried about Beijing's increasing international profile.

DOC.HEADLINE: END OF POLLS MARKS BEGINNING OF INTER-PARTY COOPERATION: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Saturday that the conclusion of the legislative and local government chief elections marks "the beginning of an era of cooperation."

In a press release issued following the announcement of the election results, Chen said all political parties should leave behind their differences and pool their wisdom to revive the economy, reform the legislature, promote relations across the Taiwan Strait and improve social welfare.
"Emotional conflict should now give way to rational thinking," Chen said.

According to official results, Chen has obtained what he wanted of the parliamentary polls -- his Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has replaced the Kuomintang (KMT) as the largest party in the Legislative Yuan.

The DPP, which until Saturday had barely one-third of the seats in the 225-member legislature, increased its presence to 87 seats -- an increase of about 40 percent. The main opposition KMT, with 110 seats going into the elections, managed to get only 68 candidates elected.

Two new parties formed by disgruntled KMT mavericks did well in their first legislative elections. The People First Party (PFP) won 46 seats and the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), with former KMT Chairman and ex-ROC President Lee Teng-hui as its "spiritual leader," got 13, with the remaining seats won by independents and fringe parties.

After learning of the DPP's emergence as the biggest party in the legislature, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said the victory is a clear indication that the electorate agrees with Chen's proposal for the establishment of a "national stabilization alliance" and for the enhancement of inter-party cooperation.
"The proposal reflects the mainstream values of our society," Chang said, promising to carry it out as soon as possible.

The DPP garnered 36.57 percent of total votes cast in the legislative elections, compared to the KMT's 31.28 percent, the PFP's 20.34 percent, the TSU's 8.5 percent and the New Party's 2.86 percent. The average voter turnout in the legislative polls was 66.16 percent.

The pro-unification New Party won just one seat in the new legislature, down from the nine it held prior to the election. The party failed to win the minimum 5 percent of the vote it needed to qualify for proportional representation seats. It also managed to win only one local government position -- the magistrateship of the frontline island of Kinmen, which lies closer to mainland China than to Taiwan.
New Party convener Hsieh Chi-ta, an incumbent legislator who lost her re-election bid, said the party will not fade away, but will "continue to flourish."
Noting that many of incumbent New Party legislators have topped the best-performing lawmakers list, she lamented that "their defeats were great losses to the nation."
Both Lee and TSU Chairman Huang Chu-wen said they were satisfied with the party's showing in the polls. "The results also show that the TSU did not win seats at the DPP's expense," said Huang.

He further said the outcome indicates that the New Party's "one country, two systems" unification advocacy and the KMT's insistence on the existence of the "1992 consensus" (one China, with each side free to interpret the notion as they see fit) do not enjoy popular support.
Huang, a former KMT member, predicted that the KMT will suffer another split in the wake of the elections.

KMT Chairman Lien Chan conceded the party's poor showing in the legislative polls. He said as the KMT remains the largest opposition party, it will do its utmost to help maintain domestic political stability and promote inter-party cooperation after the elections.

PFP Chairman James Soong said he was satisfied with the party's showing. Soong, who lost his presidential bid last year by a narrow margin, said he has no interest in joining any political alliances but stressed that the PFP will endeavor to be a dutiful, responsible opposition party.

In the local elections that also took place Saturday, the KMT managed to win mayorships and magistrateships in six previously DPP-ruled cities and counties -- Taichung City, Keelung City, Taichung County, Taoyuan County, Hsinchu City and Hsinchu County.

The DPP also won nine local government chief posts, while the PFP won in Taitung County and the outlying Lienchiang County, which covers the island of Matsu and lies closer to the mainland than to Taiwan. (By sofia Wu) (To be continued)

DOC.HEADLINE: END OF POLLS (II)

TEXT.P: The people of Taiwan made history last year by electing Chen Shui-bian, the first president from an opposition party. But Chen's inexperienced minority government has struggled to work with the legislature and has been unable to thaw relations with mainland China.

Analysts said that mainland China viewed Chen to be a weak, bungling president who wouldn't be re-elected and could be ignored. But his party's victory Saturday might convince Beijing that Chen could win another term. By continuing to ignore him, Chinese leaders could cause Taiwan to drift further toward independence.
Some of these analysts said the electoral outcome might prompt mainaldn leaders to take a second thought on their strategy toward Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Dec. 3, or the 19th day of the 10th month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1808: Madrid surrenders to French forces led by Napoleon Bonaparte.
1810: Britain captures the island of Mauritius from France.
1818: Illinois becomes the 21st state of the United States.
1828: John Quincy Adams loses the U.S. presidential election to his arch-rival Andrew Jackson.
1894: Robert Louis Stevenson, Scottish writer of essays, poetry and novels, dies at the age of 44. He authored "Treasure Island," "The Strange Case of Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde" and "Kidnapped."
1901: American film producer and film animator Walt Disney is born. He created such immortals as Mickey Mouse and Donald Duck.
1943: The Joint Declaration of the Cairo Conference is issued simultaneously in Chungking, Washington and London.
1944: U.S. forces advance across the Saar River in Germany during World War II.
1948: Republic of China government troops evacuate Hsuchow in eastern China.
1958: Dutch businesses are nationalized in Indonesia.
1960: Chou Tao-chi graduates from National Chengchi University and becomes the first student to earn a national doctorate in the Republic of China.
1966: The Kaohsiung Export Processing Zone is inaugurated.
1966: Macau imposes a curfew after massive riots allegedly incited by the Communist Chinese.
1967: South African surgeon Dr. Christiaan Barnard successfully performs a human heart transplant, the first of its kind in the world.
1971: Pakistani planes attack northwest India in a dispute over Kashmir. India responds by declaring a state of emergency.
1975: Communists take control of Laos, declare an end to the 600-year-old monarchy and set up the People's Democratic Republic of Laos.
1976: Rear Adm. James H. Morris, commander of the amphibious forces of the U.S. 7th Fleet, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1983: Taiwan's ruling Kuomintang (KMT) wins a landslide victory in supplementary parliamentary elections. The KMT captures 62 of 71 seats up for grabs in the Legislative Yuan. The opposition wins six seats and independents take three.
1989: U.S. President George Bush and Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev end a summit meeting on Malta in the Mediterranean Sea, signaling the end of the Cold War and entry into a new era of peace and cooperation.
1992: Millions of gallons of crude oil spill into the sea off the coast of La Coruna, Spain, threatening ecological disaster.
1993: Ukraine and the United States fail to resolve a dispute over Ukraine's stockpile of some 1,000 long-range nuclear warheads.
1994: The first popular elections for the governor of Taiwan Province and the mayors of Taipei and Kaohsiung municipalities are held. James C.Y. Soong is elected governor of Taiwan. Chen Shui-bian and Wu Den-yih win the mayorships of Taipei and Kaohsiung, respectively.
1995: Chun Doo Hwan, former president of South Korea, is arrested on charges of military rebellion stemming from a 1979 coup and a later massacre of civilians by the army.
1997: South Korea signs a letter of intent with the International Monetary Fund (IMF) for a loan of US$57 billion, the largest of its kind ever provided by the IMF, to help South Korea get through its financial crisis.
1999: Visiting Malawian President Bakili Muluzi and his ROC counterpart Lee Teng-hui sign a communique reconfirming the friendship between their two countries.
2000: Francis Ng wins the "Best Leading Actor Award," Maggie Cheung wins the "Best Leading Actress Award," and To Kei-Fung wins the "Best Director Award" at the 2000 Golden Horse Awards.
Motse's lesson of the day: "We are certain that heaven desires to have men love and benefit one another and abominates to have them hate and harm one another."

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSINESS LEADER CALLS FOR NEW LEGISLATURE TO WORK TOGETHER AS A TEAM

TEXT.P: The chairman of the General Chamber of Commerce, Republic of China, on Monday called on the new Legislature to fulfill its role of supervising the administration to ensure the implementation of the resolutions adopted at the Economic Development Advisory Conference in late August.
Wang Ling-lin, who served as a legislator in the ROC's most recent Legislature, did not seek reelection in the Dec. 1 elections.

Wang, also chairman of the Eastern Multimedia Group and vice chairman of the Rebar Group, said that he expects the newly elected legislators to work as a team no matter which party they belong to and no matter what doctrines they believe in.
The new Legislature should push the administration to implement the economic revitalization programs mapped out with the consensus of all the parties who attended the August conference, he added.
The changing of the nation's political map after the elections reflects the development of a society of multiple values, according to Wang.

He said that the voters' excessive zealousness regarding party politics instigated by election campaigns over the past several months needs to be soothed, adding that those in business circles always believe that prosperity comes from accommodation and tolerance.

The business leader pointed out the importance of cross-Taiwan Strait economic and trade cooperation, noting that mainland China poses a serious threat to Taiwan but also offers tremendous opportunities.

He said that Taiwan's manufacturing industries cannot afford to ignore mainland China as one of the world's largest production bases and one of the fastest growing markets. He noted that business people from Taiwan can help upgrade the industrial structure on the mainland.
With so many new faces elected, Wang said, he is very concerned about the new Legislature's lawmaking efficiency and the applicability of the new laws it passes related to economics and commerce.

Not many in the new Legislature have experience in business management or are familiar with the operations of the Legislative Yuan, he said, suggesting that the new legislators recruit experts from industry and from academic circles to act as advisers.

As the production value of service industries already accounts for two thirds of Taiwan's gross domestic product, Wang said that the new Legislature should make a thorough review of the government's tax regulations and seek to improve Taiwan's investment environment.

Noting that Taiwan was able to create an economic miracle over the past several decades because of the efforts of many men with vision, Wang said the new Legislature should encourage the administration to explore new possibilities for Taiwan's economy with an open mind.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES UP BY 205.49 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) gained ground on Monday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving up 205.49 points to close at 4,646.61.
Market turnover amounted to NT$91.93 billion (US$2.67 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Shares prices opened high and closed even higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 205.49 points to close at 4,646.61.

Despite a drop in the NASDAQ index over the weekend, the bourse opened at 4,534.37 and continued to go up due to the good performance of electronics shares. The index fluctuated between 4,647.71 and 4,532.19 during trading.

A total of 3.12 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$91.93 billion (US$2.67 billion), an increase from the previous trading session which saw 2.77 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$81.63 billion (US$2.37 billion).

All of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with electrical shares moving up the most at 5.4 percent, followed by construction stocks at 3.5 percent, bank and insurance shares at 3.4 percent, plastics and chemical stocks at 3.2 percent, textile issues at 2.7 percent, cement stocks and foodstuff shares, both at 2 percent, and pulp and paper issues at 1.3 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 545 to 46, with 56 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market were higher on Monday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for December moved up 199 points to close at 4,589, with 15,554 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for next January surged 219 points to close at 4,590, with 67 contract transactions, while next March futures increased 181 points to finish at 4,581, with 11 contracts traded.
Next June futures gained 117 points to close at 4,490, with only one contract transaction, while next September futures decreased 1 point to finish at 4,451, also with one contract traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 4,390 for December, 4,371 for next January, 4,400 for next March, 4,373 for next June, and 4,452 for next September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also higher.
December TE futures moved up 11.45 points to close at 239.2, with 4,540 contract transactions, while next January TE futures increased 10.3 points to finish at 238.8, with 24 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
December TF futures moved up 21 points to finish at 619, with 1,713 contract transactions, while next January TF futures rose 14.8 points to close at 616.8, with six contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN URGED TO STAY ON DESPITE SETBACK

TEXT.P: Two popular figures within the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) said Monday that party chairman Lien Chan need not step down to take the responsibility for the KMT's setback in the elections over the weekend.

Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou noted that during Saturday's legislative as well as local city and county chief elections, the KMT garnered more votes nationally than it did in last year's presidential election, in which Lien Chan represented the KMT and finished a distant third in the race.
The KMT also now controls nine cities and counties around Taiwan, one more than before the elections, Ma noted, adding that this was "not an easy task" to accomplish.

Moreover, although Wang Chien-shien, who in the Taipei county magistrate election represented the "pan-blue alliance," a grouping of the KMT and its two splinter parties the People First Party (PFP) and the New Party (NP), lost to the incumbent Su Tseng-chang, Wang managed to garner 820,000 votes, or the highest number of votes of any KMT candidate running for the position in the past 12 years.

Ma said that although the KMT slipped to 68 seats in the 225-seat Legislature while the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) increased its share of seats to 87, Lien should not resign from his post.
He added however that the KMT needs to review the results of the elections, including the party's campaign strategy and contingency plans.

Ma also said that inter-party cooperation is crucial, noting that cooperation between the KMT and PFP should be a basic direction and should receive the "full-hearted devotion" of both sides as the future of either party will not be optimistic if they decide to fight single-handedly.

He added however that the mechanism for such cooperation, consultation and crisis management should be carefully planned so that there will not be any misunderstandings between the top brass of the two parties.
Jason Hu, the KMT's candidate who won the Taichung mayorship, echoed Ma's words by saying that an immediate resignation by Lien would not help the party's stability.

Meanwhile, Wang Chien-shien, the KMT's candidate for Taipei County chief who was defeated, called on Lien Monday. He said after the meeting that although the KMT lost its position as the largest party in the Legislature, he hopes that both the KMT and the PFP will make some concessions and engage in sincere cooperation.
Lauding Lien as "tolerant and big-hearted," Wang said he hopes Lien can tide over the present difficulties and that the KMT members can rally behind him.

Wang, who became one of the founding members of the New Party eight years ago after leaving the KMT, said that as a former KMT member for 36 years and as one of the "pan-blue alliance," he is concerned with the future of the KMT and its impact on the fate of the nation.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP CHAIRMAN SEES NO NEED TO FORM 'STABILIZATION ALLIANCE'

TEXT.P: Opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong urged President Chen Shui-bian Monday to organize a new government in step with the new public opinion as reflected in the results of Saturday's legislative elections.

"Now that Chen's Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has emerged as the largest party in the legislature, the president has obtained the mandate to organize a new government," Soong said during a "thanksgiving" trip to the eastern county of Taitung where PFP candidate Hsu Ching-yuan was elected magistrate.

Both the ruling DPP and Soong's PFP were clear winners of the just-concluded legislative polls in which the DPP garnered 87 seats, up from its current 67 in the 225-member Legislative Yuan, and the PFP more than doubled its seats to 46.
The DPP and its ally -- the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) which gained 13 legislative seats -- can jointly control 100 legislative seats, only 13 shy of a parliamentary majority.

"Given this situation, President Chen's proposal to form a 'national stabilization alliance' has become meaningless," Soong said, adding that Chen had better scrap his plan and return to operating within the framework of the country's Constitution.

As the DPP controls barely one-third of seats in the outgoing legislature, Chen's minority administration has been plagued by parliamentary gridlock and bickering since Chen's inauguration in May 2000. In an attempt to end legislative bickering, Chen had promised to organize a broad-based, cross-party legislative alliance after the elections to pave the way for forming the island's first coalition government.
In Soong's view, the proposed alliance, would be an "outlawed" body which could disrupt or hinder normal government operations under constitutional provisions.

Soong said the PFP has no intention of joining the alliance. "Nor is the party interested in participating in any ruling coalition," he said, adding that the PFP will consistently act as an opposition party and make sure the government is kept within "checks and balances."

"We are determined to be a top-notch, responsible opposition party," Soong stressed. "The PFP will faithfully reflect mainstream public opinion and carry out the mission of 'checks and balances' with reason."
Against this backdrop, Soong said, the PFP will also not seek the speaker and deputy speaker posts of the new legislature.
Noting that the latest electoral results have strengthened President Chen's ruling mandate, Soong said everybody should accept this outcome regardless of whether they like it or not.
Soong also advised former President Lee Teng-hui not to try to use the TSU's political clout to meddle in domestic political operations.

Lee, the TSU's spiritual leader, had campaigned hard for TSU candidates in the run-up to the weekend elections. Speaking on the campaign trail, Lee said he had helped push for the TSU's establishment mainly because he hoped to help end the legislative gridlock and bickering.
With the TSU's better-than-expected showing in its first electoral battle, political analysts said Lee may emerge as a key player in the DPP's efforts to build a post-election coalition government.

Soong urged Lee to refrain from trying to "manipulate" or "dominate" government operations. "Lee should shy from stealing the show and should leave President Chen alone to make a decision," he said. "A bridegroom is a bridegroom, and a best man is best man. Lee should not misjudge the situation."

The local currency opened Monday at 34.452 and was traded between 34.431 and 34.465.
Interbank U.S. dollar trading totaled US$585 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: FINANCE MINISTER SAYS ELECTION RESULTS BENEFICIAL TO STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Minister of Finance Yen Ching-chang said Monday that the outcome of the Dec. 1 elections will ensure a stabilizing force for the administration to implement its policies, which is beneficial to the stock as well as foreign exchange markets.

The Taipei Stock Exchange market was bullish Monday, the first trading day after the elections of legislators and city and county chiefs. Share prices jumped 4.6 percent, with the weighted price index gaining 205.49 points to close at 4,646.61 points.

Yen pointed out that the sluggishness of the local economy was mainly due to the international economic recession. As an export-oriented economy, Taiwan was vulnerable to an international economic slowdown, he added.

The minister said that Taiwan's economic prospects were looking up as the international economic environment was improving. Many finance ministers he met at the Asian-Pacific Economic Conference in September suggested that Taiwan will be among the first group of economies to rebound.

The ruling Democratic Progressive Party won 87 seats in the elections for legislators, attaining the position as the largest party in the Legislative Yuan. The opposition Kuomintang won 68 seats, the People First Party won 46 seats, the Taiwan Solidarity Union won 13 seats and independent candidates won 10 seats.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLL FINDS MAJORITY SUPPORT FOR COALITION GOVERNMENT

TEXT.P: The majority of respondents to a post-elections opinion survey have voiced support for the formation of a coalition government to maintain domestic political stability, pollsters said Monday.

The telephone poll of 1,090 adults randomly chosen from around the island, conducted by Gallup opinion survey company at the request of Sanlih Entertainment Television, found that 60.5 percent of those interviewed supported the formation of a coalition government.
Only 21.9 percent gave a thumbs-down to the proposal with the remaining respondents declining to answer the question.

Even though the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) managed to garner the largest number of seats in the re-elected legislature in Saturday's polls, it still failed to control a clear majority. The DPP gained 87 out of the 225 legislative seats up for grabs. Before the elections, President Chen Shui-bian had promised to organized a broad-based, cross-party alliance in the new legislature to pave the way for the formation of the island's first coalition government after the polls.

As the electoral outcome broke the once all-powerful Kuomintang's (KMT's) grip on the legislative majority, whether incumbent Legislative Yuan Wang Jin-pyng, a KMT vice chairman, can continue serving as speaker of the lawmaking body has also drawn much attention. The KMT won only 68 seats in the latest elections, down from the current 110.
Gallup survey results showed that 27.9 percent of the respondents supported a DPP-KMT ticket for the legislature's speaker-deputy speaker election scheduled for next February.

Meanwhile, 17.9 percent said they preferred to see the KMT team up with the opposition People First Party (PFP), which gained 46 seats in Saturday's elections, to vie for the speakership and deputy speakership.

While 9.9 percent said they hoped to see a DPP-DPP ticket, 7.9 percent backed a DPP-PFP slate, and 5.5 percent backed a KMT-KMT ticket. Another 5.5 percent said they would like to see the DPP team up with the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) for the two top legislative posts, and 23.1 percent had no opinion. The four-month-old TSU capture 13 seats in the just-concluded elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: LINKS WITH MAINLAND CHINA POSSIBLE UNDER WTO FRAMEWORK: ROC MINISTER

TEXT.P: Taiwan is willing to discuss the establishment of direct transportation links with mainland China under the framework of the World Trade Organization (WTO), according to Minister of Transportation and Communications Yeh Chu-lan.

Yeh said in a report slated to be submitted Monday to a meeting of the transport committee under the Legislative Yuan that the government will continue to promote direct air, sea and postal links with the mainland after both sides of the Taiwan Strait join the WTO based on the principles of reciprocity, mutual benefit and peace.
Taiwan and mainland China are expected to enter the WTO early next year.
Yeh said the promotion of such links is a set government policy under the plan of the Mainland Affairs Council and that her ministry has made related preparations.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT BEGINS SOUL-SEARCHING AFTER ELECTION SETBACK

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) began soul-searching Monday with its chairman, Lien Chan, saying that the party will review its operations after election setbacks over the weekend.
Lien made the remarks in a closed-door meeting with nine elected KMT mayors and county magistrates, according to Chao Shou-po, director general of the KMT's organization and development committee.

The KMT was dealt a serious blow in the legislative elections by collecting only 68 seats in the 225-seat Legislative Yuan compared with the sharp increase of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) which took 87 seats. However, the KMT found some solace by taking nine city and county chiefs positions, one more than before the elections. The DPP dropped to nine from 12 before the elections.

Lien urged the KMT members to continue to work hard, and said that he will review party operations and adopt necessary measures. He also comforted those defeated KMT candidates, especially those who lost by a small margin such as Yeh Chin-feng in Chunghua County.

Lien told the elected officials that the current economic situation is not good, and each of the local chiefs should expect to face painful financial problems. He expressed the hope that they work closely with the KMT caucus in the legislature, and Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng, who is also a KMT vice chairman, to set the nation's economy on a new course.

Lien said that the results of the local elections show that the people want to give the KMT another chance, and the KMT will make good use of the opportunity to listen to the real voice of grassroots citizens.

He noted that every city and county will face debt and interest repayment problems. In addition, construction after the Sept. 21, 1999 earthquake and the impact on trade by Taiwan's imminent entry into the World Trade Organization will also be issues the local chiefs will face.

Some of the elected city and county chief said the KMT's think tanks will be able to help them with ideas to improve social order, traffic, social welfare, construction, disaster prevention and globalization.
Some said that the public is most concerned about social order, unemployment and economic problems, and programs to deal with WTO entry.
Some also said that there should be more exchanges between the local KMT chiefs, and that Penghu Magistrate-elect Lai Feng-wei will organize regular, unofficial meetings.
KMT Vice Chairmen Wu Po-hsiung, Lin Cheng-chih, and Wang Jin-pyng all concurred that this is the time for KMT unity, urging all party members to rally behind the party despite the setbacks.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ECONOMISTS UPBEAT ON ECONOMIC GROWTH FOR 2002

TEXT.P: Economists at the Academia Sinica predicted Monday that Taiwan's first-quarter economic growth next year should be able to reach approximately 2 percent as seen from several favorable indicators signaling possible recovery.

Researchers at the Academia Sinica Institute of Economics said that the stock market is one of the most sensitive indicators of economic revival. Export orders for the local electronic industry have also seen an obvious increase recently, they said, adding that production equipment will kick back into action as warehouse stockpiles are gradually depleted.

The economists said that because the fourth-quarter economic growth rate last year was only 3.82 percent, the basis for comparison for this year's fourth-quarter economic growth was already relatively low. Therefore, this year's fourth-quarter economic growth could reach negative 1 percent compared to the same period last year instead of the government-estimated negative 2.68 percent, they said.

The institute -- which is scheduled to announce its economic growth forecast for 2002 on Dec. 19 -- predicted that the economy's upswing momentum should carry into next year, with first-quarter economic growth reaching approximately 2 percent compared to the same period this year, when the economy grew by only 0.92 percent.
The economy could still reach the government-established goal of 2.6 percent annual economic growth in 2002, the institute added.

Meanwhile, the Taiwan Research Institute (TRI), a local think tank affiliated with former President Lee Teng-hui, announced in its 2002 economic forecast report that the island's average economic growth for the latter half of next year will reach 3.97 percent, while annual growth should reach 2.24 percent.

The TRI predicted that Taiwan's annual economic growth for this year could fall to negative 2.18 percent as global economic growth would reach only 1.3 percent due to the bursting of the U.S. information technology bubble and fallout from the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks on America.
However, the global economic growth rate could reach 1.7 percent next year, the TRI predicted.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP VICTORY MAY FORCE BEIJING TO RETHINK TAIWAN POLICY
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Dec. 3 (CNA) (By Tseng Chun-liang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Mainland China is expected to adjust its strategy toward Taiwan after the people of Taiwan gave their government a vote of confidence Saturday, political analysts said Monday.

Since President Chen Shui-bian assumed the Republic of China presidency in Taiwan's first-ever peaceful transition of power between different political parties in May 2000, mainland China has been promoting an "anti-independence, pro-unification" campaign in Taiwan and even to overseas Chinese communities around the world.
Moreover, Beijing has declined any contact or dialogue with Chen's administration on suspicion of what it saw as the pro-independence nature of his Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

As Chen won the presidency with only 39.3 percent of the popular vote and the pro-unification Kuomintang (KMT) still controlled a clear majority in Taiwan's legislature, leaders in Beijing regarded Chen as a "minority president" with little chance of winning re-election.

Against this backdrop, mainland China adopted a new policy toward Taiwan -- forging contacts with only those Taiwan political parties or groups which support the "one China" principle and intensifying its diplomatic embargo against Taiwan.

In the run-up to Taiwan's Dec. 1 legislative elections, mainland leaders generally forecast a poor showing for Chen's DPP as his administration has been plagued by legislative gridlock and the island's economy is in its worst downturn in three decades.

Much to Beijing's surprise, the electoral results showed that the DPP replaced the KMT as the largest party in the re-elected lawmaking body. The DPP captured 87 of the 225 legislative seats up for grabs, and the newly formed Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), which campaigned on a platform of "stressing Taiwan's separate identity and keeping mainland China at arm's length," won 13 seats.
In contrast, the KMT won only 68 seats, down from 110 before the elections.

Mainland Chinese scholars involved in study of Taiwan affairs generally admitted that the electoral outcome is favorable to Chen's administration and would boost the island's pro-independence sentiments and may even enhance Chen's confidence in seeking re-election. As for the impact on relations across the Taiwan Strait, most mainland academics painted a pessimistic picture.

Li Jiachuan, a researcher with the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait, said that most candidates who supported the "one China" principle, the existence of the cross-strait "1992 consensus" on "one China, separate interpretations," and opposed Taiwan independence were defeated in Saturday's polls.
On the other hand, Li said, those who pitched for Taiwan's "localization," separate identity and disavowal of the "1992 consensus" won their electoral bids.
"This outcome will have an adverse impact on the future development of cross-strait ties," Li said.

Nevertheless, some other analysts, who preferred anonymity, said even though mainland China is unlikely to change its fundamental attitude toward Chen's administration, it cannot completely ignore the island's political reality.
If Beijing continues rejecting any engagement with Chen's administration, the analysts said, the situation may get worse.
Beijing's recalcitrant attitude and inaction could block any chance of improving cross-strait relations and could make Taiwan drift further away from the mainland, they warned.

The analysts further said Beijing leaders should draw inspiration from the results of Taiwan's latest elections and should understand that their "one country, two systems" unification scheme has no appeal to Taiwan voters.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT REAFFIRMS NO CHANGE IN POLICY TOWARD CROSS-STRAIT TIES

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Monday his party's dramatic win in Saturday's legislative elections would not change his commitment to improving relations across the Taiwan Strait.

While meeting with more than 20 foreign scholars and experts attending a seminar on Taiwan's democratic consolidation and peace in the Taiwan Strait, Chen said his administration's policy of opening up to mainland China would not be revered after the weekend polls in which his Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) replaced the Kuomintang (KMT) as the biggest party in the new legislature.
"My sincerity to improve cross-strait relations has not changed. My wish to normalize cross-strait relations has not changed," Chen told his guests.
Chen said mainland Chinese authorities looked down on him and his administration before the elections.

"I hope they can respect the choice of the people of Taiwan after the elections" Chen said, adding that he also hopes that mainland leaders can "grasp the window of opportunity" by ending the stalemate between the two sides.

Noting that the Dec. 1 polls were the island's cleanest elections, Chen said the electoral results further consolidated Taiwan's democratic achievements and marked further progress in the island's democratic development.
Chen said he hopes Taiwan's democratization can serve a beacon to mainland China's modernization and democratization.
Mainland China has cold-shouldered Chen since his presidential election victory last year, even though he has mellowed his pro-independence stand and made numerous conciliatory gestures to Beijing.

Chen's DPP captured 87 seats in an unexpected election rout, up from 67 in the outgoing KMT-dominated legislature. The once all-powerful KMT gained only 68 out of the 225 seats up for grabs, losing its parliamentary majority for the first time in their last bastion of power.

Chen told foreign election observers that he will uphold his pre-election commitment to organize a broadbased, cross-party "national stabilization alliance" in the legislature to pave the way for the formation of the island's first coalition government after the polls.

Chen said he has asked DPP Chairman Frank Hsieh and other party heavyweights to stop any criticism of opposition parties as the end of the elections should be the beginning of inter-party cooperation.

"The electoral outcome indicates that local voters have high expectation of domestic political stability," Chen said, adding that both his administration and the DPP are obliged to deliver on their campaign promises of pursuing sweeping domestic reform in a stable environment as well as revitalizing the island's faltering economy.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOP MAINLAND CHINA POLICY-MAKER URGES BEIJING TO TALK

TEXT.P: Beijing should sit down and talk with Taipei as soon as possible now that many uncertainties between the two sides have disappeared with the end of Taiwan's elections over the weekend, a top mainland China policy-maker said Monday.

Tsai Ing-wen, chairwoman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), called on Beijing to take into account the sincerity and efforts Taipei has displayed to improve bilateral ties. She stressed that the government will not make major changes to its policy toward mainland China, although the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) won the largest number of seats in the legislative elections.
Tsai made the remarks at a seminar with the heads of Taiwan businessmen's associations in Beijing, Shanghai, Shenzhen, Dongwan, Kungshan, and Fuzhou.

Ranking government officials, including Council for Economic Planning and Development Chairman Chen Po-chih, Minister of Finance Yen Ching-chang, Central Bank of China Governor Perng Fai-nan and Straits Exchange Foundation Secretary-General Shi Hwei-yow were also present.

The MAC head also ruled out outside speculation that the DPP's election victory is tantamount to a rise of Taiwan independence sentiment and stressed that the government must first think of the possibility when working on a policy.
Taiwan voters went to the polls to elect a new Legislative Yuan and 23 county magistrates and city mayors. The leading opposition Kuomintang lost its control at the 225-seat legislature.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Dec. 4, or the 20th day of the 10th month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past.
1154: Nicholas Breakspeare becomes the first Englishman to become the pope.
1795: Thomas Carlyle, Scottish historian and essayist, is born. His works include "Sartor Resartus" and "The French Revolution."
1892: Gen. Francisco Franco, Spanish dictator from 1939 until his death in 1975, is born.
1893: Britain and France reach an agreement on Siam (Thailand).
1912: Turkey reaches an armistice with all the Balkan allies except Greece.
1947: Tennessee Williams' play "A Streetcar Named Desire" premiers on Broadway, with Marlon Brando and Jessica Tandy in the leading roles.
1936: Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek of the Republic of China leaves Loyang for Xian to meet with Chang Hsueh-liang.
1939: Wu Pei-fu, a noted Chihli faction general of the Peiyang army, China's first modern fighting force, dies of illness in Beijing at the age of 66.
1963: Pope Paul VI approves the decision of the Roman Catholic Vatican Council to authorize the use of vernacular languages instead of Latin in performing the sacraments.
1963: The Kuomintang Central Standing Committee approves the resignation of ROC Premier Chen Cheng, who is concurrently serving as the vice president, and names Yen Chia-kan as the new premier.
1965: The United States successfully launches "Gemini 7," which would orbit the earth for a record 14 days.
1966: Beijing's Red Guard arrests communist leaders such as Peng Chen, Tien Han and Wan Li.
1973: Jordanian Minister of Tourism and Antiquities Ghaleb Z. Barakat arrives in Taipei for a weeklong visit.
1975: The Third Conference of East Asia Economists opens in Taipei with 30 Japanese and 50 Chinese delegates attending.
1975: Defense Minister Kao Kuei-yuan announces that the fighting capability of the ROC armed forces has nearly quintupled over the last quarter of a century.
1975: Willem Pretorius, the new South African consul-general to the ROC, arrives in Taipei to assume office.
1976: The Central African Republic becomes the Central African Kingdom, and President Jean Bedel Bokassa is crowned king.
1976: A seminar on agricultural engineering and development is held at National Taiwan University to mark the 60th anniversary of the establishment of the Chinese Agriculture Society.
1977: A hijacked Malaysian airliner carrying 100 people crashes in Singapore, killing everyone onboard.
1989: Members of East Germany's Politburo and Central Committee resign, and Head of State Egon Krenz is forced to step down only six weeks after replacing a beleaguered Erich Hoenecker.
1994: U.S. Secretary of Transportation Federico Pena visits the ROC, becoming the first U.S. secretary to carry out the new U.S. policy governing high-ranking official visits to Taipei.
1998: A trial is held in Shanghai for a Chinese entrepreneur accused of providing e-mail addresses to an online democracy magazine.
1999: Opposition Democratic Progressive Party presidential candidate Chen Shui-bian leaves for a five-day European visit.
2000: The fourth Global Semiconductor Industry Seminar opens in the Hsinchu Science-Based Industrial Park, with more than 200 of the leading lights of the global semiconductor sector participating.
2000: David Yen, one of Taiwan's most prominent anti-smoking activists, is granted a Thai royal decoration in Taipei for his contributions toward successfully controlling tobacco consumption in Thailand.
Motse's lesson of the day: "The interest of the wise ruler lies in carrying out what makes for order among the people and avoiding what makes for confusion. When the administration of the ruler answers the desires of the people, there will be order, otherwise there will be confusion."

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC AIR FORCE TO COMMISSION F-16 FIGHTER WING

TEXT.P: The Republic of China Air Force is scheduled to commission its first F-16 fighter wing into service Dec. 18, a military spokesman said Tuesday.

Maj. Gen. Huang Suey-sheng said that the 455th tactical combat aircraft wing stationed at Chiayi Air Force Base has completed its training and will be officially called on to take on combat readiness roles after its commissioning.
President Chen Shui-bian will preside over the commissioning ceremony, Huang said.

The spokesman added that the event signals a new milestone for the ROC Air Force as it continues to work toward completing the deployment of its new generation of fighter jets to form an elite, modernized and professional force that can maintain air superiority in the Taiwan Strait.
The ROC Air Force has purchased 120 single-seat F-16 Fighting Falcons from the United States and 30 twin-seat versions to carry out mid-altitude offshore interception missions.
Together with 60 Mirage 2000-5s purchased from France and 130 locally built Indigenous Defense Fighters, these modern fighter jets form the backbone of the island's modernizing military forces.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES UP BY 119.82 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) gained ground on Tuesday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving up 119.82 points to close at 4,766.43.
Market turnover amounted to NT$119.93 billion (US$3.48 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Shares prices opened low but closed higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 119.82 points to close at 4,766.43.

Affected by a decline in U.S. stock prices, the bourse opened at 4,638.89 and began to go up later due to the good performance of both financial stocks and electronics shares. The index fluctuated between 4,767.92 and 4,603.12 during trading.

A total of 4.22 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$119.93 billion (US$3.48 billion), an increase from the previous trading session which saw 3.12 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$91.93 billion (US$2.67 billion).
Two of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with construction stocks moving down the most at 0.2 percent, followed by pulp and paper issues at 0.1 percent.

The other major categories posted gains, with bank and insurance shares moving up the most at 3 percent, followed by electrical shares at 2.9 percent, plastics and chemical stocks at 2.8 percent, textile issues at 1.7 percent, cement stocks at 1.4 percent, and foodstuff shares at 0.7 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 387 to 164, with 95 stocks remaining unchanged.
