DOC.HEADLINE: ROC GOV'T TO SET UP MECHANISM TO DEAL WITH INTERNATIONAL RELIEF WORK

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) is planning to establish a mechanism to deal with Taiwan's humanitarian relief work in the international community, a MOFA official said Tuesday.

Lo Chih-cheng, the head of MOFA's Research and Planning Board, noted that with various disasters and accidents taking place in recent years, Taiwan has increased its participation in international relief work, adding that Taiwan's current contingency measures to deal with such accidents have proved to be inadequate.

The ministry has therefore drafted a plan to establish the mechanism, Lo said, adding that such a mechanism will help upgrade the efficiency of Taiwan's international relief work as well as highlight the government's determination in the pursuit of peace.

Also, as human rights diplomacy is a major part of Taiwan's current foreign policy, Lo said, the ministry has instructed its overseas missions to actively participate in activities related to International Human Rights Day on Dec. 10.
He added that position papers on Taiwan's human rights diplomacy will be unveiled in a few days.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market were higher on Tuesday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for December moved up 152 points to close at 4,741, with 19,985 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for next January gained 140 points to close at 4,730, with 78 contract transactions, while next March futures increased 105 points to finish at 4,730, with 7 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 4,589 for December, 4,590 for next January, 4,625 for next March, 4,490 for next June, and 4,451 for next September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also higher.
December TE futures moved up 9.95 points to close at 249.15, with 4,540 contract transactions, while next January TE futures increased 9.7 points to finish at 248.5, with 27 contracts traded.
Next March TE futures rose 10.75 points to close at 250.95, with two contract transactions, while next June TE futures edged up 0.65 points to finish at 245, with 8 contracts traded.
September TE futures gained 9.95 points to close at 257.15, with 23 contracts changing hands.
December TF futures moved up 27 points to finish at 646, with 2,275 contract transactions, while next January TF futures rose 31.2 points to close at 648, with 13 contracts traded.
Next September TF futures increased 19.4 points to finish at 629.8, with 61 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: SCHOOL FOR TAIWAN CHILDREN ON M'LAND TO OFFER 12-YEAR EDUCATION

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Education has approved the opening of two classes for 10th grade students by the Dongguan School for Taiwan Businessperson's Children in Guangdong Province, mainland China, beginning in the 2002 school year, a ministry official said Tuesday.

The Dongguan school, set up in September 2000, is the first shool for Taiwan children in mainland China. The school presently has four kindergarten classes, 20 elementary school classes, and seven junior high school classes, but it offers no high school class.
Currently, there are 96 children in the kindergarten classes, 646 students in the elementary school classes, and 243 in the junior high school classes, according to Wu Canyang, the school principle.

Wu said that among the school's 29 junior high school graduates last summer, 13 returned to Taiwan to continue their education, while the others either chose to enter a mainland Chinese high school or went to Singapore to attend high school.

Junior high school graduates of this school year will now be able to continue their education in high school classes at the Dongguan school with the opening of the two 10th grade classes in September 2002, he said.
It is expected that the Dongguan school for children of Taiwan businesspeople will admit three classes of new high school students each year, according to Wu.

He said that the school in the first semester enrolled more than 700 students, much higher than the 500 that the school initially planned to receive. As the number of students who will be attending the school by the year 2005 may exceed 2,000, new classrooms and school facilities are presently under construction.

Subsidized by the Ministry of Education, the Dongguan school offers courses comparable to those offered in Taiwan's education system. Since the teachers and the teaching materials are mostly from Taiwan, the graduates of the Dongguan school will not have much trouble continuing their studies in Taiwan, Wu pointed out.
Taiwan children in the Dongguan area are lucky to have such an educational establishment, mainly because of the efforts of the large numbers of Taiwan businesspeople working there.

The chairman of the school board, Yeh Hung-teng, is the former chairman of the Taiwan Businessperson's Association, Dongguan. Since the time it was formed in October 1993, the 2,169-member association had made the school project a major goal.

In order to successfully establish this kind of "private" school, the association needed the support of authorities on both sides of the Taiwan Strait. After years of negotiations, the school preparatory committee received the approval of the Guangdong Provincial Government in October 1999 to establish a school with the status similar to that of an international school.
The Dongguan school is unique in mainland China because it is allowed to have a Taiwan principal, hire Taiwan teachers and use textbooks from Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER SAYS ROC CABINET TO RESIGN EN MASSE IN JANUARY

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Tuesday that his Cabinet will resign en masse sometime in January before the next Legislative Yuan is sworn in.
Chang made the remark while being interpellated by opposition Kuomintang Legislator Lin Jih-jia. However, he said that the exact date for the resignation was still under consideration.

In response to Lin's comment that several outstanding legislators were not re-elected partially because pre-election opinion polls led their supporters to believe that the popular candidates would have no problem winning the elections, Chang said that he agreed with Lin "100 percent" and that a draft amendment to the Public Officials Election and Recall Law to help create a fairer and more objective election environment in the future has already been sent to the Legislative Yuan.
After the interpellation session, Chang told reporters that because the premier is appointed by the president, it is too early to talk about forming a new Cabinet.
The pressing issue at hand is ratifying the fiscal 2002 general budget for the central government, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: N.T. DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The new Taiwan dollar rose NT$0.004 against the U.S. dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Tuesday, closing at 34.461.
The local currency opened Tuesday at 34.455 and was traded between 34.451 and 34.468.
Interbank U.S. dollar trading totaled US$206 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-U.S. AIRCRAFT JOINT VENTURE TAKES OFF
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 3 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: The first batch of three single-engine utility aircraft produced by Tiger Aircraft, a Taiwan-U.S. joint venture company, rolled off the assembly line and took flight at a grand ceremony in West Virginia Monday.

Republic of China Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Yiin Chii-ming, West Virginia Gov. Bob Wise, U.S. Sen. John D. Rockefeller from West Virginia, U.S. Aircraft Owners and Pilots Association President Phil Boyer and some 300 guests were present at the event.

With representatives from 11 Taiwan aviation companies in tow, Yiin said that these companies were able to vie for the opportunity to produce spare parts for the US$219,500 four-person plane and learn about the U.S. Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) aircraft certification process through the joint venture.
The company, which is 70 percent-owned by Taiwan venture capital firms, received the FAA certification for the Tiger AG-5B last Friday.

Tiger Aircraft Chairman and CEO Bob Crowley turned the keys of the first three planes over to their respective U.S. buyers at the ceremony. The company already has orders for 48 more planes and estimates it will receive orders for 96 planes next year.

David R.C. Chu, director of the ROC Executive Yuan's Committee for Aviation and Space Industry Development, said that U.S. aviation companies have been seeking production bases in Asia ever since the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in America further exasperated the sluggish business at U.S. airlines and sent the U.S. civil aviation industry into a tailspin.

This has led to the opening up of opportunities for Taiwan aviation firms, and initial negotiations with Tiger Aircraft suggest that the company could decide to manufacture fuselage and tail components in Taiwan, Chu added.

DOC.HEADLINE: M'LAND CHINESE IN H.K., MACAU TO BE GIVEN PRIORITY FOR TOURISM: MAC

TEXT.P: The government will give priority consideration to mainland Chinese citizens who have resident status in Hong Kong or Macau regarding entering Taiwan for tourism, the nation's top formulator of mainland policy said Tuesday.
Tsai Eng-wen, chairwoman of the Mainland Affairs Council, made the remarks while fielding questions in the Legislative Yuan.

Legislator Kwan Yuk-noan of the opposition Kuomintang suggested during the general intepellation session in the Legislative Yuan that the government at the start of next year open Taiwan simultaneously to mainland Chinese tourists residing in Macau and Hong Kong.

Kwan was referring to the government's recent decision to open Taiwan as of Jan.1 , 2002, to mainland Chinese tourists who have permanent resident status in other countries or who are studying overseas.

Premier Chang Chun-hsiung noted that the Economic Development Advisory Conference in August concurred that Taiwan should open up to mainland Chinese tourists and expressed the hope that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait will first consult with each other on the issue.
But the premier said that as cross-strait consultations are currently stalled, the Republic of China government has had to resort to the partial opening measure instead.

Tsai said that the number of mainland Chinese coming to Taiwan for tourism, meaning those who have permanent residency in a third country or are students studying overseas, will not be as small as others have claimed.
She added that the opening of Taiwan to mainland Chinese tourists will be a positive thing and that there is no need for foot-dragging.

The MAC chairwoman also said that the future scope of Taiwan's opening to mainland Chinese tourists as well as the question of when to implement the next stage of the opening will depend on the results of the first stage of the opening and also on the level of matching measures by mainland China.

She said that those mainland Chinese who have obtained resident status in Hong Kong or Macau will continue to be given priority consideration when the ROC government plans for the next stage of the Taiwan's opening to mainland Chinese tourists.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF BLACK-FACED SPOON-BILLS ARRIVING IN TAIWAN TOPS 600

TEXT.P: The number of black-faced spoonbills that have arrived in Taiwan for the winter has reached more than 600, a black-faced spoonbill preservation society in the southern Taiwan county of Tainan said.

But the society said that as most of the black-faced spoonbills are only using Taiwan as a mid-way stop, the maximum number of the migratory birds staying at the mouth of Tsengwen Creek, a major habitat in Tainan County for the endangered species, has remained at 526.

The society said that although it detects that the number of black-faced spoon-bills in the area has surpassed 600, the bird is migratory in nature and does not stay in the same place for long, so the society has been hesitant about publicly announcing a new record number.
The society said it will conduct a survey of the black-faced spoon-bill simultaneously with its Hong Kong counterparts, just as it did last year.
The number of black-faced spoon-bills arriving in Hong Kong for winter hit a new high last year.
It is estimated that there are more than 700 black-faced spoonbills in the world at present.

DOC.HEADLINE: COL. PAN AI-CHU TO BECOME ROC'S 3RD FEMALE GENERAL

TEXT.P: Col. Pan Ai-chu, the new political warfare department director of the Military Intelligence Bureau (MIB) under the Ministry of National Defense (MND), will be promoted to the rank of major general Jan. 1, 2002, an MND spokesman said Tuesday.

Military spokesman Maj. Gen. Huang Suey-sheng told a routine news conference that Pan was promoted to her current post from deputy director of the MIB's mainland Chinese affairs research department Dec. 1.
"As the post is traditionally reserved for a major general, Pan will be promoted to that rank at the beginning of next year," Huang explained.
Pan, 46, will be the first Republic of China female officer to be promoted to major general in more than 40 years. And in the country's military history, she will become the third female general.
Speaking on the same occasion, Pan said it will be a great honor for her to join the ranks of generals.
"The promotion will be yet another symbol of gender equality in the ROC armed forces," Pan said, adding that it also signifies the bright career prospects for women military officers in Taiwan.

Pan encouraged her fellows in the military to forget their sex in their workplaces and compete with their male peers on an equal footing. As a matter of fact, she said, the military has put much emphasis on gender equality in recent years.
"I feel that female officers and non-commissioned officers can have brilliant careers just like their male fellows so long as they work hard," Pan said.

Military records show that Pan graduated from the political science department of the military-run Fuhsingkang College and has a master's degree from the school's Graduate Institute of Political Science. Pan has also attended an MIB-sponsored graduate program.

Pan was an outstanding student and ranked among the top three when she graduated from Fuhsingkang College. She worked for two years at the ROC Army's local-level political warfare units and then entered the graduate school. She joined the MIB's mainland affairs research department after obtaining her master's degree.

Over the past 20-plus years, Pan has been involved in research of mainland Chinese intelligence and relevant information. She is now responsible for studying articles carried in major mainland Chinese magazines as well as collecting, compiling and analyzing information about the latest mainland situation.

Pan has received much acclaim from the government and military leadership for her analyses of mainland intelligence and suggestions on the development of relations across the Taiwan Strait, military sources said.

According to MIB sources, Pan's analytical reports were very useful during three critical periods -- the 1996 Taiwan Strait crisis, former President Lee Teng-hui's defining of cross-strait ties as a special "state-to-state" relationship in July 1999, and the 2000 presidential election which ushered in Taiwan's first peaceful transition of power between different political parties.

Commenting on reports that Chief of the General Staff Gen. Tang Yao-ming asked her to promote the MIB's restructuring after she assumed her current post, Pan said job adjustments in the MIB have never been based on any specific topics or problems.
"Superiors tend to make an overall, comprehensive review before making personnel adjustments, and personal qualifications or capabilities are also a major consideration," Pan said.

Noting that security is the priority concern in intelligence work, Pan said she will focus on improving security measures and helping her superiors make the right judgment calls in the policymaking process.

Pan's husband is also a career service member. They have two sons, both of whom now senior high school students. Pan said it has not been difficult for her to balance her military career and her family life.

The ROC's first women general was Chiang Yi-ying, a close aide to Gen. Tai Li, director of the MIB's precursor, known as the "chun-tung-chu" in Chinese. Chiang impressed her superiors with remarkable accomplishments in developing clandestine radio stations for intelligence delivery in Hong Kong and Southeast Asia during the eight-year War of Resistance against Japanese Aggression. After retiring from intelligence service, Chiang dedicated herself to the service of education, founding Yusheng Elementary School in Taipei.

The second women general was Maj. Gen. Chou Mei-yu, a military medical member who contributed a great deal to the establishment of the National Defense Medical College. Chou was promoted to major general in 1958 and retired from military service in 1972.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC EDUCATION MINISTER SEEKS ACADEMIC COOPERATION WITH MALAYSIA
DOC.DATELINE: Kuala Lumpur, Dec. 4 (CNA) (By Chen Yi-ping & Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Minister of Education Ovid Tzeng Tuesday urged the Malaysian government to recognize diplomas issued by Taiwan universities.

In his talks with Malaysian officials in charge of education in Penang, Tzeng said that Malaysia and Taiwan have plans to develop their countries into regional centers for scientific and technological education.
If both sides can recognize diplomas mutually to engage in academic cooperation, he noted, their plans can be realized at an early date.
At present, the Malaysian government recognizes only the diplomas issued by eight medical departments, seven dental departments and one pharmacy department from eight Taiwan universities.

Tzeng said that Taiwan has been encouraging Taiwan students to pursue advanced study in Malaysia and has been promoting bilateral academic exchanges to pave the way for the formation of a regional academic alliance.

The minister said that Taiwan's long-term target is to establish a regional academic alliance to conduct ministerial roundtable conferences to promote cooperation on scientific and technological education.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO NEED FOR KMT CHAIRMAN TO STEP DOWN: TAIPEI MAYOR

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said Tuesday that there is no need for Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan to step down to take responsibility for the party's upset in the Dec. 1 legislative and local elections.
He made the remarks while commenting on the call by some KMT members that Lien should resign.
Ma, a member of the KMT Central Standing Committee, told the media that "all of us are responsible for the defeat in the elections, but we have different ways to take the responsibility."
He said that Lien should continue serving as party chairman and find the reasons for the defeat to carry out a thorough party reforms.
Ma went on to say that the primary responsibility for Lien is how to bring back the party's members who left the party when then-president Lee Teng-hui served as party chairman.
"It will best benefit the party," he said.
The Taipei mayor is ready to present a proposal to call for cooperation between the KMT and the People First Party (PFP) at a KMT Central Standing Committee meeting Wednesday.

The PFP, headed by former KMT Secretary-General James Soong, performed well in last Saturday's elections, gaining 46 seats in the 225-seat Legislative Yuan, next to the Democratic Progressive Party's 87 seats and the KMT's 68 seats.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. THINK TANK SPONSORS SEMINAR ON IMPACT OF TAIWAN ELECTIONS
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 3 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Representatives of major Taiwan political parties debated the possible fallout of the island's latest legislative elections on future development of relations across the Taiwan Strait at a seminar here Monday.

Hsiao Bi-khim, one of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) newly elected legislator representing the overseas Chinese community, said at the seminar that President Chen Shui-bian will continue his "middle-of-the-road" policy on cross-strait affairs after the DPP emerged as the largest party in Taiwan's legislature.

However, Su Chi, a former chairman of the Republic of china's Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council who represented Taiwan's largest opposition party, the Kuomintang (KMT), at the seminar, said he is pessimistic about future cross-strait ties.

In an unexpected election rout, the DPP managed to capture 87 out of the 225 legislative seats up for grabs in Saturday's elections, up from current 67. In contrast, the KMT lost its 52-year parliamentary dominance by garnering only 68 seats.

Speaking at the seminar sponsored by the American Enterprise Institute (AEI), Wu Jui-kuo, representative of Taiwan's another major opposition party, the People First Party (PFP), which more than doubled its seats to 46, said his party looks forward to see all of the island's major political groups forge a consensus on the development of cross-strait relations.
Wu said President Chen should convene a meeting of the National Unification Council (NUC) to work out an innovative strategy to break the lingering cross-strait impasse.

If necessary, Wu said, the PFP does not oppose a change of the NUC's name so that it can become a body acceptable to all major Taiwan political parties or forces for forging a national consensus on relations with mainland China.
The trio arrived in Washington, D.C. Monday to attend the AEI seminar which attracted the attendance of more than 100 scholars and experts on China and Taiwan affairs.

Su said one of the major reasons contributing to the KMT's stunning election defeat was that the party has consistently adopted a moderate approach toward nearly all important policy issues, including cross-strait ties and ethnicity problems.
As a result, Su said, the KMT's support base has been weakened in Taiwan's increasingly polarized society.
Worse still, Su said, the KMT committed some tactical errors, including fielding too many candidates and slow progress in intraparty reforms.

Su said the division between northern and southern parts of the island, among different ethnic groups and between pro-independence and pro-unification activists has become even more serious after the elections.

"I'm worried that mainland China would become more ssuspicious of Taiwan's true stance on cross-strait relations now that President Chen has strengthened his political mandate through the weekend polls," Su said.

He also criticized the DPP government's inaction and inability to thaw stalled cross-strait ties. Su said it was regrettable that President Chen missed an opportunity to improve relations with Beijing last summer. He didn't elaborate what the chance was.

In response, Hsiao said President Chen has adopted many "market opening" measures to improve cross-strait ties since his inauguration one and half years ago, including easing restrictions on mainland China-bound investments and opening doors to mainland journalists and tourists.
In her view, Hsiao said, the DPP government has been far more active than the previous KMT administration in breaking cross-strait stalemate.

DOC.HEADLINE: REMAINS OF FORMER AIR FORCE SURVEILLANCE CREW RETURNED TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The remains of 14 crew members of a surveillance aircraft that was shot down by mainland Chinese fighters in Jiangxi province nearly four decades ago were airlifted back to Taiwan Tuesday.

Surviving relatives of the crew of the former Republic of China Air Force's 34th Squadron, nicknamed the Black Bats Squadron, gathered at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport to receive the remains of the pilots, co-pilots and technical and information officers 38 years after the secret mishap.

The 14 air force crew, led by squadron leader Colonel Chou Yi-su, were aboard a P-2V, a U.S. long-range patrol aircraft, on a reconnaissance mission in mainland China's central province of Jiangxi when the aircraft was intercepted by mainland Chinese jet fighters and shot down on June 19, 1963. None of the crew members reportedly survived.

The whereabouts of the reconnaissance officers were discovered by locals soon after the mishap and their remains have been kept in Chiangxi under the instruction of the mainland Chinese authorities, although private talks about having the remains returned to Taiwan did not start until recent years after Taiwan opened people-to-people exchanges across the Taiwan Strait.

In a simple but solemn ceremony at the CKS Airport, Major General Liu Yi-tien, the ROC Air Force's top personnel officer, covered the remains, which were in two boxes, with the ROC national flag in a gesture of respects to the late air force officers.

The remains of the 14 officers and their name plates are scheduled to be incorporated into the ROC Air Force cemetery located in Hsintien, Taipei County Dec. 10 in a ceremony to be presided over by Air Force Commander-in-Chief Gen. Chen Chao-min.
At the airport were Hsiao Chia-chen, wife of the dead squadron leader. She has been instrumental over the past decade in arranging the downed squadron's return to Taiwan.

According to Hsiao, she and some family members of the squadron visited mainland China three times before the mainland Chinese authorities gave the green light to allow the remains to be taken back to Taiwan.
Now that the officers are home they will be able to rest in peace, Hsiao said.

Also at the airport was 39-year-old Huang Fei, daughter of co-pilot Major Huang Chi-hsin. Huang Fei, who works at a bank in Taipei, said although she had no memory of her father, as she was only 10 months old when the secret incident occurred, she has her father's picture and has always believed that he was always with her.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSMC MAY LEAD WORLD IN HI-END CHIP TECHNOLOGY IN 2002

TEXT.P: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp. (TSMC) may lead the world in the 0.1 micron technology in the fourth quarter of next year, an executive of a United States-based hi-tech firm said Tuesday.

N. K. Wang, vice executive officer of Applied Micron Inc., said TSMC would capture the world's leadership role if the company based in the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park in northern Taiwan could complete development of that technology by that time.

Delivering a keynote speech on the development of the semiconductor industry, Wang said the Asia-Pacific region has replaced North America as the world's largest semiconductor market in 2001. He predicted that the Asia-Pacific market will be able to seize a 46-percent stake of the global market in 2010, ahead of the U. S. market's 24 percent, Europe's 16 percent and Japan's 14 percent.
Wang, pointed out, however, that mainland China, which is included in the Asia-Pacific market, will take 13 percent of the international market at that time.

According to the Applied Materials executive, the market scale of the international semiconductor industry hit around US$209 billion in 2000, with North America contributing 31 percent. The Asia-Pacific market and the Japanese market generated 25 percent and 23 percent, respectively.

He also estimated that the Asia-Pacific market (excluding Japan) will absorb 28.4 percent of the world's overall production of eight-inch silicon wafer chips -- 9.41 million pieces -- next year, only behind Japan's 29.3 percent, while the region's production of hi-end chips will top the world.
In face of future challenges, Wang urged businesses to cooperate to reduce production costs.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN LOSING GROUND TO MAINLAND CHINA IN JAPANESE MARKET

TEXT.P: Taiwan-made products are increasingly being replaced by those from mainland China in the Japanese market in recent years, government statistics show.

According to tallies released recently by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA), Taiwan's export value to Japan in the first nine months of this year registered the largest fall of 15 percent among the four Asian Dragons year-on-year, while mainland China's export value to that country grew by 7.2 percent.

The MOEA attributed the decline to a global economic slump, which has also slashed demand for hi-tech products in the Japanese market. Taiwan is a major supplier of computers, machinery and optical equipment for Japan.
During the same nine-month period, Japan posted a 4 percent fall in imports, while its outbound shipments declined by 14 percent.

Among the four Asian Dragons, South Korea grabbed the largest market share of 5 percent in Japan, followed by Taiwan with 4.2 percent, Singapore with 1.6 percent and Hong Kong with 0.4 percent. Mainland China enjoys a 16 percent stake in the Japanese market.

Experts have warned that Taiwan will be gradually edged out by mainland China in the Japanese market if this trend continues. They urged Taiwan businesses to sharpen their competitiveness or to face a gloomy future.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORLD PEACE PRIZE A RECOGNITION OF PEOPLE OF TAIWAN: VICE PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said Tuesday it is a great honor for her to win the 2001 World Peace Prize awarded by the World Peace Corps Academy.
In her remarks of appreciation to the academy, Lu said that instead of claiming the prize as her personal achievement, it should be deemed as the "common achievement of the people of Taiwan."

A longtime democracy activist and feminist, Lu said that as a woman, she has gone through various kinds of suffering in her life. The outspoken vice president said she not only has to overcome the poverty, but also to triumph over gender discrimination and political dictatorship.

"It is encouraging for me to say that I have never played political tricks. I have never resorted to violence. I always touch the hearts of others and lead people with my ideals and ideas through peaceful and democratic procedures, even if it needs to sacrifice myself," Lu said in her written remarks of appreciation to the World Peace Corps Academy.
Lu went on to say that she is one of many Taiwanese who have "created the soft power of "human rights, democracy, peace, love and high technology" on the island.

"In contrast to the hard power of those countries committed to military and economic plunders, Taiwan's soft power miracle is a blessing for all mankind," Lu said, adding that Taiwan is always willing to cooperate and share its fruits with others, to eliminate hatred and pursue sustainable stability with love and peace.

Lester Wolff, the chief judge of the World Peace Prize Awarding Council, announced on the U.S. Capitol Hill Nov. 28 that the 2001 World Peace Prize will be given to Lu in recognition of her contribution to promoting Taiwan's democratization and world peace.
Wolff, a former member of the U.S. House of Representatives, said the award presentation ceremony will be held in Taipei Dec. 9.

Lu, who was once jailed for six years for her pro-democracy activities during Taiwan's martial law era, has continued to promote peace, love, democracy, human rights and high-tech development since she became the ROC's first female vice president in May 2000.
Lu is the first female winner of the World Peace Prize since the inauguration of the award in 1990.

The previous recipients of the prestigious prize included former U.S. President Ronald Reagan, Egyptian President Hosni Mubarrak, South Korea's first president, Syngman Rhee, and late Israeli Prime Minister Itzhak Rabin.
In 1989, U.S. Congressman Robert Leggett and Han Min Su, a South Korean religious leader, jointly created the World Peace Corps Mission, patterned after the U.S. Peace Corps.
Under the World Peace Corps framework, the World Peace Corps Academy and the World Peace Prize Awarding Council were established in 1990 to honor those who have contributed to the peace corps cause.

DOC.HEADLINE: KINMEN DEPUTY MAGISTRATE VISITING XIAMEN

TEXT.P: Kinmen Deputy Magistrate Yen Ta-jen went to Xiamen City opposite to the Taiwan-held frontline island aboard a passenger vessel Tuesday for a four-day visit, the first of its kind for a Republic of China official in more than 50 years.

The main purpose of Yen's visit is to talk with mainland Chinese officials on the establishment of a cross-strait commodities trading center in Kinmen to promote exchanges between both sides of the Taiwan Strait.
Boarding the passenger ship "Ta Yang No. 11," Yen set off from the Shuitou wharf, western Kinmen, at 9:20 a.m.

The ROC government implemented the so-called "mini three-links" -- direct trade, transportation and postal service -- between Kinmen and Xiamen as well as between another Taiwan-held frontline island of Matsu and Mawei in mainland Chinese Fujian province from Jan. 1, 2001.

Yen, accompanied by another Kinmen County government official, will call on Taiwan affairs offices in the cities of Xiamen, Quanzhou and Jinjiang and some local tourist bureaus as well as visit Kinmen citizens residing in Fujian province before returning home Friday.
Also aboard the vessel were 135 passengers who went to Xiamen for sightseeing and to visit relatives.

DOC.HEADLINE: WHEELING AND DEALING OVER PRESIDENCY OF LEGISLATURE UNDERWAY

TEXT.P: Wheeling and dealing over the presidency of the Legislative Yuan is underway between the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the incumbent head of the legislature and Kuomintang (KMT) member Wang Jin-pyng.

The DPP whip at the legislature, Tsai Huang-lang, said Tuesday that his party might support Wang's bid for reelection if the KMT vice chairman joins in President Chen Shui-bian's "National Stabilization Alliance," and the "Taiwan Advocates" think tank founded by former President Lee Teng-hui to support Chen's administration.

Speaking at the legislature, Tsai confirmed Wang's job performance and his freedom from partisan politics over the last three years, but said his refusal to join Chen's alliance and the Taiwan Advocates will cast doubt on his political detachment, and give credit to claims that he is more a president for his KMT party.
"We may support his reelection bid if Wang joins those two groups," Tsai said.

Touting the "National Stabilization Alliance" as a forum for political parties to work out their differences, Tsai said the opposition parties that have seen seats between them pared sharply in the just-concluded legislative elections should not resist public opinion by boycotting the alliance.
His remarks have drawn sharp criticism from lawmakers of the People First Party (PFP) which is a KMT breakaway and is wary of any political deal between the DPP and the KMT.
PFP legislator Chin Hui-chu said Tsai's offer was an unveiled attempt at horse-trading, and naked political bargaining.

Chin said there is no reason for President Chen to create a "National Stabilization Alliance" -- which is not provided for in the Constitution -- now that the DPP is already the largest party in the legislature with 87 out of 225 seats.

Another PFP legislator, Liu Wen-hsiung, said President Chen should come up with economic recovery programs instead of forcing the opposition to fall behind his alliance under the pretext of "improving national stabilization."
Wang, who announced his candidacy last Saturday, gave a cold shoulder to the DPP's offer Tuesday, although he could not win reelection without the support of the DPP.
He said he will follow his party's decision on whether to join President Chen's alliance. If the KMT agrees to take part in the movement, he automatically will be a member of the alliance, he said.
The KMT vice chairman disclosed that KMT Chairman Lien Chan is expected to call on President Chen to exchange views on post-elections issues.
Wang said Lien told him of his plan to call on Chen Sunday, but didn't say when the meeting would take place or what issues are on the agenda.
Meanwhile, DPP legislator Trong Chai, who is one of several DPP aspirants to the legislature presidency, continued his tour around the island Tuesday to marshal support for his bid.

He said he has called on more than 80 newly-elected lawmakers of various parties and was met with enthusiastic support from many of them for his attempt to become the first DPP president of the Legislative Yuan.
Some of them, including KMT legislator Hung Chao-nan, even expressed the intention to be his running mate for vice presidency of the legislature, Chai said.
He admitted, however, his personal desire is subject to the approval of party leaders, especially President Chen who might decide otherwise after taking into account the overall political situation.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CHAIRMAN DENIES FORMATION OF LEE-CHEN COOPERATION

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Frank Hsieh Tuesday denied speculation that some kind of cooperation between former President Lee Teng-hui and President Chen Shui-bian will direct the nation's political affairs.
"It would be impossible," Hsieh said.

Rumors have been circulating since the DPP and Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) had major victories in the legislative elections last Saturday that the two groups would join forces to map policy for the nation.
Observers also noted that President Chen met Lee when he attended the inaugural ceremony of "Taiwan Advocates," a private think tank founded by Lee, at the Ambassador Hotel in Taipei Monday night.
Hsieh pointed out that the TSU is a political party friendly to the DPP. Both parties uphold a common goal to maintain political stabilization.

In addition, Taiwan Advocates will help form the proposed "National Stabilization Aalliance" that President Chen has proposed before the elections. The DPP welcomes all political parties or groups to join the alliance to help stabilize the nation's political situation, Hsieh said.
If someone interpreted the Lee-Chen meeting as the formation of a kind of cooperation between them, that person was simply worrying too much, Hsieh said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2001 AUSTRONESIAN CULTURAL FESTIVAL TO KICK OFF IN TAITUNG
DOC.DATELINE: Taitung, Eastern Taiwan, Dec. 4 (CNA) (By Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: The 2001 Austronesian Cultural Festival, one of 12 local festivals subsidized by the Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, will be held in Taitung, eastern Taiwan, Dec. 5-9.
In addition to programs presented by Austronesian-speaking peoples from seven countries, local aboriginal groups will also present their original and colorful programs during the five-day festival.

An official of the Taitung County Government said that performance troupes from Yunan province in mainland China, Guam, Nepal, Hawaii, Thailand, Malaysia and the Philippines will take part in the event.
Aside from the performance, an international academic seminar will be held with four foreign and five local experts presenting their papers at the prehistory hall of the Puyuma Cultural Museum.
Other activities will include an Austronesian cultural photo show, a sculpture show and dancing.
Local aboriginal groups -- Atayal, Ami, Bunun, Tsou, Puyuma, Rukai, Paiwan, and Yami -- will also send their own dancing troupes to take part in the festival, the official added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN INAUGURATES 2001 ASIAN WOMEN'S FOOTBALL TOURNAMENT

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian declared Tuesday that next year will be the "year of football in Taiwan."
President Chen made the announcement while inaugurating the 2001 Asian Women's Football Championship tournament held at the Chungshan Football Stadium in downtown Taipei.
Chen said he was happy that Taiwan was sponsoring the event after successfully hosting the 34th World Cup Baseball tournament last month.

Chen said that football is the most popular sport in the world and the rolling of a football can roll along with inspiration. The games will smash the language barrier and races and religions will become as one, the president said.
Chen hoped that the Asian Women's Football tourney would prompt greater interest in football in Asia.

A total of 14 teams from India, Malaysia, South Korea, North Korea, Thailand, Guam, Singapore, Japan, Vietnam, mainland China, Hong Kong, Uzbekistan, the Philippines and host Chinese Taipei will take part in the competition.
The mainland Chinese team, which was scheduled to arrive in Taipei at 5:30 p.m. failed to make the opening ceremony.
This was the first time that the Chinese Taipei Football Association has sponsored the tourney which will close Dec. 16.

DOC.HEADLINE: IC NATIONAL HEALTH INSURANCE CARDS IN THE OFFING

TEXT.P: Electronic national health insurance cards, which are designed to replace the existing paper cards, are scheduled to be issued July 2002, the National Health Insurance Bureau (NHIB) said Tuesday.
Some 7 million IC health insurance cards will be issued initially in July for use by patients in the cities of Taipei, Taichung and Kaohsiung, and Penghu County, NHIB officials said.
It is expected that by May 2003, every citizen in Taiwan who is covered under the national health insurance program will have an IC health insurance card.
In a ceremony held Tuesday to debut the new IC cards, Department of Health Director-General Lee Ming-liang showed off his own IC health insurance card which carries his photo on one side.
Introducing the new cards at the ceremony, NHIB deputy director Chiang Hung-che said cardholders can decide for themselves whether to have their photos on the cards or not.

Chiang said the planned IC health insurance cards, which will be designed by the German company that designed the euro and produced by Taipei's TECO Electric and Machinery Co., can be used as identification cards and will be valid for five years.

The IC card can also be used as a donor's card and a portable file of a patient's medical records, Chiang said, adding that these innovations will save patients and their doctors much time in diagnoses and filling prescriptions.

IC health insurance cards should save the nation and patients money as well, Chiang said. Although the NHIB needs to invest some NT$4 billion (US$116 million) to have all the existing paper cards replaced, the investment is expected to be recouped soon, he said.
Chiang added that the NHIB spends about NT$100 million a year on paper card renewals since each card needs to be replaced when all six spaces on the back of the card have been stamped.

IC health insurance cards will also help save labor costs that are required in paper card renewals. With the new cards, medical resources should not be wasted because each IC card will carry a patient's past diagnoses and prescription records, and will help deter fraud through unauthorized use of cards, Chiang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S OUTBOUND INVESTMENTS IN 1ST 10 MONTHS UP 8.8%

TEXT.P: Taiwan's authorized outbound investments in the first 10 months of this year totaled US$5.98 billion, an increase of 8.8 percent from a year earlier, according to official statistics released Tuesday.

Of the total, US$2.33 billion-worth was indirect investment in mainland China, an increase of 15.6 percent year-on-year, while US$3.65 billion went to other places, up 4.9 percent from a year ago, the statistics of the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) showed.

Eighty percent of mainland-bound investments were concentrated in the provinces of Jiangsu and Guangdong, amounting to US$1.87 billion, of which, US$1.05 billion, or 45 percent, was in electronics and the electric appliance manufacturing sector, the DGBAS figures showed.

The majority of outbound investments outside mainland China -- US$1.25 billion -- was made in Central America. Most of this was in electronics and the electric appliance manufacturing sector, and the banking and insurance industries, the statistics showed.
Meanwhile, foreign investments in Taiwan in the first 10 months of this year stood at US$4.27 billion, a decrease of 29.5 percent from a year earlier, according to the figures.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT OFFICIALS TO RESIGN OVER DISMAL ELECTION RESULTS

TEXT.P: Members of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) started to take the fall for the disappointing results of elections last Saturday where the party lost its majority in the legislature, a party official said Tuesday.

KMT Chairman Lien Chan approved resignations tendered by four party officials to take responsibility for the KMT's poor showing. They are: Chao Shou-po, director-general of the KMT's Organization and Development Committee; Wang Chih-kang, director-general of the KMT's Cultural and Communications Committee; and Chan Chun-po, chairman of the Taipei City Chapter of the KMT; and Lee Yuan-chuan, chairman of the KMT's Kaohsiung Chapter.

According to unconfirmed sources, Chen Chien-chih, deputy executive of the KMT Policy Coordination Committee will fill the vacancy left by Chao Shou-po; Wu Ching-chi, KMT candidate for Tainan County, will take the post left by Wang Chih-kang; Ting Shou-chung, outgoing legislator, will fill the post left by Chan Chun-po while Ke San-chi, dean of the Public Affairs Faculty of National Taipei University, could take the post left by Lee Yuan-chuan.
Lien also approved the resignation tendered by Jason Hu, deputy secretary-general of the KMT, who was elected mayor of Taichung.
But Lien did not approve the resignation submitted by KMT Secretary-General Lin Fong-cheng.
The new line-up will be made public immediately after approval at the KMT Central Standing Committee's regular weekly meeting, the official said.

As for Jason Hu's replacement, a source said that the name of Lee Chih-chu, former chairman of the Youth Council under the Executive Yuan, and former Minister of Justice Yeh Chin-feng, who lost to Wong Chin-chu of the DPP in the just-concluded race for Changhua County magistrate, has been mentioned.

The KMT official also said that the KMT Central Committee has informed Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, speaker of the Taipei City Council Wu Pi-chu and speaker of the Kaohsiung City Council Huang Chi-chuan of the line-up changes.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP NOT TO MERGE WITH OTHER PARTIES, SAYS PFP CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong asserted Tuesday that the PFP, which performed well in last Saturday's elections to win 46 seats in the legislature, has no plan to merge with other parties.
He made the remarks while commenting on some proposals that the Kuomintang (KMT) and the PFP should cooperate or merge to form a majority in the 225-seat Legislative Yuan.

The KMT suffered a defeat in the elections, gaining only 68 seats in the legislature, while the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) achieving a victory to take 87 seats. The newly established Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), supported by former President Lee Teng-hui, collected 13 seats.

Soong told a news conference that results of the elections indicated that the identity of the PFP, which was formed by Soong after the March 18 presidential election last year, has been gradually recognized by the voters.
Nevertheless, he noted that his party is willing to cooperate and communicate with other parties if it will benefit the supervising task of the opposition.

The PFP chief, a former KMT secretary-general, said he will meet with KMT Chairman Lien Chan to exchange views on how to play a more constructive opposition role after communicating with newly elected legislators of his party.
Regarding the party's basic political stand, Soong said that the country's stabilization relies on a mild solution to the ethnic and cross-Taiwan Strait issues.
President Chen Shui-bian should respect the constitutional system and the "one-China" principle as stipulated in the Constitution, Soong pointed out.

He urged Chen and Lee to cease using emotional language that was used during the campaigning because "it would not be in the interests of the Taiwan people if the Taiwan issue must be resolved through military means."
Soong also said that his party plans to introduce a new rule to name the party chairman through direct elections by the party's members.
He said that PFP Vice Chairman Chang Chao-hsiung has been entrusted with the task of consolidating the opinions of the party in this regard.
On the election of the new president and vice president of the Legislative Yuan, Soong said that the party's stance will be announced after the political situation settles down a bit.
He added that former Legislative Yuan President Liu Sung-pan, a PFP legislator, will take charge of the party's mission to promote legislative reform.
At the same time, PFP Policy Center Director Chang Hsien-yao stressed that the PFP will stick to its middle-of-the-road role.

He said that the PFP will be happy to see a successful reform of the KMT and would not like to see it fragmented. But he also said that it is "absolutely impossible for the PFP to merge with the KMT."

DOC.HEADLINE: MAURITIUS BOY HAS A NEW FACE AFTER CRANIOFACIAL SURGERY

TEXT.P: The 16-year-old Chinese boy who traveled thousands of miles to Taiwan from Mauritius for an operation to correct a facial disfigurement was happy Tuesday that his dream is coming true.
Kevin Chan-kam, who suffers from Pfeiffer syndrome, was discharged from Chang Gung Memorial Hospital Tuesday with a new, full and beautiful face that he has coveted since he was six years old.
The boy was allowed to check out only after Chang Gung surgeons announced that the craniofacial surgery operation, performed Nov. 30, was successful and the young man was recovering normally.
Despite swelling, Chan-kam now can, for the first time in his life, have his upper jaw meet the lower jaw, with doctors estimating that he will be able to chew as any normal person does in one month.

Chan-kam's parents, both Chinese descendants of early Cantonese immigrants to Mauritius, who stayed with him round-the-clock over the past week, offered their sincerest gratitude to the Chang Gung medical team for their expertise and thanked God for the success of the operation.

To correct the boy's congenital craniofacial deformity, which featured severe mid-face retrusion and mandible protrusion, the surgeons pulled his upper jaw out 1.5 centimeters and pushed his lower jaw in an equal distance.
A rib was removed and used to fill in the gap created by pulling out the upper jaw, doctors said.
Doctors said that the scope of the adjustment required to rectify the young man's dental malocclusion was three times greater than normal craniofacial surgeries are called on to deliver.
His ability to chew, speak and even breathe will be markedly improved, doctors added.
For Chan-kam, this is more important than anything else now that his dream of eating a steak will soon be realized.
The boy underwent extensive cranial remodeling in South Africa when he was four months old to allow his brain to develop normally, with subsequent follow-up remodeling operations at ages 1 and 6.

Despite his physical inconvenience, Chan-kam is an excellent student who recently placed 49th among over 14,000 teens who took part in Mauritius' nationwide high school exams. He said he hopes to become an accountant.

The Chang Gung authority promised to foot all the medical bills for the costs of the boy's operation and follow-up treatments, while Taiwan's Noordhoff Craniofacial Foundation will sponsor his living expenses for the one-and-a-half months that he is expected to stay on the island.

DOC.HEADLINE: UNIVERSITIES FROM TAIWAN, MAINLAND CHINA INK COOPERATION MEMO
DOC.DATELINE: Chiayi, central Taiwan, Dec. 4 (CNA) (By Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: National Chung Cheng University in Chiayi County signed a memorandum Tuesday on academic cooperation with mainland China's Jiangxi Normal University.
Representatives from the two universities also attended a symposium to discuss the direction of future cooperation and exchanges between the two universities.
The results of concrete cooperation projects will become an important milestone of academic cooperation between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, a representative from Chung Cheng University said.

Jiangxi Normal University is famed in Jiangxi province for its liberal arts, music, fine arts and physical education. It is also focusing more emphasis on educational psychology and mass communications.
As National Chung Cheng University has no departments of music or fine arts at present, it plans to send teachers and researchers to study at Jiangxi Normal University.
When the time is ripe, Jiangxi Normal University will establish an institute for the study of teaching to cultivate professional personnel.
The cooperation memorandum was signed by National Chung Cheng University President Lo Jen-chuan and Jiangxi Normal University President Li Xianyu.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT'S ALLIANCE WILL NOT OVERRIDE CONSTITUTION: PREMIER

TEXT.P: The "national stabilization alliance" proposed by President Chen Shui-bian will not override the Constitution; on the contrary, it will operate under and give full respect to the Constitution, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Tuesday.

In a defense of the proposed alliance, advocated by President Chen in the run-up to last Saturday's elections for legislators, city mayors and country magistrates, Chang said the alliance will be devised to break the political stalemate caused by a legislature with no one-party majority.
The opposition has been cautious about the idea. They question the constitutionality of forming such an alliance, warning that it could be a political ploy to divide them.

Premier Chang said that the alliance is the president's response to public demands for a stable government which can concentrate on addressing problems such as national security, economic development and mainland China relations.

The results of the elections, which gave the president's Democratic Progressive Party an increase of 22 seats in the legislature, vindicate the president's political wisdom in realizing beforehand what the public wanted, Chang said.

Now that the elections are over, the premier said, political parties should correctly grasp the messages from it by burying the hatchet and joining hands to do the work the public demands, Chang said, adding that the way to do this would be to participate in the "national stabilization alliance."
Although the alliance is not based on the Constitution, whatever decision taken by it will be processed and implemented by the Legislative Yuan and Executive Yuan in due process, Chang said.
There is no question of giving the alliance powers above the Constitution, Chang explained, although the detailed structure of the alliance has yet to be worked out.
The premier said it is preferable to form the alliance out of various political parties, but he could not rule out the participation of individual political leaders.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DESTROYS MALAYSIA 14-0 AT 2001 ASIAN WOMEN FOOTBALL TOURNEY

TEXT.P: Host Chinese Taipei whitewashed Malaysia 14-0 at the 2001 Asian Women's Football Championship Tournament which opened Tuesday.
Japan also blanked Singapore 14-0 in the game played at Taipei City Stadium.
North Korea trounced Guam 19-0 in the game also played at Taipei City Stadium before the opening ceremony.
Uzbekistan will play the Philippines while mainland China will take on Hong Kong Wednesday to be held at the Taipei City Stadium.

A total of 14 teams from Guam, Singapore, North Korea, South Korea, Japan, mainland China, the Philippines, Uzbekistan, Hong Kong, Vietnam, Malaysia, Thailand and host Chinese Taipei are taking part in the 12-day competition.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CHARITY GROUPS WEIGHING MEDICAL AID TO AFGHANISTAN

TEXT.P: Several private Taiwan charitable groups are weighing the possibility of providing medical aid to Afghanistan refugees on a long-term basis after a fact-finding trip to that country.

Liu Chih-chuan, president of the Taiwan Root Medical Organization, which offers medical service to Taiwan aborigines, said Tuesday that his group might extend their services to refugees in Afghanistan.

Liu said he and a member of Taiwan's Compassionate Relief Tzu Chi Foundation visited Afghanistan late last month to get first hand information about what the Taiwan groups could do to help the refugees.

Liu said they entered Nimroze province in southeastern Afghanistan from Iran and visited a refugee camp in Makaki which is home to about 10,000 displaced Afghans. But there are only 1,500 tents at the site that can accommodate five people each. The rest have to sleep in shacks made of cloth or anything they can lay their hands on or live in caves, said Liu.

There are only a few supplies of water and electricity. There were also too few toilets and the poor sanitary in the camp and the frequent sandstorms in that area of Afghanistan led to the prevalence of eye disorders and other diseases.
Medical facilities, however, were scarce and there is a serious shortage of medical personnel and medicines. Most of the people living there have never seen a dentist all of their lives, Liu said.

Liu said he left Makaki on Nov. 21 when a snowstorm set in. Since the war in Afghanistan has lulled somewhat, Liu said his group is planning to provide long-term medical aid to that country as soon as next spring if possible.

DOC.HEADLINE: SCENTED CONDOMS WELCOMED BY TAIWAN PEOPLE

TEXT.P: A recent survey found that over 90 percent of respondents in Taiwan thought that condoms with pleasant aromas could set a better mood for love-making and intended to buy the scented condoms.

According to the survey conducted by Between, a local condom retailer, 95 percent of the pollees -- men and women aged between 15 and 40 in the greater Taipei area -- thought that scented condoms could heighten the excitement while making love and 90 percent of them were eager to have a try.
The top three favorite scents for Taiwan's condom users are fruits, flowers and candies, the survey found.
According to condom retailers, besides Chinese Valentine's Day and Western Valentine's Day, the holidays from Christmas through New Year's Day is another high season for Taiwan's condom sellers.
They said that the sales in the last few days had increased significantly from ordinary days, especially for those with added features.
The survey also found that the number of male over-the-counter condom buyers is still higher than that of female buyers. However, more and more women are becoming less shy about purchasing condoms.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Dec. 5, or the 21st day of the 10th month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1782: Martin Van Buren, the eighth president of the United States, is born.
1791: Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart, Austrian composer considered among the greatest and most prolific composers in history, dies in Vienna of kidney failure at the age of 35. He had written more than 600 works.
1792: George Washington is reelected president of the United States.
1904: The Russo-Japanese War breaks out, with Japanese troops occupying Height 203, the ideal position for capturing Lushun, west of the port city of Talien.
1906: Russian Adm. Niebogatov goes on trial on charges of surrendering ships to the Japanese.
1915: Chen Chi-mei, a follower of Dr. Sun Yat-sen, leads a revolt against Yuan Shih-kai by trying to seize the warship Chaoho. His attempt fails the following day.
1928: The Legislative Yuan of the Republic of China is formally established.
1933: The United States celebrates the end of 14 long years of prohibition when the government nullifies the 18th Amendment, which outlawed the production, transportation or sale of alcohol.
1945: Six U.S. Navy aircraft carrying 27 airmen go missing without a trace in the Atlantic Ocean near Bermuda.
1946: A strong earthquake hits southern Taiwan, killing 69 people and injuring 170.
1949: Li Tsung-jen, acting president of the Republic of China, leaves Hong Kong for the United States.
1950: North Korean and Communist Chinese troops recapture Pyongyang as United Nations forces are forced to withdraw southward.
1957: The Dachien to Lishan section of the Central Cross-Island Highway opens to traffic.
1957: The Indonesian government orders the expulsion of all Dutch nationals.
1968: The Taiwan Provincial Government launches a one-person-one-dollar movement to raise money for national sports development.
1972: The Chase Manhattan Bank of New York opens a branch office in Taipei.
1975: Campaign activities for the Dec. 20 legislative elections open with 61 candidates contesting 37 Taiwan area seats.
1976: Professional golfers Kuo Chi-hsiung and Hsu Sheng-san leave for Palm Springs, Calif., to take part in the 24th World Cup professional golf tournament.
1978: The Soviet Union signs a 20-year treaty of friendship with Afghanistan.
1984: Ninety-three miners are killed in an accident at the Haishanyikeng mining pit in Shanhsia township, Taipei County.
1984: The Central Standing Committee of the Kuomintang unanimously supports a bill to amend the Firearms Control Act, imposing heavy punishments on the unauthorized manufacture of deadly weapons, with a maximum sentence of death.
1985: The United States decides to pull out of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization.
1985: Four businessmen are sentenced to prison terms ranging from two-and-a-half years to 12 years by a military court under the Taiwan Garrison General Headquarters for conducting direct trade with the Communist Chinese.
1995: Javier Solana, the Spanish foreign minister, is appointed the secretary-general of NATO.
1999: Vice Economic Affairs Minister Chang Chang-pang leaves for Miami to attend the annual Miami Conference on the Caribbean and Latin America.
2000: A total of 105 young Indonesians begin to receive two years of professional training in Taiwan as part of the ROC's efforts to help its major Southeast Asian trading partner develop small- and medium-sized enterprises.
Motse's lesson of the day: "When the administration of the ruler answers to the desire of the subjects, it manifests an understanding of approvals and disapprovals of the people. When there is such an understanding, the good will be discovered and rewarded and the bad will be discovered and punished, and the country will surely attain order."

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING CAN'T AFFORD NOT TO TALK WITH ROC PRESIDENT: TECO CHIEF

TEXT.P: The results of Saturday's legislative elections in Taiwan have given President Chen Shui-bian a stronger position in terms of implementing political and economic reforms, Taiwan's top representative in Canada said Tuesday.

Thomas T.P. Chen told an audience at the Ottawa Chapter of the Society for International Development that mainland China's leadership, which has consistently refused to talk with the Chen administration, "cannot afford not to negotiate with him" now that his Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has become the largest party in the Legislative Yuan.

Chen, who heads the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office, Canada, predicted that the DPP, which won 87 seats in the 225-seat Legislative Yuan, will be joined by the 13 newly elected Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) lawmakers as well as by 20 other independents or legislators from among the opposition parties.

"When you divide a watermelon into several slices, people swarm to the biggest slice," he said, using a Taiwanese expression to describe the phenomenon of independent and opposition lawmakers defecting to the ruling camp.

The president has termed the proposed legislative coalition "the National Stabilization Alliance," without which his administrative agenda will be blocked as it had been during the first half of his term when the DPP held only one-third of the seats in the Legislature.

The Kuomintang (KMT), which has dominated the Republic of China's Legislative Yuan for the past five decades, saw its share of legislative seats shrink to 68. The People First Party (PFP), led by former Taiwan Gov. James Soong, won 46 seats, with the remaining legislative seats going to independents or other minor parties.

Thomas Chen observed that the New Party (NP), which has advocated Beijing's "one country, two systems" arrangement for Taiwan, was almost annihilated, being reduced to a single seat in the Legislature.

Several academics and diplomats in the audience at the gathering said that Beijing certainly will not be happy with the election results, but it will have to live with the choice made by the people of Taiwan.

Some of them expressed concern that economic integration between Taiwan and mainland China may reduce Taiwan's leverage in seeking a resolution to the on-going dispute over the issue of sovereignty. For example, mainland China has made it clear that it will not talk trade issues with Taiwan in the World Trade Organization (WTO).

Chen pointed out that such strategies "cut both ways" -- by not talking with the democratically elected government of Taiwan, Beijing risks encouraging Taiwan investors to look elsewhere for business opportunities. He added that the ROC government can back them up with its huge foreign exchange reserves.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES UP BY 158.13 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) gained ground on Wednesday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving up 158.13 points to close at 4,924.56.
Market turnover amounted to NT$174.59 billion (US$5.07 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING REJECTS CROSS-STRAIT `DIRECT LINKS' TALKS UNDER WTO FRAMEWORK

TEXT.P: Beijing authorities on Wednesday sternly rejected Taiwan's proposal that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait could commence dialogue on the "three direct links" issue under the framework of the World Trade Organization (WTO).

The spokesman for Beijing's Central Office for Taiwan Affairs, Zhang Mingqing, ruled out during a routine press conference in Beijing the possibility of the two sides engaging in talks under the WTO framework on opening direct cross-strait trade, postal and transportation links.
Zhang said that both mainland China and Taiwan are becoming full members of the WTO and that both sides should observe closely the regulations and spirit of the WTO.
He noted however that the issue of the so-called "three direct links" is an "internal matter" which should be discussed under the "one China" principle.
If necessary, he added, the two sides can talk about direct links in a private manner, such as via discussions between companies or private parties from across the strait.

Commenting on Taiwan's just-concluded elections for legislators and local government chiefs, Zhang said a victory for the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) in the elections would not change Beijing's policies toward the island.

Zhang said that through the elections, Beijing has perceived that the mainstream private opinion in Taiwan is against independence and strongly for peace, stability and the positive development of cross-strait relations.

Noting that Beijing will closely monitor Taiwan's cross-strait policies, Zhang said Beijing strongly expects that the Taiwan authorities will recognize the "one China" policy and return to the "92 consensus" which he said would be conducive to the constructive development of cross-strait relations.

In response to Zhang's remarks, Yen Chien-fa, director of the ruling DPP's China Affairs Office, said that mainland Chinese authorities acted cautiously regarding the Dec. 1 elections, being careful not to get involved, but that they were startled by the election results.
Reacting to the "unexpected" election results, Beijing chose first to "steady its steps" and then to reiterate the "one China" principle, Yen continued.
He said he doesn't expect there will be any breakthrough in the development of cross-strait relations after the elections, but he added that he doesn't expect relations to regress either.

Discounting Zhang's remark that it is impossible for the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to talk about the "three direct links" issue under the WTO framework, Yen said that it is possible and feasible that the two sides talk about direct trade exchanges under the regulations and spirit of the WTO.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN VOTERS DON'T BUY `ONE CHINA, TWO SYSTEMS' SCHEME SAYS PREMIER

TEXT.P: Most Taiwan voters have said clearly via their ballots this past weekend that they do not buy the so-called "one China, two systems" overture by mainland China, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Wednesday.

Chang called for Beijing to perceive and take account of the "real mainstream private opinion" in Taiwan that has been clearly reflected in the recently concluded elections, pointing out that a majority of the Taiwan public refuses to accept Beijing's "one China, two systems" scheme that was imposed on the former British colony of Hong Kong.

The premier reiterated that Taiwan's basic policies toward mainland China will remain unchanged and that the nation will continue to work toward improving cross-strait relations based on the principles of "goodwill reconciliation, active cooperation and long-lasting peace" that President Chen Shui-bian spelled out in his inaugural speech last year.

Chang added that all "opening" policies toward mainland China, substantiating the conclusions reached by consensus during the Economic Development Advisory Conference held in August, will be carried out in accordance with a set timetable.

He also urged the authorities in Beijing to grasp the opportunity for reconciliation between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait and resume institutionalized cross-strait dialogue as well as useful interactions.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Shares prices opened high and closed even higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 158.13 points to close at 4,924.56.

Encouraged by a surge in U.S. stock prices, the bourse opened at 4,892.31 and continued to go up due to the good performance of both financial stocks and electronics shares. The index fluctuated between 4,968.64 and 4,854.24 during trading.

A total of 5.87 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$119.93 billion (US$3.48 billion), an increase from the previous trading session which saw 4.22 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$119.93 billion (US$3.48 billion).

All of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with electrical stocks moving up the most at 4.1 percent, followed by pulp and paper issues at 2.3 percent, bank and insurance shares and cement stocks, both at 2.1 percent, foodstuff shares and plastics and chemical stocks, both at 1.9 percent, textile issues at 1.8 percent, and construction stocks at 0.9 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 387 to 170, with 87 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market were higher on Wednesday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for December moved up 169 points to close at 4,910, with 23,573 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for next January gained 170 points to close at 4,900, with 106 contract transactions, while next March futures increased 130 points to finish at 4,860, with 6 contracts traded.
Next June futures surged 298 points to close at 4,940, with 55 contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC REITERATES PRINCIPLES FOR RESUMING DIALOGUE WITH MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) reiterated Wednesday Taiwan's willingness to resume dialogue with Beijing based on the principles of "sovereignty and equality" as soon as possible.
Officials from the Cabinet-level MAC said Taiwan's policies toward mainland China would not be changed by the results of the Dec. 1 elections.

Dismissing remarks made earlier in the day by Zhang Mingqing, a spokesman for Beijing's Central Office for Taiwan Affairs, who said the percentage of Taiwan people supporting the "one China, two systems" formula is on the rise, the MAC officials said the mainland Chinese authorities' perception and understanding of the people of Taiwan are apparently far from reality.

The officials said that in fact, a poll conducted after the leadership summit of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum held in Shanghai in mid-October has found that Taiwan popular support for Beijing's "one China, two systems" model for communist rule over the island has dropped compared with the results of a similar poll conducted in July.

In a routine press conference, Zhang also stressed that it is imperative that Taiwan should recognize the "one China" policy, and added that Beijing's perception of the election results is that the mainstream public opinion in Taiwan is against independence and strongly for peace, stability and the positive development of cross-strait relations.

The MAC officials said that with the passing of the elections, many uncertainties surrounding cross-strait relations have also become history and reiterated that the Republic of China is willing to return to the negotiating table with mainland authorities for talks based on the principles of sovereignty and equality.
