DOC.HEADLINE: HIV-POSITIVE COUPLE APPEAL FOR ENTRY TO ROC

TEXT.P: A married couple, both of whom are HIV-positive and one of whom is foreign, appealed for help Wednesday from Taiwan's lawmakers to allow them to be reunited after four years apart as a result of the husband's medical condition.

The wife, who is a Taiwanese surnamed Lin, appealed for help from opposition People First Party Legislator Chin Hui-chu and Kuomintang Legislator Chin Tseng Chen-li on behalf of herself and her Malaysian husband, who was barred from entering Taiwan, in the hope that the Republic of China government will allow her husband to enter based on humanitarian considerations.
Lin said during a press conference at the Legislative Yuan that she and her husband only found out they had the virus after they got married four years ago.

She said that although the Legislative Yuan passed am AIDS-related law permitting foreign nationals to file for re-examination of their rejected entry applications, her applications for her husband's entry have repeatedly been rejected.

In response to Lin's appeal, Legislator Chin urged the government to review Lin's case favorably as AIDS cases have risen noticeably in Taiwan in recent years and the government must face the problem by devising feasible regulations and policies to help halt the spread of AIDS-related problems and to take care of those already infected with HIV.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S ECONOMY TO BOTTOM OUT EARLIER THAN EXPECTED: CEPD OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: An official of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said Wednesday that the conditions needed for Taiwan's economic recovery have emerged and that Taiwan's economy will bottom out sooner than has been predicted.

According to CEPD Secretary-General Thomas Yeh, the 483.44-point su0rge in stock prices since the Dec. 1 elections -- an increase of more than 10 percent -- shows the public confidence in the election results and that all conditions for moving toward prosperity have emerged.
Yeh said that cross-party cooperation after the election will allow more room for the government to maneuver, which he said will have a positive effect on Taiwan's political and economic development.

Foreign institutional investors are also confident of Taiwan's economic recovery and are continuing to pump capital into the stock market, Yeh went on, adding that the economy in the United States is also expected to bottom out in the second quarter of next year.

Meanwhile, the Directorate-General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) said Wednesday that the wholesale price index dropped 4.68 percent in November, the ninth consecutive monthly drop and the largest since August 1999.
As wholesale prices will affect consumer prices between two and seven months, the drop shows that consumer prices will continue to slump over the next few months, Yeh continued.
DGBAS officials said that the consumer price index dropped 1.13 percent in November, the biggest drop since Nov. 1987.

The officials said that in the first 11 months of the year, consumer prices increased by 0.15 percent and estimated that consumer price index growth will be 0.11 percent this year, or the smallest increase since 1986.
The wholesale price index in the first 11 months of this year dropped 0.93 percent and the officials predicted that the wholesale price index will drop 1.05 percent this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT UNDERGOES PARTIAL RESHUFFLE

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Wednesday carried out a partial change of its line-up in the wake of its Dec. 1 election defeat.
The KMT Central Standing Committee approved the changes at its weekly regular meeting.

Chen Chien-chih, deputy executive of the KMT's policy-making committee, took the chair of the party's Organization and Development Committee left vacant by Chao Shou-po, who tendered his resignation to take responsibility for the KMT's poor performance.
Chen, 57, obtained a masters degree from Missouri State University and has served as speaker of the Taipei City Council and as KMT legislator-at-large.

Wu Ching-chi, who ran for the post of Tainan county chief and lost to ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) candidate Su Huan-chih, became head of the party's Culture and Communications Committee, replacing Wang Chih-kang, who also tendered his resignation.

Wu, 50, obtained a doctorate from National Taiwan Normal University and pursued post-doctoral studies at Missouri University and London University. He is a visiting professor at Harvard University. He has served as vice education minister and as a division director of the Executive Yuan.
Outgoing Legislator Ting Shou-chung, who lost his re-election bid, took the post of chairman of the KMT's Taipei City chapter, replacing Chan Tsun-po, who also resigned.
Ting, 47, obtained a doctorate in international political science from the Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy in the United States.

In Kaohsiung, the party had originally appointed Ke San-chi, dean of the Public Affairs Faculty of National Taipei University, to replace Lee Yuan-chuan -- who also resigned -- as Kaohsiung Chapter chairman. However, Ke's appointment came under strong opposition from the chapter members, forcing the KMT Central Committee to seek an alternative candidate.

Outgoing Legislator Lee Cheng-tsung took over as director of the party's social welfare department, outgoing Legislator Pan Wei-kang was named head of the women's affairs department and Chang Chuang-hsi took over the youth affairs department.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLITICAL PARTIES CALL FOR REFORM OF ELECTORAL SYSTEMS

TEXT.P: The Dec. 1 elections of legislators, city mayors and county magistrates have resulted in considerable changes in Taiwan's political landscape and the island's political parties are calling for an urgent reform of the electoral systems.

Both the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) advocate moving from the existing single non-transferable vote system to a single-member constituency, two-vote system.

Under the Public Officials Election and Recall Law, several legislators are elected from a single constituency, which is demarcated essentially according to administrative boundaries. Each voter can cast one vote for a candidate of his or her preference.

Both Minister of the Interior Chang Po-ya and Chairman Huang Shih-cheng of the Central Election Commission have agreed that Taiwan should adopt the single-member constituency system and that each voter should be entitled to cast two votes -- one for a district candidate and one for a political party.

The existing system, by allowing more candidates to represent one party, may encourage factionalism, as candidates of the same party are constantly at odds with one another. In-party disputes were common during the legislative election campaign.

Some local political observers have noted that quite a few candidates with high prestige in the party failed in the Dec. 1 election because of what they describe as improper functioning of the party nomination system and flaws in the electoral mechanism.

The single-member constituency, two-vote system would help reinforce internal cohesion and party discipline, which would be beneficial to negotiations and cooperation between political parties, according to the observers.

Since both the ruling and opposition parties agree over the advantages of the single-member constituency, two-vote system, the new legislature may be able to initiate efforts to revise the Public Officials Election and Recall Law regarding the electoral systems before the next election.

As the both ruling party and the largest party in the Legislative Yuan, the DPP is expected to play an important role in accomplishing this reform work. Even before the DPP gained the upper hand in the Legislative Yuan, DPP Secretary-general Wu Nai-jen had stressed his party's hopes of accomplishing the reforms in the next legislature.

Political observers have pointed out that changing from the existing multiple-member constituencies to single-member constituencies is a big project that will not be easy, especially when it is complicated by conflicts of interest.

Since the reform would involve an amendment to the Constitution, the revised law must be approved by three-quarters of the legislature and passed by the National Assembly, making consensus among legislators vital.

An official of the Interior Ministry has pointed out the difficulty in achieving such consensus, noting that the Ministry of the Interior submitted drafts of revised election laws to the Legislative Yuan in 1997 and again in 2000, but they were not even screened by the legislators.

The official said that the draft revisions were in relation to a much-criticized flaw in the existing laws regarding the publication of opinion poll results and the draft revisions stipulated that no publication of opinion polls regarding candidates or election predictions would be allowed within five days of an election.

Several candidates who were reported by the media to have the highest scores in pre-election opinion polls failed in the Dec. 1 elections and some frustrated candidates blamed their failure on misleading opinion poll results that were manipulated by their rivals.

New Party Legislator Lai Shyh-bao, for instance, was named as one of the most dedicated and knowledgeable legislators by the prestigious CommonWealth Magazine in its November issue and was constantly at top of pre-election opinion polls. However, the legislator failed in his re-election bid because, he claimed, many of his supporters believed he had votes to spare.
Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Tuesday that the Cabinet has drafted a new revised law on the issue and that he is looking forward to early legislative approval of the revised law.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOBACCO, WINE PRICE HIKE TO CAUSE MAXIMUM RISE OF 0.84% IN TAIWAN CPI

TEXT.P: Tobacco and wine prices rises after Taiwan enters the World Trade Organization early next year will cause the consumer price index (CPI) to grow by 0.74-0.84 percentage points, an official of the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) said Wednesday.

Ku Ping-chen, deputy director of the third bureau of the DGBAS, said that domestic cigarette prices will rise by an average NT$5-NT$8 per pack, which will result in a CPI increase of 0.17-0.27 percentage points, while the increase in local alcohol prices will result in CPI growth of 0.57 percentage points.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT WILL NOT JOIN COALITION GOVERNMENT: KMT CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan said Wednesday that the KMT will not join the "national stabilization alliance" or the coalition government proposed by President Chen Shui-bian.
He made the remarks while speaking at the party's Central Standing Committee meeting in the wake of the party's resounding defeat in the Dec. 1 legislative elections.
Lien said that the KMT unchanged stance is to protect and uphold the Constitution.

The KMT lost all but 68 of its pre-election 115 seats in the 225-seat Legislative Yuan, while the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) gained 87 seats to replace the KMT as the largest party in the legislature.

Lien said that the DPP and the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), which is supported by former President Lee Teng-hui, now control between them 100 seats in the Legislative Yuan and added that they can form a coalition government in line with the constitutional system.
He also said there is "no need" to establish a "national stabilization alliance," which he described as beyond the constitutional system.
The KMT chief said that his party will perform its duty as a responsible opposition to supervise the administration of the government.
If the government's policies, bills and budget are in line with the interests and welfare of the people, he said that the KMT will support them.
On the other hand, he went on, the KMT will oppose policies it believes are erroneous, such as the decision to halt the construction of the island's fourth nuclear power plant.

Regarding cooperation between the opposition parties, Lien said that the KMT is willing to cooperate with the People First Party (PFP) and other opposition parties on the formulation of policies and laws. The PFP collected 46 seats in the legislature in the elections.

DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Dec. 6, or the 22nd day of the 10th month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1774: Austria becomes the first nation to establish a state education system.
1889: Jefferson Davis, the first and only president of the Confederate States of America, dies at the age of 81. He was captured by Union soldiers in 1865 and imprisoned for two years. Although indicted for treason, he was never prosecuted.
1907: One of the worst coal mine disasters in U.S. history occurs at Mononagh, West Virginia, killing 361 people.
1911: Mongolia is declared a Russian protectorate.
1917: The Republic of Finland is proclaimed.
1917: The steamship Mont Blanc collides with the steamship Imo in Halifax, Canada, killing more than 1,500 people, injuring 8,000 others, and destroying a large part of the city.
1921: Britain signs a peace treaty with Ireland under which the Irish Free States is established and Ireland accepts Dominion status.
1941: U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt appeals to Japan's Emperor Hirohito for peace.
1943: The United States, Britain and the Soviet Union issue the Joint Declaration of the Tehran Conference.
1957: The United States fails in the launching of its first satellite.
1960: Taiwan Province implements the use of media broadcasts for the first time in the history of Republic of China military service in order to muster the required number of reservists.
1971: India recognizes the Democratic Republic of Bangladesh.
1973: The United Nations decides to establish the United Nations University in Tokyo.
1975: U.S. President Gerald Ford arrives in the Philippines for talks on new terms for U.S. air and naval basses in the country.
1975: President Yen Chia-kan receives Mrs. Paul Norman Brown, national president of the American Legion Ladies' Auxiliary, at the Presidential Office.
1979: The Communist Chinese ban the sticking of "big character posters" on Beijing's wall of democracy.
1980: The 1980 Supplementary Parliamentarian election sends 70 members to the Legislative Yuan and 76 to the National Assembly.
1986: Eighty-four members are newly elected to the Legislative Yuan and seventy-three members are newly elected to the National Assembly in the 1986 legislative by-elections. Voter turnout is 65.4 percent of the 11.8 million eligible registered voters.
1988: The ROC Legislative Yuan is paralyzed by fist-fighting, as the chairman for the first time asks police to maintain order.
1989: The worst mass killing in Canadian history takes place when a gunman shoots 13 female students to death at the University of Montreal before killing himself.
1990: President Saddam Hussein announces that all 3,400 foreign hostages held in Iraq since the invasion of Kuwait are now free to leave.
1990: Gen. Hussain Mohammed Ershad steps down at the height of a pro-democracy movement in Bangladesh.
1996: The Legislative Yuan revises the Labor Standards Law so that employees in nearly all industries will be covered by the end of 1998.
1999: The ROC-Japan Economic Conference opens in Tokyo.
2000: The Republic of China's Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs removes restrictions on workers from the Philippines, with the change effective retroactively to Dec. 1.
2000: Salvadoran President Francisco Guillermo Flores Perez arrives in Taipei for an official visit.
Motse's lesson of the day: "When the administration of the ruler does not answer to the desires of the subjects, it shows a lack of understanding of the approvals and disapprovals of the subjects. When there is no such understanding, then the good will not be discovered and rewarded and the bad will not be punished."

DOC.HEADLINE: YOUTHS FROM CENTRAL AMERICAN ALLIES TO RECEIVE TRAINING IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A total of 52 youths from four Central American countries that are diplomatic allies of the Republic of China took part in a ceremony in Taipei Thursday to mark the beginning of a one-year training program in Taiwan.

Hsieh Fa-dah, secretary-general of the Ministry of Economic Affairs, presided over the ceremony. Nine domestic manufacturers who are responsible for the training program as well as ambassadors from Central American countries were also on hand.
The MOEA solicited the nine manufacturers, including those from the machinery, food and garment sectors, who in turn traveled to El Salvador, Guatemala, Nicaragua and Honduras to pick the 52 youths.
MOEA officials said that among the 52 trainees selected, more than 80 percent are college graduates.
The officials added that the trainees will have one month's worth of orientation courses starting Thursday before they receive 11 months of on-the-job training.

The trainees are expected to complete their training in Taiwan by the end of November 2002. After their return to their own countries, they are expected to start up their own small- or medium-sized businesses, which formed the backbone of Taiwan's rapid economic development, or serve as the executives of Taiwan businesses in Latin America.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PREMIER DEFENDS STANCE ON RECONCILIATION

TEXT.P: Kuomintang (KMT) Vice Chairman Vincent Siew defended on Thursday his proposition the previous day that the opposition KMT help the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP)-led government in revitalizing Taiwan's economy.

Dismissing insinuations that some KMT heavyweights are "defecting" to the ruling DPP just to gain a few positions in the government, Siew, formerly premier, said that "it's not my style and it's against my principles as a decent human being" to suggest cooperation and reconciliation for the sake of personal gain.
Speaking at the KMT's Central Standing Committee meeting Wednesday, Siew said the KMT should help the DPP government get the nation's economy back on track.
He said the KMT shouldn't be antagonistic in handling its relations with other parties, adding that the KMT should also not be misled by rumors that some party members plan to defect to the DPP.

Siew's remarks during the KMT meeting challenged the KMT's decision made after the Dec. 1 elections not to align with the DPP in the Legislature, and led Wu Poh-hsiung, another KMT vice chairman, to take issue with Siew's comments.

Noting that the KMT should play its role as an "honest" and "loyal" opposition party, Wu said "we must not fall into a trap set by people with the intention of splitting the KMT just to gain a few positions in the government."
According to some reports, Siew is among the candidates favored by the DPP to assume the position of premier when the new Legislature convenes in February.

Clarifying his stance, Siew said he only suggested the previous day that the KMT take the initiative in cooperating with the administration simply for the sake of saving Taiwan's economy from being aggravated further.

He added that KMT Chairman Lien Chan noted later in Wednesday's meeting that it is the responsibility of all the parties concerned to work together to seek solutions to the people's plight and find ways to rev up the economy, which he said is exactly in line with what he has suggested.

Siew stressed that as a veteran economics official who has received governmental training and experience over a long period of time, he made the remarks Wednesday for the sake of the economy, the country and the people's well-being but not for the sake of anything else.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Shares prices opened high and closed even higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 284.3 points to close at 5,208.86.

Encouraged by a surge in share prices on the U.S. and European stock markets, the bourse opened at 5,097.57 and continued to go up due to the good performance of both financial stocks and electronics shares. The index fluctuated between 5,214.77 and 5,084.14 during trading.

A total of 5.98 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$174.07 billion (US$5.05 billion), compared with the previous trading session which saw 5.87 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$174.59 billion (US$5.07 billion).

All of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with bank and insurance shares moving up the most at 6.6 percent, followed by cement stocks at 6.1 percent, plastics and chemical stocks and foodstuff shares, both at 5.9 percent, textile issues and electrical shares, both at 5.7 percent, pulp and paper issues at 5.6 percent, and construction stocks at 4.5 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 616 to 15, with 22 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT AND PFP DECIDE NOT TO TAKE PART IN CHEN'S PROPOSED ALLIANCE

TEXT.P: Taiwan's two largest opposition parties decided Thursday not to participate in the "national stabilization alliance" that has been proposed by President Chen Shui-bian.

Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan and People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong met for the first time after the Dec. 1 elections Thursday and reached a four-point consensus on the state of the nation in the post-election era.

After a closed-door meeting of several hours, Lien and Soong jointly announced at a press conference that the KMT and the PFP will not participate in the Chen-proposed "national stabilization alliance" nor any other similar, informal grouping that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) is working to devise.

Soong said the KMT and the PFP are determined to allow the ruling DPP, which in the wake of the Dec. 1 elections will be the party with the most seats in the new Legislature, to fully take up the responsibility of administration as a ruling party.

Lien and Soong also came to an agreement that the KMT and the PFP, now holding 68 seats and 46 seats, respectively, in the 225-seat Legislative Yuan, jointly form a "policy coordination mechanism," to be named later, to play the role of a "rational and professional" check on the administration.
Meanwhile, the two party leaders also made it clear that they do not support the idea of KMT or PFP party members taking up prominent posts in the Chen Cabinet.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOV'T NEEDS TO SET UP EMIGRATION AGENCY: O'SEAS CHINESE COMMISSION

TEXT.P: The government needs to set up an emigration agency as soon as possible to provide needed information and services to emigrants from Taiwan, the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission (OCAC) said Thursday.
Wu Hsin-hsing, OCAC vice minister, made the remarks during a two-day symposium in Taipei on issues and challenges surrounding the emigration of Taiwan people.

He said that Taiwan people often do not make enough preparations before they emigrate and as a result have insufficient knowledge of the countries they are moving to, which in turn often leads to regrettable circumstances.

Noting that the government has no comprehensive emigration policy and that related regulations are lacking, he suggested that the government step up the pace in formulating policy so as to provide the people of Taiwan with comprehensive information and services. He added that one of the substantial measures that needs to be implemented is the establishment of an emigration agency.

Meanwhile, Professor Wu Ying-ming of National Sun Yat-sen University, also speaking at the symposium, said that many Taiwan people who have emigrated in the past have not actively participated nor contributed to the new communities within which they live. As a result, their influence in their adopted communities has been limited.

With the trend of globalization, Wu suggested that overseas Chinese and Taiwan business people build up new concepts, develop their abilities to influence others, and actively participate in activities in their new communities.

He said that emigrants from Taiwan need to change from their past methods of providing charity and assistance and turn toward more actively participating in the activities in the communities where they reside.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW KMT PUBLICITY CHIEF VOWS TO PROMOTE 'LOCALIZATION'

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) will promote "localization" in the wake of its stunning defeat in the just-concluded legislative elections, the party's new publicity chief said Thursday.
Wu Ching-chi, new director of the KMT's Culture and Communications Committee, made the pledge after being sworn into his new post at a ceremony presided over by KMT Secretary-General Lin Fong-cheng.
Noting that the 107-year-old KMT must reinvent itself to win voter support, Wu said the party will recruit new blood, introduce innovative thinking and promote "localization."
Wu explained that the KMT's "localization" drive should not be interpreted as a move to advocate Taiwan independence.
"Our localization aims to boost Taiwan's sustainable development," Wu said, adding that the KMT's localization will be characterized as "rational, ethnic harmony, non-agitation and non-independence."

Wu said the latest electoral setback augurs that the KMT must step up efforts to woo young voters. "The KMT must present policy initiatives and offer new hopes to win the hearts and minds of young adults."
Following its defeat in last year's presidential election, the KMT further lost its 52-year grip on legislative majority after the Dec. 1 polls.
"Now, we are neither a ruling party nor the largest party in the Legislative Yuan. We are an opposition party and should fulfill our duty of supervising government operations," Wu said.
As the party's new publicity chief, Wu said he will give priority to changing the KMT's stereotyped image.
"We must project a new image as an opposition party and should let the general public understand the KMT's new role in the island's post-election political arena," Wu said.
In addition, Wu said his committee will invite elite members from the academic community to offer counseling in drawing up a reform plan for the party's publicity work.

In preparation for the elections of township and village chiefs and assembly members early next year, Wu said his committee will work out new campaign strategies for KMT candidates in the near future.

Wu, who ran for the post of Tainan County chief and lost to ruling Democratic Progressive Party candidate Su Huan-chih, succeeded Wang Chih-kang as the KMT's new publicity chief and spokesman. Wang resigned to take the blame for the party's poor showing in the legislative elections in which the party garnered only 68 seats, down from 110 in the current legislature.

Wu, 50, obtained a doctorate from National Taiwan Normal University and pursued post-doctoral studies at Missouri University and London University. He is a visiting professor at Harvard University. He has served as vice education minister and as a division director of the Executive Yuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADIAN PRESS AGENCY TO CARRY CHINESE FINANCIAL DATA WORLDWIDE

TEXT.P: Full Chinese financial data could soon be available worldwide thanks to a Web-based press agency created by Quebecers, a French-language newspaper has reported.

The Quebec City daily Le Soleil quoted Raymond Boisvert, chief executive officer of China Xin Network, as saying in a report last weekend that his company wants to become a provider of financial information and strategic business intelligence for the world market.
The China Xin Network has recently been listed on the American Bulletin Board under the letters "FFAX," which will soon be changed to "CXNC."

"We're currently tying up a US$3-million financial package that will enable us to get off to a good start," he told the daily, adding that "our longer term objective is to be listed on the NASDAQ electronic exchange."

A few months ago, the company launched a joint venture with the China Economic Information Network. According to Boisvert, the latter organization has a network of 12,000 employees in various cities and regions who gather all the financial information needed by the mainland Chinese government.
"We gave them 35 percent of our company in exchange for the exclusive use of their information for foreign markets," he added.

The China Xin Network initially intended to focus on this exclusive data, which ranges all the way from unemployment figures to portraits of different sectors such as household appliances. The company president, however, has already raised his sights.

Boisvert said that his firm "just signed an agreement with Hong Yuan Securities, the third or fourth biggest brokerage firm in China. In exchange for revenue-sharing, they've guaranteed us the exclusive use of research reports on Chinese companies in the sectors they're involved in."
The financial press agency, which will post its dispatches in English, should be up and running by early next year, with about 200 news items a day, according to Boisvert.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC TOP ECONOMIC PLANNER PREDICTS 2.23% GROWTH FOR TAIWAN IN 2002
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angles, Dec. 6 (CNA) (By Chu Lu-sheng and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's unemployment will be kept below 5 percent in 2002 and the exchange rate of the New Taiwan dollar will not break NT$35 to the U.S. dollar, Taiwan's top economic planner said Wednesday.
Chen Po-chih, chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), made the remarks in a speech at a University of California-Los Angles Anderson Forecast meeting.

Chen said that although the economic performance of Taiwan has not been too good this year, there should be a 2.23 percent growth next year, which will be higher than the average global growth of 1.17 percent.

Predicting the island's economic future, he said that several industries, specifically the traditional agriculture industry, will unavoidably suffer from the impact of opening of markets after Taiwan's entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO) next year.

The ROC government is now actively helping the transformation of the agriculture sector, Chen said, adding: "Taiwan has excellent expertise in agriculture and the CEPD will encourage this sector to move toward high-tech approaches, including improvement in species breeding and the production and distribution of high value-added fruits."
He stressed that after Taiwan's entry into the WTO, products from mainland China will not pose a great threat to indigenous products in Taiwan becuase of their lower quality.
But he said that if Taiwan businessmen on the mainland re-export their products back to Taiwan, then such products could become competitive with local products.

He also said that although the government has relaxed its "no haste, be patient" policy toward investment in the mainland, it still hopes that Taiwan businessmen will make the mainland only one of its global destinations for investment and not begin an exodus to mainland China.

He said that globalization calls for all capable manufacturers have to have a global perspective. Some products could be produced on the mainland where raw material costs are cheaper, he said adding that Taiwan investors should look to all possible advantages, wherever they may appear.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEMICONDUCTOR SECTOR WAITING FOR PERMISSION TO INVEST IN M'LAND CHINA

TEXT.P: While local authorities in mainland China are offering attractive incentives to lure Taiwan's semiconductor manufacturing companies, the mainland China investment screening committee under the Executive Yuan has decided to meet on Dec. 13 to study whether to approve such investments.

Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Hsin-yi said Wednesday that the government has adjusted its policy regarding Taiwan investments in mainland China. Instead of applying a "no haste, be patient" policy, the government would take the initiative and be more open, he added.

Referring to a report from mainland China that the Soochow industrial zone administration is offering special preferential taxation treatment for Taiwan's semiconductor manufacturers, Lin said that he believed that the semiconductor manufacturers would abide by the regulations of the ROC government.

To maintain their international competitiveness, Taiwan's leading semiconductor manufacturers have sought to reinforce their global deployments, and mainland China is considered by the manufacturers as an important production base.

Dr. F. C. Tseng, deputy chief executive officer of the Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp. (TSMC), said upon returning from a recent trip to mainland China that the TSMC has set up an office in Shanghai to collect market information. Having visited several industrial zones in mainland China, he considered that it would be more suitable for the TSMC to set up chip fabs in the coastal province of Jiangsu, he added.
Refuting reports that the TSMC has purchased land in mainland China for its production facilities, Tseng said that the TSMC has not even decided on the plant sites yet.

The TSMC executive said that his company would abide by ROC government regulations. The prospects of the international market would also be an important factor for TSMC to decide on the timing to realize its investment projects in mainland China, he added.

Emphasizing that global deployment is the key to success in the semiconductor sector, Tseng said that TSMC needed to set up more chip fabs overseas in order to boost its production capacity, since Taiwan's limited resources could no longer sustain the development of this international corporation.

As one of the world's leading IC foundries, TSMC has two six-inch wafer fabs, nine eight-inch wafer fabs, a joint venture fab with Philips Semiconductor in Singapore, and more fabs are under construction in the Tainan Science-based Industrial Park.

Tseng said that the TSMC has studied possibilities to set up new fabs in the United States, Europe, Singapore, Israel or mainland China. After numerous feasibility studies, it was concluded that mainland China had more advantages than the others, he added.

The TSMC is not the only semiconductor manufacturer in Taiwan eyeing mainland China's investment advantages. A group of Taiwan manufacturers, headed by K. C. Shih, president of the IC design foundry Global UniChip, will leave for mainland China on Dec. 12 to meet with their counterparts in two seminars each in Shanghai and Beijing.

Chen Wen-hsien, president of the Taiwan Semiconductor Industry Association, said that Taiwan's manufacturers were eager to know about mainland China's market climate in the wake of Beijing as well as Taipei's admissions into the World Trade Organization. While Taiwan's authorities are likely to relax the restrictions on the semiconductor industry's investments in mainland China, the manufacturers need to familiarize themselves with the various investment regulations across the Strait.

The semiconductor sector in mainland China is also interested in seeing the development of Taiwan's semiconductor industry. The Shanghai Association of Semiconductor Manufacturing Corporations will organize a mission to visit Taiwan early next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: N.T. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar was down NT$0.002 against the greenback on the Taipei foreign exchange market Thursday, closing at NT$34.462.
The local currency opened Thursday at NT$34.448 and was traded between NT$34.425 and NT$34.462.
Interbank U.S. dollar trading totaled US$820 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: FINANCE MINISTER HAS CONFIDENCE IN TAIWAN'S MONETARY SYSTEM

TEXT.P: Minister of Finance Yen Ching-chang said Thursday that he was confident in the safety of Taiwan's monetary system, despite the fact that some international media were not positive about Taiwan's economic development.

Noting the achievements of monetary reform during the past year, Yen said that Taiwan's economic competitiveness was better recognized internationally. On the other hand, problems such as man-made flaws and rigidity of the monetary system became more obvious in times of economic sluggishness, he added.

Yen said that severe competition among the excessive number of monetary institutions has led to problems of overdue loans and problem assets. While the insurance companies were facing high risk, the brokerage firms were also operating in a much too small market.
Yen said that he hopes that the monetary reform measures will help streamline the operations of local monetary institutions which may improve their competitiveness through mergers.

Yen said that the ministry has made internationalization, improving the investment environment, and forcing unhealthy financial institutions out of the market the major tasks. He was confident in a healthy development of the monetary system, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SISY CHEN SAYS TAIPEI MAYOR SHOULD RUN FOR PRESIDENT IN 2004

TEXT.P: Independent legislator-elect Sisy Chen urged Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou Thursday to run for president in 2004 to "end ethnocentric politics" in Taiwan.
Ma and Chen were at a discussion on developing Taipei into an "Internet metropolis." Ma did not reply to Chen's suggestion but did offer a broad smile.

Chen, formerly the head of the Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP) information and propaganda affairs department, said Taiwan's politics, distorted by a wrongly-designed electoral system which has spawned ethnic political affiliations and biased governmental policies, have been a block, rather than a boost, to the development of the domestic economy.

Chen said Ma is not just popular in northern Taiwan, he is also popular in southern Taiwan where the pro-independence DPP enjoys absolute support, making him "the only chance in Taiwan to challenge ethnocentric politics."

A charismatic media guru who won the Dec. 1 legislative elections with flying colors, Chen criticized Taiwan's defective electoral system, under which she said candidates can be elected even though they obtain the support of less than half of the voters.
Chen also said that the whole of Taiwan has been in a political struggle at the cost of its economy since 1995, leading to the erosion of the country's international competitiveness.

Citing Sony as an example, she said the Japanese electronics giant planned to invest some US$291 million in Taiwan to develop broad-band telecommunications systems around the island. The plan, however, was halted after Sony became spooked by the difficulties and complexities of administrative barriers from city and county governments for approval.
Also on Thursday, Chen called on Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng, a Kuomintang stalwart, and expressed her support for Wang in his bid to be reelected.

Chen urged Wang, who was reelected as a legislator in the Dec. 1 elections with overwhelming support in the southern port city of Kaohsiung, to advocate revamping the electoral system after the new legislature convenes in February.

She said to revamp the defective electoral system, Taiwan should adopt a single-member constituency and should use the system where each voter should be entitled to cast two votes -- one for a district candidate and one for a political party.

DOC.HEADLINE: COMPUTER VIRUS 'GONER' RAMPANT IN HONG KONG
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Dec. 6 (CNA) (By Lin Li-ming and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: The computer virus "Goner," first found in the United States recently, has been rampant in Hong Kong with at least 16 companies' computer systems being hit Wednesday, sources with anti-virus authorities said Thursday.

The sources said that "Goner" is presently spreading swiftly through e-mail and ICQ. It can copy itself unceasingly, making traffic jams in the Internet, and can sabotage anti-virus and firewalls in computer systems.
The information technology department urged the public not to open e-mail of unknown origins.
Since first found in the United States, the virus has spread through 17 countries and areas in Europe and Asia, it was learned.

DOC.HEADLINE: HK MEDIA MOGUL PLANS TO BRING APPLE DAILY NEWSPAPER TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Hong Kong media tycoon Jimmy Lai plans to bring another of his maverick publications, the Apple Daily newspaper, to Taiwan, according to a report carried in the Tuesday issue of the Asian Wall Street Journal (AWSJ).

Lai told the AWSJ in a recent interview that the launch of the Taiwan version of the successful Hong Kong daily could come as soon as late next year and could cost "up to NT$5 billion (US$145.3 million)."

The new newspaper would join the Taiwan version of Lai's Next Magazine, the glossy weekly launched in May, which Lai said he expects to break even "in the next four months -- six months at the latest."

"We're going to launch our newspaper hopefully by the end of next year," Lai said. "The only thing holding us back now is we want to make money from Next Magazine before we start another new venture."
The AWSJ report said Lai, who relocated to Taiwan last year, has set his sights on expanding in what is already a very crowded media market.
In Lai's view, the report said, there is still room in Taiwan for his trademark formula of sex, gossip and muckraking investigative reports.
"You need a consumer newspaper here," Lai said. "The media here has long neglected the needs of the market."

The circulation of Next Magazine's Taiwan edition has fallen to under 200,000 copies in recent weeks from the sold-out run of 275,000 for the first edition, but even at that it still boasts three times the circulation of its closest competitor, Lai said, adding that the planned Taiwan version of Apple Daily is aimed at tapping a similar vein of demand. (By Sofia Wu) EDNITEM ZCZC CEP020 12-06-01 SAO TOME AND PRINCIPE PRESIDENT TO VISIT ROC

Taipei, Dec. 6 (CNA) President of the Democratic Republic of Sao Tome and Principe, Fradique de Menezes, is scheduled to arrive in the Republic of China Dec. 10 for a five-day visit, sources with the Ministry of Foreign Affairs said Thursday.
During his stay in the ROC, De Menezes will meet with ROC President Chen Shui-bian and discuss matters of mutual concern.
This will be De Menezes's first visit to the ROC since he took office in September this year.

Sao Tome and Principe is located in the Gulf of Guinea, western Africa, with a population of 140,000 and per capita GNP of US$220 (1999 figures). The ROC established diplomatic relations with Sao Tome and Principe on May 6, 1997.

DOC.HEADLINE: COLUMNIST PING LU TO BE NEW GIO REPRESENTATIVE TO HK
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 6 (CNA) (By Stanley Chang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Ping Lu, a noted columnist and novelist, will be the new head of the Government Information Office's (GIO) representative office in Hong Kong, the GIO said in a news release Thursday.
Ping Lu, also a Republic of China ambassador-at-large, will replace Chiang Su-hui as director of the Kwang Hwa Information and Culture Center in Hong Kong, the statement said.
The personnel change will take effect Jan. 1, 2002.

Ping Lu, whose real name is Lu Ping, graduated from National Taiwan University's Department of Psychology. She has a master's degree from the University of Iowa and is now teaching at the National Institute of the Arts.
The incumbent Kwang Hwa center chief published an article in a Hong Kong newspaper Thursday announcing her decision to leave her current post at the end of this year.
Chiang said she had informed the GIO of her decision last month and that the GIO has named Ping Lu as her successor.
"The decision to leave was made completely on my own. I feel that I have completed my mission in this historic phase," Chiang said, adding that she will pursue a new career after ending her GIO job.

Chiang began to work in Hong Kong as a correspondent of Taiwan's China Times daily newspaper in the 1980s. She came to fame in 1989 when she took the lead in reporting mainland Chinese pro-democracy student leader Chai Ling's flight abroad.

Chiang has been actively promoting cultural, academic and journalistic exchanges among the three Chinese societies -- Taiwan, mainland China and Hong Kong -- since she assumed her current post in the early 1990s. Her professionalism, diligence and eloquence have made her a media celebrity in Hong Kong.
In her article, Chiang said she has no plan to return to Taiwan as she has made Hong Kong her home.
"I'll stay in Hong Kong to continue promoting Taiwan-Hong Kong-mainland China exchanges and serving all Chinese people," Chiang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN VOWS TO FINALIZE HUMAN RIGHTS PROMOTION PLAN BY 2003

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday his administration will finalize a long-term human rights promotion plan by 2003.
Chen made the remarks at a meeting of the human rights advisory task force under the Presidential Office. The panel, founded in October 2000, is headed by Vice President Annette Lu.
The president said a draft bill governing the establishment of a national human rights commission will be referred to the Legislative Yuan for deliberation and approval in the near future.
In addition, Chen said, the government is drafting a human rights code to protect basic human rights.

Starting next year, Chen said, the government will issue a human rights white paper and a national human rights report annually. The white paper will detail the government's human rights policy, while the human rights report will review the country's human rights conditions.
In 2003, Chen said, the government will unveil a package of action guidelines for human rights promotion.
"By then, we'll have a comprehensive plan and mechanism to protect human rights to meet the requirements of a world human rights convention held in Vienna in 1993," Chen noted.
He said the government's efforts to promote human rights have received increasing recognition of international human rights promotional groups and major countries around the world.

Many international human rights associations have sent representatives to Taiwan to see for themselves Taiwan's progress in human rights protection over the past two years, Chen said, adding that a prestigious magazine published by Harvard University has decided to publish a series of articles detailing the development of human rights in Taiwan.

With the concerted efforts of the human rights advisory task force, the government and local human rights groups, Chen said he is convinced that Taiwan would become a mature democracy with comprehensive protection of human rights in the near future.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAGISTRATES-ELECT AND LAWMAKERS-ELECT TO VISIT BEIJING

TEXT.P: Some magistrates-elect and legislators-elect in Taiwan's Dec. 1 elections are planning to visit mainland China on Dec. 9 to further promote the "mini three links" between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

After a long period of planning, direct trade, postal links, and communications between Taiwan's two frontline islands of Kinmen and Matsu and mainland China's Xiamen and Fuzhou harbors in Fujian province were put into practice the first day of this year.

Lee Chu-feng, magistrate-elect of Kinmen; Chen Hsueh-sheng, magistrate-elect of Matsu; Tsao Yuan-chang, legislator-elect of Matsu; and Wu Chen-tien, legislator-elect of Kinmen, will be visiting mainland China at the invitation of Beijing authorities.

The four officials who belong to the opposition People First Party (PFP) and New Party, will visit Beijing, Fuzhou and Xiamen and meet with officials of the Taiwan Affairs Office of the State Council and the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait.

The four said that before their trip to Beijing, they will first meet with officials of the Republic of China's Mainland Affairs Council to obtain their "understanding." ROC public servants can only visit mainland China after gaining the permission of the government.

PFP Chairman James Soong said Wednesday that it is quite natural that lawmakers visit mainland China for the welfare of Taiwan people, however, he urged them to maintain the dignity of the ROC in their negotiations with Beijing.
Outgoing legislator Elmer Fung, who is familiar with affairs related to cross-strait exchanges, has also been invited by Beijing to visit the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOCIETY WANTS U.S. MEMORIAL TO JAPANESE AGGRESSION AGAINST CHINESE
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 5 (CNA) (By Nelson Chung and Ed Chen)

TEXT.P: An academic society wants to build a memorial in Washington, D.C. to Chinese victims of Japanese aggression during World War II, a spokesman for the group said Wednesday.

The issue will be discussed at the seventh international academic seminar on Sino-Japanese relations to be held in Washington D.C. Dec. 7-9, a spokesman for one of the sponsors of the event, the Society for the Study of Japanese Aggression against China, said.
The spokesman said that the University of Maryland and the Rochester Institute of Technology will also sponsor the three-day discussions.

The society wants to construct the memorial in Washington commemorating the Japanese aggression against China as soon as it can, said Wu Tien-wei, professor emeritus of history at Southern Illinois University and founder of the society.

The purpose of the establishment of a memorial would be to educate the American people of how the Japanese imperial armed forces slaughtered more than 35 million Chinese people during World War II. Their atrocities were far crueler than Nazi Germany's efforts to eradicate the Jews, Wu said.
"Those of us who have experienced Japanese aggression against China during World War II first hand should make every effort to accomplish this mission -- this is our responsibility," Wu said.

Richard Chu, president of the society and professor of history at the Rochester Institute of Technology, said that more than 100 scholars from Taiwan, mainland China, Canada, Hungary, Italy, Japan, South Korea and the United States will take part in the discussions.
Chu said he regretted that several renowned Japanese scholars who attended the last gathering will be absent this time.
This will be the second time that the meeting will be held in the United States, Chu said.
Mrs. Anna Chennault, honorary chairman of the proposed memorial organizing committee, said that the task ahead is not easy. "However, we will do our best to accomplish it," she said.
The first seminar on Sino-Japanese relations was held in August 1990 in Hong Kong. The meetings were subsequently held in Beijing, Taipei, Tokyo, Zhangzhun, and San Francisco.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIAN BEACH VOLLEYBALL COMPETITION TO OPEN FRIDAY IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The three-day 2001 Asian Beach Volleyball Competition will open Friday at the Fengshan City Sports Park in suburban Kaohsiung, organizers said Thursday.
Twenty-six men's and women's teams from eight countries in the Asian region will take part in the competition, the second of its kind to be held in Taiwan since 1994.

Teams from Australia, New Zealand, Japan, Thailand, Vietnam, Iran, Hong Kong and host Republic of China moved into the athletes village Wednesday and had some practice time Thursday to familiarize themselves with the court, although the New Zealand men's team pulled out of the competition that day.

Pundits said Australia, Chinese Taipei, and Thailand are hot favorites among the 12 women's teams, while Iran, Thailand and Chinese Taipei are considered to have the best chance of winning among the 14 men's teams.
Meanwhile that day, the organizers decided to adopt a double elimination-type seeding system.
Beach volleyball has been incorporated into the formal competition items in both the Asian Games and the Olympics.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER CONFIRMS TAIWAN'S WTO ENTRY DATE

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung confirmed Thursday that the documents relevant to Taiwan's entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO) were sent to the organization's secretariat Dec. 2 and that the nation will become full member Jan. 1, 2002.
Chang made the remarks while talking to a group of overseas Chinese medical professionals.

According to WTO entry procedures, a letter should be sent to the WTO Secretariat in Geneva to confirm the applying country's ratification of the WTO entry documents, with membership taking effect 30 days from the date of receipt of the letter.
Taiwan finished its application process Nov. 11, when a WTO ministerial conference approved its admittance in Doha, Qatar, ending its 12-year pursuit of WTO membership.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FISHING VESSEL SINKS; CREW RESCUED
DOC.DATELINE: Bangkok, Dec. 6 (CNA) (By F.C. Kuo & Ed Chen)

TEXT.P: A Taiwan-based fishing vessel sank after catching fire Tuesday off the coast of Thailand in waters near Phuket Island.
All those aboard, including Captain Tsai Ting-shou, the engineer and nine Indonesian deckhands, were rescued.
According to Phuket police, several tourists who were diving nearby helped to rescue the crew of the vessel, identified as the "KM Vaninda 34."
Officials at the Taipei Economic and Trade Office in Thailand contacted Tsai to offer assistance, but Tsai said that the ship's agent would handle the incident.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC OFFICIALS TO BRIEF U.S. ON POST-ELECTION DEVELOPMENTS
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 5 (CNA) (By Nelson Chung and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: Two Republic of China officials are scheduled to arrive in Washington, D.C. Dec. 12 to brief the U.S. on post-election developments in ROC politics, sources with the ROC representative office said Wednesday.

Chiou I-jen, secretary-general of the Executive Yuan and Tsai Ing-wen, chairwoman of the Mainland Affairs Council, will meet with U.S. government officials, Congress leaders, think tank scholars, reporters and overseas Chinese representatives to brief them on ROC President Chen Shui-bian's post-election administrative direction and policies, said the sources.
They will also exchange views on cross-Taiwan Strait and ROC-U.S. relations, the sources added.

Chiou and Tsai will talk to reporters at a news conference held by the National Press Club Dec. 12, while the ROC representative office in the United States will host a dinner Dec. 14 in Maryland to entertain Chiou, Tsai, overseas Chinese representatives, scholars and newsmen.
They are scheduled to return home Dec. 15.

Eugene Chien, deputy secretary-general to the ROC president, and Wu An-chia, a member of the Coordination Council for North American Affairs, will travel to the United States along with Chiou and Tsai.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT, PFP SAY THEY WILL NOT JOIN PRESIDENT'S ALLIANCE

TEXT.P: The leaders of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP) said Thursday they will not join any "unconstitutional" ruling coalition and will not support any of their party members serving in the Cabinet.

KMT Chairman Lien Chan and PFP Chairman James Soong told a joint news conference after hours of talks that they will respect the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP)'s right to assemble a Cabinet after it emerged from last weekend's elections as the biggest party in the legislature.
However, they went on, neither the KMT nor the PFP will join the "national stabilization alliance" advocated by President Chen Shui-bian or any similar organizations not based on the Constitution.
In a statement released at the news conference, they said they will neither encourage nor support any party member wishing to serve in the Cabinet.

Noting that according to the underlying principles of democracy, rulers should be held accountable for their policies, the two leaders said the DPP should not try to shift responsibility for the consequences of its policies in regard to domestic affairs, diplomacy, the economy and relations with mainland China.

Meanwhile the KMT and PFP will do their utmost to serve as responsible opposition parties by monitoring the government in line with the public's desire for economic development, harmony among people of various ethnic origins and peace with mainland China.
They said their parties share similar political ideas and policies on vital issues and will make decisions through the due process of their own parties.
They also said they had decided to set up an opinion-exchange mechanism to coordinate their parties' stances on major national policies.

Soong asked the public not to brand the two parties as an umbrella pro-reunification group, adding that any attempt to divide the island's political movements into pro-reunification and pro-independence is a dangerous simplification and will not serve the best interests of the nation.
He said the KMT and PFP share common positions on basic issues and that they would keep a watchful eye on the DPP government to ensure it is run on the basis of the Republic of China Constitution.
Their refusal to join the ruling coalition will also provide voters with another option in the next elections, Soong added.

He argued that a coalition such as Chen's proposed "national stabilization alliance" would obliterate the differences between the parties involved. Since they would have to share the responsibility of the government's rule, this would strip the public of the choice to punish a ruling party they dislike in elections by voting against them, he claimed.
He further admitted that he had exchanged views with Lien about who will be their choice for the next president of the Legislative Yuan.

Although he stopped short of endorsing incumbent KMT Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng's bid for re-election, he said that his party will not seek either the presidency or the vice presidency, but instead will throw its weight behind another party's candidate who is acceptable to the PFP.

Lien said at the news conference that he had already recommended Wang to KMT lawmakers and the public as the party's candidate for chief of the Legislative Yuan and that the party will seek the support of other parties for Wang's candidacy.
The KMT and PFP, which control 114 seats between them in the 225-seat legislature, technically can elect anyone of their choice as legislative president if they can agree on a candidate.

DOC.HEADLINE: FAMILY IN BABY SWAP CASE PETITION COURT FOR RETURN OF DAUGHTER

TEXT.P: A Taiwan couple went to the Taoyuan District Court recently to seek official confirmation that they were given the wrong baby when the woman gave birth nine years ago at a local hospital.

The mistake only became apparent in March this year when the father, identified only by his surname Huang, applied for an ID card for his daughter and took her for a routine test to ascertain her blood type. The test results showed that the girl has type A blood, while both parents have type O -- a biological impossibility.
Upon further investigation, they found that another woman, surnamed Liang, had given birth to a daughter at the same hospital and at almost the same time as Huang's wife.

The Huang couple then visited the Liangs and saw that their daughter bears a close resemblance to the Huangs, whereupon they demanded a DNA test that confirmed that the two couples had been given the wrong babies nine years ago.

Despite the Huangs' demand for the return of their daughter, the court's decision was uncertain, as court officials said the judge would also take into consideration the fact that neither girl is willing to leave the people they consider to be their parents and go to live with total strangers.

Meanwhile, the owner of the hospital claimed that he could not track down the nurses responsible for the mistake, but added that he would serve as a coordinator until the two families resolve the issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC, THAILAND, N.KOREA, VIETNAM WIN IN ASIAN WOMEN'S FOOTBALL TOURNEY

TEXT.P: Chinese Taipei blanked India 5-0 Thursday in the Group A preliminary round of the 2001 Asian Women's Football Championship presently under way in Taipei.

Lee Ming-su scored the first goal in the 12th minute, followed by a header from Liao Ying-wan in the ninth minute of the second half and a third goal for the Taiwan team by Huang Tsun-lan just one minute later.

Lee scored her second in the 16th minute of the second half, at which point India substituted their keeper. The substitution failed to turn the tide for India though, and Lin Chi-yi scored the fifth goal in the 43rd minute from a penalty kick, giving Chinese Taipei two wins and no losses.
In another Group A match that day, Thailand beat Malaysia 4-0.
In Group B, North Korea whitewashed Singapore 24-0 in a match played at the Taipei City Stadium, setting a 24-year goal record and giving North Korea two wins with no losses.
Also in Group B, Vietnam beat Guam 2-0.
Hong Kong will take on the Philippines Friday at the Chungshan Football Stadium while mainland China play Uzbekistan.

Score standings as of Thursday were: Group A Group B Team GP P W D L PG Team GP P W D L PG C. Taipei 4 2 2 0 0 6 North Korea 4 2 2 0 0 6 S. Korea 4 1 1 0 0 3 Japan 4 1 1 0 0 3 Thailand 4 1 1 0 0 3 Vietnam 4 1 1 0 0 3 Malaysia 4 2 0 0 2 0 Guam 4 2 0 0 2 0 India 4 2 0 0 2 0 Singapore 4 2 0 0 2 0 Group C Team GP P W D L PG Mainland China 3 1 1 0 0 3 Uzbekistan 3 1 1 0 0 3 Hong Kong 3 1 0 0 1 0 Philippines 3 1 0 0 1 0

DOC.HEADLINE: U.K. SEMICONDUCTOR INDUSTRY SEEKS ROC PARTNERS

TEXT.P: The British electronics industry, touted to be the biggest semiconductor designer in Europe, sought partnerships with their Taiwan counterparts Thursday at a symposium in Hsinchu, the capital of Taiwan's semiconductor industry.

The symposium, jointly sponsored by a British alliance for the development of system-on-a-chip technology, the Semiconductor Business Association (SBA) of the United Kingdom and Taiwan's Industrial Technology Research Institute, was aimed at promoting cooperation between the two countries.
Some 120 executives from local semiconductor firms attended the gathering to listen to briefings on Britain's electronic industry and especially its semiconductor design industry.

SBA President Chris McArdle said Taiwan, which is the world's fourth-biggest semiconductor producer, would be the perfect partner for Britain, which is good at semiconductor design and the European leader in the development of the third-generation telephones.
McArdle said that his country accounts for half of Europe's production of semiconductor components and that 70 percent of Europe-made mobile phones contain British-made components.

Although the current recession has bitten into the profits of the semiconductor industry around the world, British industry is still pouring funds into the development of the third-generation mobile phone and is ready to take off once the world economy recovers.

Noting that Taiwan is home to the world's best manufacturers for firms that outsource their chip production, McArdle said that many British firms are farming out their orders to Taiwan producers and that this trend is growing.
He predicted that Taiwan will not lose this edge to mainland China, which he described as a hard market to penetrate, despite its huge size.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAGISTRATE AND LEGISLATOR ELECT NOT YET DECIDED TO VISIT M'LAND

TEXT.P: A local magistrate-elect and a legislator-elect said Thursday that they had not decided whether to accept an invitation from Beijing to visit mainland China.

Their statement came in response to invitations the previous day from the Taiwan Affairs Office of China's State Council to four magistrates-elect and legislators-elect of the offshore islands of Kinmen and Matsu to visit some mainland Chinese cities from Dec. 9.
The four are Lee Chu-feng, magistrate-elect of Kinmen; Wu Chen-tien, legislator-elect of Kinmen; Chen Hsueh-sheng, magistrate-elect of Matsu; and Tsao Yuan-chang, legislator-elect of Matsu.
News reports said earlier in the day that the four would visit the mainland.
Lee and Wu belong to the opposition New Party, while Chen and Tsao are from the opposition People First Party.

Lee and Wu said they would not accept the invitation unless it could help the promotion of the "mini three links" between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, although Chen and Tsao had earlier accepted the invitation.
The "mini three links" refer to direct trade, postal and transport links between Taiwan's two frontline islands of Kinmen and Matsu and mainland China's Xiamen and Fuzhou ports in Fujian Province.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR DENIES MULLING OPPOSITION ALLIANCE

TEXT.P: Taipei City Mayor Ma Ying-jeou denied Wednesday that he is weighing the possibility of uniting local government heads of opposition parties into a political alliance.

The opposition Kuomintang's (KMT's) highest-ranking elected official said he is very willing to share his Taipei City Hall experience with newly elected KMT magistrates and mayors but added that he has no intention of forming such an alliance.

Ma, who is tipped by the local press to be KMT's candidate for next presidential election, said he proposed a day earlier at a meeting of the KMT Central Standing Committee that the party's magistrates-elect should be invited to join the weekly meeting of the party's policy-making group and to make regular reports on their governing experience.
He said he could not understand why his remarks were interpreted as a proposal for a political alliance among the opposition local government heads.

Ma said KMT Taoyuan County Magistrate-elect Chu Li-lung called on him earlier that day to explore avenues for cooperations between Taoyuan and Taipei, but stressed that they did not discuss the idea of an alliance.

The Taipei mayor said the Taipei city government can ill-afford not to cooperate with neighboring counties, since many people working in Taipei live in nearby counties, but added that such cooperation is not politically motivated.

DOC.HEADLINE: HANDICAPPED MEN OUTNUMBER HANDICAPPED WOMEN IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Taiwan men account for a higher proportion of physical and mental handicaps than women, according to statistics released Thursday by the Ministry of the Interior (MOI).
There was a total of 747,844 physically or mentally handicapped people in Taiwan as of the end of September, of which 445,250 were men and 302,594 were women, the MOI statistics show.

Breaking the figures down by age, 257,127 were aged 65 or above, accounting for 34.38 percent, 201,177 were between 45 and 64, accounting for 26.90 percent and 162,652 were between 30 and 44, accounting for 21.75 percent, according to the figures.
The statistics also show that an average of 3.3 people out of 100 are physically or mentally handicapped -- an average of 3.9 for men and an average of 2.8 for women.

The statistics show that an average of 13.1 people out of 100 aged 65 or above are physically or mentally handicapped, compared with an average of 4.5 people aged between 45 and 64 and an average of 2.9 people aged between 30 and 44.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Dec. 7, or the 23rd day of the 10th month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1783: William Pitt, known as "Pitt the Younger," is made British prime minister and chancellor of the exchequer at the age of just 24. He accomplished the Act of Union between Ireland and Britain but was unsuccessful in his efforts at achieving Catholic emancipation.
1808: James Madison is elected the fourth president of the United States. His presidency was marked by the War of 1812.
1858: The French and Spanish announce a blockade of the port of Taku near the Chinese city of Tientsin prior to an Anglo-French expedition against Beijing which saw the burning of the Imperial Summer Palace by invading troops.
1887: The first U.S. hospital for cancer patients is inaugurated in New York.
1902: Thomas Nast, an American political cartoonist who was born in Germany in 1840, dies at the age of 62. He was the first to depict the Democratic Party as a donkey and the Republican Party as an elephant.
1917: U.S. President Woodrow Wilson declares war on Austria.
1941: Japanese planes bomb the American naval base at Pearl Harbor, Hawaii, killing 2,400 men and destroying many aircraft and battleships.
1949: The government of the Republic of China moves its seat of power to Taipei.
1951: The Communist Chinese launch the "three antis campaign" -- anti-corruption, anti-extravagance, and anti-bureaucracy.
1971: An unmanned Soviet space capsule sends back radio and television signals from Mars.
1973: The Asian Vegetable Research and Development Center formally opens in Shanhua, Tainan County.
1974: A three-month exhibition of Chinese products is opened in Taipei by Economics Minister Y.S. Sun. The exhibition has 10 pavilions with 859 showrooms and 465 retail booths.
1975: U.S. President Gerald Ford delivers his "New Pacifism" speech in Hawaii.
1975: Premier Chiang Ching-kuo announces the ROC government's plan to build Asia's most modern farm villages under the first Six-Year Economic Development Plan beginning in 1976.
1975: Indonesian troops enter East Timor as civil war breaks out after the Portuguese, rulers of East Timor for three centuries, leave the colony.
1978: Japanese Prime Minister Masayoshi Ohira forms a new Cabinet.
1982: Robbers make away with more than NT$14 million from an armored truck of the United World Chinese Commercial Bank in Taipei.
1984: The Legislative Yuan passes the Special Education Law after its third reading.
1985: The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs announces the severing of diplomatic ties with the Republic of Nicaragua.
1986: The new Taipei City Zoo is inaugurated in the Taipei suburb of Mucha.
1988: A massive earthquake claims over 100,000 lives in Soviet Armenia.
1989: Lithuania abolishes the constitutional guarantee of Communist Party supremacy and legalizes the multiparty system.
1993: Ivory Coast President Felix Houphouet-Boigny, Africa's longest-serving ruler, dies.
1996: The space shuttle Columbia and its crew return safely to earth after ending the longest space shuttle flight ever at nearly 18 days.
1999: Premier Vincent Siew accepts the resignation of Cabinet member Peng Tso-kwei as chairman of the Council of Agriculture and appoints Ling Shiang-nung to fill the vacancy.
2000: Justice Minister Chen Ding-nan appeals to the government of France for judicial cooperation between the two countries to help in the investigation of kickback allegations surrounding the ROC Navy's purchase of six Lafayette-class frigates some 10 years earlier.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is indeed a pleasure to acquire knowledge and, as you go on acquiring, to put into practice what you have acquired. A greater pleasure still is when friends of congenial minds come from afar to seek you out because of your attainments."

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC'S MAINLAND CHINA POLICIES REMAIN UNCHANGED: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Friday that the Republic of China government's mainland China policies remain unchanged in the wake of the Dec. 1 legislative and local elections.

Fielding questions during an interpellation session at the Legislative Yuan, Chang said President Chen Shui-bian made explicitly clear his administration's mainland China policies in his inaugural speech last year and on many other prominent occasions, adding that the policies are not going to be changed because of the results of the elections held last weekend.

Chang made the remarks in response to a question by opposition Kuomintang Legislator Kao Yu-jen, who asked Chang what exactly the Chen administration's mainland China policies are, given that Chen has disavowed the existence of the "92 consensus" in recent months even though he had vowed in his inaugural speech that the leadership on the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should jointly seek a resolution to the "one China" issue on the "existing basis."

The premier responded to Kao's question by saying that President Chen has made it very clear that officials from the two sides can "sit down and talk" anytime and anywhere about differences or questions across the Taiwan Strait, including discussing the "one China" policy or anything concerning the so-called "92 consensus."

He continued by saying that negotiators from both sides did not reach any "consensus" in their landmark talks in 1992, pointing out that the only "consensus" the two sides reached that year was that political cross-strait disputes should be shelved while both sides continue expanding bilateral cross-strait exchanges.
Basically, Chang said, the so-called "92 consensus" is nothing but "each side telling a different story."

Meanwhile, Chang noted that the government would be pleased to welcome visits to Beijing by a newly-elected magistrate and several legislators at the invitation of the mainland Chinese authorities "so long as their visits do not run counter to the existing regulations and as long as national dignity is upheld."

Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen, who was also present at the Legislative Yuan interpellation session, declined to comment on the proposed visits, saying only that a further understanding of the details surrounding such an invitation is needed before the MAC can comment on the matter.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES UP BY 125.07 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) continued its upward streak on Friday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving up 125.07 points to close at 5,333.93.
Market turnover amounted to NT$182.97 billion (US$5.31 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMICS MINISTER CALLS FOR CLOSER ROC-JAPANESE EXCHANGES

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Hsin-yi said Friday the Republic of China and Japan should further strengthen bilateral economic exchanges and cooperation for mutual benefits.

Addressing the opening session of an annual ROC-Japan economic cooperation conference, Lin said that thanks to geographic proximity and historical tradition, the ROC and Japan have maintained longstanding close economic ties.
"And the annual East-Asian Economic Conference has served as a major conduit for bridging gaps, mending differences and boosting bilateral trade and economic cooperation," Lin said.

Quoting official tallies, Lin said Japan is Taiwan's second largest trading partner after the United States as well as the island's top import source and third biggest export outlet. Meanwhile, Taiwan is Japan's second largest export market and No. 4 import source.

Due to structural and technical differences, Lin said, Taiwan has suffered chronic trade deficits with Japan. In the first 10 months of this year, Taiwan registered a US$11.3 billion trade deficit with Japan.
"Although the amount marked a 40.8 percent decline from the year-earlier level, there is still ample room for the two sides to improve their trade imbalance," Lin said.

The minister went on to say that Japan has been Taiwan's second largest source of foreign capital and technical know-how. Despite the linger global economic downturn, Lin said, Japanese investors have continued swarming to Taiwan.

"In the January-October period of this year, Japanese investment in Taiwan recorded a 20 percent gain from the year-earlier level," Lin said, adding that the rise indicates the closeness of ROC-Japanese economic relations.

Noting that Taiwan's general economic and investment climate will become even more liberal and transparent following its entry to the World Trade Organization (WTO) at the beginning of next year, Lin said Japanese investors are welcome to invest more in Taiwan.

"We look forward to seeing Taiwan-Japanese trade, investment and technical cooperation increase further after our WTO accession," Lin said, adding he hopes Taiwan and Japanese business groups cooperate closely in expanding their niches in the Asia-Pacific and global markets.
More than 300 senior business and industry executives from the two countries attended the meeting, co-sponsored by the East-Asia Economic Conference's ROC Committee and Japanese Committee.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Shares prices opened high and closed even higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 125.07 points to close at 5,333.93.

Despite a decline in the U.S. and Japanese stock markets, the bourse opened at 5,234.54 and continued to go up due to the good performance of both financial stocks and plastics and chemical shares. The index fluctuated between 5,335.01 and 5,180.4 during trading.

A total of 6.56 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$182.97 billion (US$5.31 billion), an increase from the previous trading session which saw 5.98 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$174.07 billion (US$5.05 billion).

All of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with bank and insurance shares moving up the most at 5.5 percent, followed by foodstuff shares at 4.8 percent, cement stocks at 3.9 percent, pulp and paper issues at 3.6 percent, construction stocks at 3.1 percent, plastics and chemical shares at 2.6 percent, electrical stocks at 1.8 percent, and textile issues at 1.5 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 456 to 137, with 56 stocks remaining unchanged.
