DOC.HEADLINE: MAGISTRATE-ELECT AND LEGISLATOR-ELECT NOT READY TO VISIT M'LAND

TEXT.P: Kinmen magistrate-elect Lee Chu-feng said Friday that he is unlikely to visit Beijing shortly as invited by mainland China's State Council since he cannot have his "certificate of Taiwan residency" document renewed in time.

Lee, a candidate fielded by the opposition, pro-unification New Party in the just-concluded legislative and local elections and elected magistrate of the offshore county of Kinmen, said he will certainly make the trip after he is sworn in to office later this month.

Wu Cheng-tien, another Kinmen-based New Party member who was elected to the Legislative Yuan Dec. 1 and who was also invited recently by the Taiwan Affairs Office of mainland China's State Council, said he would keep his itinerary synchronous with Lee's.
Lee and Wu went to the Kinmen County Council Friday to express their appreciation for the support that the local council gave them during the elections.
Lee said he would like to visit mainland China when his entry papers are ready and on the condition that the Republic of China's sovereign dignity is fully upheld.

If he does visit Beijing, Lee said, he would like to meet with mainland Chinese officials to further tackle technical cross-strait issues, such as the interests of mainland Chinese brides living in Kinmen and other ROC-held areas, a simplification of entrance and exit procedures for elderly retired ROC servicemen who are originally from mainland China, and the opening of regular passenger flights across the Taiwan Strait.

Lee and Wu, as well as Chen Hsueh-sheng, magistrate-elect of the outlying island of Matsu, and Tsao Yuan-chang, legislator-elect of Matsu, both of whom belong to the opposition People First Party, were reportedly invited by Beijing to visit mainland China beginning Dec. 9.

During the quartet's proposed visit in mainland China, they are expected to discuss with mainland officials matters concerning the "three mini links" -- direct trade, postal and shipping links between the ROC-held frontline islands of Kinmen and Matsu and the mainland Chinese ports of Xiamen and Fuzhou in Fujian Province -- which ROC authorities implemented at the start of January this year.

Commenting on the proposed visits to mainland China by the four newly elected, Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) officials said Friday that cross-strait negotiations on matters involving public and governmental authorization, such as the "mini three links" issue, is the Executive Yuan's right and responsibility.
The MAC officials said they believe that the individuals concerned must understand their position and respect the rights and obligations of the MAC.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAILED LEGISLATOR-ELECT CAN TAKE OATH OF OFFICE IN THREE YEARS: CEC

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top election official said Friday that there is no question about the validity of Taichung County candidate Yen Ching-piao's election as legislator and that he will receive his election certificate next week.

Huang Shih-cheng, chairman of the Central Election Commission (CEC), said Yen's election as a legislator is an undeniable fact, but whether he will be allowed to be sworn in and implement his rights and duties as a legislator is another question.

Yen is currently in police detention and prosecutors are seeking a 20-year sentence for embezzlement, corruption and attempted murder, which means he is unable to attend the legislative swearing-in ceremony.
Huang noted that if Yen could be released on bail or judged not guilty, it would be possible for him to be sworn in publicly and retroactively, enabling him to undertake his duties as a lawmaker.
The legislative session, which starts Feb. 1, will last for three years and Huang pointed out that Yen can be sworn in at any point within the three-year period.

He continued that for the CEC's part, the commission will present Yen with his election certificate as scheduled, but will leave the issue of how he can take his oath of office and start his legislative duties to the Legislative Yuan to solve.

His comments followed reports that Yen, chairman of the lucrative Chenlankung Temple in central Taiwan, will not be allowed to take the oath in prison and consequently, will not be able to start his legislative duties.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-HK AVIATION PACT ISSUE TO BE SETTLED BY YEAR'S END: MAC

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) affirmed Friday that the dust raised by a spat over the expiration of a Taiwan-Hong Kong aviation accord will settle by the end of this year.

MAC Vice Chairman John C. Teng made the assurance in response to a newspaper report that air traffic between Taiwan and Hong Kong may be disrupted when the bilateral aviation accord expires at the end of the year.
According to the report, the mainland Chinese authorities may decide against extending the pact in order to force Taiwan back to the negotiating table on Beijing's terms.
Speaking at a routine MAC news conference, Teng said the report was pessimistic and exaggerated.
"The reality is that consultations and negotiations over the accord have been proceeding continuously," Teng said, refusing to divulge any details concerning the negotiations.

MAC Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen said during a tea party with local journalists earlier this week that issues regarding the Taiwan-Hong Kong aviation accord are being addressed and that the dust will settle before the end of December.
Under the current Taiwan-Hong Kong aviation pact signed in 1996, the two sides should review the agreement once every five years.
When the pact expired June 12 this year, the two sides failed to meet to review the accord. Nevertheless, they agreed to extend the validity of the accord until the end of this year.

Although the new expiry date is drawing near, sources close to the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA), which is responsible for arranging technical details for bilateral talks, said late last month that the agency had not received any notice to prepare for the talks.

Since Hong Kong reverted to mainland China's rule in July 1997, the MAC, which charts Taiwan's policy toward mainland China, has taken charge of issues related to Hong Kong, including civil aviation affairs.

Airline sources said the MAC's insistence on participating in talks may be a hindrance to the opening of negotiations. In the past, Taiwan and Hong Kong carriers operating the route reportedly played a leading role in the negotiations.
Some sources said mainland China's disapproval of any official Taiwan-Hong Kong contact may be the biggest obstacle to the opening of aviation talks.

A local newspaper said Friday that Beijing is considering instructing Hong Kong airlines not to extend the current pact with their Taiwan counterparts in order to prevent Taiwan from stalling the negotiations any further.
Should that be the case, the paper said, airlines from both sides would have to maintain Taiwan-Hong Kong flight services with chartered planes starting next year.

At present, Taiwan and Hong Kong are each allowed to operate 121 flights between the two destinations per week. Of Taiwan's quota, China Airlines (CAL) accounts for 105 flights and EVA Airways can only operate the remaining 16 flights.

On the Hong Kong side, Cathay Pacific Airways accounts for 100 flights and Dragonair is allowed to operate 21 flights. Both EVA and Dragonair hope that the aviation accord can be revised to offer them additional quotas, as the demand for Taiwan-Hong Kong flight services has continued to rise, despite the current economic downturn.

Now that Taiwan has eased restrictions on mainland China-bound investment, airline sources said, more Taiwan businessmen intend to travel to the mainland via Hong Kong for market-inspection tours, pushing up demand for additional flights.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN UNLIKELY TO FACE FINANCIAL CRISIS: ECONOMIC PLANNING OFFICIALS

TEXT.P: Taiwan is unlikely to face a currency or banking crisis but should still continue to speed up financial reform to prevent such possibilities from becoming reality, officials at Taiwan's top economic planning agency said Friday.

According to officials at the Overall Planning Department under the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), Taiwan's foreign reserves as of the end of October were as high as US$116.2 billion. These, combined with a managed floating exchange rate system, make the probability of a currency crisis remote, the CEPD predicted.

The officials added that the government has been improving the island's financial climate since the beginning of the year by setting up a financial rehabilitation fund, resolving non-performing loans at grassroots financial institutions, promoting bank mergers, ratifying major finance laws and allowing the establishment of financial holding companies.

Citing a study on the history of financial crises by Harvard University economics professor Robert Barro, the CEPD officials said that although the short-term effects of a financial crisis would be significant, a nation's economic growth in the long run eventually depends on economic fundamentals.

According to Barro's study, each time a currency crisis occurred between 1980 and 2000, GDP growth decreased by 1.3 percentage points and each time a banking crisis occurred, the GDP would go down by 0.6 percentage points.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORLD PEACE PRIZE AWARD MISSION ARRIVES IN TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: CKS International Airport, Dec. 7 (CNA) (By Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: A three-member World Peace Prize Award Council Mission led by former U.S. Congressman Lester L. Wolff arrived in Taipei Friday to present the 2001 World Peace Prize to Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu.

The other members of the mission were Han Min Su, president of South Korea's World Peace Prize Award Council and Carlifo S. Puno, director of the Higher Learning Council of the Philippines Presidential Office.
Wolff said upon his arrival that Lu was chosen as the recipient of the 2001 World Peace Prize in recognition of her contributions to Taiwan's democratization and to world peace.

Lu, who is the first female winner of the World Peace Prize since the inauguration of the award in 1990, has said that the prize, which will be presented Monday, should be considered an award for "the common achievement of the people of Taiwan" rather than a personal prize for her.

The previous recipients of the prize include former U.S. President Ronald Reagan, Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak, South Korea's first president Syngman Rhee and late Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin.

The World Peace Prize Award Council was established in 1990, a year after U.S. Congressman Robert Leggett and Han Min Su, a South Korean evangelist, jointly created the World Peace Corps Mission, patterned after the U.S. Peace Corps.

DOC.HEADLINE: HIV SPREADING THROUGHOUT TAIWAN SOCIETY

TEXT.P: The number of Taiwan people infected with HIV, the virus that causes deadly AIDS, had exceeded 3,500 as of the end of November, the Center for Disease Control (CDC) under the Department of Health said Friday.

CDC officials noted that HIV carriers have been found in nearly every walk of life, with military servicemen, civil servants and teaching faculty accounting for about 10 percent of all HIV carriers and housewives accounting for 40 percent of female HIV carriers.

"Eight doctors and five nurses are also on the list of Taiwan's HIV carriers," CDC Deputy Director Chiang Ying-lung said, adding that four of the doctors and two of the nurses have already died from AIDS.

Chiang added that as none of the HIV-positive medical personnel work or worked in the surgical department, they would be unlikely to transmit the killer virus to their patients and he pointed out that the 13 infected medical professionals form a tiny proportion of the country's HIV carriers.
Chiang said the CDC was informed a few months ago that a male homosexual doctor had tested HIV-positive.

Under existing laws, he went on, the carrier's personal data should have been kept secret. "It is regrettable that the information was leaked," Chiang said, adding that the doctor's right to work must be protected in accordance with the law.

In foreign countries, he noted, the work rights of HIV-infected doctors are carefully protected and the decision as to whether such doctors should be allowed contact with the public in a professional capacity should depend on each individual situation.
"If they are surgeons, foreign hospitals usually reassign them to departments that maintain no direct contacts with patients," he explained.

According to CDC tallies, civil servants make up 2.4 percent of Taiwan's 3,500-plus HIV carriers, military servicemen account for 5.3 percent, and professionals in various fields, including teachers and medical personnel account for 4.6 percent.
Homemakers make up 40 percent of the more than 200 female local HIV carriers, CDC officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: FINANCE MINISTRY PREDICTS RESUMPTION OF POSITIVE EXPORT GROWTH

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Finance predicted Friday that the island's export trading should be able to resume positive growth after April 2002.

According to the ministry's latest customs figures, November exports were down 33.5 percent from the same month last year, while imports were down 19.7 percent. However, officials said that November exports totaled US$10.19 billion -- the second consecutive month that the figure has stayed above US$10 billion -- indicating a gradual return to stable growth.
With November imports totaling US$7.95 billion, the island had a trade surplus of US$2.24 billion, continuing the trend since March 2000 that each month has ended with a trade surplus.
Finance officials said that the primary reason for the drop in November imports and exports was the relatively high basis for comparison from last year.

The ministry predicted that annual exports for 2001 would face a contraction of 16.7 percent, while annual imports would drop by 23.1 percent. Trade surplus this year would total US$15.7 billion, a record high since 1988, and 89 percent higher than last year.

Officials said that Sept. 11 terrorist attacks on America have delayed a global economic recovery, citing the latest forecast figures from the WEFA Group -- a U.S. economic research and consulting company that was founded as Wharton Econometric Forecasting Associates.
According to WEFA economists, global economic growth this year will drop from last year's 4 percent to 1.3 percent and is likely to see a small improvement to 1.7 percent in 2002.

However, ministry officials were optimistic that a gradual elimination of uncertainty factors from the U.S. war on the Taliban regime in Afghanistan combined with an expected increase in trading between Taiwan and mainland China after the two sides enter the World Trade Organization will help the island expand its export trading.
Domestically, officials said that financial and economic reforms are expected to improve the domestic investment and economic climate.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP TO RECEIVE NT$ 517 MILLION IN ELECTION SUBSIDIES

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), which emerged as the largest party in the legislature after the Dec. 1 legislative elections, will receive NT$517 million (US$14.77 million) in election subsidies from the national coffers.
In accordance with the Election and Recall Law for Public Functionaries, the government provides election subsidies for political parties each year.
The criteria are that the political parties that collect more than 5 percent of the total number of ballots cast are entitled to receive the subsidies, with each vote worth NT$50 in subsidies.

The DPP collected 3.44 million votes in last Saturday's legislative elections, which means it will receive NT$517 million from the government over the three years beginning from when the newly elected legislators are sworn on Feb. 1.
The opposition Kuomintang will receive NT$442 million, while the People First Party will get NT$287 million and the Taiwan Solidarity Union will get NT$120 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEVOTED SWISS CATHOLIC FATHER HONORED ON 101ST BIRTHDAY

TEXT.P: A special birthday party was held at the Sacred Heart Home in the southern Taiwan county of Chiayi Friday for the facility's founder, Francis Borkhardt, a Swiss Catholic father who will turn 101 years old Saturday.

Father Borkhardt, a member of the Society of Jesus, has preached his faith in Taiwan for 50 years. He founded the Sacred Heart Home in the remote Chiayi county township of Tungshih in 1990 to provide care for the seriously mentally disabled.

The center is now home to more than 100 mentally challenged persons. The Republic of China government offers less than NT$20,000 (US$579.71) in living subsidy to each mentally-challenged person per month. Borkhardt has tried every possible means to raise funds to help the home break even. The center needs at least NT$30 million annually.
In appreciation of Borkhardt's dedicated services, the Diocese of Chiayi Catholic Bishop's Curia and the Sacred Heart Home jointly organized a special party in celebration of his 101th birthday.
More than a dozen mentally-challenged residents in the home performed many pieces of beautiful music with various kinds of traditional and alternative instruments.

"This is the most pleasing and memorable music I have ever heard," an excited Borkhardt said, adding that he is grateful for assistance he has received from a number of people in operating the Sacred Heart Home.
Borkhardt said he hopes that he can build a permanent home for elderly and orphaned mentally-challenged residents at the Sacred Heart Home during the rest of his life.

The Swiss clergyman has devoted the prime of his life to serving local people over the past five decades. Borkhardt, who can speak fluent Mandarin Chinese and Taiwanese, said he has integrated himself into Taiwan society and life.

In appreciation of his dedicated services, President Chen Shui-bian decorated Borkhardt with the Order of Brilliant Star with Grand Cordon on his centennial birthday last year. The Order is the highest honor the ROC presents to foreign nationals who have contributed to Taiwan's educational and charity services.
The Holy See also presented a grand cross gold medal to Borkhardt in March this year in recognition of his contribution to Catholic Church.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMICS OFFICIAL INKS AEROSPACE MEMORANDUM IN CANADA

TEXT.P: Taiwan and Canada's largest aircraft undercarriage maker -- Messier Dowty -- have signed a memorandum on aerospace technology cooperation, an official from the Ministry of Economic Affairs said Friday.
The official said Vice Economics Minister Lin Yi-fu and Kenneth Laver, president of Messier Dowty, inked the memorandum in Canada.
Under the terms of the memorandum, Messier Dowty will cooperate with the Taiwan aerospace industry to produce and test aircraft undercarriage spare parts in Taiwan.
Messier Dowty is an affiliate of France's Snecma Group, the world's largest producer of aircraft undercarriage. Its products are used on more than 15,000 aircraft around the world.
The signing of the memorandum will provide a shot in the arm to the domestic aerospace industry, the official added.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL HUMAN RIGHTS MEMORIAL HALL PLANNED: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Friday that the government is planning to set up a national human rights memorial hall.
Chen said that the hall will serve as both a memorial hall and a museum, the main purpose of which will be to provide education on constitutional universal human rights.
He made the remarks while speaking at the opening ceremony of an exhibition on Taiwan's democratic human rights held at the Presidential Office.
The exhibition is being jointly sponsored by the Cabinet-level Council for Cultural Affairs, the Government Information Office (GIO) and the 228 Memorial Foundation.

In order to emphasize the importance of human rights, Chen said that his administration has upgraded Taiwan's human rights policy to the same status as international human rights, which means that a proposed national human rights committee will be set up in accordance with the standards set by the United Nations.

Chen said the government will ratify the international conventions on civil and political rights and on social and cultural rights. He added that it will also strengthen international human rights exchanges and cooperation.

December marks the 53rd anniversary of the world human rights declaration and the second International Human Rights Day of the new century which falls on Dec. 10, which Chen said adds significance to the timing of the Presidential Office exhibition.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE TO BECOME MOST WIDELY USED INTERNET LANGUAGE BY 2007: PAPER
DOC.DATELINE: London, Dec. 7 (CNA) (By Mark Ou and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: Chinese will outrank English to become the most widely used Internet language by 2007, according to a Financial Times report Friday.
The Financial Times quoted a United Nations' Internet seminar report as saying that presently English is still the most widely used language on the Internet.
However, it went on, along with the generalization of the Internet, the situation has changed rapidly.

The newspaper also quoted the World Intellectual Property Organization (WIPO) as saying that as early as next year, most Internet surfers will be of a mother tongue other than English as the language circulating on the Internet and by 2003 one-third of Internet surfers will use another language on the Internet.

It said that although languages used on the Internet have been pluralized, until now the language used to make Web site registrations has been still limited to those belonging to Latin-rooted languages, including English.
However, new technology will make non-Latin-rooted languages such as Chinese, Japanese, Russian and Arabic possible to be languages that are suitable for Web site registrations, the newspaper said.

Meanwhile, the Financial Times indicated that the multi-language Web site registrations will bring some technical problems for Web site registration institutions and will probably provoke disputes over the use of Web site trademarks in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: TZU CHI CONTINUES PROVIDING RELIEF MATERIALS FOR AFGHAN REFUGEES

TEXT.P: A cargo ship carrying relief materials for Afghan refugees provided by Taiwan's Buddhist Compassionate Relief Tzu Chi Association left Keelung Harbor Friday.
A spokesperson for the association, Wu Chi-chun, said that the relief materials will reach Afghan refugee camps early next month through the help of an Iranian charitable organization.
The relief materials include 80,000 pieces of winter clothes which have been packed into individual bags for some 6,300 families.
In the past few weeks, Tzu Chi has mobilized over 600 volunteers to do the packing work.

Other relief materials are more than 900 pairs of shoes provided by the Chi Feng Tsao Association, a civilian charitable group, 14,000 blankets provided by the Ministry of National Defense, and various kinds of medicines provided by governmental and non-governmental organizations.
Tzu Chi started sending foods and other relief materials for Afghan refugees in early November through Knight Bridge International, a Los Angeles-based charitable group.
The group will visit Mazar-e-Sharif and Bamiyan in northern Afghanistan this month to deliver rice, wheat, tea bricks, edible oil, sugar, tents and family-use medical boxes provided by Tzu Chi.

Tzu Chi, the largest charitable group in Taiwan, dispatched an official, Religious Affairs Department Deputy Director Hsieh Ching-kuei, to inspect Afghan refugee camps in southwestern Afghanistan in mid-November.
Hsieh said that Master Shih Cheng Yen, founder of Tzu Chi, is deeply concerned about the suffering of the Afghan refugees.

Besides continuing to provide relief materials through the help of international organizations, he noted that Tzu Chi is also considering to organize Tzu Chi volunteers in Turkey and Jordan to visit Afghan refugee camps.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI INTERNATIONAL TRAVEL FAIR TO KICK OFF DEC. 15

TEXT.P: Over 1,600 tourism industry representatives from 47 countries are slated to participate in the 2001 Taipei International Travel Fair to be held Dec. 15-18 at the Taipei World Trade Center, organizers said Friday.

The travel fair, organized by the Taiwan Tourism Association with assistance from the Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, will serve as a venue for 362 companies or organizations manning 548 booths to promote tourist attractions in their respective countries.

Tourism Bureau Director-General S.L. Chang said that the local tourism industry had been expecting to attain 10 percent annual growth this year and had been performing well in the first six months of 2001, but the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks on America have seriously affected the industry.
However, Chang said that he was confident of the industry's ability to quickly recover and its ability to attain its 10 percent goal next year.

The Council of Agriculture is in charge of 45 booths to promote recreational farming tourism in the wake of Taiwan's imminent entry in the World Trade Organization, which is expected to have adverse effects on the island's traditional agriculture industry.
A "virtual travel fair" will be available online for one month beginning Dec. 15 at www.taipeiitf.org.tw for those who are unable to attend the actual travel fair, organizers said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC LEGISLATURE WILL HAVE NEW SCENE, NEW STYLE: VICE PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said Friday she is convinced that the Republic of China's often unruly legislature will have a new feel and new style with the entry of 50 female lawmakers early next year.
A jubilant Lu made the forecast while meeting with Alice Schwarzer, founder of the German magazine EMMA, and senior editors of the publication.
Lu, an outspoken democracy and human rights activist and feminist, told her guests that she is very pleased to see 50 ROC women emerge as victors in the hotly contested legislative elections Dec. 1.

"Some of them are incumbents and others are newcomers. They are all elite members in various professional fields, and many of them are young, pretty and well-mannered," Lu said. "I believe that after they are sworn in next February, our Legislative Yuan will have a new scene and new working style."

When she launched a women's rights movement in Taiwan 30 years ago, Lu said, few Taiwan women participated in politics. Worse yet, she said, Taiwan women were facing various sorts of discrimination and even political persecution.
With the concerted efforts of women's rights groups and the government, Lu said, Taiwan has made progress in protecting women's rights and removal of gender inequalities.

"Of course, there is still ample room for Taiwan to upgrade women's status and promote women's rights," Lu said, adding that she feels that the women's rights movement should be associated with politics to facilitate realization of its cause.
Earlier in the day, Lu met with a delegation of overseas Chinese medical professionals to exchange views on promoting Taiwan's bid to join the World Health Organization (WHO) as an observer.
Noting that Taiwan will become a full member of the World Trade Organization Jan. 1, 2002 after a 12-year struggle, Lu said joining the WHO should be the ROC's next diplomatic target.

"All of our people at home and abroad should make concerted efforts to realize this goal as early as possible," Lu said, adding that the U.S. Congress has passed a resolution supporting the ROC's WHO bid. "We should now seek the support of the U.S. executive branch."

In her view, Lu said, Taiwan should stop complaining about mainland China's obstruction to its WHO bid and should instead tell the world what it can do for the international community in medical and health services as well as in humanitarian aid and relief work.
Lu also urged her guests to lobby countries of their residence to support the ROC's WHO bid.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT SPOKESMAN QUESTIONS CREDIBILITY OF HUMAN RIGHTS SURVEY

TEXT.P: A government spokesman said Friday that it was unfair to describe Taiwan's human rights record as being "so tragic that one cannot bear to look at it" simply based on a local opinion survey that gave non-passing grades in nine out of 10 areas.

Government Information Office Director-General Su Tzen-ping said that respected human rights organizations around the world usually use actual incidents of human rights violations and not approval ratings to determine the state of progress for any particular country's human rights conditions.

Su said that the study conducted by the Chinese Association for Human Rights is at most an approval rating survey with scores handed out by some experts and scholars based on their opinions, and not a "human rights index report" as the association called it.

Although the government "humbly accepts" the report for its reference value, Su continued, the government had to respond to the description put forth by the association's president, Chai Sung-lin, to prevent the report from misleading the public.

According to the association's survey, which was released only days ahead of International Human Rights Day on Dec. 10, Taiwan's human rights progress is considered unacceptable in such categories as political human rights, economic human rights, judicial human rights, environmental human rights, human rights for women, human rights for children, human rights for senior citizens, human rights for laborers and human rights for handicapped citizens.
Only the island's cultural and educational human rights received a passing mark in the study, which was conducted through surveys on scholars, experts, civic organizations, lawmakers and reporters.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHOULD PLACE MORE EMPHASIS ON SERVICE SECTOR: RESEARCHER

TEXT.P: The director of the Taiwan Institute for Economic Research, Wu Rong-i, said in Kaohsiung Friday that Taiwan should put more emphasis on developing the service sector as a way to absorb more jobless workers.
He made the remarks while giving a report at the 29th East Asian Economic Conference which opened at the Kaohsiung Ambassador Hotel with the participation of representatives from Japan and Taiwan.
Wu said that the service sector has been contributing a bigger share to the island's economic growth, while the shares from the agricultural and industrial sectors are on the decline.
Under such a trend, he noted that the jobless rate tends to increase.
Coupled with the continuing economic sluggishness, Wu said that Taiwan's unemployment rate this year was rising faster than other countries.
He said that the government should take effective steps to improve the structure of the island's industries so that the service sector can absorb more unemployed workers.
The researcher also said that foreign trade has been playing a very important role in Taiwan's economic development over the past few decades.

Facing the first negative growth rate in half a century this year, he said that the government should realize and resolve the bottleneck in economic development if it wants to take advantage when the economy begins to pick up.
Wu said that the government's attaching importance to the development of a knowledge-based economy is correct thinking.

As the ruling Democratic Progressive Party has now emerged as the largest party after the Dec. 1 legislative elections, he said that it will be helpful for the government to formulate financial and monetary policies in the future.

Talking about Taiwan's investment in mainland China, Wu said that in the first 10 months of this year alone, Taiwan businessmen have invested US$2.33 billion there, a figure almost equal to that made by Taiwan investors in mainland China last year.
Compared with the slowdown in domestic investment, he said that the amount of investment in mainland China by Taiwan businessmen is obviously too high.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO MAJOR PETROLEUM COMPANIES TO CUT OIL PRICES FROM SATURDAY

TEXT.P: An oil price war between the state-run Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) and the privately run Formosa Petrochemical Corp. (FPC) began Friday following the two major oil suppliers on the island announcing prices cuts for their respective oil products.
The two companies announced Friday that beginning Saturday, they would lower the price of gasoline by NT$1 and cut the price of diesel by NT$0.5.
The FPC, which is affiliated with the Formosa Plastics Group, announced the price cuts in the afternoon. The CPC followed suit 90 minutes later.

The CPC had dropped the price per liter for gasoline by NT$1 in May 1991, a decrease of 5.5 percent at that time, CPC sources said, adding that the NT$1 cut (4.81 percent) for its gasoline price this time is the largest since May 1991.

Taiwan has put into practice a law governing the management of petroleum and complete liberalization for its oil market will come into force after related rules for implementation of the law are completed.

Besides announcing meeting the FPC's cuts, the CPC has also authorized all of its gas stations to set their own gasoline and diesel prices depending on the market situation, making it possible that the price cuts at some of its gas stations will be even more.
The new prices for CPC oil products sold to its gas stations are as follows:
-- 98 octane unleaded gasoline, NT$19.4 per liter;
-- 95 octane unleaded gasoline, NT$18.2 per liter;
-- 92 octane unleaded gasoline, NT$17.1 per liter;
-- Premium diesel, NT$13.3 per liter; and
-- Ordinary diesel, NT$12.5 per liter.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP REITERATES DECISION TO FORM NATIONAL STABILIZATION ALLIANCE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian's "national stabilization alliance" will be created, said ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Secretary-General Wu Nai-jen Friday.
Wu said that the decision will not be affected by the boycott by Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan and People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong.
After meeting Dec. 5, Lien and Soong announced that the two opposition parties would not join the proposed alliance, nor would they join in the formation of a coalition government.
Wu said that the DPP was still evaluating the effect of the Lien-Soong statement, but stressed that the alliance would be created no matter what.

DPP spokesman Cheng Yun-peng said that the party's first choice would be to conduct party-to-party discussions on the issue, but that it was possible that individuals would be asked to join the alliance.

In the Dec. 1 legislative elections, the DPP won 87 of the 225 seats in the Legislative Yuan, followed by the KMT with 68 seats, the PFP with 46 seats, the Taiwan Solidarity Union with 13 seats, the New Party with one seat and 10 seats going to independents.
DPP legislative whip Tsai Huang-lang said that the ruling party will not give up its plan to establish the alliance simply because the KMT and the PFP do not wish to participate.

He said that President Chen will explain his idea clearly and sincerely to Lien and Soong, and added that the DPP will also try to contact legislative groups from the opposition to try to get the alliance started ahead of the new legislature taking over Feb. 1.
Meanwhile, DPP Chairman Frank Hsieh urged the KMT and the PFP to reconsider their decisions on refusing to join the "national stabilization alliance."

On the proposal by some DPP members that President Chen concurrently serve as party chairman, Hsieh said that he has no thoughts on the issue, but noted that Chen has openly stated that he would not participate in party affairs.
Regarding legislative reforms, he said that they should be done as early as possible.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2001 AUSTRONESIAN CULTURAL FESTIVAL OPENS IN TAITUNG
DOC.DATELINE: Taitung, eastern Taiwan, Dec. 7 (CNA) (By Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: The opening ceremony of the 2001 Austronesian Cultural Festival was held at Peinan Park in Taitung City Friday evening, with famed singer Chang Hui-mei giving a performance.
Taitung County Magistrate Chen Chien-nien said that the annual festival has received wide recognition from home and abroad since it was first staged in 1999.
Through it, he said that Taitung County can reach the international community by inviting more people to Taitung to understand the outstanding aboriginal culture.
Later Chang, widely known as "A-mei," gave a 30-minute performance, bringing the atmosphere to a new high.
Performing groups from Taiwan, Nepal, Guam, Thailand and Hawaii also performed to mark the opening of the festival. The festival will close Dec. 9.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LAWMAKERS UNVEIL THREE-PHRASE REFORM PLAN FOR LEGISLATURE

TEXT.P: A group of Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lawmakers unveiled a three-phrase program for reform of the legislature at a news conference Friday and sought the endorsement of other parties.

The plan envisioned the revision of five statutes governing the legislature's daily function in the first phrase, a switch to single-seat constituencies and a cut by half of the number of lawmakers in the second phrase, and the enactment of several bills crafted to limit conflicts of interests by lawmakers in the third phrase.

The DPP whip at the legislature, Tsai Huang-lang, who presided over the news conference, said his party hopes the first phrase of the reform will be carried out by the current legislators before the end of December.
The second phrase, which is the soul of the whole plan, will be left to the new legislators who are expected to gather for their first session in February.

Since any downsizing of the legislature and changes in the electoral system entails the amendment of the Constitution -- a task of the National Assembly -- the second phrase is expected to take longer and hopefully be finished by Dec. 1 next year, Tsai said.

The third phrase of the reform involving the legislation of bills regulating lobbying, political parties, political contributions and conflicts of interests by legislators will be acted on by the next legislature during its second session, according to the DPP plan.
Noting that polls have shown that 65 percent of people are unhappy with the legislature's performance, Tsai said the DPP is giving legislature reform the top priority of its legislative agenda.

Although the reform has to go through legal red tape, Tsai said his party, which will be the largest in the next legislature, will press ahead with it, adding: "If you cannot stand the heat, get out of the kitchen."

However, DPP legislator Lee Wen-chung said at the news conference that he doesn't foresee any serious challenges to the reform in the legislature since the plan was not only the common campaign platform of the DPP and the Taiwan Solidarity Union in the just-concluded islandwide elections, but has also been endorsed by People First Party's Secretary General Chung Jung-chi and 33 Kuomintang (KMT) lawmakers.

In a related development Thursday, a group of outgoing and incoming legislators, including independent legislator-elect Sisy Chen and outgoing KMT legislator Ding Shou-chung, called for the introduction of a single-seat district system and balloting whereby each person would cast two votes; one for a candidate, another for a party.

Ting claimed the current system that has voters in one constituency return several representatives to the legislature is susceptible to factionalism because it boosts the competition among candidates of one party and lowers the number of votes needed to win a seat.
The system encourages candidates to attract the support of a narrow sector instead of appealing to general middle-of-the-roaders, because of the low threshold needed to be elected, Ting said.

Sisy Chen prodded the current legislature, which will end its current session at the end of January, to carry out the changes immediately, saying that now is the time for politicians to vote with the DPP without fearing reprisals from their own parties as 50 of the 225 incumbent lawmakers failed to be re-elected.
The job can be done by simply revising the Public Officials Election and Recall Law, Chen claimed.

DPP lawmakers, however, denounced the calls as "inappropriate," on the grounds that the change in the electoral system would have a serious impact on the political map and should not be done hastily in the twilight of the outgoing legislature.
DPP legislator Lee Wen-chung said changes in the electoral system could not have the desired results without re-drawing the election districts and revising related laws simultaneously.
"It is better that such an important task be done by the new legislature," Lee said.

His views were shared by the Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng who said consultation among various parties is needed to ensure successful legislature reform. The current legislature is unlikely to see the consultation begin before its term expires.

DOC.HEADLINE: STOCKS' MARKET VALUE INCREASED BY NT$ 1.63 TRILLION LAST WEEK

TEXT.P: The market value of Taiwan's stocks rose by NT$1.63 trillion (US$47.24 billion), or 20 percent, over the last week ending Friday to NT$9.73 trillion (US$282.2 billion), according to the Taiwan Stock Exchange Corporation.
The TAIEX Index, a general barometer of stock prices, surged by 20.1 percent, or 17.62 percent when electronics stocks were excluded, or 19.76 percent when finance stocks were excluded.
Measured by the index, finance stocks led the pace with a rise of 22.31 percent.
Judged by maket value, finance stocks still topped the list with a gain of 21.97 percent, followed by electronics stocks, swelling by 21.56 percent; plastic stocks, growing by 19.52 percent.

The total market value of the top three kinds of stocks stands at NT$6.28 trillion (US$182.02 billion) for electronics stocks, NT$1.63 trillion (US$47.24) for finance stocks, and NT$329.6 billion (US$9.55 billion) for plastic stocks.

Winbond Electronic Corporation tops the list of the top riser by seeing its stocks price rise by 38.7 percent in the last week. Orient Semiconductor Electronics and ASUS came closely behind with by gaining 38.51 percent each.

That means the total value of Winbond's stocks has increased by NT$22.3 billion (US$646.37 million), while OSE's has increased by NT$3.1 billion (US$898.55 million), and ASUS' has increased by NT$10 billion (US4289.85 million).

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINA BLANKS UZBEKISTAN 11-0 IN WOMEN'S FOOTBALL

TEXT.P: Mainland China blanked Uzbekistan 11-0 Friday in the Group C preliminary round of the 2001 Asian Women's Football Championship Tournament now being held in Taipei.
Mainland China's Zhang Ouying drew first blood as the score stood at 5-0 at the half.
It was mainland China's second victory in the tournament.
Also in Group C, Hong Kong beat the Philippines 2-1 Friday.

Score standings as of Friday are as follows: Group A Group B Team W D L Team W D L C. Taipei 2 0 0 Japan 1 0 0 S. Korea 1 0 0 N. Korea 2 0 0 Malaysia 0 0 2 Singapore 0 0 1 India 0 0 2 Guam 0 0 1 Thailand 1 0 0 Vietnam 1 0 0 Group C Team China 2 0 0 Uzbekistan 1 0 1 Philippines 0 0 2 Hong Kong 1 0 1

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Dec. 8, or the 24th day of the 10th month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1886: The U.S. Labor Union is established.
1914: Britain's Royal Navy destroys a German naval squadron off the Falkland Islands.
1938: "The Count of Chaplin," the first German aircraft-carrier, is launched at the port of Kiel.
1941: Japan invades Thailand.
1941: The United States, Britain and Australia declare war on Japan.
1944: U.S. forces attack Iwo Jima, 750 miles south of Tokyo, beginning the longest and fiercest battle in the Pacific War.
1949: The U.N. General Assembly asks world powers to recognize the political independence of China, as the Republic of China government moves to Taiwan.
1953: The United States proposes the international control of atomic energy in the U.N. General Assembly.
1958: The first African People's Convention opens in Accra, the capital of the Republic of Ghana.
1959: The ROC Legislative Yuan amends Article 12 of the Organization Law of the National Assembly to enable the president to appoint an acting secretary-general of the National Assembly when it is not in session.
1962: Rebellion in Brunei fails after British intervention.
1974: Greece votes to become a republic, abolishing a 142-year-old monarchy.
1975: Yu Chi Chien, South Korean education minister, arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1975: Hsieh Min-nan and Kuo Chi-hsiung return from Bangkok after taking second place in the 23rd World Cup Golf Championship.
1976: Abdullah B.H. Mohammed, a member of the Asian Amateur Athletic Association, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1976: Dr. Charles R. Anderson, professor emeritus of American literature at John Hopkins University, arrives in Taipei for a brief visit.
1978: The ROC Legislative Yuan passes the revised Foreign Exchange Management Regulations under which the new Taiwan dollar is no longer pegged to the U.S. dollar.
1978: Golda Meir, who resigned as Israel's first woman prime minister in April 1974, dies at the age of 80.
1980: Soviet Communist Party General Secretary Leonid Brezhnev visits India.
1986: The ROC and the United States reach agreement on tobacco and wine tariffs. The ROC's Ministry of Finance announces that from January 1987, U.S. cigarettes and alcohol are free to enter the Taiwan market.
1990: Thailand's Prime Minister Chatichai Choonhavan resigns but is re-appointed within 24 hours.
1991: Russia, Belarus and the Ukraine form the "Commonwealth of Independent States," with the capital in Minsk.
1993: Kao Chun, a young mainland Chinese citizen, hijacks a Northern Airlines flight to Taiwan.
1995: Communist China enthrones a new six-year-old Panchen Lama, pressing Tibetans to accept its controversial choice for Tibetan Buddhism's second-ranking monk over the one named by the Dalai Lama, the exiled religious leader.
1995: The World Health Organization announces that a new outbreak of the Ebola virus, which killed 250 people in Zaire earlier in the year, has been confirmed in the Ivory Coast.
1995: Flight services between Taiwan and Macau begin.
1997: U.S. President Bill Clinton welcomes Wei Jingsheng, mainland China's noted democracy activist, to the White House.
1998: Japanese scientists report that they have cloned eight calves from the same dead cow.
1999: On behalf of the victims of the Sept. 21 earthquake, Master Cheng Yen expresses her appreciation to the international community and to individuals who have extended a helping hand to the victims.
2000: President Chen Shui-bian signs papers granting amnesty to 21 prisoners in a move to uphold human rights, the first of its kind since he took office May 20.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "With plausible speech and fine manners will seldom be found moral character."

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY (Dec. 9)
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Dec. 9, or the 25th day of the 10th month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1608: British poet John Milton, writer of "Paradise Lost," is born in London.
1824: Simon Bolivar's forces defeat the Spanish army at Ayacucho, Peru.
1905: France decrees the separation of church and state.
1908: Germany's Bundestag passes the Child-Labor Act, prohibiting the employment of children under the age of 13 years.
1930: Chiang Kai-shek, chairman of the Nationalist government, convenes a military meeting in Nanchang, in China's Kiangsi Province, to begin an anti-communist campaign.
1935: Students demonstrate in Beijing to protest against the Japanese invasion of northern China and urge unity to save the nation.
1940: The British 8th Army, better known as the Desert Rats, begin an offensive against Germany's Afrikakorps in North Africa.
1941: China formally declares war on Japan, Germany and Italy.
1949: The Executive Yuan of the Republic of China holds its first meeting after moving its office to Taipei.
1961: Tanganyika declares independence.
1965: The United States provides F-5A Fighters to the ROC.
1972: The Soviet Union and North Vietnam reach an accord on military and economic aid to Hanoi.
1974: Col. Manuel Alfonso Rodriguez, chief of the general staff of the Republic of El Salvador, arrives in Taipei for a six-day visit.
1974: Japanese Prime Minister Takeo Miki forms a new Cabinet.
1974: Sheikh Ibrahim Al-Sultan, deputy minister of Foreign Affairs of Saudi Arabia, arrives in Taipei for a four-day visit.
1975: Hammer De Roburt, president of the Republic of Nauru, arrives in Taipei to preside over a ceremony marking the opening of flight services between Taiwan and Nauru.
1975: U.S. Assistant Secretary of State Phillip Habib arrives in Taipei to brief the ROC government on President Gerald Ford's visit to the Chinese mainland. Habib reiterates America's policy of maintaining friendly relations with the ROC.
1976: The U.N. General Assembly calls for a Middle East peace conference in Geneva with the Palestine Liberation Organization participating.
1976: W.W. Kethan, president of the International Softball Federation, arrives in Taipei for an eight-day visit.
1986: The Legislative Yuan of the ROC passes a new income tax regulation raising the income tax deduction for each dependent to NT$30,000.
1986: ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo receives Nobutaka Shikanai, president of Japan's Sankei Shimbun.
1987: Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev meets with U.S. President Ronald Reagan in Washington after the signing of the U.S.-Soviet nuclear arms treaty.
1990: Lech Walesa, head of Solidarity, an organization advocating free trade unions, is elected president of the Republic of Poland.
1991: Gorbachev calls the newly formed Commonwealth of Independent States illegal and dangerous.
1992: Britain's Prince Charles and Princess Diana announce they are separating but have no plans to divorce.
1996: The military government closes universities as police chase protesting students through the streets of Rangoon, Burma.
1999: ROC President Lee Teng-hui receives Rotary International President Larlo Ravizza and former Rotary presidents Mat Caparas and Glen W. Kinross at the Presidential Office.
2000: Professor Reuben Jih-ru Hwu of National Tsinghua University is selected a fellow of the Third World Academy of Sciences (TWAS) for his outstanding achievements in chemistry studies.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "When directing the affairs of a great nation, a man must be serious in attending to business and faithful and punctual in his engagements. He must study economy in the public expenditure, and love the welfare of the people. He must employ the people at the proper time of the year."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN LAW ENFORCEMENT OFFICIALS TO VISIT MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: A delegation of Taiwan police officials are scheduled to begin a 12-day visit to mainland China on Monday as members of a civilian law enforcement organization to carry out a series of academic exchanges with the mainland's Police Society.

Criminal Investigation and Prevention Association (CIPA) Chairman Lu Yu-jun said that although the trip will be billed as a visit by a civilian group following a similar trip by the mainland's Police Society to Taiwan in July, issues concerning cross-Taiwan Strait cooperation in apprehending criminals who escape to the mainland might also be discussed.

Lu, former director-general of the National Police Administration (NPA), will lead the delegation, which will include NPA Criminal Investigation Bureau Commissioner Cheng Ching-sung, Central Police University Vice President Lo Yi-an and other high-ranking police officials.

Lu said that at present, cross-strait coordination in the pursuit of fugitives who flee to mainland China mostly depends on the Red Cross and on the semi-official organizations in charge of bilateral relations -- Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation and the mainland's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits.

However, Lu continued, with a lack of direct communication channels between law enforcement authorities on opposite sides of the Taiwan Strait, criminals often choose to hide in mainland China, adversely affecting the mainland's public security.

Therefore, he said, the CIPA -- which serves as a semi-official channel between Republic of China and foreign police authorities -- hopes to increase mutual understanding through academic exchanges and, in the long run, carry on discussions related to bilateral cooperation in law enforcement.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC VICE ECONOMICS MINISTER VISITS CANADA

TEXT.P: Lin Yi-fu, Republic of China vice minister of economic affairs, made a whirlwind visit to three major cities in eastern Canada Friday.

In Toronto, he signed a memorandum of understanding with Kenneth Laver, president and CEO of Messier Dowty of the Snecma Group, the world's largest manufacturer of aircraft landing gear whose sales in 2000 amounted to US$540 million.

Under the agreement, both sides will pursue technical cooperation projects in research and development and in landing gear design. Lin noted that depending on the results, both sides may eventually enter into joint ventures in manufacturing and services.
During his brief stay in Ottawa, Lin hosted a luncheon party for ranking officials of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office, Canada, and senior staff of Bombardier Aerospace of Canada.
He also took time to visit senior officials of the Department of Foreign Affairs and International Trade (DEFAIT) to exchange views with them on matters of mutual concern.
Taiwan is Canada's eighth largest trade partner, with two-way trade totaling over C$6 billion (US$3.8 billion) a year. Taiwan is also a leading source of tourists, students and immigrants to Canada.
After the DEFAIT visit, Lin boarded a special passenger jet and flew to Montreal, where he toured the head office of Bombardier, one of the world's leading manufacturers of passenger aircraft.
He was accompanied by, among others, Sze Chung-King, chairman of Taiwan's Uni Airways Corp., who had purchased 22 regional jets from Bombardier.
Lin said his itinerary in Montreal included taking a look at amphibious aircraft, which Bombardier is interested in selling to Taiwan for fire-fighting and marine disaster rescue and relief purposes.

DOC.HEADLINE: DGBAS, FINANCE MINISTRY SHOULD BE KEPT SEPARATE: FORMER DGBAS HEAD

TEXT.P: A former head of the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) said Saturday that the accounting agency should be kept separate from the Ministry of Finance in the ongoing effort to streamline the government.

Wei Duan, who headed the Cabinet-level DGBAS from 1996 to 2000, said at a meeting of the Chinese Statistical Association that the government should not merge the two agencies for the mere sake of streamlining but should take into consideration whether such a move can strengthen the functions of the government and improve overall government efficiency.

Wei said that it would take time to build and experiment with a new financial and statistical system, whereas the existing system has already helped make Taiwan the world's fastest growing economy over the past 50 years with an average annual economic growth rate of 8.1 percent.

In terms of cost-effectiveness, Wei said, Taiwan's statistical and accounting system should be praised for such an accomplishment. Over the past several decades, government expenditures have taken up only between 17 percent and 33 percent of the GDP, with total expenditures currently at 23.2 percent of the GDP, 16 percent of which is by the central government.
Wei said that such a figure is 10-30 percentage points less than what other countries spend in terms of their GDP.

The Cabinet-level Research, Development and Evaluation Commission has established the goal of cutting one-third of the existing government ministries and agencies so that only 21 will remain after the first phase of the massive government streamlining project is completed.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC REP. BRIEFS HUNGARIAN NEWS MEDIA ON POST-ELECTIONS SITUATION
DOC.DATELINE: Berlin, Dec. 7 (CNA) (By Liu Hsing and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China representative to Hungary on Friday briefed Hungarian news media on the ROC's post-elections situation.

Speaking at a news conference, Rock J. Leng said that although the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) candidate Chen Shui-bian won the 2000 presidential election, the party has controlled fewer seats in the Legislative Yuan than the opposition Kuomingtang (KMT) has, causing some embarrassment to the DPP in its attempts to implement government policy.

However, he went on, the Dec. 1 legislative and local elections have changed the situation, with the DPP winning the most seats in the Legislature, which he said will make Taiwan's political situation more stable.
Leng said that the results of elections show that the people of Taiwan have chosen stability and have identified Taiwan's stability with their own personal prosperity.

The sustained surge in Taiwan's stock market over the past week demonstrates the positive reaction of the people of Taiwan, he said, adding that after experiencing many democratic elections, the people of Taiwan are more and more sure of themselves.

The journalist-turned-diplomat also quoted President Chen Shui-bian as saying that the ROC government will proceed with plans to reform the Legislature, help the economy recover and promote social welfare, as well as continue to work toward improving cross-strait relations.
Leng indicated that although two-way trade between the ROC and Hungary this year is lower than last year's level, Hungary is still the ROC's largest trade partner in Eastern Europe.

DOC.HEADLINE: SCHOLAR SEES DIFFICULTIES IN INTER-PARTY MERGER

TEXT.P: It's no easy task for Taiwan's major political parties to merge among themselves under the current electoral system, a scholar said Saturday at a seminar on the island's political trends in the wake of the legislative elections.

Hung Yung-tai, a political science professor at National Taiwan University, said at the seminar, co-sponsored by an opposition Kuomintang (KMT)-affiliated think tank and the Shanmeng (Mountain Alliance) political group, that inter-party cooperation is not equivalent to an inter-party merger.

Noting that Taiwan's present electoral system, which involves single non-transferable votes in multi-member constituencies, is conducive to the development of multiparty politics, Hung said the chances of party mergers are slim, if not nil.
"And even if party mergers do take place, they are very likely to split again in a short period of time," Hung asserted.
As to inter-party cooperation, Hung said the issue must be addressed at two levels -- namely at the leadership level and at the grassroots members and supporters level.

In his view, Hung said, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the four-month-old Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) are most likely to cooperate because the TSU's spiritual leader -- former President Lee Teng-hui -- can help mediate DPP-TSU cooperation at the leadership level. And the other advantage for a DPP-TSU partnership lies in the fact that their supporters share a similar ideology of "Taiwan first" and "separate Taiwan identity from China," Hung said.
He further pointed out that the results of the Dec. 1 legislative elections showed that the TSU did not snatch away traditional DPP supporters.

Instead, Hung said, the TSU mainly drew votes away from the pro-Taiwan faction within the KMT which Lee led for 12 years until the party lost the presidential election in March 2000 for the first time.
"At the moment, we see no major obstacles to DPP-TSU cooperation," Hung said.
The DPP and the TSU will jointly control 100 seats in the newly elected 225-member Legislative Yuan.
As for the New Party, Hung said he expects the tiny pro-unification party to "evaporate" or be sidelined in Taiwan's new political landscape.

Hung further said that Lee's ouster from the KMT has made it easier for the KMT and the People First Party (PFP), a splinter group founded by former KMT Secretary-General James Soong, to cooperate as their key figures originally belonged to the same "family" and share a common dream of promoting Taiwan's eventual unification with a democratic China. The two parties jointly gained 114 seats in the new Legislature.

Nevertheless, Hung said, KMT Chairman Lien Chan and his proteges' efforts to rid the party of Lee's legacy may lead to another party split, with the possible departure from the KMT of the pro-Taiwan faction.
Touching on the possibility of DPP-PFP cooperation, Hung said ideological differences are the main obstacles to forging partnership between the two parties.
In comparison, Hung said it may be easier for the DPP to cultivate cooperative ties with the KMT, particularly the KMT's pro-Taiwan faction.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW PARTY TO UNDERGO ORGANIZATIONAL REFORM INSTEAD OF DISBANDING

TEXT.P: Opposition New Party leaders decided Saturday that the party will undergo organizational reform instead of being disbanded in the face of its near-total defeat in the recent legislative, county chief and mayoral elections.

At a meeting of the party's national election and development committee, New Party legislative caucus convener Levi Ying replaced Hsieh Chi-ta as convener of the committee, while committee secretary-general Lee Ben-nan also stepped down from his post.
Ying will complete Hsieh's term and serve as committee convener until Jan. 31, when a new convener will be elected.

Although a number of New Party members have called for the party to disband after it lost all but one of its nine seats in the Legislative Yuan, the committee members who attended the meeting decided instead to press ahead with reform.
In the Dec. 1 elections, the traditionally pro-unification New Party claimed both the legislative seat and the county chief position in the outlying island-county of Kinmen.

DOC.HEADLINE: PARTY REALIGNMENTS NOT TO BE FINALIZED BEFORE 2004 POLL: LAWMAKER-ELECT

TEXT.P: Domestic party realignments are not expected to be finalized before the 2004 presidential elections, independent Legislator-elect Sisy Chen said Saturday at a symposium on Taiwan's post-election political prospects.

Chen said the results of the Dec. 1 legislative elections will usher in a brand new political landscape in Taiwan's Legislative Yuan, with the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) replacing the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) as the largest party in the lawmaking body.
In her view, Chen said, the legislature's post-election political climate and landscape are still shaping. The newly elected parliament will not open until next February.
"It remains unclear at this moment what the new parliamentary landscape will be," said Chen, who once served as DPP spokeswoman when the party was still in opposition.

In an unexpected election rout, the DPP captured 87 of the 225 legislative seats up for grabs, compared to the KMT's 68 seats, the People First Party's (PFP's) 46 seats and the Taiwan solidarity Union's (TSU's) 13 seats. The remaining seats went to independents and margin parties.

Among the major political parties, the DPP and the TSU share a similar ideology of "Taiwan first" and "separate Taiwan identity from China," while the KMT and its splinter group PFP have a common dream of Taiwan reunifying with a democratic China.

Chen said it remains to be seen how these four major parties will interact in the new legislature. She predicted that party realignments are not expected to be completed until after the next presidential election scheduled for 2004.

Speaking on the same occasion, Hung Yung-tai, a National Taiwan University political science professor, said he sees no major hindrances to DPP-TSU cooperation as their supporters share a similar ideology and TSU's spiritual leader -- former President Lee Teng-hui -- can help mend their possible differences at the leadership level.

As for relations among the DPP, the KMT and the PFP, Hung said that forging a KMT-PFP partnership should be easier than pushing for DPP-KMT cooperation in consideration of the DPP's pro-independence or hardline stance on relations with mainland China.

Hung further said since both the KMT and the PFP have decided against joining President Chen Shui-bian's coalition offer, the Chen-proposed "national stabilization alliance" in the legislature is not expected to operate smoothly or effectively, even if it can be formed.

Chou Yu-jen, a Taipei University public administration professor, echoed Hung's view, saying that without the participation of the KMT and the PFP, the DPP will have to seek the support of independent legislators or maverick lawmakers of opposition parties.
"Such an alliance will be weak and vulnerable," Chou said, adding that he don't think the DPP-led "stabilization alliance" could really dominate future parliamentary operations.
The seminar, co-organized by a KMT-affiliated think tank and the Shanmeng (Mountain Alliance) political group, was attended by scholars, experts and politicians of different political stripes.

DPP Legislator Shen Fu-hsiung said although many political observers, scholars and legislators-elect have been pushing for an overhaul of Taiwan's electoral system after last weekend's polls, it won't be easy to alter the current voting system should the change require constitutional amendments.
"We should pool wisdom to craft a new voting system that only needs revisions of the current Election and Recall Law," said Shen, a three-term lawmaker.

Taiwan's present electoral system involves single non-transferable votes in multimember constituencies. Many politicians have been advocating a single-seat, two-vote electoral system that would allow voters to choose both individual legislative candidate and political party of their preference.

PFP Legislator Liu Sung-fan, who once served as speaker of the Legislative Yuan when he was still a KMT member, said re-demarcation of electoral districts for a single-seat constituency voting system is no easy task.

As for the proposal advocated by some incumbent lawmakers and legislators-elect to trim the number of parliamentary members, Liu said the proposed reduction could lead to difficulties in parliamentary operations and affect the representation and dignity of individual legislators.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN COMPUTER GAMER TO COMPETE IN WORLD CYBER GAMES FINALS
DOC.DATELINE: Seoul, Dec. 8 (CNA) (By Tsai Su-jung and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: Computer gamer Tseng Jeng-cheng from Taiwan is slated to go up against his Korean rival Kang Byung-geon Sunday to vie for the championship in the Age of Empires II: The Conquerers division of the first World Cyber Games in Seoul.
Tseng defeated Hong Kong player Chun Yu-shing in the Saturday semi-finals to be assured at least a second-place finish in that division on the final day of the five-day competition.
Over 400 players from 37 countries have been competing for US$300,000 in prize money in what has been termed the Cyber Olympic Games.
The Chinese Taipei team has fielded 14 players to compete in such online games as FIFA 2001, Quake 3, Starcraft, Unreal, Age of Empires II and Counter Strike.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LAWMAKER TO PRESENT BILL CALLING FOR CUT IN LEGISLATIVE SEATS

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Legislator Chang Chuan-tien said Saturday that he will submit a bill next week to amend the Republic of China Constitution to cut the number of seats in the Legislative Yuan from 225 to 103.

He told reporters that the bill has been signed by more than 60 legislators from the ruling party and the opposition, adding that he hopes the bill will be deliberated during the present legislative session which will close at the end of January.
Chang noted that there is a consensus among the people for legislative reforms and that appeals from the ruling party and the opposition for such reforms have become common.

Although no agreement has been made regarding the number of seats to be cut, he said, the bill should be presented for discussion first before letting the issues of the number of seats that should be cut and the term for legislators be discussed on the floor.
The term for legislators presently stands at three years.

The bill to be presented to the Legislature next week calls for the election of 89 legislators from the Special Municipalities, counties and cities, with at least one member being elected from each county and city.
Two legislators each would be elected from among the lowland and highland aboriginal citizens in the free area.

Also, eight legislators would be elected from the nationwide constituency and two would be elected to represent overseas Republic of China citizens based on the party proportional representation system.
Meanwhile, some legislators from the opposition are considering proposing the introduction of a "single constituency, two-votes system" during the current legislative session.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S ECONOMY TO BEGIN RECOVERING NEXT YEAR: CEPD OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) Vice Chairman Lee Kao-chao said Saturday that Taiwan's economy is expected to begin bottoming out in the first quarter of next year.
He made the remarks while appearing on a radio program to discuss Taiwan's economic problems with former CEPD Vice Chairman Schive Chi.
Lee predicted that Taiwan's private-sector investment will not increase significantly in the first half of next year.

In the past, Lee said, Taiwan's economic growth relied heavily on exports and the construction industry. However, he pointed out that in the present situation, the role of the construction sector has become insignificant, while the increase in exports has been limited.
Lee said that construction on the Taiwan high-speed railway project will begin in the second half of next year, adding that it is expected to contribute to Taiwan's economic growth to some extent.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN REAFFIRMS COMMITMENT TO COOPERATION WITH PFP

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan reaffirmed his commitment Saturday to cooperating closely with other opposition parties in supervising the government's operations.

In a written message to a seminar on Taiwan's political landscape in the wake of the Dec. 1 legislative and local elections, Lien said the KMT is willing to respect the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) right to form a new Cabinet now that the DPP has emerged from the polls as the largest party in the Legislative Yuan.

With a view to ending legislative gridlock that has characterized his first 18 months in office, President Chen Shui-bian had offered to form a broadbased, cross-party "national stabilization alliance" before the legislative elections.

In an unexpected election rout, the DPP managed to capture 87 out the 225 legislative seats up for grabs, ending the KMT's 52-year grip on the parliamentary majority. The KMT gained only 68 seats in the polls, down from 110 in the outgoing legislature.
Under this new circumstance, Lien said he sees no need for President Chen to form the so-called "national stabilization alliance" outside the country's constitutional framework.

Touching on future inter-party interaction, Lien said the outcome of the just-concluded local government chief elections augured that both the KMT and its splinter group -- the People First Party (PFP) -- will benefit if they cooperate closely.

The KMT did well in the local-level elections, tied with the DPP by winning nine mayoral and magistrate posts. In the six cities and counties that the KMT reclaimed control from the DPP, many believe that the KMT candidates owed their election victories partially to the support of PFP loyalists.
Lien said he is convinced that so long as the KMT and the PFP can integrate between themselves, they would be able to win major future elections.

In order to effectively supervise government operations and prevent the DPP administration from abusing its power, Lien said the KMT will strengthen cooperation with other opposition parties in the new legislature.

Lien admitted that the KMT had committed some tactical errors in the legislative elections, including fielding too many candidates due to pressure from local political factions and incumbent lawmakers and failing to allocate ballots evenly among its candidates.
In his written message read by KMT Secretary-General Lin Fong-cheng at the seminar, Lien also set the tome of the party's policy toward relations across the Taiwan Strait.

Lien said the 107-year-old KMT, founded in mainland China and moving to Taiwan after losing a civil war to the Chinese communists in 1949, will adhere to its fundamental stance on safeguarding the Republic of China and its constitutional system as well as opposing any pro-Taiwan independence movement.

Lien further said the KMT will uphold its stance on respecting a dual-leadership system prescribed in the ROC constitution and promoting constructive exchanges with mainland China under the principle of "one China, with each side of the Taiwan Strait free to make interpretation of 'one China'."
The seminar was co-sponsored by a KMT-affiliated think tank and the Shanmeng (Mountain Alliance) political group.

DOC.HEADLINE: FLIGHT DELAYED IN SEATTLE DUE TO SMALLPOX SCARE RESUMES FLIGHT

TEXT.P: An EVA Air jetliner that was delayed for several hours Friday during a stopover in Seattle after a smallpox scare that turned out to be a case of influenza continued its flight to Newark, New Jersey, in the evening, EVA Airways Corp. said Saturday.

U.S. police, customs agents, doctors, firefighters and immigration officials boarded the Boeing 747-400 jumbo jet, en route from Taipei to Newark, shortly after it landed at the Seattle-Tacoma International Airport at 1:13 p.m. Friday to examine a passenger who had reportedly contracted smallpox, EVA Air said in a press release.
U.S. Customs had received a message before the plane arrived at the Seattle airport that one of the passengers on board was suspected of having contracted smallpox, the press release said.

All passengers were led off the plane in order to let U.S. authorities carry out a detailed inspection, cleaning and preparation for the plane's takeoff. It turned that the passenger who was suspected of having smallpox actually only had the flu, EVA Air said.
The jetliner finally took off from the Seattle airport for Newark at 5:40 p.m., it said.

EVA Airways Corp. thanked U.S. police, customs agents, doctors, firefighters and immigration officials for their swift response and detailed check and apologized to all passengers on board for the delay.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'DURIAN DURIAN' WINS BEST PICTURE AWARD IN GOLDEN HORSE AWARDS
DOC.DATELINE: Hualien, eastern Taiwan, Dec. 8 (CNA) (By Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: "Durian Durian," a film by Nicetop Independent Ltd., won the best picture award and three other prizes in the 38th Golden Horse Awards held in Hualien Saturday.
Qin Hailu was given the best actress award and the best new actress award for her role in "Durian Durian." The play for the film by Fruit Chan was voted for the best original play award.

"Lanyu," a production by Omiao International Management Co. based on the Internet novel "The Story of Beijing," was also a winner with four prizes -- the best director (Stanley Kwan), the best actor (Liu Ye), the best rewritten play and the best fine cut.
Winners of both the best actor award and the best actress award are from mainland China.

Dubbed as the Taiwan version of the Oscars, the Golden Horse Awards have been presented annually since 1962 to advance the art of motion pictures and recognize outstanding achievements in Chinese-language production.
Seventy-eight entries from Taiwan, Hong Kong and mainland China were selected to compete for this year's Golden Horses in a number of categories.

It was the first time that the event was held in the eastern port city of Hualien. Government Information Office Su Tzen-ping said that he was happy to see the event being held outside Taipei. He urged the public to support Chinese-language films.
Winners of major Golden Horse Awards are:
Best picture -- "Durian Durian"
Best director -- Stanley Kwan ("Lanyu")
Best actor -- Liu Ye ("Lanyu")
Best actress -- Qin Hailu ("Durian Durian")
Best supporting actor -- Patrick Tam ("Born Wild")
Best supporting actress -- Yoky Lo ("Gimme Gimme")
Best new actress -- Qin Hailu ("Durian Durian")
Best original play --Fruit Chan ("Durian Durian")
Best rewritten play -- Jimmy Ngsi ("Lanyu")
Best shooting -- Lee Ping-bing ("Millennium Mambo")
Best visual effect -- Centro Digital Pictures ("Shaolin Soccer")
Best fine cut -- William Chang ("Lanyu")
Best sound effect -- Du tuu-chih ("Millennium Mambo")
Best documentary -- Chu Hsien-jer & Lai Meng-hsio ("Pick of the Litter")
Best creative short -- Cheng Yu-chieh ("Summer Dream")
Jury's special awards --Tsai Ming-liang & "What Time Is It There"
Life achievement award -- Soong Tsun-shou (director)

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE TAIPEI BEATS THAILAND 5-0 IN ASIAN WOMEN'S FOOTBALL

TEXT.P: Chinese Taipei defeated Thailand 5-0 in Group A preliminary round of the 2001 Asian Women's Football Championship in Taipei Saturday.
In three other games, South Korea blanked Malaysia 3-0, North Korea upset Vietnam 4-0 and Japan beat Guam 11-0.
Win-loss standings of the participating teams as of Saturday are:
Group A -- Chinese Taipei 3-0, Malaysia 0-3, India 0-2, South Korea 2-0, Thailand 1-1.
Group B -- North Korea 3-0, Guam 0-3, Singapore 0-2, Japan 2-0, Vietnam 1-1.
Group C -- Mainland China 2-0, Hong Kong 1-1, Uzbekistan 1-1, Philippines 0-2.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Sunday are as follows:
