DOC.HEADLINE: GARUDA INDONESIA RESUMES BALI-TAIPEI FLIGHTS

TEXT.P: Garuda Indonesia Airlines resumed flights from Bali to Taipei Sunday after a hiatus of three years.
The first Garuda flight on the route, an MD-10, arrived at the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport in Taoyuan at 8:40 a.m. Sunday morning with 88 passengers, and returned at 10 a.m.
The airlines will operate four flights per week on the route, said a Garuda Indonesia official.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP TO STAY ON SIDELINES OF RACE FOR LEGISLATURE PRESIDENCY

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian has the final say regarding who will be the next president of the Legislative Yuan and the People First Party (PFP) will stay out of the contest, said PFP heavyweight and former Legislative Yuan President Liu Sung-pan Sunday..

Although Liu wasn't specific, it is understood that most PFP legislators-elect feel that current president of the Legislative Yuan, Wang Jin-pyng of the Kuomintang (KMT), will succeed in his bid for reelection since the PFP has agreed to cooperate with the KMT. The two parties have a fragile majority of 114 seats between them at the 225-seat legislature.

However, who Wang will pick up as his running mate for vice president is still anybody's guess. The position of vice president carries with it heavy political undertones, particularly with the incoming legislature having a decidedly different make-up from the one that is in session now.

Wang took the position from Liu as president of the Legislative Yuan three years ago after a fierce fight within the KMT, of which Liu was then a member. The competition drove a wedge between the two former comrades and led to Liu's breakaway from the KMT and eventually joining the PFP.

Observers say this is probably the cause behind Soong's stopping short of publicly endorsing Wang's candidacy for the presidency after meeting with KMT Chairman Lien Chan Wednesday. He preferred not to offend Liu by giving the PFP's support to Liu's former rival.

Most PFP lawmakers believed Wang is likely to choose a Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lawmaker as his running mate given that the DPP, with 87 seats, will be the largest party at the new legislature.

PFP lawmaker Liu Wen-hsiung said there are voices within his party to field a candidate for vice presidency as Wang's running mate, but that the idea was rejected by party leaders because such an alliance with the KMT would antagonize the DPP and intensified its attempts to lure away KMT lawmakers who are friendly toward the DPP.

In that case, Liu Wen-hsiung said, not only will the PFP's attempts at the vice presidency be thwarted, but Wang's bid for the presidency will also be jeopardized and, therefore, the new cooperation between the two opposition parties could be ruined.

This might explain why PFP spokesman for its legislative caucus Hsieh Chang-chieh said last week that the PFP prefers to stay on the sidelines in the race for legislature chiefs, and instead throw its weight behind Wang's reelection bid.
But that doesn't means the PFP will support any person chosen by Wang as his running mate. The party would rather keep its options open regarding candidates.

A PFP source close to its chairman, James Soong, said the former Taiwan provincial governor would support Wang's bid for reelection by refraining from entering a PFP candidate, but is opposed to any DPP candidate for either the presidency or the vice presidency.
This stance might not change the result of the race but will underline the party's role as the third-largest party in the new legislature, the source said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO INTRODUCE ITS SEMICONDUCTOR INDUSTRY IN MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: The Taipei-based China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) is planning to lead Taiwan's prominent semiconductor companies to mainland China in search of cross-Taiwan Strait cooperation in this area.

Huang Chih-peng, CETRA's general-secretary, will lead the Taiwan delegation composed of seven major semiconductor design companies to organize a "Taiwan Semiconductor Day" respectively in Beijing and Shanghai on Dec. 13 and Dec. 17.
The seven companies will include Faraday Technology Corp., Sunplus Technology, and Global Unichip Corp.
According to CETRA officials, many Chinese enterprises have shown strong interest in participating in the meeting with Taiwan's semiconductor design firms and have applied to participate.
The CETRA officials revealed that the Haier Group, Bear Technology Group, and Julongshuini Group -- all established business groups in mainland China -- have confirmed their attendance for the event.
The Taiwan delegation is scheduled to leave for Beijing on Dec. 12 and will return to Taipei on Dec. 19.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT RECEIVES WORLD PEACE PRIZE AWARD

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu was given the 2001 World Peace Prize Sunday for her work in women's and human rights, democracy and the promotion of peace at a ceremony at the Presidential Office.
Lu said that the award marks "the beginning of responsibility," and that she plans to dedicate more of her time to world peace in the future.
The award was presented by representatives of the World Peace Prize Award Council.

Lu said that Taiwan security goes hand in hand with world peace. She also said that in the past, wars were generally started by men and that if women could take a more active role in world affairs, wars could be avoided.

Lu said that when she received the golden plaque from former U.S. Congressman Lester L. Wolff and chief presiding judge of the award council, she felt honored but understood the weight of responsibility that comes with being given such an award.

Lu said she was born on D-day, 1944, and although she has not been directly involved in wars, she said that she has heard so many tragic stories about them. During her childhood, Lu said that her parents nearly put her up for adoption simply because she was a girl -- a fact that sowed the seeds of her desire for gender equality.
She started to promote feminism at age 27, suffered from thyroid cancer at 30, and was thrown into jail for promoting democracy at 36.

With all these things in her past, Lu said that she was eternally grateful to first lady Wu Shu-chen for recommending her to team with President Chen Shui-bian on the 2000 presidential ticket, creating history with a male-female president and vice president for the Republic of China.

She also said the first lady received the Liberal International's 2001 Prize for Freedom in France in mid-November on the president's behalf. Lu now receiving the World Peace Prize shows that the international community has recognized not only Taiwan's economic miracle, but also its political miracle, which she said "is the fruit of the efforts of 23 million people in Taiwan."

Lu, the first female to receive the award since its inauguration more than a decade ago, noted that Taiwan has gone through poverty in its half century of colonial rule and during its 38-year martial law rule. Taiwan has also constantly been threatened by mainland China's verbal attacks and military intimidation, but despite such adversity, she said that security and stability has been protected in Taiwan, and the island's economy and democracy continues to develop.

Lu said that since assuming the vice presidency, she has promoted the idea of human rights, democracy, peace and love, hoping to use the "soft" instead of the "tough" approach in promoting the nation.

Witnessing the award ceremony were First Lady Wu Shu-chen, Secretary-General to the president Yu Shyi-kun, former Vice President Li Yuan-tsu, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung, Legislative Yuan President Wang Jyn-pyng, Examination Yuan President Hsu Shui-teh, Control Yuan President Fredrick Chien, Judicial Yuan President Weng Yueh-sheng and several presidential advisers.

The first lady, speaking on the same occasion, said that there have been two miracles over the past month, referring to her -- a woman confined to a wheelchair receiving a freedom award on behalf of her husband, who is limited in the overseas trips he can make and the countries that will diplomatically receive him -- and Lu, who was convicted for sedition for taking part in the pro-democracy movement being given the World Peace Prize.

"This is indeed a Taiwan miracle," Wu said, adding, however, that the president and the vice president did not create the miracle, but it was "created by the people of Taiwan," and the honor should go to all of them.

Wu said that Taiwan people use wisdom to choose and make good use of the democratic system, adding that they use votes to decide the direction of the nation, and show the world that a "Taiwan of solidarity is brave and not afraid."

The World Peace Prize Award Council was established in 1990, a year after U.S. Congressman Robert Leggett and Han Min-su, a South Korean evangelist, jointly created the World Peace Corps Mission, patterned after the U.S. Peace Corps.

Previous recipients of the prize include former U.S. President Ronald Reagan, Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak, South Korea's first president, Syngman Rhee, and late Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANTHRAX USED BY JAPAN KILLED 1 MILLION CHINESE IN WORLD WAR II: EXPERT
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 8 (CNA) (By Nelson Chung and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Evidence has been found that Japan used biological agents, including anthrax, in mainland China during World War II, killing more than one million people, experts said at a seminar Saturday.

Yin Ji-jun, a Chinese American and author of "The Rape of Biological Warfare," said the Japanese military, not only the notorious 731 Troops, but also the Japanese navy and army, had used all sorts of biological weapons to kill mainland Chinese people during World War II.

Speaking at a seminar on China-Japan relations being held in Washington, D.C., the former engineer said his investigation found that Japan's 731 Troops were only a special branch of the Japanese army in charge of research into biological warfare. The Japanese navy established a special air force in Feb. 1942 and dispatched 18 airplanes to spread massive amounts of biological agents along the Yangzi River.

In addition, Yin pointed out, at least two divisions of the Japanese army underwent special training in Shanghai and carried out germ warfare in southern Zhejiang province and regions adjacent to what was then Burma and the delta areas of the Yellow River for military aims.

After the first U. S. air attack on Tokyo in 1942, the Japanese military launched large scale biological warfare in Zhejiang and Jiangxi provinces, Yin said, adding that Zhejiang was particularly hard hit by Japan's military airplanes due to its holding of mainland China's airports nearest to Japan. Japan feared that the U. S. might use those airports to conduct airborne attacks on Japanese territory, he noted.

More than 100,000 Chinese troops and civilians were killed in Jiangxi, and the anthrax spores used by the Japanese military there were found to be still effective until the early 1950s, according to Yin. Rats in Jiangxi are still testing positive for anthrax today, he added.
Yin said mainland China approved the establishment of its first research institute on Japanese biological warfare in September of this year at Changde Normal College in Hunan province.

The major purpose of the Japanese military's germ warfare was to kill more Chinese troops and civilians efficiently, Yin said. Many Chinese people with anthrax were captured alive and many dead bodies were dug out to be autopsied by Japanese troops to know the effect of their biological agents.

Daniel Bareublatt, an American academic who is writing a book about Japan's anthrax attacks in mainland China, agreed that Japan resorted to such approaches in mainland China during World War II and killed thousands of captives.

At least more than one million people were killed in Japan's germ war in mainland China, Mongolia and Burma at that time, he went on, adding that the Japanese military also conducted germ tests on captured American soldiers. Chemical weapons left by the Japanese military on the mainland after its surrender still cause huge problems for local people, he noted.

Participants at the three-day seminar which ends Sunday also discussed issues related to the Rape of Nanking and comfort women. A film about the Rape of Nanking, "In the Name of the Japanese Emperor" was shown at the seminar.

Those at the seminar Sunday will discuss topics focusing on Japan's economic exploration in mainland China, Japan's war compensation and Japan's criminal war activities in Asia. Yale professor James B. Crowley will give a keynote speech on the closing day.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR, MAINLAND CHINA PRESIDENT TOP MEN OF YEAR LISTS: POLL

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou and mainland China President Jiang Zemin topped the men of the year lists in Taiwan and across the Taiwan Strait respectively, a poll released on Sunday showed.
The survey, conducted between Nov. 23 and Dec. 6, received 1,023 effective questionnaires from 20 colleges and universities in Taiwan, and had a margin of error of 2.35 percent.

The 20 men of the year in Taiwan are Ma, former President Lee Teng-hui, opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong, President Chen Shui-bian, opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan, Vice President Annette Lu, Legislator-elect Sisy Chen, tycoon Wang Yung-ching, ruling Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Frank Hsieh and Legislator Lo Fu-chu.

Rounding out the 20 are Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp. Chairman Morris Chang, Taipei Magistrate Cu Chen-chang, Legislator Shih Ming-teh, former Kuomintang Secretary-General John Chang, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung, former Foreign Affairs Minister Jason Hu, baseball star Chen Chin-feng, writer Hou Wen-yung and Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh.

The 20 men of the year across the Taiwan Strait are mainland China president Jiang Zemin, President Chen Shui-bian, mainland China Premier Zhu Rongji, Taiwan tycoon Wang Yung-ching, former President Lee Teng-hui, Taiwan's top negotiator with mainland Koo Chen-fu, Academia Sinica's President Lee Yuan-tseh, PFP Chairman James Soong, TSMC Chairman Morris Chang and KMT Chairman Lien Chan.

Rounding out the 20 are mainland China Vice Premier Qian Qichen, ROC Vice President Annette Lu, mainland China's top negotiator with Taiwan Wang Daohan, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, Taiwan popular singer A-mei, Hong Kong Chief Executive Tung Chee-hwa, mainland National People's Congress Chairman Li Peng, Hong Kong movie star Jacky Chan, Taiwan's Buddhist Master Cheng Yeng, and DPP Chairman Frank Hsieh.

Dr. Feng Kuang-ling, Chairman of the ROC Business Management Society, in unveiling the survey said that the survey showed that Taiwan students have become mature in recent years, adding that this is the first time that Taiwan students have chosen mainland China leaders to top the men of the year across the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: KOREAN WOMEN TO BARE 'JESUS MORNING STAR' FOUNDER'S ALLEGED SCANDAL

TEXT.P: Two Korean women arrived in TaipeI Sunday to tell how Cheng Myong Suk, founder of the Jesus Morning Star sect, assailed them sexually in Korea.
Both accusers, identified only as P and K, will hold a news conference here Monday to relate their experiences with the Korean sect founder, who has denied sex abuse charges.
Wang Wu-kuei, a former Jesus Morning Star priest, said the two women, both former members of the sect, would substantiate their accusation of Cheng Myong Suk.

"They will produce copies of the written indictment against Cheng by a Seoul district prosecutor," said Wang, who is organizing the press meeting. The press will also be shown a TV report footage of the scandal and a copy of the written verdict a Seoul district court judge handed down on the sect founder.
A number of female sect members in Taipei made similar charges against Cheng Myong Suk last month. Wang, who has arranged the two Korean women's visit here, advanced the charges.
Cheng Myong Suk was "deified" in Korea, Wang said. "His two Korean victims will tell how the 'deified' sect leader forced women followers to have sex with him," he added.

While here, the two Korean accusers will file a libel suit with the Taipei district court against Huang Ching-yuan, a Taiwan spokesman for the Korean sect, on behalf of Kim Do Hyong, a Seoul resident and Cheng Myong Suk's ex-follower.
Huang denied the charges and told the press he welcomes Kim to sue him for libel, adding that truth will come out in the court of law.

Former women sect followers like the two Korean accusers have formed an assistance group, Exodus, to help track down Cheng Myong Suk, now wanted by the Korean law enforcement authorities, according to a CNA report from Seoul.
Exodus members are helping locate the sect founder, who reportedly left Korea sometime ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN COMPUTER CAME PLAYER WINS WORLD CYBER GAMES

TEXT.P: Parents in Taiwan who believe excellent academic performance in schools is the only guarantee of their children for a bright future should read this.
A teenage high school dropout in Taichung won the first World Cyber Games in Seoul Sunday.

Tseng Jeng-cheng, the 17-year-old boy from the central Taiwan city, took only 30 minutes in the morning to beat his South Korean rival Kang Byung Geon in the final video game, "Age of Empires 2: the Conquerors, AOC."
Kang Byung Geon, a heavily favored adversary, is a veteran video competition player with many international titles, whom Tseng had encountered in Internet games before.

In a blitz, at which he is good, Tseng attacked Kang from the very beginning of the game. The Korean did his best to defend and tried to launch conterattacks, but his fate was sealed 20 minutes into the game, though he soldiered on to fight to the last man.
A capacity crowd watched the final game and burst into cheers when Tseng vanquished Kang.
Tseng attributed his victory to his skill and good luck. "I was under pressure, but my good luck held," he said.

Aside from a World Cyber Games prize of US$20,000, the teenage champion won a cash reward of NT$500,000 from a cyber cafe chain. Together with NT$150,000 in prize money offered by a Taiwan telephone company, he collected enough cash, NT$1.35 million or US$38,500, to equal a lump sum retirement pay of an ordinary white collar worker in Taiwan.

Asked what his plan for the future is, the teenager, who stayed out of school after finishing Taiwan's nine-year compulsory education, said -- to the relief of most parents across the island -- he will enrol at a senior high school next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT ATTENDS CONTAINER ART SHOW IN KAOHSIUNG

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian, on a visit to the 2001 International Container Art Festival in Kaohsiung, said Sunday he never believed artists could breathe a new life into cool, rigid metal freight compartments.

After touring the exhibition in the morning, Chen said Kaohsiung, the world's fourth top container shipping port, is uniquely qualified to show what few believe is possible, a metamorphosis of cool metal compartments into pieces of art.
Chen toured the site aboard a container-converted limousine.
"With fine touches," President Chen said, "the artists have given the lowly containers a new lease on life."
Altogether 36 artists from 16 countries are displaying their masterworks at the one-month international exhibition, which opened at Wharf 21 Saturday.
On display are containers decorated with graffitti, paintings and artistic designs. A few appear as coffee shops, while 123 others form a "labyrinth," which has become a chief attraction.

Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh, who accompanied President Chen, said he hopes the container art show would further strengthen cultural exchange with other cities of the world. Also on Chen's entourage was Chen Yu-hsiu, chairwoman of the Council of Cultural Affairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAL CHAIRMAN AWARDED FOR FLIGHT SAFETY ACHIEVEMENT

TEXT.P: China Airlines Chairman Lee Yun-ling's lifetime devotion to flight safety was finally recognized worldwide. He won this year's lifelong achievement award of the International Air Flight Safety Foundation.

At an annual conference in Athens on Nov. 7, the foundation awarded the honor to Lee in recognition of his 50-year-long effort to improve the flight safety of Taiwan-based carriers. Lee was the first Chinese to receive the award.
Lee, a former Air Force pilot, said Sunday he will continue working to ensure flight safety. "It's a lifetime job requiring persistent efforts, research and dedication," he added.
He first worked as a pilot for American Airlines, where he learned flight safety is "not just a slogan."
After joining Far East Air Transport Corp., Lee successfully improved the fight safety record of the domestic carrier. He set up a flight safety office for the China Airlines.
Chiang Hung-i, a former China Airlines chairman, highly praised the former pilot for flight safety work. "Lee is the best flight safety manager," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN AND CANADA TO PROMOTE ECONOMIC RELATIONS

TEXT.P: Taiwan and Canada will increase their trade consultations with a purpose to improve their economic relations, Vice Economic Minister Lin Yi-fu said here Saturday evening.

Lin told reporters at the San Francisco Airport on his way home from Toronto that he met with Canadian trade officials earlier this week to exchange views on how to improve economic relations between the two countries.

The two countries have not hold trade consultations for three years; they held instead a series of talks on matters relating to Taiwan's admission to the World Trade Organization. Taiwan was admitted to the WTO last month.
He said that trade consultations between the two countries will be resumed soon, and that the two countries will increase exchange of visits by trade officials in order to improve economic relations.
Trade conferences between the private sectors of the two countries will also be resumed soon, he added. (by Neil Lu)

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINA DEFEATS PHILIPPINES 10-0 IN WOMEN'S FOOTBALL

TEXT.P: Mainland China emerged as the top team in Group C of the 2001 Asian Women's Football Championship with three wins against no loss after defeating the Philippines 10-0 in Taipei Sunday.
In another Group C preliminary match, Uzbekistan beat Hong Kong 4-0 to rank second with two wins against one loss.
The teams from Hong Kong and the Philippines, ranked third and fourth place respectively, will leave Taipei Monday.

Meanwhile, Chinese Taipei will meet with its arch rival South Korea in Group A Monday. Chinese Taipei Football Association President Huang Shih-cheng has offered a NT$200,000 (US$5,700) reward for the Chinese Taipei team to win over South Korea.

In the past encounters, Chinese Taipei upset South Korea 2-0 in the 1994 Asian Games in Hiroshima and beat it 1-0 in the 1997 Asian Women's Football Championship in Guangzhou. They tied 1-1 in the Bangkok Asian Games in 1998.

DOC.HEADLINE: YOUNG AND MID-AGED PEOPLE FORM BULK OF TAIWAN POPULATION

TEXT.P: People between 15 and 64 years old have made up the large part of Taiwan's population, which is rapidly aging, according to government statistics released Sunday.

A demographic survey by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) showed that Taiwan's population reached 22.26 million as of the end of 2000, with men accounting for 51.2 percent and women 48.8 percent.
Those below the age of 15 totaled 4.58 million, accounting for 20.7 percent of the population. The people in the 15-to-64 age bracket numbered 15.69 million, representing 70.8 percent.
Elderly people, 65 years old and older, totaled 1.89 million, accounting for 8.5 percent, against 6.1 percent in 1990.

Officials of the DGBAS said Taiwan's demographic structure now is very different from that of ten years ago, which can be seen as a pyramid with the number of aged people at the top and children in the bottom.
The officials noted that the top of the pyramid has grown rapidly. The number of the elderly, they said, has increased by 52.7 percent in the last decade.

The survey showed that 58.1 percent of the aged people lived with their children in 2000. They accounted for 61.9 percent in 1990. The elderly people living alone increased -- from 13.5 percent in ten years ago to 16 percent last year.
Among the old people 172,000 need long-term care, according to the DGBAS.
There were 374,000 single-parent families as of the end of last year, the survey indicated. Single mothers accounted for 70.5 percent of the total.
Over half, or 51.9 percent, of the families had one of the parents dead. Unmarried or divorced parents made up the remaining 48.1 percent. Most of the single parents were between 25 and 49 years old.
The single-parent families with underage children accounted for 39 percent of the total.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Dec. 10, or the 26th day of the 10th month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1898: Spain signs treaty with the United States, ending the Spanish-American War and ceding Cuba, Puerto Rico, Guam and the Philippines to the United States in exchange for US$20 million dollars.
1901: The first Nobel Prize presentation ceremonies are held separately in Stockholm, Sweden, and Oslo, Norway.
1902: Construction of the Aswan Dam is completed in the upper section of the Nile River in southwest Egypt.
1911: French scientist Marie Curie wins a second Nobel Prize, becoming the first person to do so.
1929: Chen Tu-siu, one of the Chinese Communist Party's co-founders, issues a statement to party comrades calling Joseph Stalin an opportunist who caused a massive split within the Communist Party.
1936: Britain's King Edward VIII abdicates, becoming the Duke of Windsor. He is succeeded by his brother, George VI.
1941: Japanese warplanes sink the British battleships "Repulse" and "Prince of Wales," killing nearly 800 in the South China Sea.
1948: The Third United Nations General Assembly adopts the Convention on Genocide and Human Rights.
1949: Republic of China President Chiang Kai-shek flies from Chengtu, Szechwan Province, to Taipei.
1952: The ROC government drafts its first four-year economic development plan.
1955: Cambodian Prime Minister Norodom Sihanouk arrives in Taipei for a visit.
1959: ROC President Chiang Kai-shek appoints Ku Cheng-kang as the acting secretary-general of the National Assembly.
1960: The ROC establishes diplomatic relations with Gabon.
1973: A five-day Seminar on Agricultural Development with special reference to Taiwan is opened at the JCRR (Joint Commission on Rural Reconstruction) Building in Taipei.
1974: Toshio Urabe, newly appointed chief of the Taipei office of the Japanese Interchange Association, arrives in Taipei to assume his post.
1975: China Petroleum Corporation President Jerome Hu confirms the discovery of undersea oil deposits some 15 kilometers west of central Taiwan.
1975: A 12.5-kilometer section of the North-South Freeway between Chungli and Yangmei is completed. A 42-kilometer section of the roadway is now open to traffic.
1979: Mother Teresa is awarded the Nobel Peace Prize for her ceaseless work in helping the destitute.
1979: The Formosa Incident, during which Formosa magazine demonstrators clash with police, occurs in Kaohsiung.
1986: Lee Yuan-tseh is awarded as the co-winner of the 1986 Nobel Prize in chemistry at the Stockholm Concert Hall in Sweden.
1988: Mainland Chinese troops shoot into crowds of Tibetans demonstrating for human rights in Lhasa.
1988: The Indigenous Defense Fighters (IDF), manufactured by ROC aviation experts, are formally named "Ching-kuo" class fighters by President Lee Teng-hui.
1993: African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela says he and South African President F.W. de Klerk are bound by the Nobel Peace Prize they accepted to spend the rest of their lives building a democratic South Africa free of racial discrimination.
1996: The Cabinet-level Council of Aboriginal Affairs is established. The Taiwan Independence Party, which is a Democratic Progressive Party splinter group, is also established.
1999: The first human rights monument in Asia is officially inaugurated, on Green Island off the southeastern coast of Taiwan.
1999: Chen Shui-bian, the presidential candidate of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), formally names Annette Lu as his running mate for the 2000 presidential election.
2000: Under an amnesty decree issued by President Chen Shui-bian, 21 prisoners are released on International Human Rights Day.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A young man, when at home, should be a good son; when out in the world, a good citizen. He should be circumspect and truthful. He should be in sympathy with all men, but intimate with men of moral character. If he has time and opportunity to spare, after the performance of those duties, he should then employ them in literary pursuits."

DOC.HEADLINE: `COMMITTEE OF 100' DELEGATION MEETS TAIPEI MAYOR

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said Monday that his municipal government is willing to play a leading role in promoting city-to-city cooperation between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

"I think if each major Taiwan city can choose a suitable mainland Chinese city for bilateral exchanges of experiences in environmental protection, traffic management, crime fighting, urban development and other non-political issues, just like Taipei and Shanghai, both sides will benefit and cross-strait relations will also gradually improve," Ma said while meeting with a "Committee of 100" delegation.

The New York-based "Committee of 100" is a non-partisan, non-political association of ethnic Chinese celebrities aimed at helping bridge cultural and institutional gaps between Americans and Asian people. Its founding members include architect I. M. Pei, cellist Yo Yo Ma and Tien Chang-lin, a former chancellor of the University of California at Berkeley.

Ma told his guest that although he looks forward to visiting mainland China to woo investment, he must wait until after the Republic of China government formally lifts the ban on mainland visits by elected domestic government chiefs.

"I feel a bit anxious over the phenomenon that mainland Chinese city mayors and even provincial government chiefs have swarmed to visit Taiwan to attract investors," Ma said, adding that he hopes the central government will ease travel restrictions on city mayors and county magistrates as early as possible.
He said the Shanghai city government has tentatively agreed to send representatives to attend the third Taipei-Hong Kong twin city forum to be held in Taipei early next year.
"We hope that a formal three-way Taipei-Hong Kong-Shanghai forum can be held on a regular basis in the not-too-distant future," Ma said.

Noting that cross-strait relations are now very weak and vulnerable, Ma said each side should respond positively to any goodwill gesture from the other side and should refrain from making provocative speeches to hurt the other's feelings.

Touching on Taiwan's political development in the wake of the recent legislative elections, Ma said the opposition Kuomintang's (KMT's) stunning electoral defeat augured an urgent need for the party to reinvent itself in order to win back voter support.

Ma, the KMT's brightest political star, said the KMT should also form an alliance with other like-minded political parties to fulfill its duty as a responsible opposition loyal to the people, the country and the ROC Constitution.

The charismatic mayor further advised the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to seek inter-party cooperation through party-to-party negotiations instead of trying to sway elite members of other parties to defect to its camp. "Such moves would only trigger political instability," he warned.
The visiting "Committee of 100" delegation is headed by Fu Lu-jen, the committee's vice president, and is made up of 20-plus members, including David Ho, an AIDS expert.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Shares prices opened high but closed lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 12.65 points to close at 5,321.28.

Despite a decline in the NASDAQ index over the weekend, the bourse opened at 5,345.51 but began to go down later due to profit-taking selling pressure on electronics shares. The index fluctuated between 5,435.48 and 5,304.9 during trading.

A total of 6.12 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$166.43 billion (US$4.83 billion), a decrease from the previous trading session which saw 6.56 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$182.97 billion (US$5.31 billion).
Only one of the eight major stocks categories posted losses, with electrical shares moving down 2.2 percent.

The other major categories gained ground, with pulp and paper issues moving up the most at 6.2 percent, followed by textile issues at 6.1 percent, plastics and chemical shares at 6 percent, construction stocks and foodstuff shares, both at 4.6 percent, cement stocks at 4.4 percent, and bank and insurance shares at 2.6 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 511 to 113, with 26 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-HONG KONG AIR TRAFFIC WILL NOT BE DISRUPTED: MOTC HEAD

TEXT.P: Air traffic between Taiwan and Hong Kong will not be disrupted at the end of the year when a Taiwan-Hong Kong aviation accord expires, Minister of Transportation and Communications Yeh Chu-lan said Monday.

Yeh made the remarks during a legislative committee meeting during which Legislator Liu Wen-hsiung of opposition People First Party expressed concern about the lack of contact between Taiwan and Hong Kong with the pact set to expire in less than one month.
Liu criticized the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) for stressing the issue of ideology and for not being able to help the aviation industry solve the problem.

The Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) under the MOTC is responsible for arranging technical details for bilateral talks, but since Hong Kong reverted to mainland Chinese rule in July 1997, the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), which charts Taiwan's policy toward mainland China, has taken charge of issues related to Hong Kong, including civil aviation affairs.

Liu said that if the two sides fail to renew the aviation accord, airlines from both sides will have to apply to maintain Taiwan-Hong Kong air services with chartered planes on a case by case basis starting next year.

Yeh said negotiation of a Taiwan-Hong Kong aviation pact is a sensitive issue involving affairs with mainland China. She said a task force headed by the MAC is currently working in a "cautious, responsible" manner for the talks, adding that she knows perfectly well the importance of the Taiwan-Hong Kong route to both sides of the Taiwan Strait.
Yeh said that the task force has explored all scenarios. Although she said she could not divulge the details, she assured the Legislature that air services will not be disrupted.

Legislator Liu suggested that Taiwan-Hong Kong aviation pact negotiations be left to unofficial airline associations on both sides as in the past, saying that otherwise, the insistence on official talks will fail to achieve anything.
Reports said that the MAC also wants to send officials as advisers during aviation pact talks with Hong Kong.

Under the current Taiwan-Hong Kong aviation pact signed in 1996, the two sides must review the agreement once every five years. When the pact expired June 12 this year, the two sides failed to meet to review the accord, although they agreed to extend the accord to the end of this year.
Although the pact's new expiration date is drawing near, sources close to the CAA said that the agency has still not been able to prepare the agenda for negotiations.

At present, Taiwan and Hong Kong are each allowed to operate 121 flights between the two destinations per week. Of Taiwan's quota, China Airlines accounts for 105 flights and EVA Airways operates the remaining 16 flights.

On the Hong Kong side, Cathay Pacific Airways accounts for 100 flights and Dragonair is allowed to operate 21 flights. Both EVA and Dragonair hope that the aviation accord can be revised to allow them to operate more flights as the demand for Taiwan-Hong Kong flight services has continued to rise, despite the current economic downturn.

Now that Taiwan has eased restrictions on mainland China-bound investment, airline sources said, more Taiwan businesspeople intend to travel to the mainland via Hog Kong for market-inspection tours, pushing up demand for additional flights.

DOC.HEADLINE: HIGH-PROFILE POLICE MISSION LEAVES FOR MAINLAND VISIT

TEXT.P: A high-profile police delegation, headed by Cheng Ching-sung, director of the Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) under the National Police Administration (NPA), left for mainland China Monday on a fact-finding mission.
This is the first time that senior Republic of China police officers have visited mainland China to promote bilateral cooperation in cracking down on crime.
Prior to his departure, Chen said his group will meet with mainland China's public security officials on possible cooperation in fighting criminal activities across the Taiwan Strait.

"In addition to exchanging views on halting cross-strait human and firearm smuggling as well as drug trafficking," Cheng said: "The two sides will also discuss cooperation in fighting economic crimes following their accession to the World Trade Organization."
The delegation is scheduled to visit mainland China's Ministry of Public Security and the Public Security Bureau under the Beijing City Government Tuesday.

During its 12-day visit, the delegation will also meet public security authorities in Shanghai and Guangdong and Fujian provinces as well as the mainland Chinese Police Society and its branches in major mainland cities.

The visit was organized by the private Taipei-based Criminal Investigation and Prevention Association (CIPA). Members of Cheng's mission also included CIPA Chairman Lu Yu-jun, who once served as the NPA director-general, and several incumbent CIB section chiefs.

Two middle-ranking Taiwan police officers made a trend-setting visit to mainland China after 24 Taiwan tourists were murdered at Qiandao Lake in the southeastern mainland province of Zhejiang in March 1994.

In August 1996, Taiwan launched a large-scale crackdown on organized crime, resulting in the flight of a number of underworld ringleaders to the mainland. In November that year, then-CIB Director Chang Yo-wen intended to travel to the mainland via Hong Kong to seek possible mainland cooperation in bringing underworld figures back to Taiwan. However, Chang was forced to cancel his trip when the media caught wind of his plans.

Thanks to the assistance of private academic groups on both sides, cross-strait police exchanges have gradually increased in recent years. Two senior Shanghai public security officers attended a seminar on cross-strait criminal activities in May 1998.

In July this year, 15 mainland Chinese incumbent and retired senior public security officers also made a low-profile visit to Taiwan. (By Sofia Wu) EDNITEM ZCZC CEP010 12-10-01 N.T. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET
