DOC.HEADLINE: MAC CHIEF RENEWS CALL ON BEIJING TO RESPOND TO 'MINI LINKS'

TEXT.P: Nearly a year after the opening of three direct "mini links" across the Taiwan Strait, the Republic of China's top mainland policy planner renewed her call on Beijing to make positive response to the "open door" measure.

Tsai Ing-wen, chairwoman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), made the appeal after receiving a certificate of honorary citizen of Kinmen County from outgoing Magistrate Chen Shui-tsai.

Chen said the county government has decided to name Tsai and two other senior MAC officials the county's honorary citizens in recognition of their efforts to open three direct "mini links" of trade, mail and shipping between the two ROC-held frontline islands of Kinmen and Matsu and mainland China's Xiamen and Mawei port cities in Fujian province, which lies opposite Taiwan, at the beginning of this year.

"It was the most important step in Kinmen's development in more than 50 years," Chen said, adding that although the effects of the new opening measure has not fully lived up to public expectations, it's not the fault of the MAC.
The biggest obstacle to the expansion of the "mini links" mainly lies in Beijing's reluctance to resume talks with Taipei and its refusal to adopt coordinate measures, Chen noted.
For her part, Tsai said the opening of three direct links between Kinmen/Matsu and Xiamen-Mawei is a critical step to the development of cross-strait relations.

Over the past year, Tsai said, the central government has devoted much energy and administrative resources to the "mini links" project. Despite its limited functions due to Beijing's incooperation, she said, the government will not be daunted and will instead continue carrying out the project in a pragmatic manner.

Tsai urged mainland Chinese leaders to recognize the benefits the "mini links" have brought to the people on both sides and take necessary steps to pave the way for the opening of regular direct Kinmen-Xiamen and Matsu-Mawei shipping services as early as possible.

Beijing now still approves applications for direct Kinmen-Xiamen and Matsu-Mawei shipping services on a case-by-case basis and imposes stringent restrictions on visits by mainland people to the ROC's two defense outposts, both of which lie closer to mainland China than to Taiwan.

Tsai said the MAC is conducting an overall review of the "mini links" and will adopt feasible measures to upgrade Kinmen and Matsu's functions as a midpoint for cross-strait exchanges, including boosting legal trade between Kinmen/Matsu and mainland China to curb smuggling.
The two other MAC officials awarded the Kinmen honorary citizen status were Vice Chairman John C. C. Teng and MAC Chief Secretary Pao Cheng-kang.

DOC.HEADLINE: FINANCE MINISTER CONFIDENT OF TAIWAN'S ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT

TEXT.P: Republic of China Minister of Finance Yen Ching-chang Monday expressed his confidence in the development of Taiwan's economy in the coming months, saying that "the worst has passed."
Yen made the remarks while reporting the progress of financial reforms at the Finance Committee of the Legislative Yuan.

Legislator Lin Wen-lang of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party said that after the Dec. 1 legislative and local elections, the weighted index on the Taiwan stock market has shot up 1,200 points, coupled with the influx of foreign capital amounting to NT$40 billion.
He attributed the encouraging performances mainly to the post-elections stable political situation and the financial reforms being implemented by the Ministry of Finance.

In response, Yen said that during last September's ministerial meeting of the Asian-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum in Shanghai, some foreign ministers predicted to him that the success of Taiwan to engage in financial reform amid global business sluggishness would enable Taiwan to catch the first wave of the global economic rebound.
"I have a deep confidence in Taiwan's future economy," he stressed.
Regarding the establishment of financial holding companies, Yen said that his ministry would strictly screen the applications submitted by the financial institutions.
He noted that although he has stated that the reasonable number of financial holding companies for the island is 15, he added that it is not a binding figure.

Legislator Lai Shih-pao of the tiny opposition New Party asked the minister to help bring down the interests charged on house mortgages by banks, saying that the interests remain as high as 8 percent per annum, while the interests for time deposits are only around 2.5 percent.
Yen said that he is not in a position to promise lowering the interests for house mortgages on behalf of banks, but he can send messages to banks persuading them to try to lower the interests.

DOC.HEADLINE: RAND REPORT SEES CLOSER TAIWAN-U.S. TIES IN NEAR TERM

TEXT.P: Political, economic and military ties will strenghten between Washington and Taipei over the next four to five years, but the United States should maintain a degree of ambiquity regarding its stance on cross-strait affairs, according to a report recently published by the Rand Corporation.

In the 172-page report titled "Taiwan's Foreign and Defense Policies: Features and Determinants," analysts Michael Swaine and James Mulvernon wrote that the Chen Shui-bian administration's defense policy will seek to obtain quantitatively and qualitatively greater levels of weaponry and related military assistance from the United States, and to develop closer military and political relations between Taipei and Washington.

Yet internal debates will continue to rage over the dangers, costs and opportunities presented by President Chen's policy proposals, such as the adoption of offensive strike capabilities and the construction of sophisticated ballistic missile defense systems.

Convinced that Taiwan's foreign and defense policies will continue to exert a profound impact on American relations with both Taiwan and mainland China, they made the following specific policy recommendations:

-- Since Taiwan's foreign and defense policy-makers rely on U.S. military intervention as a key assumption in their planning, U.S. policy should be calibrated to deter or prevent any Taiwan leader from undertaking political actions that Washington believes might provoke an attack by mainland China.

-- Significant benefit is gained by preserving ambiguity over U.S. intentions towards Taiwan's security and international status. The U.S. government should maintain a public allegiance to the notion of "one China" as originally defined in the U.S.-PRC normalization agreements, combined with a posture of public ambiguity regarding the level of U.S. commitment to defend Taiwan.

-- Privately, the United States should make it clear to Beijing that it will respond militarily out of necessity in the event of a mainland Chinese attack, while stating privately to Taipei that the United States will prevent what it views as any unilateral attempt to secure an independent status for Taiwan. "American support for Taiwan's democratic development should not equate with support for independence," the analysts said.

They added that Beijing will not accept a mere avoidance of a formal declaration of independence by Taiwan as sufficient to guarantee "no independence"; Taiwan could take other actions, with U.S. support, that Beijing would view as dangerous -- and Taiwan would be more inclined to do so if the United States provides a public defense guarantee.

However, Rand analysts Michael Swaine and James Mulvenon wrote that domestic constraints on Taipei and Beijing will likely perpetrate a policy stalemate over cross-Strait relations, with both sides appealing to outside constituencies to facilitate a deal.

But given the reluctance of Washington to directly mediate talks between the two sides, they said, "there is little prospect for improvement in (cross-strait) ties in the short-term." (by Nelson Chung)

DOC.HEADLINE: KINMEN COUNTY CHIEF, LEGISLATOR-ELECT VISIT MAINLAND

TEXT.P: Kinmen County magistrate-elect Lee Chu-feng and legislator-elect Wu Cheng-tien of the opposition New Party left for Beijing via Hong Kong Monday to meet officials on the mainland to discuss the "mini three links."

They are to join two others from the island of Matsu -- Lienchiang County magistrate-elect Chen Hsueh-sheng and legislator-elect Chao Yuan-chang, both of the People First Party -- and outgoing legislator Elmer Feng of New Party, in Beijing for a four-day visit. The trio arrived in Beijing a day earlier on Sunday.

Lee said that he has visited the mainland many times over the past year, and during his campaign, he had promised mainland spouses who married Taiwan men and veterans that he would visit the mainland after the elections, hoping to convince the mainalnd to simplify their entry and exit procedures and to better understand the needs of Kinmen citizens currently residing in the mainland.

Lee said the most important thing will be to communicate with the mainland on the direct trade, postal and transportation links, or "mini three links" between the islands of Kinmen and Matsu and mainland China.

Lee noted that the "mini three links," inaugurated Jan. 1, 2001, will need an overall review after a year of implementation. He also said that he has appealed to the Mainland Affairs Council several times to ease the restrictions that only allow direct cross-strait travel for those who have resided on Kinmen or Matsu for six months or more. Lifting this restriction, Lee said, would help Taiwan businessmen and Kinmen citizens living overseas to travel to the mainland directly to help the inauguration of regular shipping services between Kinmen and Xiamen.
Legislator-elect Wu also said that he promised to promote the inauguration of regular shipping services between Kinmen and Xiamen during the campaign, and he is hoping to deliver on that promise.

Both Lee and Wu said that they hoped to make headway in the technical matters involving the "mini three links" to respond to the voters' needs. They also wanted residents to be able to get support from the governments on both sides so that cross-strait relations could enter a new stage.

The group will call on officials from the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait and Taiwan Affairs Office in Beijing before heading to Fuzhou, Xiamen Wednesday. Their trip will end Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: RESEARCH INSTITUTE WARNS AGAINST SHARP FLUCTUATIONS OF LOCAL UNIT

TEXT.P: The Chung Hua Institution for Economic Research warned Monday in a report that drastic fluctuations of the local currency will have a negative impact on the Taiwan economy.

Sharp devaluation or appreciation of the New Taiwan dollar will disturb normal economic activities and the effects of such an approach to boost local exports will be limited, the report said, calling on the government to act cautiously when considering such measures.

The report commissioned by the Board of Foreign Trade on Taiwan's 2000-2001 currency policy showed that the New Taiwan dollar depreciated by 6.96 percent in the first two quarters of this year, while exports dwindled by 10.8 percent during the same period. It is obvious that currency devaluations will not help lift export levels, the report pointed out.
The report also said that currency deprecations will push up prices of import products and result in increased production costs for local exporters, thus also affecting the export trade.

DOC.HEADLINE: MACRONIX DONATES US$8.7 MILLION TOWARD HIGHER EDUCATION

TEXT.P: Leading non-volatile memory maker Macronix International Co. donated NT$300 million (US$8.7 million) to National Tsing Hua University in a ceremony Monday toward the building of a NT$1.2 billion (US$34.8 million) learning resource center.

The seven-story building will be centered around a library and will incorporate distance learning, multimedia production and conference facilities taking up a total floor space area of approximately 46,300 square meters.
Construction on the center -- the first of its kind at Taiwan universities or colleges -- is scheduled to begin in 2003 and is expected to be completed by 2006.
Macronix Chairman Hu Ding-hua said that his company hopes to give back to society by encouraging innovation and supporting education.
Of the 3,700 employees at Macronix, over 200 are Tsing Hua alumni -- "a tribute to the university's academic excellence," Hu added.

Tsing Hua University is located in Hsinchu City, 72 kilometers south of Taipei and neighboring the Industrial Technology Research Institute, National Chiao Tung University and the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park, which is home to Macronix and nearly 300 other high-tech companies.

Founded in 1989, Macronix is the world's seventh-largest supplier of non-volatile memory chips and is the world's largest supplier of Mask ROM. It became the first company from Taiwan to be listed on the NASDAQ in 1996 and is capitalized at approximately NT$45 billion (US$1.3 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING SHOULD RENOUNCE MILITARY THREAT AGAINST TAIWAN: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung urged mainland China Monday to renounce military threat against Taiwan in line with the United Nations-initiated Universal Declaration of Human Rights.
Chang made the appeal in a ceremony marking the Dec. 10 World Human Rights Day.
Noting that human rights are universal values, Chang said human rights can be truly protected only in a peaceful environment.

Chang said the U.N. Assembly on Dec. 10, 1948 adopted the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, which states that "all human beings are born with equal and inalienable rights and fundamental freedoms."

"Mainland Chinese leaders should respect the common aspiration of the people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait for basic human rights and renounce their threat of the use of force against Taiwan," Chang said.

The premier further called on mainland leaders to be broad-minded and forward-looking enough to work together with Taiwan in breaking the lingering cross-strait impasse and forging mutual trust for creating permanent peace in the Taiwan Strait.
Chang went on to say that Taiwan's history over the past five decades is characterized by its people's pursuit of human rights and dignity.

"We have come a long way in ending martial law and authoritarian rule to become a mature democracy," Chang said, adding that President Chen Shui-bian, who swept to power in Taiwan's first-ever peaceful transition of power between different political parties in May 2000, has vowed to substantiate human rights protection during his term of office.

Chang said the Cabinet already asked the Legislative Yuan on April 25 to ratify the two major international conventions on the protection of civic and political rights as well as economic, social and cultural rights.

In addition, Chang said, the Cabinet has ordered relevant government agencies to conduct a comprehensive review on current domestic laws to see whether they violate any international human rights conventions.
Meanwhile, Chang said, the Cabinet has set up a human rights task force to push for the establishment of a national human rights commission to better protect basic human rights.

On Feb. 1, 2002, Chang said, the Cabinet is scheduled to unveil its first white paper on human rights policy. From then on, the government will release a national human rights report annually to review the domestic human rights conditions.
In the future, Chang said, the government will sponsor international seminars on human rights issues from time to time to arouse public attention to human rights protection.

DOC.HEADLINE: 4.5-MAGNITUDE QUAKE ROCKS EASTERN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: An earthquake measuring 4.5 on the Richter scale rocked the eastern Taiwan county of Taitung Monday, the Seismology Center of the Central Weather Bureau said.
The quake, which occurred at 4:24 p.m., had its epicenter at a depth of 3.1 kilometers, 20.7 kilometers south of the Lidao Seismology Station in Taitung County.
No casualties were reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT MEETS WITH `COMMITTEE OF 100' DELEGATION

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian reiterated Monday in a meeting with the delegates of a non-partisan overseas Chinese group that "one China" is an issue that can be discussed in future dialogue with mainland China.

However, Chen said that "one China" should not be a precondition to such talks until such time as Taipei and Beijing have reached a mutually acceptable meaning for the term through "wisdom and creativity."

Chen told the visiting "Committee of 100" delegation, headed by its vice president, Fu Lu-jen, and comprised of over 20 members including world-renowned AIDS treatment expert David Ho, that "one China" was originally not a problem according to the Republic of China Constitution.

The problem, he went on, is that if the so-called "one China" principle cherished by Beijing "makes the Republic of China vanish," then as a guardian of ROC sovereignty, dignity and security, he cannot accept the principle.

The president said that the government will continue to push for normalized relations between Taipei and Beijing and to look forward to the moment when the leaders from both sides meet and shake hands.
The two sides of the Taiwan Strait could temporarily shelve disputed issues and begin with those related to commercial and cultural integration, he added.
Chen urged Beijing to focus more on economics and less on politics and called for greater contact and less misunderstanding as well as greater trust and less oppression of Taipei by Beijing.

The New York-based "Committee of 100" is a non-partisan, non-political association of ethnic Chinese that aims to help bridge cultural and institutional gaps between Americans and Asians. Its founding members include architect I.M. Pei, cellist Yo Yo Ma and Tien Chang-lin, a former chancellor of the University of California at Berkeley.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIR FORCE USING MODEL PLANES AS BIRD-SCARERS

TEXT.P: The Republic of China Air Force has found using remote-controlled model planes to be an effective method of scaring birds away from runways and sky over at its airbases, an air force officer said Monday.
Lin Yu-pao, a deputy head of the 401 Wing based in Hualien, eastern Taiwan, said that extensive testing of the method at the Hualien air base in eastern Taiwan has proved it to be very effective.

Lin said that two of the model planes are flown at the same time from either end of the runway, which scares away birds and prevents them from approaching real airplanes that are landing and taking off. The method, he went on, is particularly effective against doves and egrets.

Lin noted that the 30 minutes before sunrise or after sunset are the times when birds are on the move between their roosts and their feeding grounds and added that pilots know to avoid landing and taking off during these times.

Kung Shiang-Kai, director of the 401 Wing's Political Warfare Department, said bird-hits by aircraft is a major problem all over the world and one that has caused many accidents. He added that the downing of at least one F-5F from the Taitung base and the crash of a Mirage jet fighter from the Hsinchu base were attributed to bird-hits.
Kung said the other methods used by the air force to deal with birds, such as using shotguns or erecting nets, have all gradually become ineffective.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO SEND RELIEF MATERIALS FOR AFGHAN REFUGEES

TEXT.P: Taiwan will send some 6,500 bags of relief materials for Afghan refugees with the assistance of an Iranian charitable organization, the Government Information Office (GIO) said Monday.
A GIO official said that a container ship, which will transport the relief materials in seven 40-foot containers, will depart Taiwan Wednesday.
He added that volunteers from the Buddhist Tzu Chi Compassionate Relief Foundation will join the relief operation once the materials reach Iran at the end of this month.

The official noted that the relief materials, carrying a total value of over US$7 million, have been provided by government organizations, the Tzu Chi foundation and three other civilian groups. Tzu Chi is the largest charitable group in Taiwan.
The goods, including food, tents, winter clothing, blankets, medicine and medical equipment, will be delivered to some 6,500 Afghan families now living in refugee camps.

In the wake of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks on New York and Washington, Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian expressed the government's support of the U.S. move to eradicate terrorism as well as its willingness to provide humanitarian aid for Afghan refugees.
The official said that the government is also seeking the assistance of other international charitable groups for sending a second batch of aid for Afghan refugees in the near future.
Last month, Tzu Chi cooperated with the Los Angeles-based Knight Bridge International to send relief goods to Afghan refugees through Uzbekistan.

DOC.HEADLINE: REMAINS OF FORMER AIR FORCE SURVEILLANCE CREW LAID TO REST IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The remains of 14 crew members of a surveillance aircraft that was shot down by mainland Chinese fighters over Jiangxi province nearly four decades ago were laid to rest Monday after being airlifted back to Taiwan last week.
Surviving relatives of the crew gathered at the Republic of China Air Force cemetery located in Hsintien, Taipei County, to pay homage to the dead.

Air Force Commander-in-Chief Gen. Chen Chao-min presided over the ceremony for the pilots, co-pilots and other officers aboard the downed P-2V long-range patrol aircraft of the 34th Squadron, known as the "Black Bats."
Eulogizing the crew's heroic actions, Chen said that the Air Force hopes that the new precedent will allow for the return of the remains of other officers downed over mainland China.

The P-2V, led by squadron leader Col. Chou Yi-li, was on a reconnaissance mission in the central mainland province of Jiangxi when it was intercepted by communist jet fighters and shot down on June 19, 1963. None of the crew members reportedly survived.

Their bodies were discovered by locals soon after the mishap, whereupon the remains were kept in Jiangxi by the mainland authorities. Private talks about having the remains returned to Taiwan did not start until recent years after Taiwan began allowing civilian exchanges across the Taiwan Strait.
Hsiao Chia-chen, the widow of the dead squadron leader, has been instrumental over the past decade in arranging for the downed squadron's return to Taiwan.

According to Hsiao, she and some of the other squadron family members visited the mainland three times before the mainland authorities gave the green light to allow the remains to be taken back to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT SIGNS HUMAN RIGHTS DECLARATION FOR TEENAGE GIRLS

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian reiterated Monday that the government is determined to protect teenage girls from commercial sexual abuse.
He made the remarks while signing a "Human Rights Declaration for Teenage Girls" worked out by the Garden of Hope Foundation, a charitable group devoted to the welfare of women and children.
Chen said that since he assumed the presidency last year, the government has placed more emphasis on the promotion of human rights.
He added that the government will take steps to protect teenage girls so that they can grow up with dignity and gender equity.

An official with the Garden of Hope Foundation said that the "Human Rights Declaration for Teenage Girls" will be taken to an international meeting on sexual abuse against children to be held in Japan in the middle of this month to seek foreign support.
Also Monday, to coincide with World Human Rights Day, the Garden of Hope Foundation launched a series of activities around Taiwan to urge the public to respect the human rights of teenage girls.
Red feathers were distributed as a symbol to heighten public awareness of the need to protect the human rights of teenage girls.
In central Taiwan, meanwhile, Taichung Mayor-elect Jason Hu and several other local dignitaries attended a news conference where they pledged to guard the human rights of teenage girls.

DOC.HEADLINE: DE MURAT RE-ELECTED CHAIRMAN OF ECCT

TEXT.P: Fabrice de Murat, general manager of L'Oreal Taiwan, was re-elected chairman of the European Council for Commerce and Trade (ECCT) Monday, according to ECCT sources.
Paul Zeven, board chairman of Philips Taiwan, was re-elected vice chairman of the council, the sources added.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVA AIRWAYS TO OPEN TAIPEI-PHNOM PENH SERVICE

TEXT.P: EVA Airways began accepting reservations Monday for a new flight service between Taipei and the Cambodian capital of Phnom Penh scheduled to begin Jan. 19, with three flights operating per week.

An EVA official said that the airline had hoped to open the Taipei-Phnom Penh route four years ago but gave up the plan because of the unstable political situation in the war-torn Southeast Asian country at that time.
After years of negotiations, the official went on, both sides agreed that the Taipei-Phnom Penh air route should be jointly operated by EVA Airways and Cambodia's President Airlines.
In the initial period, the route will be served with 152-seat MD-90 aircraft leased from Taiwan's UNI Airlines. The crews will also be provided by UNI Airlines, the official added.
The three-and-a-half hour flights will depart Taiwan at 8:40 a.m. on Tuesdays, Fridays and Saturdays, with return flights on the evening of the same day.

DOC.HEADLINE: HIGH-RANKING TAIWAN POLICE OFFICERS VISIT MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: A delegation of high-ranking Taiwan police officers arrived in Beijing Monday for a 12-day visit to the mainland.

In an apparent attempt to keep the visit low-profile, Cheng Ching-sung, director of the Criminal Investigation Bureau under the National Police Administration and head of the delegation, would not elaborate on the purpose or the itinerary of the visit.
The delegation is the first of its kind to visit the mainland since the two sides separated following the end of China's civil war in 1949.

As Cheng and his delegation are all specialized in fighting crime, they are expected to meet their mainland counterparts for discussions on issues related to cross-strait cooperation on crime, prevention of organized crime and protection of Taiwan businessmen on the mainland.
Officials with the Taiwan Affairs Office of the Beijing's State Council said that the visit by Cheng's delegation is "unofficial."

After its three-day stay in Beijing, the delegation is expected to proceed to Shanghai and several cities in the southern mainland provinces of Fujian and Guangdong to exchange views with law enforcement officers there.

Member of the delegation include Lo Yi-an, vice president of the Central Police University and Lu Yu-chun, former NPA director-general and chairman of the Criminal Investigation and Prevention Association.

DOC.HEADLINE: KOREAN WOMAN URGES TAIWAN POLICE TO INVESTIGATE RELIGIOUS SEX SCANDAL

TEXT.P: A former follower of a South Korean religious sect who came to Taiwan from South Korea to debunk the sect's founder urged police Monday to investigate her claims that the religious leader sexually abuses his local female followers.
Cheng Myong Suk, the founder of "Jesus Morning Star," has denied all charges through a spokesman.

The Korean woman, who identified herself only as "K," said at a news conference organized by legislator Chin Huei-chu that she is not Cheng's only victim and that there are others in Japan, Singapore, Malaysia and Germany.
She urged the other victims to come forward to relate their own experiences with Cheng.
A number of female sect members in Taipei -- many of whom are college students -- pressed charges against Cheng last month, alleging that he sexually abused them.
Other former sect members in South Korea have formed a group called Exodus to help track down Cheng, who is wanted by Korean law enforcement authorities, according to a CNA report from Seoul.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE TAIPEI LOSES TO SOUTH KOREA IN ASIAN WOMEN'S FOOTBALL

TEXT.P: South Korea beat Chinese Taipei 1-0 in the Group A preliminary round of the 2001 Asian Women's Football Championship in Taipei Monday.
With the loss, Chinese Taipei's hope of entering the Dec. 14 semi-finals among the best four teams have become very slim.
A total of 14 teams are competing in the tournament in three divisions.
The top team from each division qualifies for the semi-finals, while the fourth semi-finalist will be the team with the most goals among the three runners-up in the three divisions.
The only chance for Chinese Taipei to get into the best four will be if Thailand can defeat South Korea in Group A Dec. 12 or if Vietnam can force a tie or beat Japan in a Group B match the same day.
In other games Monday, Thailand downed India 1-0, Vietnam beat Singapore 8-0 and North Korea blanked Japan 1-0.
Preliminary matches for Group C finished Sunday with mainland China ranking first with three wins and no losses. Uzbekistan was second with two wins and one loss.
The standings in Group A and B as of Monday:
Group A -- Chinese Taipei 3-1, Malaysia 0-3, India 0-3, South Korea 3-0 and Thailand 2-1.
Group B -- North Korea 4-0, Guam 0-3, Singapore 0-3, Japan 2-1 and Vietnam 2-1.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BIO-TECH EXHIBITION TO BE HELD IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The Second Taipei International Biotech Exhibition will be held Dec. 15-18 at the Taipei World Trade Center, organizers said Monday.

The bio-tech industry is regarded as a star industry. Unaffected by the recession, the industry is prospering and "every country in the world" has made bio-tech development a top priority, according to the organizers
The Republic of China is no exception and the government has earmarked NT$5 billion per year for the next five years for the industry's local development.

Mainland China, Malaysia, Hong Kong, Vietnam and Japan will send delegations to the exhibition and the mainland delegation, which comprises academics, will study the feasibility of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait cooperating in sci-tech development.
Organizers estimated that there will be over 60,000 visitors to the exhibition, compared with 45,000 visitors to the last bio-tech exhibition held last September.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Dec. 11, or the 27th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1816: The British restore Java, Indonesia, to the Dutch.
1853: Britain annexes Nagpur, one of the leading Mahrata states in India.
1927: The Chinese Communist Party stages a riot in Kwangchow (Canton) which results in massive burning and looting.
1935: The Nationalist government sets up the Hopei-Chahar Political Affairs Commission, with Soong Chih-yuan being appointed as chairman.
1936: George VI becomes King of England following the abdication of Edward VIII.
1941: The United States declares war against Germany and Italy during World War Two.
1951: The Taiwan Provincial Assembly is established, with Huang Chao-chin being elected as speaker.
1961: Two companies of U.S. military helicopters arrive in Saigon on an aircraft carrier, representing the first direct U.S. military support for the South Vietnam regime's battle against communist guerrillas.
1970: Taipei Mayor Henry Kao is impeached by the Control Yuan for breaking the law and for misfeasance.
1972: The U.S. Apollo 17 astronauts land on the moon and begin extensive exploration of the lunar surface.
1973: Maj. Gen. Slade Nash, newly appointed chief of the U.S. Military Assistance Advisory Group, arrives in Taipei to assume office.
1974: The Executive Yuan of the ROC approves the Sino-Ivory Coast Agricultural Development Technical Cooperation Pact.
1974: Ten "outstanding entrepreneurs" of the year are awarded plaques and citations in Taipei.
1976: The opening ceremony of the National Conference on Atmospheric Science is held at the Central Weather Bureau in Taipei with some 100 experts participating.
1976: Eric G. Sandstrong Jr., deputy commander of the Veterans of Foreign Wars of the United States, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1976: Lt. Gen. Kung Ling-cheng becomes head of the National Police Administration and concurrently the director of the Taiwan Provincial Police Department, succeeding Lt. Gen. Chou Chu-tsun.
1977: Kaohsiung County's Hsingta Port, the largest fishing port in Taiwan, is inaugurated and formally opened for use.
1989: Liu Pin-yen, a mainland Chinese writer residing in the United States, arrives in Taipei with his wife for a visit.
1990: Albania announces it will allow the formation of independent political parties.
1991: Leaders of 12 European countries agree to establish a loose federation with a common foreign policy and a single currency by 1999.
1994: Russian troops and armored vehicles roll into Chechnya in a bid to restore Moscow's control over the breakaway region.
1996: Tung Chee-hwa, a shipping magnate, sweeps to victory in the election for Hong Kong's leader-in-waiting to take over when the British colony reverts to Chinese rule.
1998: A Thai Airways Airbus crashes into a flooded rubber plantation, killing 101 people in southern Thailand.
1999: Chinese Taipei wins an across-the-board victory at the Czech Table Tennis Open with both the men and women's teams gaining group singles and group doubles victories.
2000: David Hu, director-general of the South and Central American Affairs Department of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, is confirmed by MOFA to be the new ROC ambassador to Panama.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise man who is not serious will not inspire respect; what he learns will not remain permanent. Make conscientiousness and sincerity your first principles. Have no friends who are not as yourself. When you have bad habits do no hesitate to change them."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Tuesday are as follows:
The China Times:
President Chen urges Beijing to shelve disputes and resume dialogue.
The United Daily News:
Cabinet panel OKs major new changes in retirement plans.
The Liberty Times:
The government may lift the ban on advocating secessionism.
The Taiwan Daily:
Doubts surround President Chen's alliance as attention switches to economic bills.
The Central Daily News:
Legislators voice strong opposition to proposal for partial hikes in National Health Insurance premium.
The China Post:
DPP urged to cease scrounging for opposition allies.
The Taiwan News:
U.S. marines cut off Kandahar escape routes.
The Taipei Times:
Annan says U.N. needs new focus.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG PLANS TO BID FOR RIGHTS TO HOST 2010 ASIAN GAMES: MAYOR
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Dec. 10 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's second largest city, Kaohsiung, plans to bid for the rights to host the 2007 Universiade and the 2010 Asian Games, Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh said Monday during a courtesy call on San Francisco Mayor Willie L. Brown Jr.
Hsieh said his city will cooperate with neighboring cities to host the Asian Games, adding that valuable experience can be gained by first hosting the Universiade.
If Kaohsiung were to win the bid to host the Asian Games, it would mark the largest international sporting event ever to be held in Taiwan.
For Kaohsiung's reference, Brown said that he will provide Hsieh with the complete version of San Francisco's own bidding proposal to host the 2012 Olympic Games.

San Francisco is among eight U.S. cities that are currently in the process of bidding for the 2012 Olympic Games. The U.S. candidate city is scheduled to be named during the October 2002 meeting of the United States Olympic Committee Board of Directors.

Hsieh and Brown also exchanged opinions on such issues as urban and harbor development. Kaohsiung Harbor is the world's fourth-largest container port, and San Francisco Bay is one of the world's largest natural harbors.

Meanwhile, touching on issues related to Taiwan's domestic politics, Hsieh told reporters after his meeting with Brown that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party remains dedicated to the establishment of a "national stabilization alliance" but that it has slowed down the pace to refrain from provoking the opposition parties.
Hsieh serves concurrently as DPP chairman.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES DOWN BY 47.31 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) lost ground on Tuesday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving down 47.31 points to close at 5,273.97.
Market turnover amounted to NT$149.06 billion (US$4.33 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Shares prices opened low and then fluctuated on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 47.31 points to close at 5,273.97.

Affected by a decline in U.S. stock prices, the bourse opened at 5,252.71 and continued to go down due to profit-taking selling pressure before a rebound of certain electronics shares curbed the downward streak. The index fluctuated between 5,322.05 and 5,191.32 during trading.

A total of 5.61 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$149.06 billion (US$4.33 billion), compared with the previous trading session which saw 6.12 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$166.43 billion (US$4.83 billion).
Only one of the eight major stocks categories gained ground, with electrical shares moving up 0.7 percent.

The other major categories posted losses, with bank and insurance shares moving down the most at 4.6 percent, followed by plastics and chemical stocks at 4.3 percent, textile issues and cement stocks, both at 3.6 percent, construction stocks at 3.5 percent, pulp and paper issues at 3 percent, and foodstuff shares at 2 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 389 to 217, with 46 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market were higher on Tuesday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for December moved up 6 points to close at 5,299, with 17,907 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for next January rose 22 points to close at 5,290, with 102 contracts traded. No transactions were reported for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 5,292 for December, 5,268 for next January, 5,275 for next March, 5,289 for next June, and 5,251 for next September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, reported mixed results.
December TE futures rose 4 points to close at 275.9, with 5,888 contract transactions, while next January TE futures increased 7.4 points to finish at 279, with 55 contracts traded.
No transactions were reported for other months.
December TF futures moved down 34 points to finish at 733, with 3,970 contract transactions, while next January TF futures lost 31.2 points to close at 731, with only one contract changing hands.
Next September TF futures decreased 51.6 to finish at 735.2, with only one contract traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWS ALLEGEDLY VIOLATING SPEECH FREEDOM NOT YET DISCUSSED: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Tuesday that the Cabinet has not yet formulated a policy to discuss possible amendments to a number of laws that might violate freedom of speech by banning open discussions on splitting the country.

Chang said while being interpellated by a legislator that the details of the issue will only be discussed when the Ministry of the Interior has reported its findings to the Cabinet. Even then, he went on, any amendments would require ratification by the Legislative Yuan.

Stressing that the Cabinet did not order such amendments to be drafted, Chang said that the issue nevertheless must be discussed and handled solemnly because it was brought to light when two local professors were charged with violating related laws, kindling debate on the constitutional guarantee of freedom of speech.

In a ceremony marking World Human Rights Day on Monday, Chang said that the Cabinet has ordered relevant government agencies to conduct a comprehensive review of current domestic laws to determine whether they violate any international human rights conventions.
According to local reports, government officials said Monday that a number of laws should be evaluated and amended because of certain "outdated" provisions that might run counter to human rights.

Article Four of the Gathering and Parade Law states that public gatherings and parades should not be held to promote communism or a splitting of the country. Article Two of the Civic Organization Law also stipulates that organizations and activities should not be geared toward such causes.

Chang is a member of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, which has traditionally been in favor of forming an independent Taiwan republic, an act that could be construed as "splitting the country" under the previous Kuomintang administration's policy of "one China" which allowed Taipei and Beijing to interpret the term in their own way.
Beijing has repeatedly warned it would attack Taiwan if the island were to move toward independence.

Meanwhile, at the same interpellation session, Chang said that he has ordered relevant government agencies to look into whether the organizers of a cross-Taiwan Strait technology forum sponsored by the National Science Council have violated Cabinet regulations by calling the mainland Chinese participants by their official titles while self-degradingly removing the titles of Taiwan's own participating officials out of fear of angering Beijing.

Chang said that such cross-strait academic meetings must be held under the principles of respect and parity and that organizers must not damage national dignity in the process of holding such meetings.
