DOC.HEADLINE: ROC ROLLS OUT RED CARPET TO WELCOME SAO TOME AND PRINCIPE PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: The Republic of China rolled out the red carpet Tuesday to welcome the arrival of Sao Tome and Principe President Fradique Bandeira Melo de Menezes for a five-day state visit.
President Chen Shui-bian presided over the welcoming ceremony in the National Concert Hall at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall complex in downtown Taipei.

During the ceremony, Menezes was accorded with full military honors, complete with a 21-gun salute. Menezes was elected the West African state's third popularly elected president in a landslide victory in July this year. This is his first visit to Taiwan.
In a brief welcoming speech, President Chen first congratulated Menezes on his election victory. Chen said Menezes is not only a knowledgeable politician but also a successful entrepreneur.
"I admire you for your outstanding contributions to political and economic development in your country," Chen said in his speech.
Despite the geographic distance, Chen said, relations between the ROC and Sao Tome and Principe have continued to grow steadily since the two countries forged formal diplomatic ties in May 1997.

With concerted efforts of the two countries, Chen said bilateral cooperative programs in the fields of agriculture, culture, medicine, education and infrastructure construction have been proceeding smoothly and have borne fruit.
For his part, Menezes said he takes great pleasure in visiting Taiwan and appreciates all the hospitality extended to him and his entourage.
Menezes further expressed his gratitude for the ROC's assistance to his country in agricultural and economic development as well as medical services over the past years.

At the end of the ceremony, Taipei Ma Ying-jeou presented a "key to the city" to Menezes as a souvenir. Vice President Annette Lu and many other senior ROC officials and members of the diplomatic corps also attended the welcoming ceremony.
Later in the day, Menezes paid a visit to the Presidential Office where he held wide-ranging talks with President Chen.

Chen said he looks forward to seeing bilateral exchanges and cooperation further grow based on the current foundation, particularly in agriculture, medical services and industries related to people's livelihood.

Noting that the ROC sent a delegation of political scientists to observe Sao Tome and Principe's July presidential election, Chen said he was pleased to learn that it was a fair, just and credible democratic election.
"This indicates that Sao Tome and Principe is a mature democracy and can be a model for other African countries to emulate," Chen said.

Menezes told President Chen that he admires Taiwan's progress in political democratization and economic prosperity. "I hope my current visit will help strengthen bilateral ties," he said, adding that his country desires to learn from Taiwan's developmental experience to boost its own economic development.

Menezes and his entourage arrived in Taipei Monday. Members of his entourage included Minister of Foreign and Cooperation Affairs Patice Emery Trovocada and Minister of Economic Affairs Julio da Silva.

DOC.HEADLINE: N.T. DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The new Taiwan dollar rose NT$0.001 against the U.S. dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Tuesday, closing at 34.456.
The local currency opened Tuesday at 34.455 and was traded between 34.448 and 34.461.
Interbank U.S. dollar trading totaled US$329 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND AFFAIRS COUNCIL CHIEF LEAVES FOR WASHINGTON

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairperson Tsai Ing-wen was to leave for Washington Tuesday for a three-day tour at the invitation of the Heritage Foundation.

Tsai will report on the Republic of China's policy toward mainland China as the international community is concerned about the development of cross-Taiwan Strait relations in the wake of the Dec. 1 legislative and local elections.

The ruling Democratic Progressive Party emerged as the largest party by winning 87 seats in the 225-seat Legislative Yuan in the elections, while the opposition Kuomintang's seats dropped from 110 to 68.

The People First Party, founded by former KMT Secretary-General James Soong last year, performed well in the elections with a gain of 46 legislative seats. The Taiwan Solidarity Union, supported by former President Lee Teng-hui, collected 13 seats.
The MAC chief will explain Taipei's mainland policy under the new political formation in the legislature and meet with U.S. China experts to exchange views on matters of mutual concern.
Executive Yuan Secretary-General Chiou I-jen and Wu An-chia, an official with the Coordination Council for North American Affairs under the ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs, will go with Tsai.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN LAPTOPS TO SEIZE 70 PERCENT OF WORLD MARKET BY 2005: MIC

TEXT.P: The semi-official Institute for Information Industry's Market Intelligence Center (MIC) predicted Tuesday that the global market share of notebook computers made in Taiwan will reach over 70 percent by 2005.

According to the latest statistics released by the MIC, international orders for Taiwan-made laptops surged in the fourth quarter, allowing the island to ship out a single-season record of over 4 million units for an annual total of 13.966 million units, a 9.9 percent increase from last year.
The MIC predicted that Taiwan-made laptop computers will take up 59 percent of the global market next year, up from this year's 55 percent.

Similar growth is expected in the liquid crystal display (LCD) and digital camera sectors, with the MIC predicting a whopping 88.4 percent growth for LCDs and 36.9 percent growth for digital cameras made in Taiwan in 2002, gradually leading to an 80 percent market share for Taiwan-made LCDs in five years.

Taiwan's NT$130 billion (US$3.77 billion) information software industry on average registered lower-than-expected 12.4 percent growth this year, but the MIC predicted 19.2 percent growth for the industry in 2002.
Meanwhile, the MIC predicted that Taiwan's information appliance industry will grow by 30 percent in 2002 and 40 percent in 2003.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW CHAIRMAN OF KMT'S TAIPEI CITY COMMITTEE ASSUMES DUTIES

TEXT.P: Kuomintang legislator Ting Shou-chung, who failed to be reelected Dec. 1, was appointed Tuesday as the chairman of the KMT's Taipei City Committee.

He replaced Chan Chun-po who stepped down to take responsibility for the KMT's upset in the legislative elections in Taipei City. Of the eight KMT candidates nominated for Taipei City, only four were elected.

The handover ceremony was presided over by KMT Secretary-General Lin Fong-cheng with several KMT leaders witnessing, including Organizational Development Committee Chairman Chen Chien-chih, former Council for Economic Planning and Development Council Chairman P.K. Chiang and Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou.
Lin said that Ting's primary task will be helping the party's candidates to win in next year's elections for mayor and city council members.
He stated that Ma's reelection as Taipei mayor and having the KMT become the largest party in the city council are the primary targets of the party.

Ting said that he will do his best to help the KMT achieve satisfactory gains in next year's elections. (By Victor Lai) EDNITEM ZCZC CEP014 12-11-01 EDUCATORS AND LEGISLATORS PONDER IMPACT OF WORLD CYBER GAMES CHAMP

Taipei, Dec. 11 (CNA) Educators are scratching their heads after Tseng Jeng-cheng, a 17-year-old Taiwanese boy who never bothered to go to high school, won first prize in the World Cyber Games in Seoul, South Korea Dec. 9. Parents fear that the boy's lack of education will be seen by his peers as a badge of honor.

Tseng finished junior high school two years ago. After that, his education consisted mainly of playing video games, a fact that helped him win the top spot in the computer game "Age of Empires 2: The Conquerors," and take home prize money of US$20,000 and NT$650,000.

Since Tseng won recognition with his talent in playing "games," Taiwan society has begun to examine the influence of the "skills" involved and the fact that a player could advance to such a high level without much education.
Even Minister of Education Ovid Tzeng has spoken of including video game-related technology applications in the curriculum of schools.

Video games became a topic of great interest at a meeting of the committee on educational affairs of the Legislative Yuan Monday. Several legislators wondered how to incorporate information technology applications into the existing science-related courses in school, and how to cultivate talents in this field.

Legislator Chen Chin-jun said that the Tseng Jeng-cheng phenomenon exposed the rigidity of Taiwan's educational system. Special talents or interests of students very often are subjugated to stricter disciplines of conformity.
Legislator Wong Chin-chu called on the education ministry to make some adjustments to the school curricula and to accommodate subjects that will interest youths more.

Minister Tseng said that he agreed with the legislators regarding creating a proper educational environment for students with special talents. On the other hand, he stressed the importance for youngsters to learn the basics within the school system. He suggested that the young video champion finish his schooling.

Tseng said after receiving the gold medal in Seoul that he wanted to continue his education. Like Tseng's parents, many other parents were relieved to hear this. Tseng's success in Seoul had worried many educators and parents that this single case might lead some youngsters into believing that they could also forsake their studies and make a name for themselves by simply playing video games.

DOC.HEADLINE: RESEARCHER SAYS BUSINESS CLIMATE TO RECOVER NEXT YEAR

TEXT.P: Despite global economic uncertainties, Taiwan's business climate may recover next year, Taiwan Research Institute President Liu Tai-ying forecast Tuesday.

Speaking at a seminar on economic cooperation in East Asia sponsored by the institute, Liu said although it remains to be seen when the world economy will regain momentum, Taiwan's economy will improve in 2002 after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks against the United States.
According to Liu, Taiwan's hi-tech exports have slumped by 20 percent following the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.

Liu said Taiwan and other East Asian countries rely greatly on the United States for their hi-tech outbound shipments. Sharp declines in the tech-heavy Nasdaq since March 2000 resulted in a global recession and have hugely affected the high-tech industries of those countries, he added.

Although the United States has cut its interests rates many times, Liu said it remains uncertain when the global economy will recover. It has been forecast that East Asian economies, including Japan, Singapore and Hong Kong will register negative growth for this year. Taiwan is expected to post a negative 2 percent economic growth.

In face of the global economic sluggishness and fierce competition from mainland China, Liu contended that most East Asian countries have to boost demand at home and seek cooperation with other countries to sustain their economies. At the same time, currency stability and a sound financial system are also key issues in economic cooperation between East Asian countries, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOV'T TO STUDY SEMICONDUCTOR SECTOR'S INVESTMENTS IN M'LAND CHINA

TEXT.P: The Investment Commission under the Ministry of Economic Affairs will convene a meeting Thursday to study whether to allow local semiconductor manufacturers to invest in eight-inch wafer fabs in mainland China.
John C.C. Teng, vice chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), said Tuesday that the council has no predisposition over whether to relax the restrictions.
He said that government and industry representatives are expected to reach conclusions at the meeting.

The semiconductor sector is strongly in favor of further relaxation of investment restrictions. The Taiwan Semiconductor Industry Association has proposed to allow investments in eight-inch wafer fabs and the IC design sector in mainland China.

Yu Ting-hua, chairman of Macronix International Co., said Tuesday that he believes that the government will soon give permission to eight-inch wafer fab investments in mainland China. Macronix President Min Wu said that his company was very interested in the investment environment in Soochow in coastal Jiangsu province.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST ROC AID SHIPMENT TO AFGHAN REFUGEES LEAVES WEDNESDAY

TEXT.P: The first batch of relief goods donated by the Republic of China government and private charitable groups to Afghan refugees will be delivered Wednesday, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Tuesday.

The relief goods include 90,000 pieces of second-hand clothing donated by the Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Foundation, 940 pairs of sneakers donated by the Field Relief Agency, NT$300,000 (US$8,695.65) worth of pharmaceuticals donated by the Taiwan Pharmaceutical Industry Association as well as 14,000 blankets and pharmaceuticals donated by the ROC government.
MOFA Chief Secretary Peter Cheng said the relief goods will be shipped to Iran from the northern Taiwan port of Keelung Tuesday and are scheduled to arrive at their final destination Dec. 24

According to Cheng, the ROC government and private charities will donate NT$110 million worth of relief goods and cash in two batches to help Afghan people displaced by the ongoing U.S.-led anti-terrorist strikes on the Taliban regime in Afghanistan.

"The donations are expected to benefit 6,300 Afghan families," Cheng said, adding that the government will continue coordinating with private organizations in offering humanitarian aid to Afghan refugees.
Cheng said the government will also seek to cooperate with international disaster relief organizations in helping Afghan people.

In addition, Cheng said, MOFA is keeping a close watch on an upcoming meeting of representatives from the 15-member European Union, the United States, Japan and other major countries on possible long-term financial aid to Afghanistan in the wake of the downfall of the Taliban regime.
"We may refer to the conclusions reached at the planned meeting in drawing up our future aid program for Afghan refugees," Chen said.

He further said the ROC's relief goods will be distributed to Afghan refugee camps in Mashad in the north and Zahendan in the south through the Iranian chapter of the International Red Crescent Society, the only non-government organization authorized by the Iranian government and the Taliban regime to conduct relief and aid activities in Afghanistan.
Meanwhile, Cheng said, the ROC will take part in an aid program to assist Afghan children, organized by a U.S.-based international charitable group.

"We'll offer humanitarian assistance to 10,000 displaced Afghan households in northern Afghanistan through the U.S.-based organization," Cheng said, adding that under this project, the ROC will donate 240 tons of rice, 250 tents and 76,000 blankets, worth NT$87.76 million.
Moreover, Cheng said, the ROC government will offer US$200,000 in cash to help finance the organization's various rescue and relief projects.

Cheng said Chiang Kuo-chiang, director of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Seattle, will sign a memorandum of understanding with the U.S. charitable organization in the near future on the relief cooperation.
The government will foot the bill for shipping the relief goods to Afghan refugees, which is estimated at NT$8.4 million, Chen added.

DOC.HEADLINE: STATE-RUN TAISALT MAKES EFFORTS TO PROMOTE SALES IN U.S. MARKET
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Dec. 10 (CNA) (By C. S. Chu and Ed Chen)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan state-run Taiwan Salt Industrial Corp. (Taisalt) is hoping that its new products will enable the company to make inroads into the U.S. market, a senior Taisalt official said in Los Angeles Monday.

Yu Kuang-hua, chairman of the Taiwan Salt Industrial Corp., said at a news conference that the company's four new products will be introduced into the U.S. market through supermarkets operated by overseas Chinese. The products are face-cleaning lotion, shampoo, body lotion and toothpaste.
Taisalt products will be introduced into the U.S. market through its more than 100 agents around the United States, he said.
Yu also said that Taisalt will tap the mainland Chinese market after its operations in the United States have been developed.
Taisalt is expected to be privatized next July, Yu said, adding that the company will strengthen its research and development program to develop more products.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT DIALOGUE MAY RESUME NEXT YEAR: MAC CHIEF

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen said Tuesday she foresees the possibility of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait resume dialogue next year.
Tsai made the remarks during a meeting with a delegation of the "Committee of 100," a New York-based non-partisan association of ethnic Chinese celebrities.

Noting that President Chen Shui-bian has on many occasions expressed goodwill to mainland China, Tsai said so long as Beijing leaders can carefully mull the significance of Chen's statements on cross-strait affairs, particularly the "one China" issue, there should be opportunities for the two sides to resume talks.

"It all depends on how mainland China interprets President Chen's latest remarks on cross-strait relations and how the two sides cultivate an environment favorable for resumption of their long-stalled dialogue," Tsai explained.

While meeting with the "Committee of 100" delegation Monday, President Chen said "one China" is an issue that can be discussed in the future with mainland China. However, Chen said "one China" should not be a precondition for talks until such time as Taipei and Beijing have reached a mutually acceptable meaning for the the term through "wisdom and creativity."

Chen also told the visiting members of the overseas Chinese group that the so-called "one China" was originally not a problem according to the Republic of China Constitution. The problem, he went on, is that the so-called "one China" principle cherished by Beijing "makes the Republic of China vanish." Therefore, as a guardian of the ROC sovereignty, dignity and security, he cannot accept the principle.
Tsai said cross-strait dialogue is not expected to resume overnight.
"The two sides must forge mutual trust and work out certain procedures to ensure that talks are conducted on a solid basis," Tsai noted.

In her view, Tsai said, both sides have been endeavoring to prevent the results of Taiwan's recent parliamentary and local government chief elections from affecting the stability of cross-strait relations.

Tsai said although the spokesman for mainland China's Taiwan Affairs Office failed to give any positive response to Taiwan's goodwill in his first post-Taiwan election news conference, he appeared to be fully aware of the importance of maintaining stability in the Taiwan Strait.

The nation's top mainland policy planner also assured her guests that the government's policy toward mainland China will remain unchanged after the ruling Democratic Progressive Party emerged from the recent legislative elections as the island's largest party in the Legislative Yuan for the first time.
Tsai left for the United States Tuesday evening to brief American scholars and politicians on Taiwan's political situation and policy direction in the wake of the Dec. 1 elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: 30 PEOPLE RESCUED ON UNDERSEA CABLE OPERATION PLATFORM

TEXT.P: Thirty-two men were airlifted off an offshore platform that came unmoored as they were working to lay an undersea NHK communications cable near the mouth of Tamsui River, northern Taiwan, early Tuesday morning, according to the rescue center involved.

The Cabinet-level Taipei Rescue Coordination Center (TRCC) said Tuesday in a news release that 32 engineers and technicians working to prepare the way for an undersea cable belonging to the Japanese network NHK were in danger after the platform they were on broke from its undersea anchor and began to be tossed by waves around 2 a.m. Tuesday.
The National Coast Guard Administration sent patrol boats to the area but strong winds and high waves prevented them from transferring the workers to their vessels.

The coast guard then asked for the help of the TRCC, which sent a military rescue S-70C-6 helicopter and successfully picked up 30 of the workers at 5:25 a.m. Two were left on the platform to secure machinery.
The TRCC said the 30 were engineers from Japan, France, Singapore, Malaysia and Indonesia.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, SINGAPORE REACH AGREEMENTS ON ECONOMIC COOPERATION

TEXT.P: Taiwan and Singapore reached various agreements on two-way economic cooperation at an annual ministerial meeting which ends Tuesday.

According to information provided by the Taiwan delegation from Singapore, agreements reached by Republic of China Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Hsin-yi and his Singapore counterpart are as follows:
-- The two countries will assist each other to explore trade and investment opportunities in other countries;
-- Promote reciprocal recognition of approval certificates for electronics products from either side;
-- Promote bilateral cooperation in desalination and recycling of waste water;
-- Enhance two-way cooperation in the financial, sea and air traffic and distribution industries; and
-- Strengthen exchanges of data on trade, investment and economic statistics, including with mainland China and Southeast Asian countries.
Traveling at the head of a 16-member delegation, Lin left for Singapore Sunday to attend the meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: WHITE-COLLAR UNEMPLOYMENT SURGING

TEXT.P: Taiwan's rising joblessness has spread to the white-collar sector, with executive unemployment in October surging to a record high of 2.54 percent, according to a recent newspaper report.

Citing statistics compiled by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics, the China Times report said Monday that the ratio represents a growth of 1.01 percentage points over the January level. It also said that the job vacancy rate for executives had reached around 9.98 percent and called this an indication that there is a gap between demand and supply in the sector.

According to www.CTCareer.com.tw, a local executive research Website, middle-aged job seekers accounted for 26 percent of those searching for jobs on the Internet. Around 40 percent of the job opportunities offered for executives were in mainland China and those aged over 45 were said to have little chance of getting an interview.

One manager at a consulting company claimed that the chances of executives aged over 50 getting a foot in the door on a job search are only 10 percent of the chances in the past. He said more than 50 percent of new jobs are in mainland China -- mainly in the hi-tech manufacturing sector -- and that new job opportunities for middle- and high-level executives are few in Taiwan.
According to www.104.com.tw, another job-related Website, middle-aged job seekers have to wait at least three months for a new job and it is more difficult for them to change their professions.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONTROL YUAN IMPEACHES FORMER HEAD OF NAT'L POLICE ADMINISTRATION

TEXT.P: The Control Yuan, the nation's highest watchdog body, Tuesday impeached Ting Yuan-chin, former director -general of the National Police Administration, for filing a fraudulent report on payments for a luxury house.

Chao Jung-yao, a member of the Control Yuan, said that Ting also dishonestly reported his property holdings to the Control Yuan in 1997 and 1999 in accordance with the Public Functionary Assets Disclosure Law.
The case will be submitted to the Committee on the Discipline of Public Functionaries for further handling, Chao said.
The Control Yuan subcommittee on screening impeachable cases approved the proposal made by Control Yuan members Chao Jung-yao and Lee Shen-I.

Chao said that Ting told a Control Yuan task force investigating the case that he had borrowed NT$20 million from a friend, surnamed Lin , and had sold his own house in downtown Taipei for NT$8 million. Ting's son gave his father NT$6 million to help buy a new house on Chunkung Road, Wenshan district, Taipei. Ting's wife put in NT$2 million.
The investigating team found, however, that Ting could not explain the source of NT$10 million from Singapore discovered in one of Ting's accounts, Chao said.
Meanwhile, Ting has refused to make any comments on the Control Yuan's impeachment proceedings.
Ting said that he has been serving the nation for more than 30 years and he believed that he is a law-abiding and God-fearing public functionary.
He said he has already explained clearly about the source of the money he paid for his new house in surbuban Taipei when he was summoned by the Control Yuan members.

DOC.HEADLINE: CSC MULLS ESTABLISHING OVERSEAS MILLS

TEXT.P: The China Steel Corp. (CSC) is mulling the feasibility of setting up large mills overseas to sharpen its competitiveness, the Industrial Development Bureau reported Tuesday.

The bureau said CSC is studying the possibility of establishing steel mills in mainland China, Indonesia, Malaysia and Vietnam, rather than in the yet-to-be built Pinnan Industrial Park in southern Tainan County.

Although the bureau said it had not been officially notified of the change in plan, it noted that the information it has received shows that the CSC may be abandoning its original plan because the development plan of the Pinnan Industrial Park remains uncertain due to rising environmental protection awareness and the recession.
According to the bureau, it is vital for the CSC to set up large mills if it wants to maintain its competitiveness in the face of the prevailing trend of mergers in Japan and the United States.
Taiwan produces 16 million metric tons of raw steel per year but still has to import 8 million metric tons to satisfy local demand, the bureau noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-BASED CHARITY DISTRIBUTES WINTER COATS TO POOR IN N.Y.
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Dec. 10 (CNA) (By Eric Tseng and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: The New York branch of the Buddhist Compassionate Relief Tzu Chi Foundation, a Taiwan-based charity organization, has begun distributing winter coats to poor people in New York City, foundation sources reported Tuesday.

On Sunday, some 40 Tzu Chi volunteers sent more than 1,000 winter coats donated by the public to the Lower East Side of Manhattan for distribution to the poor of the area, where they received a warm welcome, the sources said.
Tzu Chi plans to have another distribution session Dec. 16 in Brooklyn and a third Dec. 22 in Chinatown.

DOC.HEADLINE: BIO-TECH EXHIBITIONS TO KICK OFF IN TAIPEI DEC. 15

TEXT.P: The Second Taipei International Biotechnology Fair and Bio Taipei 2001 will be held simultaneously Dec. 15-18 at the Taipei World Trade Center, organizers said Tuesday.

The biotech industry, unaffected by the world recession, has prospered, with "all countries" regarding it as a star industry, according to Chan Chao International Co., one of the organizers of the exhibition.
The Republic of China government regards the biotech industry as a top priority and is to budget NT$5 billion (US$145 million) per year over the next five years for the development of the industry.
The organizers estimated that the Second Taipei International Biotechnology Fair is expected to attract more than 60,000 visitors, an increase of 33 percent from last year.

In view of the success of last year's exhibition, many biotech research and development institutions in Taiwan are very keen to participate in this year's fair, the organizers added, while companies from the United States, Germany, Russia, South Korea and mainland China will also send delegations to the show, the biggest of its kind in Asia.
In Bio Taipei 2001, the Taipei city government will focus on biotech education, searching for biotech talent for local enterprises and soliciting foreign investment in Taiwan's biotech industry.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI URGES ESTABLISHMENT OF CROSS-STRAIT WAR-PREVENTION MECHANISM

TEXT.P: Republic of China Minister of National Defense Wu Shih-wen urged Tuesday the establishment of a mechanism to prevent war across the Taiwan Strait.

Speaking in Taipei at the International Symposium on National Security and Military Strategy organized by the National Defense University, Wu said that it is not easy to break the stalemate between Taiwan and mainland China, mainly because of political factors and the lack of mutual understanding and trust.
Under these circumstance, he said, the two sides should learn from the experiences of European countries and set up a mutually acceptable mechanism to prevent conflict.
"This would be to the benefit of the people on either side of the Taiwan Strait," said Wu.

He said that the ROC armed forces have sufficient strength to protect the country and the people, as mainland China still refuses to renounce use of military force against Taiwan, but he added that the measures taken by some Western countries to prevent conflict could also be borrowed.
He further said that through the promotion of research and discussion by scholars, the two sides of the Taiwan Strait would be able to build up mutual trust.

Regarding Japan's recent move to enact a new law empowering the government to dispatch forces abroad to help the U.S. forces against the Taliban regime in Afghanistan, Wu said this indicates that Japan, to some extent, is attempting to increase its influence in the Asian region and even the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEXUAL HARASSMENT SUIT FILED AGAINST SECT LEADER

TEXT.P: Members and officials of South Korea's "Jesus Morning Star" sect traded accusations Tuesday at the Taipei District Court following accusations last month that sect founder Cheng Myong Suk has sexually abused some of his female followers.

Huang Ching-yuan, a Taiwan spokesman for the sect, filed a suit against Kim Do Hyong, a Seoul resident and ex-follower of Cheng, Wang Yun-ting, a director of the "Religious Purification Promotion Association," and two others for "groundless accusations" against Cheng.
Shang Chieh-mei, chairwoman of the "Religious Purification Promotion Association" meanwhile filed a lawsuit against Huang and Cheng for defamation and sexual harassment.

Shang also urged Cheng's local female followers who have been abused to come forward and stand together with two Korean women who came to Taiwan to tell how they were sexually abused by Cheng in Korea before he fled to Taiwan to escape a police investigation. (By Edward Chen)

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. ANALYST SEES LITTLE CHANCE OF REOPENED CROSS-STRAIT TALKS
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Dec. 10 (CNA) (By Jennifer Huang & Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: A U.S. analyst of China affairs said in New York Monday that there is little chance of Beijing resuming talks with Taiwan, despite the fact that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) made significant gains in the recent legislative elections.

Andrew J. Nathan, professor at the Graduate School of East Asian Studies at Columbia University, noted that it seems impossible that Beijing will make major concessions on cross-strait issues and added that the differences between the two sides remain great.

He said Beijing is unlikely to resume bilateral negotiations with Taiwan -- which have been stalled since the second half of 1999 -- as doing so would have a favorable effect on Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian's 2004 re-election bid.

Nathan visited Taiwan for one week to observe the campaigns for the Dec. 1 legislative and local elections through the arrangement of his student Hsiao Bi-khim, a legislator elected in the Dec. 1 elections to represent the DPP from among the overseas Chinese candidates.

Some analysts have said that the sharp increase in the number of legislative seats held by the DPP will increase the chance of Chen's re-election in 2004, but Nathan disagreed, pointing out that Taiwan's economy remains unpredictable while the DPP's support is only between 35 percent and 39 percent.

The power of the pan-blue alliance cannot be underestimated, he went on, especially if People First Party Chairman James Soong (a former KMT secretary-general) or Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou of the Kuomintang decide to run for the presidency in 2004.
He further predicted that Beijing will continue taking steps to exert pressure on Chen and the Taiwan people.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING OFFICIAL MEETS WITH VISITORS FROM KINMEN, MATSU
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Dec. 11 (CNA) (By Liu Cheng-ching & Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: Newly elected county magistrates and legislators from Kinmen and Matsu met Tuesday in Beijing with Li Bingcai, deputy director of the Taiwan Affairs Office under the State Council, to discuss exchanges between the mainland and the two Taiwan-controlled islands.

The visitors are legislators Tsao Yuan-chang and Wu Cheng-tien, Lienchiang County Magistrate Chen Hsueh-sheng and Kinmen County Magistrate Lee Chu-feng and their trip was approved by the Mainland Affairs Council.

Beijing reportedly agreed to accept a proposal to shorten the time for presenting applications to the mainland authorities before the departure of Xiamen-bound ships from Kinmen or Matsu from present 20 days.

The mainland side is also considering allowing the operation of regular shipping services between the two islands and the mainland following the implementation by Taiwan in January of direct trade, postal and transport links between the two islands and the mainland.
Beijing has until now refused to reciprocate on the links, so that all sailings must be approved on a case-by-case basis.

DOC.HEADLINE: 4 SENIOR ROC OFFICIALS LEAVE FOR U.S

TEXT.P: A delegation of four senior Republic of China officials left Tuesday for the United States to brief U.S. officials on the post-election political situation in Taiwan.

The delegation comprised Executive Yuan Secretary-General Chiou I-jen, Presidential Office Deputy Secretary-General Eugene Chien, Mainland Affairs Council Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen, and Wu An-chia, a member of the Coordination Council for North American Affairs (CCCA).
Chiou told reporters prior to departing that he will visit Washington, D.C. at the invitation of the Washington Press Club, where he will deliver a keynote speech and answer questions.
He said he will also exchange views with U.S. officials on political developments in Taiwan in the wake of the Dec. 1 legislative elections.

Tsai, who was invited by the Heritage Foundation, a U.S. think tank, said she will explain Taipei's mainland policy under the new political situation and will meet with U.S. China-watchers to exchange views on matters of mutual concern.

DOC.HEADLINE: HONG KONG DOTCOM TO BUY TAIWAN PUBLISHING COMPANY
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Dec. 11 (CNA) (By Mandy Wong and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: A Hong Kong Internet company backed by tycoon Li Ka-shing said Tuesday that it will buy Taiwan's Business Weekly Publishing Inc. for HK$370 million (US$47.5 million).

The acquisition by Tom.com is another example of a Hong Kong enterprise participating in Taiwan's publishing sector after Jimmy Lai began publishing Next magazine in Taiwan last year. The move is expected to increase the already tense competition between the two Hong Kong entrepreneurs.
Li and Lai compete in a number of industries -- from supermarkets to media -- in Hong Kong.
According to the agreement, Tom.com will pay HK$185 million in cash and about HK$92.6 million in shares for the publishing company.
The remainder will be settled by the issue of new shares upon the listing of Tom.com's print media.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO SELL 24.93 MILLION MOBILE PHONES NEXT YEAR

TEXT.P: Taiwan has delivered 12.89 million mobile phones to clients so far this year, an increase of 33.8 percent over last year, according to statistics released Tuesday by the Institute for Information Industry (III).
The III estimated that the total for 2002 will be 24.93 million, an increase of 93.4 percent from this year.
The III estimated Taiwan's cellular phone production value this year at US$857 million, a growth of 11.2 percent from last year.
However, it predicted that production value next year will register a significant growth of 88.3 percent to reach US$1.614 billion.

It based its forecast on the premise that the global economy is expected to begin a recovery and that the market share of the high profile GPRS (general packet radio service) cellular phones will account for a certain proportion of the market.

III adviser Wu Hsien-tung said that because of the global recession, Taiwan's cellular phone deliveries in the first half of this year stood at just 4.474 million with a value of US$369 million, up 7.5 percent and 7 percent from the respective figures of the same period of last year, respectively.

Due to the fall of OEM prices, production value in the second half of this year only reached US$488 million, an increase of 32.25 percent from the first half of the year and a growth of 14.6 percent from a year earlier, according to the III statistics.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT THANKS TAIWAN FOR RELIEF SUPPORT AFTER SEPT. 11 ATTACKS

TEXT.P: Acting Director Joseph R. Donovan of the American Institute in Taiwan's Taipei Office Tuesday expressed its appreciation to Taiwan for the relief provided to the United States after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks on New York and Washington, D.C.

"Americans living in Taiwan, and indeed many Americans in the United States, have been greatly heartened by the support shown by friends in Taiwan for both the victims of the Sept. 11 attacks and the ongoing fight against terror," Donovan said in a ceremony marking the three-month anniversary of the event.

"We are especially thankful to the Taiwan Red Cross, the Tzu Chi Foundation and the Taiwan government for their outpouring of support," he said, adding that public and the private sectors here have donated more than US$9.1 million in humanitarian assistance to the relatives of the 911 victims and to Afghan refugees.

He said that the Republic of China government has also rendered its "unswerving support" in the U.S. efforts to combat terrorism, especially in acting promptly and thoroughly to close loopholes in the banking system through which money to fund terrorists could be funneled.
AIT reprsents U.S. in Taiwan in the absence of formal relations between the two nations.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Dec. 12, or the 28th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1642: Abel Yasman, a Dutch navigator, discovers New Zealand.
1787: Pennsylvania becomes the second state of the United States.
1804: Spain declares war on Britain.
1894: Japanese troops invade Korea.
1901: Italian physicist Marchese Guglielmo Marconi completes his first trans-Atlantic wireless radio transmission.
1906: The German company Telefunken successfully tests a wireless telephone.
1915: Yuan Shih-kai, the provisional president of the Republic of China who promised to establish a republican government, proclaims himself emperor.
1932: The ROC resumes diplomatic relations with the Soviet Union.
1936: Chang Hsueh-liang's troops mutiny in Xian and hold Chiang Kai-shek and other ranking ROC government officials hostage.
1937: Japanese planes bomb and sink a U.S. warship in the Yangtze River in China, straining relations between Japan and the United States.
1941: The "Taiwan Revolutionary Alliance" is set up in Chungking and issues a statement urging all compatriots to unite against Japanese aggression.
1946: The ROC Ministry of the Interior rebuilds a national boundary monument at its southernmost boundary in the Nansha (Spratly) Islands.
1959: The "Hai Ming" freighter of China Merchants Steam Navigation Co. begins plying a route between Taiwan and the east coast of the United States, becoming the first Chinese ship to sail the route.
1971: Yiu Mi-chien, who was known as "the father of Taiwan's tourism industry," dies in Taipei at the age of 74.
1972: The Taipei City Council adopts a resolution on the establishment of sisterhood relations with Guam.
1972: The Sino-Guatemalan agricultural technical cooperation agreement is put into effect.
1975: Premier Chiang Ching-kuo declares that the ROC will become a nation of heavy industry after the completion of the "Ten Basic Construction Projects."
1979: Maj. Gen. Chun Doo-hwan and his colleagues stage an army coup and seize power in South Korea.
1982: The ROC wins a high proportion of medals, including 4 golds and 16 others as well as a special prize, at the 31st World Fair for Inventions held Dec. 4-12 in Brussels.
1984: An extradition treaty between the ROC and the Republic of Costa Rica is signed, the first such treaty signed by the ROC.
1991: Boris Yeltsin wins landslide approval in the Russian Parliament for his new Commonwealth of Independent States.
1992: Major earthquakes kill 2,500 people on Flores Island in eastern Indonesia.
1994: The Lien Chan Cabinet is re-organized, and new Cabinet members are sworn in three days later.
1995: The Association of Southeast Asian Nations passes a resolution to implement a treaty to set up a non-nuclear zone.
1999:A four-member delegation led by Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng departs for Panama to attend a forum of presidents of legislative assemblies of the ROC and Central American countries.
2000: Legislator Shih Ming-teh, a former chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, takes the helm of an association of lawmakers to promote relations between the Republic of China and the United States.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise and good man, in the matter of food, should never seek to indulge his appetite; in lodging, he should not be too solicitous of comfort. He should be diligent in business and careful in speech. He should seek the company of men of virtue and learning in order to profit by their lessons and example. In this way, he may become a man of real culture."

DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Wednesday are as follows:

New legislators, city mayors and county magistrates will be eligible to recommend major public construction projects.

The Taipei Times:

DOC.HEADLINE: FARMING PRODUCTION TO SHRINK US $ 715.94 MILLION AFTER WTO ENTRY

TEXT.P: Council of Agriculture Chairman Chen Hsi-huang said Wednesday that Taiwan's agricultural production will decline an estimated NT$24.7 billion (US$715.94 million) in the first year of its accession to the World Trade Organization (WTO).

Fielding questions at a meeting of the Legislative Yuan's Economic Affairs Committee, Chen said the agricultural sector will bear the brunt of possible fallout from the island's WTO entry at the beginning of next year.

According to the COA's estimate, Chen said, sales reductions resulting from the mandatory market opening following the WTO entry would cause a decrease of at least NT$24.7 billion in agricultural production in 2002.
To cope with the anticipated challenges, Chen said the COA has set up three funds to help local farmers tide over their difficulties.

Due to the government's financial straits, Chen said, the COA only sets aside a budget of NT$2.3 billion in fiscal 2002 for helping farmers victimized by an anticipated influx of cheap foreign agricultural products in the wake of the island's WTO accession.
Nevertheless, Chen said the Cabinet has promised to offer additional funds if the budget is used up.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES UP BY 265.34 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) gained ground on Wednesday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving up 265.34 points to close at 5,539.31.
Market turnover amounted to NT$167.52 billion (US$4.86 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: QUEBEC SUPREME COURT ORDERS NEWSPAPER TO STOP SLANDERING FALUNG GONG

TEXT.P: In an unprecedented move, Quebec's Superior Court on Monday ordered a Montreal-based Chinese language newspaper to stop publishing and circulating anti-Falun Gong hate messages.

Judge Danielle Grenier ordered Bing He of the weekly Les Presses Chinoises not to cause to be published or circulated material either written by her or provided by any other source that slanders Falun Gong, its founder or its practitioners.
The court warned that failure to comply with the judgment could result in penalties and sanctions provided by law.

Last Thursday, Falun Gong practitioners in Canada began their first legal action to stop the circulation of hate literature after what they termed slanderous articles began to appear in the Montreal Chinese-language newspaper Nov. 3, 2001.

Yumin Yang, a spokesman for Montreal Falun Gong practitioners, alleged that the weekly carried articles by Bing He as well as other messages, in the form of advertisements or editorials, that included "extremely base and vicious" language aimed at defaming and attacking Falun Gong, a practice of meditation and exercise with teachings of the universal principle of "Truthfulness-Compassion-Tolerance."

The accused newspaper, published every Saturday, is circulated in Montreal and Ottawa as well as on the Internet. The alleged hate literature appearing in Les Presses Chinoises repeats language used by the Communist Chinese government to demonize Falun Gong and justify its two and a half-year-long persecution of Falun Gong practitioners in China.
While the case is still in progress, the court's Safeguard Order in the preliminary hearing Monday signified an initial success for the practitioners in their legal action.

Canadian practitioners said the mainland Chinese government has been waging a smear campaign both on the mainland and abroad to justify its crackdown. They said the Chinese Embassy and Consulates in Canada have been inciting hate toward Falun Gong by sending defamatory material to officials at all levels of government in Canada. (S.C. Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high and closed even higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 265.34 points to close at 5,539.31.

Encouraged by the latest U.S. interest rate cut, the bourse opened at 5,333.73 and continued to go up due to a strong rebound in electronics shares. The index fluctuated between 5,553.89 and 5,333.73 during trading.

A total of 5.65 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$167.52 billion (US$4.86 billion), compared with the previous trading session which saw 6.61 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$149.06 billion (US$4.33 billion).

All of the eight major stocks categories gained ground, with plastics and chemical shares moving up the most at 5.9 percent, followed by electrical stocks at 5.3 percent, bank and insurance shares at 4.6 percent, textile issues at 4.5 percent, cement stocks and construction shares, both at 4.1 percent, foodstuff shares at 2.6 percent, and pulp and paper issues at 2.1 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 613 to 20, with 24 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market were higher Wednesday as Taiwan Stocks Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for December moved up 351 points to close at 5,649, with 21,496 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for next January rose 334 points to close at 5,624, with 443 contract transactions, while next March futures surged 369 points to finish at 5,650, with 9 contracts traded.
Next June futures gained 355 points to close at 5,650, with two contracts traded, while next September futures increased 366 points to finish at 5,623, with two contracts changing hands.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 5,298 for December, 5,290 for next January, 5,281 for next March, 5,295 for next June, and 5,257 for next September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also higher.
December TE futures moved up 19.3 points to close at 295.2, with 6,243 contract transactions, while next January TE futures increased 17.1 points to finish at 296.1, with 215 contracts traded.
Next March TE futures rose 19.3 points to close at 297, with only one contract traded, while next September TE futures gained 18.85 points to finish at 288.45, also with one contract changing hands.
No transactions were reported for other months.
December TF futures moved up 39 points to finish at 772, with 5,078 contract transactions, while next January TF futures surged 41.2 points to close at 772.2, with 73 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC DEFENSE MINISTER TO VISIT NEW YORK'S CHINATOWN
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Dec. 11 (CNA) (By David Wang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Defense Minister Wu Shih-wen is scheduled to arrive in New York Sunday for a transit stop on his way home after an official visit to the Dominican Republic, an ROC diplomatic ally in the Caribbean region.

Wu will be the first incumbent ROC defense minister allowed to set foot on U.S. soil since the late President Chiang Ching-kuo made a visit to the United States during his stint as the minister of national defense.

During his one-night transit stopover, Wu will visit Chinatown and meet with Chinese community leaders in the New York area. Major overseas Chinese organizations will jointly host a luncheon in honor of Wu at a Chinatown restaurant Sunday.
Wu will leave New York for Taipei Sunday evening.

Because of the absence of bilateral diplomatic ties, the U.S. government has traditionally banned visits by incumbent ROC defense ministers. But the U.S. government has allowed visits by the ROC's chief of the General Staff as it views the military chief as a service member rather than a politician.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BUSINESSPEOPLE CAUTIONED AGAINST HIGH HOPES FOR M'LAND MARKET

TEXT.P: Taiwan businesspeople interested in investing in mainland China have been warned against having expectations that are too high regarding the advantages of mainland China's admission into the World Trade Organization (WTO).

Chen Ping, a businessman-turned-writer with several best sellers on mainland China's business opportunities, said that the Beijing authorities need to revise at least 2,300 laws and regulations to meet the WTO requirements.
He said that many Taiwan businesspeople have found that one of the biggest challenges in doing business in mainland China is figuring out the ambiguous laws and regulations.

Taiwan businesspeople are likely to meet even more severe competition from foreign investors in mainland China who have shown increasing enthusiasm in that marketplace following Beijing's admission into the WTO, according to Chen.

In the past years, Taiwan manufacturers have helped mainland China's manufacturing industry boost its production capabilities. Mainland China-made industrial products, ranging from low-end bicycles to high-end electronic products, have been very competitive in the international market.
However, Chen said, many Taiwan businesspeople in mainland China have found their mainland Chinese counterparts fearful.

Day Sheng-tong, chairman of the National Association of Small & Medium Enterprises, also expressed his concern that Taiwan manufacturers who have moved their product processing lines to mainland China will meet strong competition from their mainland Chinese counterparts when Beijing succeeds in upgrading its industrial structure.

Day said that 75 percent of the world's umbrellas were manufactured in Taiwan 10 years ago but that now 75 percent are manufactured on the mainland by Taiwan businesspeople. He pointed out that 10 years ago, a dozen umbrellas cost US$23, but now only costs US$8, saying that this example shows that Taiwan manufacturers must devise ways to increase their competitiveness.
Day called on Taiwan manufacturers to learn from the experiences of those businesspeople who have operated businesses on the other side of the Taiwan Strait for more than a decade.

DOC.HEADLINE: HONG KONG DOTCOM ACQUIRES TAIWAN PUBLISHING COMPANY

TEXT.P: Internet and media firm tom.com Ltd. and Taiwan's Business Weekly Publishing Inc. have reached agreement that tom.com will purchase the magazine group's equity interest for NT$1.65 billion, a company spokesman said Wednesday.
Tom.com will pay half in cash, one quarter in tom.com stock and the rest with stocks of Newco, a new company formed by PC Home, Cite Publishing and tom.com.

The spokesman said that the acquisition will enable tom.com to build the largest Chinese print media platform in Greater China. Tom.com has already acquired two other leading publishing groups in Taiwan this year -- PC Home and Cite Publishing.

A joint venture between Hong Kong's Hutchison Whampoa Ltd. and Cheung Kong (Holdings) Ltd., tom.com is adopting a cross-media strategy, with emphasis on four business segments -- print media, Internet portals, sports marketing and outdoor media.
The spokesman said that the management team will be made up of experts and specialists from Hong Kong and from both sides of the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC VICE PRESIDENT TO VISIT GAMBIA NEXT WEEK

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs Tien Hung-mao confirmed Wednesday that Vice President Annette Lu will leave for The Gambia next Tuesday to attend the West African state's presidential inauguration on behalf of President Chen Shui-bian.

Tien told lawmakers at a Legislative Yuan committee meeting that the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) has not arranged for Lu to visit any other Republic of China allies in West Africa during her trip.

On her way home, she will have to make a transit stop in a West European country, but as the country does not maintain formal diplomatic ties with the ROC, Tien said, some technical problems have yet to be resolved. He did not identify the country in question.
"As a result, Lu's itinerary has not yet been fully finalized," Tien said, adding that the MOFA will keep Lu's whole travel schedule simple.
According to the MOFA plans, Tien said, Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Chiu Jung-nan will accompany Lu on her Gambia visit, along with an entourage of fewer than 20 people.
Two ROC Central American allies -- Nicaragua and Honduras -- will also hold presidential inaugurations next month, one in early January and the other in late January.
Tien said MOFA and other relevant government authorities have yet to decide whether to let Lu attend those ceremonies on Chen's behalf.

DOC.HEADLINE: MICROSOFT ANNOUNCES THREE COOPERATION PROJECTS IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Microsoft President and Chief Operating Officer Richard Belluzzo announced in Taipei Wednesday that the company will take part in three cooperation projects with research institutes, the software industry and educational establishments in Taiwan.
Belluzzo arrived in Taipei the previous day for a series of discussions with government officials and industry leaders.
In talks with Economics Minister Lin Hsin-yi, Belluzzo said that Microsoft plans to set up a Website -- microsoft.net -- as a technological service center for the Asia-Pacific region.
More than 10 software houses in Taiwan have agreed to participate in the project, he added.

To promote cooperation between the industry and academic and research institutes, Belluzzo said that Microsoft has decided to donate NT$18 million to help with the National Science Council's web technology development program, while two local universities will be chosen to set up XML web service research labs.

Belluzzo said that in the past two years, Microsoft Taiwan has developed 20 computer learning centers around the island, while in fiscal 2002, it will donate NT$50 million-worth of computer equipment to educational establishments in remote regions.

DOC.HEADLINE: N.T. DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar appreciated NT$0.001 against the greenback on the Taipei foreign exchange market Wednesday, closing at NT$34.455.
The local currency opened Wednesday at NT$34.450 and was traded between NT$34.438 and NT$34.456.
Interbank U.S. dollar trading totaled US$348 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: RESIDENCY QUOTA RESTRICTIONS ON MAINLAND SPOUSES LARGELY EASED

TEXT.P: Mainland Chinese spouses of Taiwan residents will no longer have to wait for at least 15 years to obtain permanent residency in Taiwan under a new package of regulations to be put into force at the beginning of next year.
At its weekly meeting Wednesday, the Cabinet approved the new package, which greatly eases quota restrictions on mainland spouses intending to settle in Taiwan.

While the annual residency quota for mainland Chinese people who have been married to Taiwan residents for two years or who have given birth will remain at 3,600 under the new system, a new category of mainland spouses will also be granted permanent residency.
The new category covers mainland spouses who have been on the quota waiting list for more than four years and whose accumulated legal length of stay in Taiwan after marriage has exceeded two years.
"This category of mainland spouses will be granted legal residency from 2002 and they will not be subject to any annual quota restrictions," said a Ministry of the Interior (MOI) official.

Stressing that the new measure is being implemented out of humanitarian considerations, the official said about 2,300 mainland spouses will be eligible to obtain permanent residency in the coming year.

Intermarriage across the Taiwan Strait has increased steadily over the past decade, resulting in the swelling of the residency waiting list. The new measure is expected to help improve the situation, the official said.

Meanwhile, mainland Chinese people who married Taiwan residents on or before Dec. 31, 1949 will continue to be free of any quota restrictions regarding permanent residency applications under the new package.

In addition, the annual quota for mainland Chinese people who intend to take up residence in Taiwan for political, economic, social, educational, technological or cultural reasons will be increased to 60 from 2002.

According to MOI estimates, about 9,500 mainland Chinese people will be able to obtain legal residency in Taiwan next year under the new regulations. The number is estimated to drop to around 9,300 in 2003 and to surge to 11,000 in 2004.

To prevent human smuggling rings from arranging marriages of convenience between mainland women and local men so that the women can obtain legal Taiwan residency, the official went on, the MOI is considering establishing a screening mechanism that will require those who intend to marry mainland Chinese people to be interviewed face-to-face by relevant government officials.
The interviewing officials are expected to remind Taiwan people of government regulations and the problems that may arise from tying the knot with a mainlander, the official added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER REAFFIRMS ROC SUPPORT FOR U.S. CRACKDOWN ON TERRORISM

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung reaffirmed Wednesday his government's "unwavering and firm" support for the United States' anti-terrorism campaign.

Chang noted that Control Yuan President Fredrick F. Chien visited New York Nov. 3 to express the country's sympathy for the people of the city and donated US$1 million on behalf of the government to a fund set up to help the survivors and the families of the victims of the Sept. 11 attacks.

Chang further pointed out that the government also donated relief goods worth more than US$16 million to refugees in Afghanistan, to live up to Taiwan's promise to play a responsible role in the international community.

The premier said his government has carefully studied the possible fallout in Taiwan from the U.S. airstrikes in Afghanistan and has done its utmost to prevent possible terrorist attacks on Taiwan, whether by suicide attacks on the island's nuclear facilities or by the spreading of anthrax spores.

Noting that the crusade against terrorism will not end in the near future, the premier assured the people of the island that his government will not relax its efforts to shield them from terrorist attacks.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET APPROVES 2002 NATIONAL DEVELOPMENT PLAN

TEXT.P: The Cabinet approved Wednesday Taiwan's economic development plan for 2002, with the annual gross domestic product (GDP) growth rate projected at 2.7 percent.

According to the 2002 national development plan drafted by the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), Taiwan's unemployment rate for the coming year is estimated at 4.5 percent and the employment growth rate at 1.2 percent.
The Cabinet-level council also forecast that the domestic inflation rate will maintain this year's level of 0.1 percent.
The plan places priority on revitalizing the ailing economy, increasing job openings and lowering the unemployment rate for the new year.

Under the terms of the plan, the government will stimulate economic growth by encouraging innovation and expanding public investment, while GDP growth, coupled with structural adjustments, will in turn increase job opportunities.

The plan also outlines five major national development goals for the new year -- upgrading Taiwan's competitiveness with a global perspective; reinvigorating Taiwan's vitality with sustainable management; boosting social justice through improved law and order, medical services, a social security system and cultural development; upgrading administrative efficiency by wiping out corruption and "black gold" politics; and strengthening human resources by raising educational levels.

The CEPD also presented a review of the domestic and global economic situations at the Cabinet meeting in which it predicted that the global economic growth rate will decline from last year's 4 percent to 1.3 percent this year.

On the domestic front, the CEPD said the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks on the United States and the trail of devastation left by typhoons Toraji and Nari have hindered Taiwan's economic recovery in the second half of this year.
As a result, the report said, Taiwan's unemployment rate has continued to rise, pushing up the annual jobless rate to an estimated 4.5 percent.

On the economic outlook for 2002, the report said as major countries around the world have adopted easy monetary and fiscal policies to rev up their sluggish economies, the world economy will gradually regain steam in the first half of the new year, which will be a boon to Taiwan's export-driven economy.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC DEPUTY CHIEF CAUTIOUSLY OPTIMISTIC ABOUT CROSS-STRAIT TIES

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Lin Chong-pin expressed cautious optimism Wednesday about interaction between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait in the coming year.

Lin told local reporters after attending an international seminar on national security and military strategy that he thinks that cross-strait dialogue may resume after Taiwan's Cabinet is reshuffled early next year.
"The two sides are most likely to resume talks during the interval from the inauguration of Taiwan's new Cabinet to mainland China's annual Beidaihe meeting," Lin said.
Lin was referring to the mainland Chinese leadership meeting that takes place each summer at Beidaihe, a resort on the outskirts of Beijing.

In his view, Lin said, there will be a "window of opportunity" during this period. "More specifically, the suitable period for the two sides to resume dialogue ranges between February and April next year," he noted.
Lin said he hopes both sides can take advantage of this opportunity. "Otherwise, the chance will slip away," he added.
Lin's optimistic forecast came a day after MAC Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen made a similar prediction.
Lin said although the two sides have not yet come to terms on the "one China" issue, the general situations on both sides are favorable for resumption of cross-strait talks.
For one thing, Lin said, mainland China's political, economic and social situations are generally good and its relations with the United States have stabilized in the second half of this year.

"Mainland China is more willing to deal with cross-strait issues when its domestic and diplomatic situations, particularly its relations with the United States, are stable," Lin observed. (by Sofia Wu)

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC SENDS CONDOLENCES OVER DEATH OF WIFE OF BASEBALL GREAT
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Dec. 12 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Ed Chen)

TEXT.P: The wife of former Japanese baseball great Sadaharu Oh, known as Wang Chen-chih in Chinese, passed away Tuesday and Republic of China Representative to Japan Lo Fu-chuan expressed his condolences Wednesday to the family on behalf of Taiwan.
Lo will attend the funeral service for Oh's wife, Takako, Friday.
There was an outpouring of sympathy from Taiwan officials to Oh, who had been made an ambassador-at-large for the ROC last November.

Wreaths will be sent to the memorial service in the names of ROC President Chen Shui-bian, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung, Minister of Foreign Affairs Tien Hung-mao, minister of the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission Chang Fu-mei, Chung Ming-yao, president of the East Asian Relations Association and Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Wu Tzu-dan.
Oh's wife had undergone surgery for stomach cancer three years earlier. She was re-admitted to hospital this August.
The two were married in December 1966 after a six-year courtship.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC DONATES $ 250,000 TO C. AMERICAN NATURAL DISASTER RELIEF BODY
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Panama, Dec. 11 (CNA) (By Oscar Chung and Ed Chen)

TEXT.P: ROC Ambassador to Panama David Hu donated US$250,000 Tuesday to the Central American Natural Disaster Preventive Coordination Center on behalf of the ROC government.
The presentation ceremony of the donation, the second of its kind, was held at the Panamanian Natural Disaster Preventive Center with more than 20 Chinese and Panamanian dignitaries witnessing.

The first donation was made by former ROC Ambassador to Panama Lan Chih-min last year. The ROC promised to donate US$500,000 to the center at a meeting between foreign ministers of seven Central American countries and the ROC held at San Salvador last year.

Speaking at the ceremony, the ROC envoy said that the donation will help improve the forecasting of natural disasters and way to mitigate their destructive forces. Hu said that he was pleased to know that the Central American Natural Disaster Preventive Coordination Center will become operational shortly after two years of preparation and planning.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO IMMEDIATE RESHUFFLE OF GOVERNMENT: PRESIDENTIAL OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian is not considering reshuffling the Central Government any time soon, said a government spokesman Wednesday responding to media speculation.
Yu Shyi-kun, secretary-general to the president made the denial while answering queries raised by legislators at a meeting of the Legislative Yuan's legal and budget committees.
"President Chen has made it clear that he will not consider personnel changes for the Central Government before the end of this year," Yu said.
The Cabinet, led by Premier Chang Chun-hsiung, is expected to resign en masse when newly elected lawmakers gather for the new legislative session in February.
Local media has recently reported that Yu will succeed Chang as premier. Yu had shortly served as vice premier in the Cabinet led by former Premier Tang Fei.
Yu said that he was not qualified to be premier: "I fully understand the limits of my abilities."
He said that preparations for forming the "national stabilization alliance" have been progressing smoothly and the work will not stop simply because the opposition parties have boycotted the idea.
President Chen proposed late last month to create an alliance of political party leaders, lawmakers and experts to help stabilize the political situation.
The major opposition parties, the Kuomintang and the People First Party, have refused to take part in the alliance, saying the body would be unconstitutional.
Yu said the proposed alliance would recruit individuals if the opposition parties continue to refuse to cooperate.

DOC.HEADLINE: SAO TOME AND PRINCIPE PRESIDENT VISITS TAIWAN ECONOMIC ESTABLISHMENTS
DOC.DATELINE: Yunlin, Central Taiwan, Dec. 12 (CNA) (By Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: Visiting Sao Tome and Principe President Fradique Bandeira Melo de Menezes, accompanied by his counterpart, ROC President Chen Shui-bian, visited the Sixth Naphtha Cracking Plant of the Formosa Plastic Group (FPG) Wednesday at Mailiao in Yunlin County, southern Taiwan.

FPG Vice Chairman Wang Yung-tsai, on behalf of FPG Chairman Wang Yung-ching, welcomed the two presidents upon their arrival at the compound. Wang briefed the head of state from the western African country on the current development of the plant.
In a speech, President Chen said that FPG had to overcome a number of difficulties to build the Sixth Naphtha Cracking Plant. The plant is situated on land that was reclaimed from the ocean.
"This is Formosan spirit," said President Chen. He said he hoped that under the able leadership of President Menezes, Sao Tome and Principe will become Africa's Formosa.
Chen further pointed out that under the concerted effort between the government and the 23 million people of Taiwan, they have let nothing stand in their way to create the Taiwan miracle.
The Republic of Sao Tome and Principe, which is 1,001 square kilometers and consists of two islands, has a population of 140,000.
Chen said he hoped that the ruling Advanced Democratic Independence Party will become the largest political party next year after parliamentary elections.
In the afternoon, President Menezes, accompanied by staff members from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, visited the Tantse Export Processing Zone in Tantse in suburban Taichung.

President Menezes showed a keen interest in whether his country could build such a zone. President Menezes even suggested that Taiwan send an expert to help Sao Tome and Principe create its own export processing zone.
President Menezes, accompanied by a 10-member entourage, arrived in Taiwan Monday night for a five-day state visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONTROL YUAN TO RELEASE REPORT ON CAPTAIN'S YIN'S DEATH NEXT YEAR

TEXT.P: The Control Yuan's report on the mysterious death of a naval captain in 1993 will be released early next year, said Tu Shan-liang, secretary-general of the Control Yuan.

In a response to questions from local journalists, Tu said the Control Yuan's investigation into the death of Captain Yin Ching-feng and the scandal surrounding the ROC Navy's purchase of six French-made Lafayett-class frigates in 1991 is substantially completed.

However, Tu said, the investigation took a strange twist earlier this year when Andrew Wang, an arms broker who fled to the United States after being wanted in Taiwan in connection with the death of Yin, relayed a letter to the Control Yuan through his contacts in Taiwan proclaiming his innocence. Control Yuan members are looking into the details of Wang's letter which have not been made public.
Also, documents from France obtained by Control Yuan investigators earlier this year need to be further examined by government agencies to certify their authenticity, Tu said.
All this takes extra time, Tu said, but the Control Yuan is also aware that the public is eager for an early conclusion to the investigation and that they have been waiting for the final report.

Captain Yin, whose dead body was found floating in a harbor near a navy base in northern Taiwan in 1993, was in charge of the navy's weapons acquisitions and had threatened to go public with what he called irregularities involving in navy's purchases before his sudden death.
The navy launched its own probe into the death, but no conclusions were reached. The entire investigation all but came to a halt before civilian police stepped in to take over the case.

Investigators have been able to put some pieces of the puzzle together. In Paris, French authorities in 1996 found the country's former foreign minister, Roland Dumas, had been paid to approve the sale of the six frigates to Taiwan in 1991.

The finding gave new life to the case in Taiwan and investigators renewed their efforts to put together events that could have led to the death of Yin. The probe expanded to include allegations of purchasing irregularities surrounding the French frigates.
The Control Yuan began its own investigations this year and have questioned several prominent navy officials.

One interesting discovery was the fact that recordings of telephone conversations at the General Headquarters of the Navy immediately before and after Yin's death had been taped over by unrelated conversations.

Another was a tape secretly recorded by Captain Yin allegedly to be used as evidence of the purchasing irregularities by the General Headquarters of the Navy. The tape surfaced, only to be found to have been corrupted to the point that the speech on the tape was not understandable.
Many navy officials who were first questioned in connection with Yin's death were either retired or assigned to other jobs immediately afterward.
All these have complicated the investigations, Tu said, and raised suspicions that at least one person in the navy was trying to prevent the truth from coming out.
A parallel investigation by a panel of prosecutors has turned up no evidence of alleged kickbacks in the purchase of the frigates thus far, and no one has been arrested for the murder of Yin.

DOC.HEADLINE: PERSONALIZED STAMPS RELEASED IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Authentic ROC stamps printed with pictures provided by the public began to be distributed Wednesday, but demand had been so overwhelming -- more than 100,000 orders -- that the Directorate General of Posts was unable to give them all out as promised.
The personalized stamps, printed with photos provided by buyers themselves, drew an avalanche of orders after the post office began to take orders a month ago.
The post office has only managed to fill orders taken before Nov. 29. The others will take another 10 days.
Two spouses, one from Taipei City and one from Kaohsiung City, were honored in a ceremony Wednesday marking the launch of the personalized stamps.

The two newlyweds, whose wedding pictures were chosen as the best photos for stamps among all orders, appeared at the ceremony in traditional Chinese costumes and Western gowns, and were given the stamps that they had ordered free.
One of the two newlywed couples had submitted pictures of themselves cross-dressed in their wedding finery.
Customers can check the post office's Web site at http://www.post.gov.tw/up.asp to see if their orders have been processed, Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: BOTH KOREAS, JAPAN, M'LAND CHINA ON ASIAN WOMEN'S SOCCER SEMIFINALS

TEXT.P: South Korea, North Korea, Japan and mainland China have advanced to the semifinals of the 2001 Asian Women's Football Championship Tournament which ended the eight-day preliminary round in Taipei Wednesday.
There are no games Thursday and the semifinals will begin from Friday.
Mainland China will take on North Korea at 1:00 p.m. Friday at the Chungshan Football Stadium while Japan will play South Korea at 4:00 p.m.
South Korea whitewashed Thailand 4-0 while India blanked Malaysia 3-0 at games played at the Taipei City Stadium.
Japan beat Vietnam 3-1 and Singapore edged out Guam 2-1 at games played at the Chungshan Football Stadium.
South Korea is in first place with a win-loss record of 4-0 in Group A, followed by Chinese Taipei at 3-1, Thailand at 2-2, India at 1-3 and Malaysia is winless.
North Korea topped the list in Group B followed by Japan, Vietnam and Guam.
Defending the title for the past eight consecutive events, mainland China captured the Group C title followed by Uzbekistan, Hong Kong and the Philippine.

Chinese Taipei and Japan stood in second place with three wins and one loss. After comparing the total goals scored at the tournament, Japan, which scored more goals than Chinese Taipei, advanced to the semifinals.
