DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Dec. 13, or the 29th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1784: Samuel Johnson, British writer and lexicographer known as "Dr. Johnson," dies at the age of 75. The leading literary figure in the second half of the 18th century, he wrote the "Dictionary of the English Language" and "Lives of the Poets."
1797: German poet and critic Heinrich Heine is born in Dusseldorf.
1897: Russian forces occupy Port Arthur on the Yellow Sea.
1904: The first electric train comes into service on London's Metropolitan Railway.
1916: Some 9,000 Austro-Hungarian troops are killed in an avalanche in the Alps.
1918: U.S. President Thomas Woodrow Wilson arrives in France, becoming the first American president to visit a European country.
1921: Britain, the United States, France and Japan sign the Washington Treaty, pledging to respect each others' claims over insular possessions in the Pacific.
1937: Japanese troops occupy Nanking. During the following two months, the aggressors rape and kill some 300,000 Chinese and lay waste to the city in what would become known as the "Rape of Nanking."
1944: A Japanese kamikaze pilot crashes his plane into the U.S. cruiser Nashville, killing 133 crew members.
1955: In the U.N Security Council, China vetoes the admission of Outer Mongolia to the United Nations.
1961: Anna Mary Robertson Moses, known as "Grandma Moses," an American painter noted for her colorful primitive-style paintings of rural scenes, dies in New York at the age of 101.
1963: The Junior Chamber of the Republic of China announces the list of winners of the ten "outstanding youth awards."
1968: The Hsin Hsin Bus Co. is established, becoming the first private bus company in Taipei City.
1972: On the last U.S. mission to the moon, Apollo 17 astronauts unveil a plaque on the lunar surface dedicated to peace.
1974: Malta, the former British crown colony which became an independent country in 1964, changes its form of government to that of a republic.
1976: A four-member Chinese judo team leaves Taipei for Spain to participate in the second world youth judo championships.
1978: The first council meeting of the Organization of African Freedom opens in Abidjan, Ivory Coast.
1982: An earthquake devastates Dhamar Province in Yemen, killing 3,000 people and injuring 2,000 others.
1988: South Africa signs an accord in Brazzaville granting independence to Namibia.
1989: The first Vietnamese refugees are repatriated from Hong Kong, escorted to an airplane at dawn by police in riot gear.
1991: A non-aggression agreement aimed at working toward negotiation of a permanent peace treaty is signed by North and South Korea.
1995: Wei Jingsheng, noted Chinese democracy advocate and a 1995 Nobel Peace Prize nominee, is imprisoned for 14 years for subversive acts.
1996: Ministers and officials from 128 countries, including those from the ROC, adopt a wide-ranging declaration at the end of the five-day World Trade Organization meeting in Singapore.
1999: President Lee Teng-hui reiterates that the "special state-to-state relationship" theory is the Republic of China's basic stance on relations with mainland China.
2000: The Executive Yuan approves a draft of rules governing the implementation of trial transport links scheduled to be established between Taiwan's outlying Kinmen and Matsu islands and mainland China beginning Jan. 1, 2001.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "If in governing you depend upon laws and maintain order by enforcing those laws by punishments, you can also make the people keep away from wrongdoing, but they will lose the sense of shame for wrongdoing. If, on the other hand, in government you depend upon moral sentiment and maintain order by encouraging education and good manners, the people will have a sense of shame for wrongdoing and, moreover, will emulate what is good."

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC OFFICIALS REITERATE TAIWAN'S M'LAND POLICY DURING U.S. VISIT
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 12 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: Senior Republic of China officials visiting Washington said Wednesday that the ROC government's policy toward mainland China remains unchanged after the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's emergence from the recent legislative elections as the largest party in the Legislature.

ROC Executive Yuan Secretary-General Chiou I-jen told reporters at the National Press Club in the U.S. capital that the ROC government continues to place priority on maintaining peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait.
Chiou urged Beijing to work together with Taiwan toward such ideals and toward the welfare of "the entire human race."
He added that any issue can be discussed between Taipei and Beijing at the negotiating table.

Meanwhile, Taiwan's top planner on mainland policy told the reporters that Taiwan must be careful in its words and deeds so as not to be provocative toward mainland China, which has deployed missiles aimed at Taiwan.

Tsai Ing-wen, who is chairwoman of the Mainland Affairs Council, added that Taipei's basic stance on cross-strait relations includes ROC President Chen Shui-bian's proposal of aiming to ultimately achieve political integration through economic and cultural integration, as well as the "five noes" as spelled out in his inauguration speech.

Namely, the five noes are: no declaration of independence as long as Beijing does not intend to use force against the island, no change in the nation's official name, no adoption of the "state-to-state" theory into the ROC Constitution, no referendum on the fate of the nation in regard to the unification versus independence issue during his term in office, and no abrogation of the Guidelines for National Unification.

The ROC officials were on a three-day visit at the invitation of the Heritage Foundation to brief U.S. scholars and politicians on Taiwan's political situation and policy direction in the wake of the Dec. 1 elections which made the Democratic Progressive Party the party with the most seats in the Legislative Yuan for the first time.

The delegation also included Presidential Office Deputy Secretary-General Eugene Chien and Wu An-chia, an official with the Coordination Council for North American Affairs under the ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADIAN MP ACCUSES PRC EMBASSY OF TARGETING MISTRUTHS AT HIM

TEXT.P: A Canadian member of Parliament who is known for his strong support of Canadian Falun Gong practitioners accused on Wednesday the Communist Chinese Embassy in Canada of targeting mistruths at his office.

Rob Anders made the remark in a statement congratulating Falun Dafa Canada on a court decision against a Montreal-based Chinese-language newspaper which the practitioners charge has been conducting a smear campaign against them by carrying defamatory articles and advertisements.
Quebec's Supreme Court on Monday ordered Les Presses Chinoises to stop publishing and circulating anti-Falun Gong hate messages.
Anders said the newspaper's propaganda campaign against Falun Gong and its repetition of what he called the lies of the Embassy of the People's Republic of China "is shameful."

He praised the court for issuing "the first ever court order" to stop the spread of lies, adding such efforts in stopping the incitement of hatred toward practitioners of Falun Gong makes Canada a better place.
"This initial victory sends a strong message that Canada, governed by the rule of law, will not tolerate such manipulation," he said.
"I understand the uphill battle practitioners are facing," he pointed out, saying that his own office has been a target of mistruths spread by the Embassy of the People's Republic of China.
"They have attempted to spread their misrepresentations widely in Canada, and it is heartening to hear that such practices are beginning to be stopped," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES DOWN BY 131.77 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) lost ground on Thursday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving down 131.77 points to close at 5,407.54.
Market turnover amounted to NT$226.2 billion (US$6.57 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Shares prices opened high but closed lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 131.77 points to close at 5,407.54.

Encouraged by a rise in U.S. stock prices, the bourse opened at 5,623.6 and continued to go up before profit-taking selling pressure drove prices down. The index fluctuated between 5,651.98 and 5,349.67 during trading.

A total of 7.13 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$226.2 billion (US$6.57 billion), an increase from the previous trading session which saw 5.65 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$167.52 billion (US$4.86 billion).

Three of the eight major stocks categories gained ground, with construction stocks moving up the most at 3.4 percent, followed by plastics and chemical shares at 0.3 percent, and cement stocks at 0.2 percent.

The other major categories posted losses, with foodstuff shares moving down the most at 3.9 percent, followed by textile issues at 3.1 percent, electrical stocks at 2.8 percent, pulp and paper issues at 1.9 percent, and bank and insurance shares at 1.4 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 375 to 216, with 63 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market were lower Thursday as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for December moved down 224 points to close at 5,425, with 27,507 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for next January lost 189 points to close at 5,435, with 744 contract transactions, while next March futures plunged 228 points to finish at 5,422, with 6 contracts traded.
Next June futures fell 46 points to close at 5,600, with 17 contracts traded, while next September futures decreased 122 points to finish at 5,501, with two contracts changing hands.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 5,649 for December, 5,624 for next January, 5,650 for next March, 5,446 for next June, and 5,623 for next September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also lower.
December TE futures moved down 11.3 points to close at 283.9, with 8,302 contract transactions, while next January TE futures decreased 13.9 points to finish at 282.2, with 286 contracts traded.
Next June TE futures lost 6.3 points to close at 292, with only one contract traded. No transactions were reported for other months.
December TF futures moved down 27.2 points to finish at 744.8, with 5,541 contract transactions, while next January TF futures plunged 31.2 points to close at 741, with 174 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC VICE PRESIDENT TO VISIT NICARAGUA, PARAGUAY, THE GAMBIA

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu will lead a delegation to visit Nicaragua to attend the inauguration of the Central American nation's president, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Thursday.
Ho Ching-shan, director of MOFA's Department of Central and South American Affairs, said Lu will attend the inauguration of Enrique Bolanos Geyer Jan. 4 on behalf of President Chen Shui-bian.

Lu will also visit Paraguay, an ROC ally in South America, whose vice president, Julio Cesar Ramon Franco Gomez, extended the invitation to visit to Lu when he visited Taiwan in February this year. The itinerary is still not finalized, Ho added.
Ho also said that the United States has agreed to allow Lu to transit there.

Minister of Foreign Affairs Tien Hung-mao confirmed Wednesday that Lu will leave next Tuesday for The Gambia, the ROC's ally in West Africa, to attend the West African state's presidential inauguration on behalf of President Chen.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP ADMINISTRATION WORKING TOWARD A THREE-BRANCH GOVERNMENT: OFFICIAL
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 12 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: A senior Republic of China official visiting Washington said Wednesday that the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration will promote government structural reforms that may include overhauling the five-branch government system such that only three branches remain in "four to six years."

Stressing that he was merely reiterating an old proposal, ROC Executive Yuan Secretary-General Chiou I-jen told reporters at the National Press Club in the U.S. capital that the DPP has always wanted to adopt a constitutional system similar to the three-branch system used in the United States.
However, Chiou stressed that the process must involve negotiations with other political parties because of the steep requirements involved in ratifying the relevant constitutional amendments.

Chiou added that the DPP administration hopes to complete the first stage of government reform next year by ratifying the necessary amendments to slim down the Executive Yuan by one-third its current size.

In response to a question on whether the position of the premier, who heads the Executive Yuan, would also be abolished in order to set up an executive branch headed by the president, Chiou said that such a possibility exists but that the conclusion would depend on negotiations with other parties.

The ROC Constitution, promulgated in 1947, installed a complex system of checks and balances between five branches of government -- the Executive Yuan, the Legislative Yuan, the Judicial Yuan, the Examination Yuan and the Control Yuan -- with a president serving as the head of state.

Chiou is on a three-day visit to brief U.S. scholars and politicians on Taiwan's political situation and policy direction in the wake of the recent elections which made the DPP the party with the most seats in the Legislative Yuan for the first time.

The delegation also includes Mainland Affairs Council Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen, Presidential Office Deputy Secretary-General Eugene Chien and Wu An-chia, an official with the Coordination Council for North American Affairs under the ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: FARMERS FORMING ALLIANCES TO MEET INTERNATIONAL COMPETITION

TEXT.P: Cooperation between mango growers in southern Taiwan has resulted in improved production and increased profits this year and is just one example of the benefits of stratigic alliances in the agricultural sector, according to Council of Agriculture (COA) Chairman Chen Hsi-huang.

Chen said that in the past several months, 12 strategic alliances have been formed among floricultural farmers, fruit growers, aquaculture farmers, dairy farmers and farm families engaged in agri-tourism.
Under the framework of the Taiwan Agricultural Strategic Coalition, the alliances have improved the production and marketing efficiencies of most small farms.
The COA is encouraging farmers to cooperate in production and product processing and distribution to enhance the efficiency of their operations.
Mango growers in southern Taiwan have been especially pleased with this year's harvest and the assistance given by the Tainan Region Mango Growers Strategic Alliance.

The eight mango-growing townships and villages in Tainan County had fallen on hard times in recent years with overproduction that had led to cut-throat competition and entire seasons without showing a profit. In March this year, agricultural officials talked to executives of the farmers' associations in the region and recommended that they form a production and marketing alliance.

Before last summer's harvest, farmers in the region had established a marketing mechanism with the assistance of the Taiwan Agricultural Strategic Coalition, which was set up by the COA in November last year to coordinate farmers' associations and cooperatives and help small farms facing the challenges of international competition.
Chen said that Taiwan's small farms had been too vulnerable to meet the challenges of a more open international market.
However, with the proper organization, Taiwan's agricultural sector should be able to expand into the international market and not just take a defensive posture, he said.
As a member of the World Trade Organization (WTO), Taiwan will be required to lift the protective restrictions that have been in place for the benefit of local farmers and growers, Chen said.

Anticipating the unprecedented impact after entry in the WTO, many farm households have sought to make adjustments in their production and management over the past few years. Some rice growers have shifted to specialty crops with higher yields and better market value. Agri-tourism is another alternative for farm households to improve their incomes.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT ENTERPRISES MAY BE FORCED TO STREAMLINE

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan will study whether to include government enterprises, non-profit foundations and corporations in a slimming program of the Cabinet, according to Lin Chia-cheng, chairman of the Research, Development and Evaluation Commission.

Lin said that the commission will submit a draft of the revised Executive Yuan Organization Law to the Legislative Yuan for approval before April next year. It is planned that the 36 ministries, councils and commissions will be reduced to 25.
The next step of the slimming program will involve the 12 government enterprises and non-profit foundations and corporations under the Executive Yuan, he added.
Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Hsin-yi said in April this year that most government enterprises had big deficits and they should reduce their expenses by laying off staffs or cutting salaries.
According to the slimming program of the Central Personnel Administration, 15,000 workers of government enterprises will be laid off.

DOC.HEADLINE: OFFICIAL'S PROPOSAL FOR THREE-BRANCH GOVERNMENT DRAWS MIXED RESPONSES

TEXT.P: A remark by Cabinet Secretary-General Chiou I-jen that the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration aims to promote a three-branch governmental system over the next four to six years drew mixed responses from government officials and political parties Thursday.

Chiou told reporters Wednesday at the National Press Club in Washington that the DPP has always wanted to adopt a constitutional system similar to the three-branch system used in the United States, instead of the five-branch system currently in place according to the Republic of China Constitution.

In response to Chiou's remark, Presidential Office Public Affairs Director Kuo Yao-chi said that working toward a three-branch government system is an important direction of development that might be discussed within the framework of a recently established government restructuring committee or a "national stabilization alliance" proposed by President Chen Shui-bian.

The government restructuring committee is headed by the president, and includes as vice chairmen Premier Chang Chun-hsiung -- who is head of the Executive Yuan -- and Examination Yuan President Hsu Shui-teh.

The ROC Constitution, promulgated in 1947, installed a complex system of checks and balances between five branches of government -- the Executive Yuan, the Legislative Yuan, the Judicial Yuan, the Examination Yuan and the Control Yuan -- while a president serves as the head of state.

Examination Yuan Vice Secretary-General Tsai Liang-wen said that the planned reforms are aimed at maximizing the government's effectiveness. Such restructuring will go through several stages, beginning with a slimming down of the Executive Yuan and gradually spreading to include the other four Yuans, he said, adding that the possibility of involving changes to the constitutional system cannot be ruled out.

A Control Yuan official said that Control Yuan President Fredrick Chien has already established a special task force within the Yuan to gather related information domestically and from abroad to evaluate the issue of whether the Control Yuan should be abolished.
Meanwhile, opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong criticized Chiou, saying it was unheard of that a Cabinet chief of staff would say that the premier's post "might disappear."

Chiou had told reporters in response to a question on whether the position of the premier would be abolished to set up an executive branch headed solely by the president, that such a possibility exists but that the conclusion would depend on negotiations with other parties.

Lee Cheng-chong, a legislative whip of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT), said that his party supports the existing five-branch government constitutional system. However, Lee went on, the KMT will offer its support if a new system is "a good system." Whether the three-branch government is feasible can be discussed, he added.
DPP Legislative Whip Tsai Huang-liang said that constitutional amendments involve a wide-ranging number of issues, and that public opinion as well as opposition parties must be consulted.

Noting that although a three-branch government is indeed a long-time proposal of his party, DPP legislator Shen Fu-hsiung said that a move to focus executive power on the president -- thereby marginalizing or eliminating the premier -- has not yet received overwhelming support within the DPP legislative caucus.

Stressing that it is necessary to work toward amending the Constitution to establish a three-branch government, DPP legislator Lin Cho-shui said that the president-versus-premier issue remains to be discussed within his party and within society.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN LIEN CHAN MAY VISIT JAPAN

TEXT.P: A senior official of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) said Thursday that party chairman Lien Chan is considering a visit to Japan at the invitation of the Japan-ROC Dietmen Council, a Japanese partisan parliamentary organization to promote closer Taiwan-Japan relations.
KMT Secretary-General Lin Feng-chih said that Lien's schedule has yet to be finalized.
According to news reports, Lien will visit Japan Saturday. If true, Lien will become the first KMT chairman to visit Japan.

During his stay in Japan, Lien may call on ruling Liberal Democratic Party leaders and government officials. Lien may also inspect the KMT Tokyo chapter and call on overseas Chinese community leaders.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO DECISION ON 8-INCH WAFERS, IC DESIGNER INVESTMENT IN MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said Thursday that it has not decided whether to allow Taiwan's eight-inch wafer chip manufacturers and IC packaging and designers to invest in mainland China.
Vice Economic Affairs Minister Chen Ruey-long made the remarks after a four-hour meeting with industry leaders over which he presided.
Chen added, however, that the ministry had decided to allow light-emitting diode (LED) and liquid crystal display (LCD) module (LCM) makers to invest in the mainland.

Chen said that as investment in wafer chip manufacture is enormous and it is the most important industry in Taiwan, it is necessary to establish a management mechanism before allowing such companies to invest in the mainland.

The MOEA and the Taiwan Semiconductor Industry Association will invite related industry leaders for more discussions and will take into consideration the capital risk and industry competitiveness across the Taiwan Strait before mapping out a management mechanism and making a final decision, he said.

Those participating in the discussion were Wu Ming-chiu, representative of the Taiwan Electrical & Electronics Manufacturers Association and president of Macronix International, Taiwan Semiconductor Industry Association Secretary-General Chen Wen-hsien, Taipei Computer Association Chairman Huang Chung-jen and Institution for Information Industry Chairman Huang He-ming.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-BORN ARTIST AWARDED U.N. GLOBAL TOLERANCE AWARD
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Dec. 12 (CNA) (By Eric Tseng and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan-born artist Chen Chin-fang became one of four winners of the United Nations' 2001 Global Tolerance Award Tuesday.
Chen, singer Alanis Morissette and two artistic groups were given the honor at a ceremony attended by more than 300 guests at U.N. Headquarters in New York.
Chen will serve as a Cultural Ambassador for Tolerance and Peace and will visit more than 20 countries, including Taiwan, to present art exhibitions and related activities.
In 1995, the U.N. announced Nov. 16 as International Day for Tolerance and established the Global Tolerance Award to encourage non-government agencies, people and groups to promote tolerance.
Chen was awarded for his effective use of art to enhance tolerance and the value of harmony.

Speaking at the ceremony, Chen said that the source of conflict comes from poverty, ignorance and intolerance, and that only tolerance, justice and love will heal the wounds and achieve harmony, peace and prosperity.

Chen, a graduate of National Taiwan University's Department of Foreign Language and Literature, lived in France for 12 years since 1963 and settled in the United States in 1975, where he opened an art gallery in 1980 and took part in international shows. In 1996, he built an art building in Soho, New York and established a non-profit cultural organization through which he promoted exchanges between eastern and western cultures.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SEMICONDUCTOR DESIGNERS HOLD TALKS IN BEIJING

TEXT.P: Semiconductor designers from Taiwan met in Beijing Thursday with mainland Chinese high-technology representatives to sound out the possibility of technological cooperation across the Taiwan Strait.
China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) Secretary-General Huang Chih-peng was at the head of the seven-member delegation, according to a CETRA official.
More than 500 mainland Chinese high-tech industry representatives attended the "Taiwan Semiconductor Day" sponsored by CETRA in Beijing.
In addition to showcasing new products and technology, the delegation also held a seminar with their mainland counterparts.
According to statistics, mainland companies produced 4.1 billion chips with sales amounting to 10 billion renminbi last year, while the mainland imported 24 billion chips during the same period.
Mainland manufacturers are expected to produce six-fold more wafers by 2005, which will still only meet 30 percent of local demand.
The Taiwan delegation will proceed to Shanghai to meet with more than 400 industry representatives there.

DOC.HEADLINE: DIRECT TAIPEI-MOSCOW AIR LINKS EXPECTED TO BEGIN SOON
DOC.DATELINE: Moscow, Dec. 12 (CNA) (By Chang Hung-kuang and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: Direct Taipei-Moscow air links may be established soon after seven years of bilateral talks, the Republic of China deputy representative to Russia said Wednesday.
Chan Hsiu-ying made the remarks at a dinner he hosted for a group of Taiwan reporters who are in Moscow at the invitation of the Moscow city government.
Transaero Airlines, an agent for direct Taipei-Moscow flight routes, will introduce Taiwan's economy and culture in the next issue of a Russian air transport magazine, Chan said.

He noted that after the signing of an agreement with the Russian authorities, flights by Taiwan's China Airlines and EVA Airways have begun flying over Siberia to cut three hours flying time to Frankfurt and Paris from the previous routes over the Middle East.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO INTEGRATE REGIONAL ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT: CHEN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday that the government is confident in its ability to promote the information-based economy and integrate economic development in the Asia-Pacific region.
Chen made the remarks at a reception for young Chinese business leaders from Taiwan and overseas.
The president lauded the young business leaders for creating unlimited possibilities from the most inferior conditions, which he termed the "spirit of Taiwan's sons."

He further said that entrepreneurship is Taiwan's spirit and that the future of Taiwan hinges upon it. Noting that Taiwan's small- and medium-sized enterprises created an economic miracle in the past, the nation in future will have to rely on knowledge, technology and creativity if it wants to continue to enjoy a competitive edge on the world stage.

He stressed that the present time is crucial and that the key to its success will be the integration of the government and private sectors. He said that the government should allow the nation's entrepreneurs to make the best use of their potential and create a sound investment environment.
He reiterated that the government will implement the conclusions reached at the Economic Development Advisory Conference in August and listen to private entrepreneurs.

The president also spoke of the just-concluded legislative and county and city chief elections, saying that the government is not elated by its election victory, but in fact is more humble and more prepared to listen to the voice of the grassroots and think about the future of the country.
The ruling Democratic Progressive Party gained 87 seats in the 225-seat legislature, making it the largest party in the legislature and breaking the grip of the Kuomintang.

Chen reiterated that he will dedicate himself to the stability of the political situation and to economic development, and that he will try to improve cross-strait relations with sincerity, creativity and wisdom.

DOC.HEADLINE: SAO TOME AND PRINCIPE PRESIDENT VISITS TAICHUNG PORT
DOC.DATELINE: Taichung, central Taiwan, Dec. 13 (CNA) (By Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: Visiting Sao Tome and Principe President Fradique Banderira Melo de Menezes visited Taichung Port Thursday.
Port Director Hsieh Ming-hui briefed Menezes on the man-made seaport that became operational in 1976 and Menezes then visited Uniglory Marine Corp., one of the companies with facilities at the port.
Menezes, who arrived in Taiwan Monday for a five-day visit, said that he will use the data for reference as his country is trying to expand its port facilities.

DOC.HEADLINE: N.T. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The new Taiwan dollar was down NT$0.009 against the U.S. dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Thursday, closing at 34.464.
The local currency opened Thursday at 34.449 and was traded between 34.447 and 34.465.
Interbank U.S. dollar trading totaled US$423 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: CETRA DECIDES TO DISSOLVE TAIPEI DESIGN CENTER IN MILAN

TEXT.P: The China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) has decided to dissolve the Taipei Design Center in Milan, CETRA sources said Thursday.
Besides dissolving the design center in Milan, CETRA has also decided to dissolve three of its trade centers in Jakarta, Madrid and Montreal, the sources added.
Presently, the CETRA operates four design centers. The other three are located in Osaka, San Francisco and Dusseldorf.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP LOOKING INTO REPORTS ON WPCM HEAD

TEXT.P: The office of Vice President Annette Lu said Thursday that it is looking into reports that the South Korean organizer of the World Peace Corps Mission (WPCM), which awarded a prize to Lu in Taipei last week, is a "con man."
A press release from Lu's office said that the vice president will reveal her findings after checking the press report.

The press statement said a report in Next magazine, a local weekly, about a bungled business deal between Han Min Su, co-founder of the WPCM, and the island Kingdom of Tonga, seems to be about Han's private business and nothing to do with the organization he help found in 1983.

However, the statement said that the same magazine's report about former U.S. Congressman Lester Wolff, who serves as chief judge of the WPCM's prize-awarding council and who presented its World Peace Prize to Lu on Dec. 4, is "not based on fact" and is "unfair" to the long-time human rights activist.
Meanwhile Kuo Yao-chi, director of the Public Affairs Office under the Presidential Office, said Thursday that prize or no prize, Lu's contributions to peace are widely acknowledged.

However, Kuo said the Presidential Office had nothing to do with the affair and that although the prize was awarded in the auditorium of the Presidential Office, the arrangements were made by Lu's staff.

Meanwhile, Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Chang Siao-yue said that the WPCM is a civic organization registered in Washington and that while the Foreign Ministry helped it to organize the presentation of the prize to Lu, it did not offer any financial help.
Chang said that Wolff last month contacted Taiwan's representative in Washington, Chen Chien-jen, to tell him that Lu had been chosen to receive the peace prize.

The Foreign Ministry served as a conduit between the vice president and the WPCM, but neither recommended Lu as prize winner nor asked the organization to honor the vice president and did not mention giving any funds to the WPCM.

According to Next magazine, Han Min Su is a con man who offered King of Tonga Taufa'ahau Tupou IV the peace prize in 1996 and tried to win Tupou's approval for Tonga to buy from him a plant touted to be able to convert sea water into natural gas.
The deal turned out to be a confidence trick and Seoul was later forced to apologize to the Kingdom of Tonga, the magazine said.
The weekly also cited AFP correspondent Field Michael as saying he believes Han is trying to play a similar trick on Taiwan.
The magazine also disputed Han's claims that his organization awarded the WPCM peace prize to Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak and Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin in 1995.
The magazine said that Wolff, who came to Lu's defense when she was tried for sedition in 1979, quit politics 21 years ago after losing a re-election bid.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG HAS BRIGHT PROSPECTS WITH WTO ENTRY: SCHOLARS

TEXT.P: Experts said Thursday that Kaohsiung City will have bright prospects once Taiwan and mainland China are admitted into the World Trade Organization (WTO).

Associate Professor Lee Liang-chien of the Financial Department of I-Shou University said that according to the results of a survey he commissioned, a majority of the respondents said they attach great importance to the opening of direct postal, trade and transport links across the Taiwan Strait.

The results also show that the respondents believe hikes in labor costs and repeated confrontations between those who wish to exploit the environment and those who want to preserve something of Taiwan's natural resources are two key factors prompting local enterprises to move away from Taiwan, Lee said.
According to Lee, Kaohsiung City, which possesses Kaohsiung Port and Kaohsiung International Airport, will be more competitive than other cities in Taiwan.
He pointed out that Kaohsiung badly needs promotional talent and suggested that the city should set up a task force charged with encouraging foreign investors to put their money into Kaohsiung.

Chen Hai-ni, board chairman of the Kaohsiung City Tourist Hotel Association, said that Kaohsiung should develop its tourism industry and expressed hope that the government will open the Taiwan tourism market to mainland Chinese people as soon as possible.
Citing Hong Kong as an example, he claimed that the tourism industry has continued to develop since the former British colony reverted to mainland Chinese rule in 1997.
Lee Wen-liang, director of the Construction Bureau of Kaohsiung City, said that Kaohsiung will develop its software, bio-tech and tourist industries.
He also said that the mass rapid transport system currently under construction will help build Kaohsiung into a multifunctional international city.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WINS 2 GOLDS, 1 SILVER, 1 BRONZE AT ASIAN ARCHERY CONTEST

TEXT.P: Chinese Taipei's Wang Chih-hao beat his Malaysian rival Thursday to win a gold medal for Chinese Taipei in the compound bow category of the 12th Asian Archery Championship Tournament now being held in Hong Kong.
Wang had earlier edged out his teammate Chen Chen-kuo 117-115 in the semifinals and Chen, playing for the bronze, then lost to his teammate Yuan Chu-chung 108-111, giving Yuan the bronze.
A day earlier, Chinese Taipei's Huang Yi-ting and Yen Hsiu-pi won gold and silver, respectively, in the compound bow, women's division.
Chinese Taipei's medal tally as of Thursday stood at two golds, one silver and one bronze. The team is expected to return to Taiwan Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC CABINET STAFF CHIEF MEETS WITH U.S. CONGRESSMEN
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 13 (CNA) (By Jay Chen & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Chiou I-jen, secretary-general of the Republic of China Executive Yuan, met with around 20 U.S. congressmen at a dinner given by Taiwan's top Representative to Washington, Chen Chien-jen Wednesday.
Chiou thanked them for Washington's long-standing support for Taiwan's democratization and its assistance in Taiwan's bid for World Trade Organization entry.

He also called for Washington's continued concern over Taiwan's security and peace across the Taiwan Strait, as well as its support for the island's bid to join the World Health Organization, according to a press release issued by the representative office.
Chiou also met with government officials that afternoon, but what transpired at the meeting was not disclosed.
He was to exchange views with more U.S. congressmen at a reception to be held at Capitol Hill Thursday, the press release said.

Chiou arrived in Washington Dec. 11 for a four-day visit along with Tsai Ing-wen, chairwoman of the Mainland Affairs Council, Eugene Chien, deputy secretary-general of the Presidential Office, and Wu An-chia, a member of the Coordination Council for North American Affairs.

During their stay in Washington, the four officials will explain the political significance of Taiwan's Dec. 1 elections and Taiwan's future approach toward mainland China. They will also exchange views with Washington officials on the development of Washington-Taipei-Beijing ties.

The statement noted that 24 congressmen attended the dinner, including senators Daniel Inouye and Daniel Akaka -- both Democrats from Hawaii -- Rep. Gary L. Ackerman, a Democrat from New York, Rep. Roy Blunt, a Republican from Missouri and Jennifer Dunn, a Republican from Washington.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Dec. 14, or the 30th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1783: William Pitt, known as "Pitt the Younger," is made British prime minister and chancellor of the exchequer at the age of just 24. He accomplished the Act of Union between Ireland and Britain but was unsuccessful in his efforts at achieving Catholic emancipation.
1808: James Madison is elected the fourth president of the United States. His presidency was marked by the War of 1812.
1858: The French and Spanish announce a blockade of the port of Taku near the Chinese city of Tientsin prior to an Anglo-French expedition against Beijing which saw the burning of the Imperial Summer Palace by invading troops.
1887: The first U.S. hospital for cancer patients is inaugurated in New York.
1902: Thomas Nast, an American political cartoonist who was born in Germany in 1840, dies at the age of 62. He was the first to depict the Democratic Party as a donkey and the Republican Party as an elephant.
1917: U.S. President Woodrow Wilson declares war on Austria.
1941: Japanese planes bomb the American naval base at Pearl Harbor, Hawaii, killing 2,400 men and destroying many aircraft and battleships.
1949: The government of the Republic of China moves its seat of power to Taipei.
1951: The Communist Chinese launch the "three antis campaign" -- anti-corruption, anti-extravagance, and anti-bureaucracy.
1971: An unmanned Soviet space capsule sends back radio and television signals from Mars.
1973: The Asian Vegetable Research and Development Center formally opens in Shanhua, Tainan County.
1974: A three-month exhibition of Chinese products is opened in Taipei by Economics Minister Y.S. Sun. The exhibition has 10 pavilions with 859 showrooms and 465 retail booths.
1975: U.S. President Gerald Ford delivers his "New Pacifism" speech in Hawaii.
1975: Premier Chiang Ching-kuo announces the ROC government's plan to build Asia's most modern farm villages under the first Six-Year Economic Development Plan beginning in 1976.
1975: Indonesian troops enter East Timor as civil war breaks out after the Portuguese, rulers of East Timor for three centuries, leave the colony.
1978: Japanese Prime Minister Masayoshi Ohira forms a new Cabinet.
1982: Robbers make away with more than NT$14 million from an armored truck of the United World Chinese Commercial Bank in Taipei.
1984: The Legislative Yuan passes the Special Education Law after its third reading.
1985: The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs announces the severing of diplomatic ties with the Republic of Nicaragua.
1986: The new Taipei City Zoo is inaugurated in the Taipei suburb of Mucha.
1988: A massive earthquake claims over 100,000 lives in Soviet Armenia.
1989: Lithuania abolishes the constitutional guarantee of Communist Party supremacy and legalizes the multiparty system.
1993: Ivory Coast President Felix Houphouet-Boigny, Africa's longest-serving ruler, dies.
1996: The space shuttle Columbia and its crew return safely to earth after ending the longest space shuttle flight ever at nearly 18 days.
1999: Premier Vincent Siew accepts the resignation of Cabinet member Peng Tso-kwei as chairman of the Council of Agriculture and appoints Ling Shiang-nung to fill the vacancy.
2000: Justice Minister Chen Ding-nan appeals to the government of France for judicial cooperation between the two countries to help in the investigation of kickback allegations surrounding the ROC Navy's purchase of six Lafayette-class frigates some 10 years earlier.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is indeed a pleasure to acquire knowledge and, as you go on acquiring, to put into practice what you have acquired. A greater pleasure still is when friends of congenial minds come from afar to seek you out because of your attainments."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI, BEIJING CAN BUILD TRUST THROUGH WTO FRAMEWORK: ROC OFFICIAL
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 13 (CNA) (By Nelson Chung and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: Taipei has no intention of discussing political issues with Beijing within the World Trade Organization (WTO) framework but believes the two sides can build trust and develop rules of mutual engagement through WTO trade discussions, an ROC official said Thursday.

Mainland Affairs Council Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen said in a speech delivered at the Heritage Foundation, a conservative Washington think tank, that the possibility of increasing trust and developing mutual engagement rules already exists but remains dependent on whether leaders in Beijing are willing to explore such a possibility.
Taiwan's top planner on mainland China policy pointed out that the most difficult part will be the process of finding common interests and beginning a dialogue.

Tsai said that WTO entry represents a major opportunity for the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to interact in a more structured and systematic manner, helping to stabilize bilateral relations and allow both sides to focus on their own respective internal reforms.

She said that the relationship between Taiwan and mainland China is complex and requires careful handling because the mainland is both a source of military intimidation and a trading partner for Taiwan.

Bilateral interaction will be checked by the international community's common expectations, she said, adding that both governments will face new challenges in the wake of their WTO entry due to the tremendous changes that will occur to their domestic economies and to their political and social structures.
"If the two governments are unable to face these challenges, the damage brought about by WTO entry will exceed the benefits," she noted.
Tsai also reiterated that the Republic of China government's mainland policy remains focused on maintaining peace and stability without provoking Beijing despite political differences.

She added that Taipei's basic stance on cross-strait relations also includes ROC President Chen Shui-bian's proposal of aiming to ultimately achieve political integration through economic and cultural integration, as well as the "five noes" as spelled out in his inauguration speech.

Namely, the five noes are: no declaration of independence as long as Beijing does not intend to use force against the island, no change in the nation's official name, no adoption of the "state-to-state" theory into the ROC Constitution, no referendum on the fate of the nation in regard to the unification versus independence issue during his term in office, and no abrogation of the Guidelines for National Unification.

Tsai is on a three-day visit to the U.S. capital to brief U.S. scholars and politicians on Taiwan's political situation and policy direction in the wake of the Dec. 1 elections which made the ruling Democratic Progressive Party the party with the most seats in the Legislative Yuan for the first time.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC DEPUTY CHIEF STRESSES SIGNIFICANCE OF INTERMEDIARY CHANNELS

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Lin Chong-pin urged Beijing Friday to make the most of the existing intermediary channels across the Taiwan Strait and contribute to constructive interactions between the two sides.

Lin called for the Beijing authorities to take advantage of the functions of the Taiwan-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and its Beijing counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), which were established in February and December 1991, respectively, by the governments on the two sides as intermediary arms for formal dialogue on issues pertaining to cross-strait affairs.

The MAC deputy chief stressed that Taiwan's invitation to ARATS Chairman Wang Daohan for a formal visit to Taiwan remains open and will continue to remain open in the hopes that the mainland Chinese authorities will make the most of the two intermediary bodies to resume cross-strait dialogue which has been suspended since 1996.
Lin said that regardless of how much cross-strait relations have fluctuated in recent years, the Taiwan public's support for the invitation to Wang has remained high in all public opinion polls.
He added that the MAC will continue to create "windows of opportunity" for the resumption of cross-strait dialogue and to call for Beijing to make a favorable response to Taiwan's initiative.
Noting that the two sides do not lack formal intermediary bodies to resume cross-strait dialogue, Lin said the only thing at present that is required is a positive response from Beijing.

Lin said many practical issues, including protection for Taiwan investments in mainland China, intellectual property rights protection, the repatriation of illegal mainland Chinese immigrants, judicial assistance and agricultural cooperation, remain urgently in need of being tackled by the participation of officials from both sides.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES UP BY 79.19 POINTS

TEXT.P: After a setback the previous day, the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) continued its recent upward streak on Friday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving up 79.19 points to close at 5,486.73.
Market turnover amounted to NT$156.95 billion (US$4.55 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIWAN STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened lower and closed unexpectedly higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 79.19 points to close at 5,486.73.

Affected by a nose-dive in U.S. stock prices Thursday, the bourse opened at 5,293.52, the day's lowest point, but gained momentum in later hours as funds poured in on speculation of a bright future for the market. The index fluctuated between 5,293.52 and 5,486.73 during trading.

A total of 5.17 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$156.95 billion (US$4.55 billion), compared with the previous trading session which saw 7.13 billion shares change hands on a market turnover of NT$226.2 billion (US$6.57 billion).

Six of the eight major stocks categories gained ground, with banking stocks moving up the most at 3.4 percent, followed by pulp and paper shares at 1.7 percent, electrical stocks at 1.5 percent, construction issues at 0.9 percent, textile stocks at 0.6 percent, and plastics and chemical shares at 0.1 percent.
Two categories posted losses, with cement stocks moving down the most at 1.2 percent, followed by foodstuff issues at 0.4 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 355 to 220, with 72 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC, SAO TOME AND PRINCIPE PRESIDENTS PLEDGE EXPANDED COOPERATION

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian and visiting Sao Tome and Principe President Fradique Bandeira Melo de Menezes pledged to expand bilateral cooperation in a joint communique issued Friday before Menezes ended his five-day state visit to Taipei.

In the joint communique, Chen praised his counterpart from the West African island republic for his efforts at political, economic and social reform, and Menezes congratulated Chen for Taiwan's impending Jan. 1 World Trade Organization entry.
Menezes pledged that his country will continue to help the Republic of China to gain participation in other international organizations including the United Nations.

The two presidents jointly called on the international community to adopt immediate and effective measures to combat the global challenges that threaten world peace and development, namely international terrorism, AIDS, poverty and environmental degradation.
Menezes expressed his full support for the ROC government's efforts at resolving the various differences on cross-Taiwan Strait issues through peaceful dialogue.

At the communique signing ceremony, Menezes thanked Chen for his hospitality and expressed gratitude for the ROC government's assistance to Sao Tome and Principle in agricultural and economic development as well as in medical services over the past years.
Chen accepted an invitation by Menezes to visit Sao Tome and Principe, with the date to be decided later through bilateral diplomatic channels.

In a farewell ceremony, Menezes was accorded full military honors, complete with a 21-gun salute. He and his 10-member entourage, which arrived in Taiwan Monday, departed from Chiang Kai-shek International Airport.
Menezes was elected the West African state's third popularly elected president in a landslide victory in July this year. This was his first visit to Taiwan.
The Republic of Sao Tome and Principe, consisting of two islands off the west coast of Africa totaling 960 square kilometers in area, has a population of 160,000.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIWAN FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taiwan's stock index futures market ended higher Friday as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) capitalization weighted index futures for December edged up 125 points to close at 5,550, with 23,316 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX index futures for next January rose 85 points to close at 5,520, with 1,249 contract transactions, while next March futures surged 108 points to finish at 5,530, with two contracts traded.
Next June futures gained 150 points to close at 5,750, with seven contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX index futures trading were set Friday at 5,425 for December, 5,435 for next January, 5,422 for next March, 5,600 for next June, and 5,501 for next September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on TAIEX-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also higher.
December TE futures moved up 4.10 points to close at 288, with 5,833 contract transactions, while next January TE futures increased 6.80 points to finish at 289, with 265 contracts traded.
Next June TE futures declined three points to close at 289, with 19 contracts traded.
No transactions were reported for other months.

December TF futures moved up 41.2 points to finish at 786, with 4,421 contract transactions, while next January TF futures rose 44 points to close at 785, with 279 contracts traded. Next September TF futures surged 41.2 points to close at 788.2, with one contract traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO STOP PROVIDING AVIATION INSURANCE COVERAGE GUARANTEE

TEXT.P: The government won't continue to provide a war risk insurance coverage guarantee to domestic airlines after Dec. 25 as the insurance market has gradually returned to normal three months after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks on America, the transportation ministry said Friday.

According to a Ministry of Transportation and Communications news release, domestic airlines should be able to purchase adequate aviation insurance on the market as other regional airlines in Japan, the Philippines, Vietnam, Indonesia, Thailand, New Zealand, India and Bangladesh have already been able to purchase reasonable coverage.
Therefore, the ministry will not recommend to the Cabinet that it continue providing the coverage guarantee, the statement added.

In late September, the Legislative Yuan approved the administration's plan to provide a 30-day war risk insurance coverage guarantee to domestic airlines, effective until Oct. 25. That plan was later extended by one month on two occasions, with the coverage guarantee now scheduled to end Dec. 25.

In the wake of the terrorist attacks on America, international underwriters raised aviation insurance premiums across the board and slashed the maximum third-party liability compensation from US$1.5 billion per accident to only US$50 million, dealing a major blow to the world's airline industry.

The government's financial guarantee gave the nation's airlines temporary coverage above that amount in the event of any claims resulting from hijackings or war while giving the companies time to negotiate new contracts with insurance companies.
The U.S. government and a number of other governments around the world also helped their aviation industries through their difficult times by providing similar assistance.

Airlines sometimes operate with rented aircraft that come with contract clauses stating that certain amounts of insurance coverage must be obtained. If an airline is unable to purchase the adequate amount of insurance, this is tantamount to breaking the rental contract, thereby giving the rental companies the legal right to forcibly repossess the planes.
An airport could also demand adequate insurance coverage before allowing a plane to land.

DOC.HEADLINE: ORGANS OF MAN WHO DIED IN ACCIDENTAL FALL TO BENEFIT 50 PEOPLE

TEXT.P: The family of a young man in eastern Hualien County who died Wednesday of an accidental fall donated his organs, benefiting 50 people, doctors said Friday.
The young man, surnamed Chen, was declared brain dead by doctors at the Buddhist Tzu Chi Medical Center in Hualien after receiving emergency treatment Wednesday.
Chen was confirmed brain dead Thursday after doctors double-checked his condition and reconfirmed their earlier diagnosis.

His family then agreed to allow all of Chen's organs to be donated, whereupon Tzu Chi Medical Center surgeons began harvesting the organs -- all of which were in good condition because of Chen's youth.

Doctors said Chen's kidneys, corneas and skin would be placed in storage in readiness for transplants to be conducted at the Tzu Chi Medical Center. His bones were deposited in the Tzu Chi Bone Bank, while his heart and liver were transferred to National Taiwan University Hospital in Taipei for transplants there.
The doctors said that almost all Chen's organs had already been allocated to recipients, but added that further comparisons will need to be made in order to find suitable recipients for his lungs.
It is estimated that Chen's donation will benefit 50 people awaiting transplants.
Despite sadness over the death of his son, the senior Chen said he took comfort from the thought that his son's organs are helping to save 50 other people.

DOC.HEADLINE: N.T. DOLLAR UP DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar dropped NT$0.031 against the greenback on the Taipei foreign exchange market Friday, closing at NT$34.495.
The local currency opened at NT$34.463 and was traded between NT$34.462 and NT$34.506.
Interbank U.S. dollar trading totaled US$685 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN: PARTY'S BASIC POLITICAL CONCEPT REMAINS UNCHANGED

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan said Friday that the KMT's basic concept remains unchanged despite the party's upset in the Dec. 1 legislative elections.
He stressed that the KMT's basic political concept is based on a middle-of-the-road, rational and reformist way.
Lien made the remarks while meeting with representatives from several of the party's groups in the Legislative Yuan to exchange views on the future development of the party.

The number of seats held by the KMT in the 225-seat Legislative Yuan dropped to 68 from a pre-election 110 in the elections earlier this month so that the party lost its status as the largest party in the legislature to the ruling Democratic Progressive Party.

Several re-elected KMT legislators, including Ho Chih-hui, Chen Hsueh-sheng and Huang Chao-shun, expressed their support for Lien to continue leading the party, but at least four KMT groups in the legislature did not send representatives to the meeting.
Chen proposed that Lien should convene a symposium to discuss the direction of the KMT's future development.
KMT Secretary-General Lin Fong-cheng agreed with the proposal and instructed the KMT legislative caucus and the party's think tank to organize the symposium.

Lien, who also listened to the views of party legislators on the party's election performance, said that the KMT should conform to the pulse of the country, while sticking to its basic political ideals.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT MIGHT ALLOW PETROCHEMICAL INVESTMENT IN MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: The government may allow domestic petrochemical companies to invest in mainland China on a conditional basis, an official of the Ministry of Economic Affairs said Friday.
The announcement came after a meeting of a task force comprising experts and officials in which they discussed whether or not to allow such investment.

Vice Economics Minister Chen Ruey-long presided over the meeting that was also attended by Mainland Affairs Council Vice Chairman Teng Chen-chung and Chen Wu-hsiung, board chairman of the Petrochemical Industry Association of Taiwan.

No conclusion was reached but the committee decided to meet again within two weeks to review the situation and the government may allow the local petrochemical industry to invest in mainland China if mass capital outflow can be controled, the official said.
Chen said after the meeting that taking into account supply and demand, the government may consider permitting local petrochemical industry to invest in the naphtha cracking plant in mainland.

The construction of seventh and eighth naphtha cracking plants -- which would produce higher quality ethylene -- have been not smoothly implemented because difficulty with land acquisition, labor, and environmental protection issues, Chen said.

However, he went on, the ethylene produced by the second, third and fourth naphtha cracking plants operated by the Chinese Petroleum Corp. and the sixth naphtha cracking plant operated by the Formosa Plastic Group have been able to meet domestic demand, and petrochemical makers therfore thought they need to invest in the mainland to expand operations

Local industry leaders believe investment in the mainland is essential, but Chen pointed out that enormous amounts of capital are needed to invest in naphtha crackers. He added that the government should know about the source of the capital and the type of investment before giving its permission to local industry.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE TAIPEI TEAM LEAVES FOR 6TH ASIAN U-19 YOUTH RUGBY CONTEST

TEXT.P: A 27-member Chinese Taipei team left Friday for the Japanese city of Fukuoka, where it will take part in the Sixth Asian U-19 Youth Rugby Championship Tournament.
Tsai Chen-wei, board chairman of the Republic of China Rugby Football Union, presented a national flag to Tsai Kung-kuei, leader of the team.
A total of 12 teams are classified to two categories based on their accumulated ratings from past performance in competition.

Taiwan, Japan, South Korea, Hong Kong, Sri Lanka and Singapore have been classified in category A, while Kazakhstan, United Arab Emirates, Malaysia, Thailand, India and mainland China are in category B.
Category A teams will compete in Fukuoka Dec. 16-22, while the Category B teams will compete in Dubai.
Taiwan will take on South Korea Dec. 18.

A spokesman for Chinese Taipei said that the team, which won fourth place in the last competition, will hope for at least third place so that it can represent Asia in the World Cup Tournament scheduled to be held in Italy next April.

DOC.HEADLINE: HAWAII WOOS TAIWAN INVESTORS

TEXT.P: Hawaii welcomes Taiwan investors who wish to put their money into tourist hotels or the high-tech industry, a senior official of the Hawaii state government said here Friday.

Richard Bahar, director of the Commercial and Industrial Bureau of the Commerce, Industry and Tourism Department of the Hawaii state government, told the participants in a seminar on education promotion and industrial development that now is a good time for Taiwan investors to purchase Japanese-built hotels in Hawaii.
Bahar said that many Japanese-owned hotels in his state are up for sale because the Japanese economy is mired in recession and many Japanese investors are selling up.
One investor from Taiwan has already purchased a Japanese-invested hotel there, Bahar noted.
He added that Hawaii's high-tech industry is also worth investing in and has already attracted some Taiwan investment.

Bahar also encouraged Taiwan hotel operators to enter into a training cooperation agreement with the Hawaii state government, which already has a four-year training cooperation agreement with mainland China's Guangdong provincial government and plans for similar agreements with Beijing and Shanghai.

He further noted that the Hawaii state government will help investors or students who wish to pursue advanced studies in Hawaii. An investor who opens a branch company in Hawaii can obtain a green card (permanent residency status) within three months, Bahar added.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF CALLS FOR RESUMPTION OF CROSS-STRAIT TALKS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) called Friday for the resumption of cross-strait talks after years of hiatus.

The SEF, the quasi-official body authorized by the government to handle exchanges across the strait in the absence of formal contacts, made the call in a letter to its mainland counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) upon the 10th anniversary of ARATS' founding.
SEF Chairman Koo Chen-fu noted that ARATS informed SEF of its formal inauguration Dec. 16 ten years ago, signaling the opening of dialogue channels between the two sides.
Between then and 1995, Koo said, the two organs have held regular negotiations and have helped solve cross-strait disputes resulting from increasing civilian exchanges.

Koo, who met ARATS Chairman Wang Daohan in Singapore in 1993 for the historic high-level talks, visited Wang again in Shanghai in 1998 and expressed the hope that he and Wang would be able to "sit down and talk again."
Beijing unilaterally suspended talks with Taipei following a visit to the United States by former President Lee Teng-hui 1995.
He suggested that both sides begin with the building of mutual trust by resuming the suspended regular talks, which he said would allow cross-strait ties to move forward.

DOC.HEADLINE: REHEARSAL HELD FOR COMMISSION OF 1ST F-16 FIGHTER WING

TEXT.P: A rehearsal for the formal commission of Taiwan's first F-16 fighter wing was held at Chiayi air force base in southern Taiwan Friday.

Air Commander-in-Chief Chen Chao-min presided over an inspection of the 455th tactical combat aircraft wing stationed at the base involving 377 military personnel, 18 F-16 fighters An the ground and a fly-past of 24 F-16 fighters that roared over the inspection stand in combat formation.
The fighters are equipped with 20-mm cannon, AIM-7M radar guided missiles, AIM-9M air-to-air missiles, harpoon missiles and the LANTIRN (low-altitude navigation and infrared targeting for night) pod.

The ROC Air Force purchased 120 single-seat F-16 "fighting falcons" from the United States and 30 twin-seat versions in 1992 to carry out mid-altitude offshore interception missions. The first batch of the advanced fighters arrived at Chiayi air base in April 1997.

President Chen Shui-bian will preside over the commissioning ceremony next Tuesday, signifying the deployment of a new generation of fighter jets to form a modernized force that can maintain air superiority in the Taiwan Strait, according to a spokesman for the air base.

Together with 60 Mirage 2000-5s fighter jets purchased from France and 130 locally built indigenous defense fighters, these modern fighters form the backbone of the island's modernized military force, the spokesman added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TUBERCULOSIS IS TAIWAN'S 12TH-BIGGEST KILLER

TEXT.P: Tuberculosis has become the 12th-biggest killer in Taiwan, according to statistics released by the National Health Department Friday.

Taiwan has 15,000 new cases of the disease per year with 1,500 of those dying each year. Of the new yearly cases, 1,500 are communicable, a health department official said, adding that those cases can be cured after a six-month regime of antibiotics.

Tu Hsing-che, director of the Sickness Control Section of National Health Department, said that communicable tuberculosis is contracted through the air and is highly communicable. In the initial stage, its symptoms are that of a cold with fever, cough.
Tu said that people who have a persistent cough should see a physician.

DOC.HEADLINE: GIO DISPUTES U.N. CLAIMS ABOUT SEXUAL EXPLOITATION CASES IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: No more than 20,000 women and children in Taiwan have been victims of sexual abuse over the past five years, far fewer cases than has been reported by the United Nations Children Fund (UNICEF), the Government Information Office (GIO) said Friday.

In a statement in response to a UNICEF report that said that 100,000 women and children were sexually exploited in Taiwan, the GIO said what constitutes sexual exploitation is controversial, but according to statistics compiled by police, there were no more than 20,000 victims of sexual offenses in Taiwan between 1997 and October, 2001.
Only 10,576 females were attacked sexually during this time, including 6,874 minors, which made up 75 percent of the total victims, the GIO said.

In addition, police statistics show that there were 1,889 cases of sex involving minors; 1,711 minors were subjected to child-trafficking or were coerced into having sex; 603 minors were caught serving as hostesses at restaurants that allegedly offered sex to clients; and 327 children or teenagers were caught working in the sex industry.
Although the cases reported to police are always fewer than what is most likely the actual total, the figures cited by UNICEF are disproportionally high, the GIO said.
Moreover, the number of victims of sexual offenses are declining yearly, said the GIO, citing police statistics as proof.

The GIO said the Republic of China firmly supports the efforts of UNICEF to put an end to the sex trade and the confinement and abuse of children. The ROC is improving its existing laws, which already embody many of the U.N. goals, to bring them fully into harmony with international standards.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP TO HELP PROMOTE DEMOCRATIZATION IN DEVELOPING COUNTRIES

TEXT.P: Taiwan's ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will continue cooperating with other Western countries to help promote democratization in developing countries, a party official said in Manila Friday.
Tien Hsin, director of the DPP's international affairs department, made the remarks while speaking at an international conference on the democratization of Myanmar.
He said that Taiwan has drawn international attention with two achievements -- economic development and democratization.
The DPP official noted that Taiwan has in the past used its economic power to expand its external influence, but has not yet used its achievement in democratization as a tool.
He said that the island's example will be helpful to countries that have encountered difficulties in the development of democracy.
As Taiwan has completed democratization in only 15 years, Tien said that its experience will be significant and valuable for other developing countries.
He said that the DPP will cooperate with the National Democratic Institute of the United States next month to raise Taiwan's international profile within the context of democratization.

The Manila meeting, with "the dawning of democracy" as its theme, was designed to promote democratization in Myanmar. It was jointly organized by a Philippine think tank and a news organization in Myanmar with the support of the DPP and the Jean Jaures Foundation.
Participants were from Australia, Myanmar, Bangladesh, India, the Philippines, Taiwan, Thailand and the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHIEF JUDGE OF PEACE AWARD SPEAKS OUT IN DEFENSE OF CO-ORGANIZER

TEXT.P: The chief judge of an organization that recently awarded Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu a peace prize defended Friday the integrity of the World Peace Corps Mission (WPCM) after a local magazine accused one of its co-founders of being a con man.

Lester Wolff, former U.S. congressman and chief judge of the WPCM, made the remarks after Next magazine reported that Han Min Su, the South Korean organizer of the WPCM, which awarded the World Peace Prize to Lu in Taipei last Sunday, had tried to bilk money from the island kingdom of Tonga.

Wolff condemned the magazine's report that said Han had offered the King of Tonga, Taufa'ahau Tupou IV, the peace prize in 1996 and in exchange for Tonga building a plant Han touted as being able to convert sea water into natural gas.

The entire incident had been blown out of proportion in the Tongan media at the time, Wolff said, adding that he had documentation to prove his statements -- a signed apology by the prime minister of Tonga to the WPCM for any misunderstanding.
Wolff said that it is ridiculous for Next magazine to publish such an unfounded report.

Lu's office said Thursday that it would look into the magazine report about the alleged bungled business deal, but it said that Han's private business had nothing to do with the peace organization which was established in 1989.

Wolff also said that the organization is run independently and does not receive subsidies from any governments, including Taiwan. He also said that Han has kept the operation of the organization low-profile, and has not hyped it as is the case with the Nobel prizes.
Wolff said he met with Lu several times and admired her for her long-term efforts in promoting women's and human rights, and peace, saying that Lu is "well deserving of the award."

The former U.S. congressman also said that there are three kinds of awards bestowed by the organization, and only four political leaders have received the top awards -- former U.S. President Ronald Reagan, former Israel Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin, Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak, and Lu. The ones bestowed on Cambodia Primer Minister Hun Sen and Tonga King Taufa'ahau Tupou IV are from a different category, and the media in Taiwan has confused the two.

Regarding giving an award to former South Korean President Syngman Rhee who has been dead for over 30 years, Wolff said that it is fairly common to award someone posthumously for his contributions during their lifetime. He also defended giving the award to such a controversial figure as Hun Sen, saying that the prize also aims to encourage people to make changes.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMOSA'S HDPE PLANT IN LINYUAN STOPS PRODUCTION AFTER FIRES

TEXT.P: The two production lines of the Formosa Group's high-density polyethylene (HDPE) plant in Linyuan, Kaohsiung County, were halted by fires Friday.
An official with the Formosa Group, the largest producer of HDPE in Taiwan, said that the accident will not affect market supply.
He said that the Linyuan plant produces 180,000 tons of HDPE annually, while the group's other plant in Yunlin County is capable of producing 200,000 tons per year.
Polyethylene is used in the manufacture of various kinds of plastics.
A petrochemical company in Kaohsiung also produces HDPE, the official added.
Preliminary investigations have found that the fires were caused by explosions of a chemical gas leaked from the loosened part of a connecting ring on the production line.

Ten fire engines and about 100 firefighters were mobilized to fight the fires which were extinguished after about two-and-a-half hours. Two workers suffered from burns and were rushed to hospital for treatment.
Officials from the Kaohsiung County Government and the Council for Labor Affairs visited the scene after the fires. They ordered a halt to the production lines for safety considerations.
Company officials said that one of the damaged production lines is likely to resume operations in a week, while the repairs for the second production line may take as long as a month.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN, NORTH KOREA TO VIE FOR TROPHY OF ASIAN WOMEN'S FOOTBALL

TEXT.P: North Korea upset defending mainland China 3-1 and Japan defeated South Korea 2-1 in the semifinals of the 2001 Asian Women's Football Championship in Taipei Friday.
After one day of rest Saturday, North Korea and Japan will meet in the final Sunday to vie for the 2001 title which has been held by mainland China for seven straight years.
Mainland China will play against South Korea for third place before the final.
In Friday's semifinals, North Korea led mainland China 2-1 at the half. North Korea scored another goal in the second half.
The coach for mainland China, Ma Yuanan, admitted that the defeat to North Korea was the most bitter experience of the mainland team in the past decade.
The mainland Chinese team had been the title holder of the Asian Games three times between 1990-1998 and the Asian Women's Football champions for the last seven years.
He said that he hopes the mainland team will make a comeback in the not too distant future.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1ST PRESIDENTIAL CULTURE AWARD CEREMONY TO BE HELD TUESDAY

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian will present first-ever awards for cultural achievements at a ceremony at the Presidential Office Tuesday.

The awards in five categories are the Yushan (jade mountain) award, given to an entire community for their collective contribution to their neighborhood; the Paihe (lily) award, given for artistic creation and cultural exchanges; the Puti (Bodhi) award, given for ethnic peace and harmony; the Taiyang (sun) award, given for social service; and the Fengtieh (colorful butterfly) award, given for environmental conservation. The Fengtieh award was not given out this year as no one was deemed qualified.

The four winners this year were announced earlier and they are Master Cheng Yen, founder of Taiwan's largest charity organization, the Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Foundation for the Taiyang award; Shanmei community in Mt. Ali for the Yushan award; Lin Chung-yi for the Puti award; and Wu Shou-li for the Paihe award.
Each winner will receive a commemorative plaque and NT$1 million (US$28,985).

DOC.HEADLINE: GRAND JUSTICES RULE ON SEARCHES WITHOUT WARRANTS BY POLICE

TEXT.P: Police searches without warrants are not unconstitutional, but such searches must be conducted only under special circumstances and with proper justification, the Council of Grand Justices ruled Friday.

In an interpretation of a provision of the Police Operation Statute, the Grand Justices said the statute, which provides for the right for searches without warrants, does not empower police to carry out inspections whenever, wherever and on whomever they choose.

Rather, the Grand Justices said, such searches should be limited to places, vehicles or public sites where the risk to public safety has been clearly established or where such searches would be needed to achieve a specific objective to mitigate such risks.

Noting that body searches and investigations into residents and places of business have been considered routine by police, the Grand Justices said that such measures can easily be construed to be a serious infringement on the freedom of movement, privacy and right to property of individuals. The Grand Justices added that the legal requirements and procedures for making police searches without warrants which are absent in the existing law should be written down clearly and in detail.
Police should identify themselves by showing proper documents before performing such searches and inform citizens of the reasons for the searches.

When challenged, police may overrule the objections of the citizens and carry out the search if their commander at the site determines that there are sufficient grounds for the search, and must give documentation that acknowledges the details of the search to citizens who protest.
The documentation may serve as the basis of any ensuing legal actions, the Grand Justices said.
The Grand Justices also concluded that police should follow their ruling regarding searches without warrants immediately, and revise the Police Operation Statue within two years.

In a news conference called to make public the ruling, Judicial Yuan Secretary-General Yang Jen-shou said from now on, the public can refuse any police inspection not in line with the Grand Justices' ruling, and police who perform such inspections are risking infringing the personal freedom of the citizens of the nation.

Under this ruling, Yang said police will no longer be able to raid such establishments as restaurants and love hotels as they often do currently unless there is reasonable suspicion that the establishment in question is in fact engaging in illegal activities.
The days when police can scrutinize these places at random are gone, Yang said.

However, Friday's ruling will not stop the police practice of setting up road blocks to prevent teenagers racing on their motorcycles as this situation presents a clear risk to the public and meets the requirement of a clear objective in conducting searches, Yang said.
However, even this practice is not to be done beyond what is reasonable or to the detriment of the ordinary life of the general public, Yang said.
Although the Grand Justices' ruling has drawn praise from human rights activists, police have lambasted their interpretation.
Lin Hsin-ho, a director of the Chinese Association For Human Rights lauded the ruling as a small step toward better protection of human rights, but said that there is much yet to be done.
He criticized police searches as a serious infringement of personal freedom and said that the practice should be done away with completely.
