Lin also said that the two-year grace period to conform the Police Operation Statute to the ruling of the Grand Justices is too long. One year ought to be enough, he said.
Meanwhile, rank-and-file police reacted angrily to the ruling, saying it will deteriorate the already frayed social order and peace.

Police protect the general public by inspecting areas known to be frequented by criminals, they say, and checking people in these areas is one good way to keep a check on their activities. Limiting the rights of the police to make searches will please potential law-breakers, but hurt the law-abiding public, some police said privately.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER CONFIDENT OF ECONOMIC REBOUND NEXT YEAR

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Friday that he is "100 percent sure" that the economy will rebound next year.

Fielding questions in the legislature, the premier also said that economic growth is expected to reach 2.7 percent, and the jobless rate will be kept at under 4.0 percent next year, based on the plan presented by the Council for Economic Planning and Development.

Chang was responding to legislator Lee Chia-chin of the opposition Kuomintang, who asked the premier to show the determination to reinvigorate the economy so that the stock market could rebound to the 7,000-point level. The market closed at 5,486.73 Friday.
The premier said that he is quite confident about an economic rebound, but he will have to "respect market mechanisms" regarding the stock market.
Lee said that the Executive Yuan has always adjusted the economic growth downward, saying that he found the figure of 2.7 percent economic growth quite "incredible."

The premier said that economic difficulties have been the result of the world economic downturn and the entrenched ills of domestic grass-roots financial institutions. Looking to the future of the economy, he said he was confident that the situation will improve after the recent overhaul of the grass-roots financial institutions.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DELEGATION WINS SUPPORT FROM U.S. CONGRESSIONAL LEADERS

TEXT.P: A high-ranking delegation of ROC officials called on influential members of Congress Thursday and received pledges of continued support and friendship.

House Republican Whip Rep. Tom Delay (R-TX) told the delegation led by Secretary-General of the Executive Yuan Chiou I-jen that he will continue to support Taiwan's efforts to participate in the World Health Organization and other world bodies.

Tipped to become the next House Republican leader, Delay has been a staunch supporter of Taiwan on Capitol Hill and played a crucial role in winning better treatment for President Chen Shui-bian during his transit in New York and Houston last summer.

Chiou is at the head of a four-member delegation which arrived in Washington Tuesday to brief U.S. members of Congress, think tank experts and administration officials on Taiwan's latest developments following the Dec. 1 Legislative Yuan and county and municipal elections.

Other members of the delegation include Tsai Ing-wen, head of the Mainland Affairs Council, Eugene Chien, deputy secretary-general of the Presidential Office and Wu An-jia, member of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs' Coordination Council for North American Affairs.

Earlier in the day, the delegation had a closed-door discussion with Henry Hyde (R-IL), chairman of the House International Relations Committee. They also called on Jeff Bingaman (D-NM), chairman of the Senate Energy Committee.
In a statement released to the media, Hyde called the latest election in Taiwan "the completion of a democratic revolution which began with the presidential elections of 1996 and 2000."

"Taiwan has now seen a peaceful transfer of both executive and legislative power," he said, adding that the island "remains the model for democracy with Chinese characteristics and a beacon of hope for freedom- loving people throughout the Chinese world."

During the three-day visit, Chiou and his delegation also held discussions with officials representing the White House National Security Council, the State Department and the Defense Department although neither side would comment on the meetings.

On Thursday evening, the delegation met with several former U.S. officials at a dinner at Twin Oaks, including Walter Slocombe and Stanley Roth, both holding senior positions during the previous Clinton administration.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Dec. 15, or the 1st day of the 11th month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1891: The Bill of Rights, the first 10 amendments to the U.S. Constitution, goes into effect.
1915: Noted Taiwan folklore writer Chung Li-ho is born.
1920: China and Austria are admitted into the League of Nations.
1927: The Republic of China government orders the closure of the Soviet consulate in Shanghai and begins rounding up communists following an attempted communist coup in Canton the day before.
1931: Chiang Kai-shek, chairman and premier of the Nationalist government, retires, citing the interests of party unity as the reason for his move.
1938: The United States agrees to lend US$25 million to China under a Sino-American oil loan agreement.
1944: Chinese expeditionary forces capture Bhamo in northern Burma.
1946: The U.N. General Assembly decides to set up its permanent headquarters in New York City.
1948: France completes the construction of its first nuclear reactor.
1949: The ROC Executive Yuan names Wu Kuo-chen as governor of Taiwan.
1952: Beijing rejects India's plan for a Korean armistice.
1961: The U.N. General Assembly votes against a Soviet proposal to admit Communist China as a member.
1965: The U.S. Mariner spacecraft flies past Venus and relays data about the planet to scientists on Earth.
1966: Walter Elias Disney -- the U.S. animator, showman and film producer known as "Walt" -- dies at the age of 65.
1970: The first Sino-American Conference on Mainland China is opened in Taipei.
1971: The state-run Bank of China becomes a private bank and changes its name to the International Commercial Bank of China.
1972: The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with the Malagasy Republic.
1972: The Japanese embassies in Taipei and Kaohsiung are closed.
1973: Tachien Dam, which had been under construction in central Taiwan for four years, becomes operational.
1977: A newly built integrated steel plant of the state-run China Steel Corp. starts operating in Kaohsiung.
1978: U.S. President Jimmy Carter announces that he will establish diplomatic relations with Communist China from Jan. 1, 1979, and break off relations with the Republic of China at the same time.
1978: The "Chang Sheng," the first Taiwan-built 20,000-ton container vessel, is launched in Keelung.
1980: The ROC's Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park is inaugurated.
1988: The U.N. General Assembly overwhelmingly calls for the convening of an international Middle East peace conference.
1993: The ROC Legislative Yuan approves a revision of the University Law, giving more autonomy to colleges and allowing students to participate in meetings related to school affairs.
1995: Beijing sentences Wei Jingsheng, a noted dissident, to 14 years in jail for "conspiring to subvert the government," a move that arouses international condemnation.
1999: The U.S. State Department clarifies its stance on the ROC's bid to join the World Health Organization, saying the U.S. supports Taiwan's "meaningful participation," not its membership, in the body.
2000: Chiang Peng-chien, a member of the Control Yuan and founding chairman of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), dies of pancreatic cancer at the age of 61.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Think how anxious your parents are when you are sick, and you will know your duty toward them. The duty of a good son nowadays means only to be able to support his parents. But you also keep your dogs and horses alive. If there is no feeling of love and respect, where is the difference?"

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Saturday are as follows:
The China Times:
The Council of Grand Justices rule that random raids without search warrants went against the laws of the Constitution.
The United Daily News:
Grand justices: police search must be lawful.
The Liberty Times:
Grand justices say police should stop conducting random spot checks, raids or frisks without due authority.
The Taiwan Daily:
One more DPP legislator jumps in rhetoric dogfight.
The Central Daily News:
Police's practice of raiding people's homes and belongings without legal reason will be outlawed by a new interpretation of the Constitution.
The China Post:
Police searches must be lawful: Grand Justices.
@The Taiwan News:
Grand Justices restrict police powers; Highest court rules mass searches in violation of Constitution.
The Taipei Times:
Judges tell police to act within laws.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC HOPING TO ADOPT FRENCH PRESIDENTIAL SYSTEM: ROC OFFICIAL
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 14 (CNA) (By Nelson Chung and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: A visiting Republic of China official said Friday that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) might consider amending the ROC Constitution and adopt a presidential system similar to that used in France.

Cabinet Secretary-General Chiou I-jen said in a meeting with 20 U.S. think tank scholars that the existing "dual leadership" system where the head of state is the president and the head of government is the premier causes confusion over constitutional authority.

However, Chiou went on, constitutional reform to resolve the problem is unlikely in the short term. The government will instead first focus on streamlining the existing 36 ministries and government agencies and adjusting the relationship between the central government and local governments, he added.
The DPP administration has announced that it hopes to complete the first stage of government reform next year by ratifying the necessary amendments to slim down the Executive Yuan by a third.

Chiou said that his recent remarks on the DPP administration's plans to promote a three-branch system of government merely touched on one aspect of reform that the government hopes to undertake. He told reporters Wednesday at the National Press Club in Washington that the DPP has always wanted to adopt a constitutional system similar to the three-branch system used in the United States, instead of the five-branch system currently in place.

The ROC Constitution, promulgated in 1947, installed a complex system of checks and balances between the five branches of government -- the Executive Yuan, the Legislative Yuan, the Judicial Yuan, the Examination Yuan and the Control Yuan -- with a president serving as the head of state.

Chiou added that the government will also focus on cutting down on the number of legislative seats and introducing a single-seat district system whereby each person would cast two votes -- one for a legislative candidate, another for a party.

The current system has voters in one constituency return several representatives to the Legislative Yuan, making the system susceptible to factionalism because it increases the competition among candidates of one party and lowers the number of votes needed to win a seat. The system encourages candidates to attract the support of a narrow sector instead of appealing to general middle-of-the-roaders, because of the low threshold needed to be elected.

Commenting on the results of the recent Dec. 1 legislative elections, Chiou said that the DPP did not achieve its election victory because of better election strategies but rather because the people were voting for stability and reform.

Chiou is on a three-day visit to brief U.S. scholars and politicians on Taiwan's political situation and policy direction in the wake of the recent elections which gave the DPP a legislative majority for the first time.

His delegation also includes Mainland Affairs Council Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen, Presidential Office Deputy Secretary-General Eugene Chien and Wu An-chia, an official with the Coordination Council for North American Affairs under the ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs.
Chiou is scheduled to depart for Taipei Saturday, while Tsai will depart the following day.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN OFFICIALS WIN PLEDGE OF SUPPORT FROM U.S. CONGRESSMEN

TEXT.P: A high-ranking delegation of ROC officials visited influential members of Congress Thursday and received pledges of continued support and friendship.

Rep. Tom Delay (R-TX), the House Republican whip, told the delegation, led by Executive Yuan Secretary-General Chiou I-jen that he will continue to support Taiwan's efforts to participate in the World Health Organization and other international bodies.

Tipped to become the next House Republican leader, Delay has been a staunch supporter of Taiwan on Capitol Hill and played a crucial role in winning better treatment for President Chen Shui-bian during his transit stops in New York and Houston last summer.

Chiou is head of the four-member delegation that arrived in Washington on Tuesday for a three-day visit to brief U.S. members of Congress, think tank experts and administration officials on Taiwan's latest developments following the Dec. 1 Legislative Yuan and city and county chief elections.

The rest of the delegation consists of Tsai Ing-wen, head of the Mainland Affairs Council, Eugene Chien, deputy secretary-general of the Presidential Office and Wu An-jia, member of the Foreign Ministry's Coordination Council for North American Affairs.

Earlier in the day, the delegation had a closed-door discussion with Henry Hyde (R-IL), chairman of the House International Relations Committee. They also called on Jeff Bingaman (D-NM), chairman of the Senate Energy Committee.
In a statement released to the press, Hyde described the recent elections as "the completion of a democratic revolution that began with the presidential elections of 1996 and 2000."

"Taiwan has now seen a peaceful transfer of both executive and legislative power," he said, adding that the island "remains the model for democracy with Chinese characteristics and a beacon of hope for freedom-loving people throughout the Chinese world."

The delegation also held discussions with officials representing the White House National Security Council, the State Department and the Defense Department, although neither side would comment on the meetings.
Later Thursday, the delegation met with several former U.S. officials, including Walter Slocombe and Stanley Roth, both of whom held senior positions during the Clinton administration.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC DEFENSE MINISTER TO MAKE STOPOVER IN NEW YORK
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Dec. 14 (CNA) (By Eric Tseng and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Republic of China National Defense Minister Wu Shih-wen is scheduled to make a two-day stopover in New York Sunday and Monday on his way home from a visit to Central America.
Wu, who will be returning from a week-long official visit to the Dominican Republic -- one of the ROC's diplomatic allies -- is scheduled to depart Santo Domingo Sunday for New York.

During his stopover, Wu, the first ROC defense minister to visit the United States in recent decades, will meet with representatives of the overseas Chinese and Taiwanese communities in the Greater New York area.
A native of Taishan, in mainland China's Guangdong Province, Wu is also expected to visit the New York-based Taishan Clan Association and pay his respects to his Taishan ancestors.
Wu's father was an ROC legislator from Taishan and some of Wu's distant relatives live in the Greater New York area.
Wu was appointed defense minister last year after former Defense Minister Tang Fei was appointed premier by President Chen Shui-bian.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI INTERNATIONAL BIO-TECH EXPOSITION OPENS

TEXT.P: The Second International Bio Science and Technology Exposition opened at the Taipei World Trade Center Saturday, with over 300 firms from home and abroad participating.
The four-day event is being held to coincide with the activities of the "2001 Taipei Bio Science and Technology Week" organized by the Taipei city government.
Besides exhibiting the latest bio-tech developments, the show also features study courses and seminars.
The exposition has received wide support from bio research firms and academic institutions since it was first held in September last year.

The Ministry of Education, six other government agencies and 26 other official and unofficial institutions, including National Taiwan University, National Chunghsing University, National Sun Yat-sen University, the Taipei City Government and the Kaohsiung City Government, support the exposition.
More than 20 companies from Germany, the United States, South Korea and mainland China are exhibiting their products at the show's international pavilion.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER OPPOSED TO RASH BARRING OFFICIALS FROM MEDIA OPERATIONS

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Saturday that the government's decision to bar partisan, government and military influences from domestic media, particularly TV, should not be implemented rashly.

Amid rising calls for such influences to be pulled out of Taiwan's mass media circles, Chang said such moves would result in "commercialization and profiteering" of the media if acted upon too hastily.

Chang said the Executive Yuan had already instructed the Government Information Office, the Ministry of Education and other related government agencies to work out measures to implement the policy, which he was keen to stress is a long-term goal with no set timetable.

Chang added that the most important consideration at the moment is to inject the media with more professionals with practical experience in the media industry and to then gradually begin phasing out political influences.

Also Saturday, Hu Chung-hsin, host of a television talk show and author of "Son of Taiwan" -- a biography of President Chen Shui-bian -- urged Chen to personally make sure that political, governmental and military influence in the media is ended once and for all.
Hu said Chen had promised to do this during his presidential election campaign and that it is time for him to deliver on his promise.
Hu also called for independent legislator-elect Sisy Chen to quit her job as presenter of a political talk show on a local cable channel, to avoid "straddling two boats -- politics and the media."

Meanwhile, Chang Hsien-yao, director of the Policy Coordination Center of the opposition People First Party (PFP), said the PFP is working to establish a supra-party Rainbow Alliance aimed at helping the president eradicate political, governmental and military influence from the media.

Chang also said that Trong Chai, a legislator of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, should quit his post as chairman of the Taiwan National Broadcasting Company television station before attempting to seek election as president of the Legislative Yuan in February.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN DEPARTS FOR JAPAN

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan left Saturday for Japan for a week-long visit, making him the first KMT chairman to visit Japan since the party moved its headquarters to Taiwan in 1950.

Visiting at the invitation of the Japan-ROC Dietmen Council, a Japanese partisan parliamentary organization that promotes closer Taiwan-Japan relations, Lien is scheduled to call on ruling Liberal Democratic Party leaders, government officials and other Japanese parliamentarians.
KMT sources said that during his stay in Japan, Lien is also expected to inspect the operations of the KMT's Tokyo chapter and meet with overseas Chinese community leaders.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DOES NOT NEED TO ADOPT FRENCH PRESIDENTIAL SYSTEM: SCHOLAR

TEXT.P: The government has no need to adopt a presidential system similar to that used in France, a scholar said Saturday in response to a government official's remarks on possible reforms.

Soochow University political science professor Sheng Chih-jen said that although the similarities between the Republic of China's and France's constitutional systems would make the scope of such amendments relatively small, there is no urgency to resolve the inherent confusion of the existing "dual leadership" system.

This, he went on, is because a constitutional precedence has just been established whereby the president has the authority to form the Cabinet regardless of whether his or her political party is the majority party in the legislature.

Under the ROC Constitution, the head of state is the president, while the head of government is the premier, who is appointed by the president. The ruling and opposition parties have been at odds as to whether an opposition party or coalition with a legislative majority -- either relative or absolute -- should have the right to form the Cabinet, or whether that power should remain in the hands of the president even if his party has a legislative minority.

Sheng said that President Chen Shui-bian established constitutional precedence by declaring before the Dec. 1 legislative elections that regardless of the election results, he would form a "national stabilization alliance" that would be allowed to recommend Cabinet members, although he would retain the actual right to form the Cabinet.

As the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) emerged from the elections as the largest party in the Legislative Yuan, Sheng went on, Chen has in effect secured the precedence that a president has the right to name the premier and form the Cabinet even if his party does not have an absolute legislative majority.
The previous Kuomintang (KMT) administration never had to face a similar problem because it had always retained a legislative majority during its time in power.
Sheng said that although the ROC president cannot preside over Cabinet meetings like the French president, his constitutional authority actually far surpasses that of the French president.

The establishment of the new precedent extends the ROC president's authority beyond that of a president under a purely presidential constitutional system like that of the United States, where the Cabinet is headed directly by a president, Sheng said, because the ROC president does not have to report to the Legislative Yuan. Only the premier and his Cabinet have to answer to the legislators.

Sheng's remarks were made in response to Cabinet Secretary-General Chiou I-jen, who is currently on a three-day visit to Washington to brief U.S. experts and officials on post-election ROC policies and who said Friday that the DPP might consider adopting a presidential government system similar to the French system.

Questioning the appropriateness of adopting such a system in Taiwan, KMT spokesman Chou Shou-shun said that the DPP should stop blaming the constitutional system for the current chaos and claimed that the political instability is a result of the DPP's lack of respect for the KMT's majority in the outgoing Legislative Yuan.
Chou said that Taiwan's political situation will not be "100 percent stable" as long as the president is elected by a relative majority and not an absolute majority.
Also in Washington, Chiou said Wednesday that the DPP has always hoped to replace the current five-branch governmental system with a three-branch system similar to the U.S. system.

The ROC Constitution, promulgated in 1947, installed a complex system of checks and balances between five branches of government -- the Executive Yuan, the Legislative Yuan, the Judicial Yuan, the Examination Yuan and the Control Yuan -- while a president serves as the head of state.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CALLS FOR SPEEDY READJUSTMENT OF AGRICULTURE SECTOR

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian on Saturday called for speedy readjustment in the structure of the domestic agricultural sector to help alleviate the impact of Taiwan's accession to the World Trade Organization (WTO).

In an address at the opening of a meeting of 21 agricultural organizations in Taiwan held at the National Pingtung University of Science and Technology in the southernmost county of Pingtung, Chen said the agricultural sector should promote the specialties of local farm products and strengthen the marketing division between these and imported products as tactics for sharpening the competitive edge of domestic produce and goods.
Chen urged the agricultural sector to seek evolution in its development to allow Taiwan agriculture to become an industry "rich in technological, cultural, ecological and leisure comforts."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DETERMINED TO CREATE ASIAN SCIENTIFIC TALENT CENTER: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice Premier Lai In-jaw reiterated Saturday the government's determination to create an "Asia-Pacific center of scientific and technological personnel."
He made the remarks while speaking at the annual meeting of the ROC Management Science Society.

In order to recruit more foreign personnel with high-technology backgrounds, Lai said that the government has relaxed restrictions and provided incentives on the employment of such personnel, especially those from mainland China.
He went on to say that the government is considering establishing a dedicated channel to handle affairs related to the recruitment of foreign scientific and technological personnel.
The vice minister added that the government will also step up infrastructure development to transform Taiwan into "a paradise" so as to attract more foreigners to the island.

In this respect, he noted that in the next six years, some NT$280 billion (US$8 billion) will be used to improve the island's water supplies, while relevant measures are being taken to encourage the private sector to build power plants as a way of diversifying the nation's power resources.
Lai said that the government began implementing NT$810 billion-worth of public projects this year and added that 54 percent of the amount is being used to improve railway and highway facilities.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PREMIER OPTIMISTIC ABOUT CROSS-STRAIT ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT

TEXT.P: Former Premier Vincent Siew said in Kaohsiung Saturday that he is optimistic about the economic developments of mainland China and Taiwan after they join the World Trade Organization (WTO).
Becoming a member of the global trade regulatory body is a challenge, but it also provides opportunities, Siew said in a speech at a symposium held at National Sun Yat-sen University.
For mainland China especially, WTO membership will be a "severe test," said Siew.
"If the mainland fails to pass the test in three to five years, social problems and other troubles may arise," he went on. However, he added, "if it passes the test, the mainland will be reborn."
In Taiwan's case, Siew continued, WTO membership will mean more liberalization and globalization of the island's economic development.

He predicted that the global economic map will be changed following WTO entry for the mainland and Taiwan. The mainland became a full member recently, while Taiwan's membership will become effective Jan. 1.
Analyzing the possible impact on Taiwan, Siew said that WTO membership will deal a blow to the island's agriculture sector, with unemployment among agricultural workers likely to rise to 100,000.
Taiwan will have to improve the management of its agricultural sector and will have to try to have the island recognized as a "free trade zone," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WILLING TO PROMOTE CROSS-STRAIT EXCHANGES, SAYS PREMIER

TEXT.P: Republic of China Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said in Kaohsiung Saturday that the government is willing to promote cross-Taiwan Strait communications and exchanges with an open attitude.
He made the remarks while speaking at the opening of the "2001 Taiwan Mass Communication Forum" which was jointly organized by the Government Information Office and the Kaohsiung City Government.

The premier said that cross-strait interaction is unlikely to reach a satisfactory level overnight and urged the media to help the government promote better communications and exchanges across the strait.

Chang said that maintenance of a harmonious relationship as well as co-existence and co-prosperity across the Taiwan Strait is not only in line with the interests of the two sides but also a common expectation of the Asian-Pacific countries.
He stated that the government will take positive steps to promote communications with mainland China with an open attitude.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Sunday are as follows:
The China Times:
U.S. cancels Navy Area Missile Defense Program due to its poor performance.
The United Daily News:
A lone bomber behind a serious blasts in Guangdong Province nabbed.
The Liberty Times:
China shocked by serious of blasts in Shaanxi Province and Guangdon Province.
The Taiwan Daily:
Education reform conference concludes, pre-school education to be made part of formal education system.
The Central Daily News:
Education reform to be revamped with one-year extention of compulsory education, an expansion of students in high schools and universities, and abolishment of senior vocational schools.
The China Post:
Al-Qaida crumbles as support rolls over.
The Taiwan News:
Al-Qaida Chechens fight to death in Tora Bora.
The Taipei Times:
US again vetoes UN resolution regarding Middle East conflict.

DOC.HEADLINE: SURVEY OF COLLEGE STUDENTS SHOWS PRESIDENT FAVORED FOR REELECTION

TEXT.P: If a presidential election were held tomorrow, college students responding to a poll released Sunday said they would vote for President Chen Shui-bian for reelection.

The Chinese Culture Society conducted the survey by issuing questionnaires to 20 colleges and universities Dec. 1-15. A total of 1,563 effective samples were collected with a margin of error of 2.48 percent.

The poll showed that 38.1 percent said they would vote for President Chen if a presidential election were held tomorrow, while 26.9 percent would vote for popular Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, 16.8 percent for People First Party Chairman James Soong, and 3.6 percent for Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan.

The poll also showed that of those polled, 40.1 percent said that President Chen would likely win if a presidential election were held tomorrow, while 25.3 percent said Soong would win, 19.4 percent said Ma, and 2.6 percent named Lien.

On the performance of government leaders, the respondents said they were most satisfied with Minister of Justice Chen Ding-nan, followed by President Chen Shui-bian, Environmental Protection Administration administrator Hau Lung-bin, Minister of Education Ovid Tzeng, and Mainland Affairs Council Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen.

DOC.HEADLINE: SURVEY SHOWS TEENAGER MISERY ON THE INCREASE

TEXT.P: Taiwan's teenagers generally feel more miserable than a year ago according to a survey released Sunday.
The 2001 Teenager Misery Index, compiled by the non-profit Shiang-yang (Facing the Sun) Foundation, found that the greatest source of teenagers' sufferings is "the grim future for the nation."
It signifies the teenagers' worry about the future of the country, said the authors of the survey.

Other concerns, in order, were "lawmakers' ignorance of the people's welfare," "inappropriate behavior of politicians," "ineffective protection provided by law to law-abiding people" and "the ever-changing education policy."
To the surprise of the survey's authors, the top-10 concerns chosen by teenagers from a list of 34 possible causes of misery were politics and society.
In contrast to widely held belief, teenagers feel relative comfort with their families, ties with the opposite sex, leisure activities and the environment.

Worry about poor academic performance and not having friends of the opposite sex, the two issues that worry their parents most, are no longer a cause of concern among those interviewed, the survey said.

Compared with a similar survey conducted one year ago, the foundation said the "vision for the nation" showed the greatest drop in confidence, which signals a deepening worry among teenagers about the country's future.
The second sharp drop in confidnece was found in "social disorders," which reflects their increasing concerns over the disturbances surrounding them.
"How do you view the future?" showed the third-sharpest drop, which indicates teenagers are more pessimistic about their futures than one year ago, according to the survey.
Although "treatments from parent" is at the bottom of the misery list, it shows the parents-children conflict remains a serious issue, the foundation said.
The survey was carried out among students of junior and senior and vocational high schools between September and December. Altogether, 3,114 valid questionnaires were received.
The Shiang-yang Foundation is a non-profit organization set up last October to assist dropouts from senior and junior high schools.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC CHIEF SAYS NATIONAL SECURITY, DIGNITY KEY FOR ROC'S CHINA POLICY

TEXT.P: National security and dignity are the top priorities of the Republic of China government's mainland China policy, the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said in a news release Sunday.

Quoting remarks made by MAC Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen in a speech Saturday during a gathering with ROC nationals residing on the West Coast of the United States, the statement said Taiwan will continue promoting peace and stability across the Taiwan Strait and economic and trade exchanges between the two sides.

In an effort to build a positive atmosphere for Taiwan and mainland China to resume institutionalized dialogue to mend bilateral political disputes, Tsai was quoted as saying that the ROC government will do its best to create all possibilities to achieve the goal.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER JUSTICE MINISTER SAYS HE WILL NOT RUN FOR KAOHSIUNG MAYOR

TEXT.P: Former Minister of Justice Liao Cheng-hao said Sunday that he will not run for mayor of Kaohsiung next year as he is putting all his efforts into helping improve the social welfare of the citizens of the Republic of China.
Liao is currently chairman of the Shiang-yang (Facing the Sun) Foundation, a non-profit organization set up recently to help senior and junior high school dropouts.
Before seeking a different position, Liao said, he must consider whether the job would be maximizing his usefulness to the people.

Liao pointed out that the government and the people should join forces to improve the economy and society since the December legislative and county chiefs elections have given the nation a renewed mandate.
He called on political figures to invigorate the nation's stagnant economy with actions, not with slogans.

Speaking on the government's intention to investigate the assets of the opposition Kuomintang, Liao said he agreed that the government should look into the matter, but not before other, more pressing national issues have been attended to. He also said that he hoped that such an investigation would not be conducted solely for political purposes.

DOC.HEADLINE: INFORMATION TECNOLOGY FORUM STARTS FIVE-DAY DISCUSSIONS MONDAY

TEXT.P: A five-day discussion on Taiwan's information technology development will be held in Taipei from Dec. 17-21.

Sponsored by the Market Information Center under the auspices of the Institute for Information Industry (III), participants will review IT developments this year and map future developments for next year.
The first day, will be called the "system day," participants will center their discussions on the future development of notebook and desktop computers and their analysis of online operations.
Participants will also analyze the current combination of notebook computers, personal data assistances (PDA) and smart handheld devices and study their prospects.
They will also analyze the U.S. IT market and its future development and Taiwan's future IT development.

The forum, which will be held at the Taipei International Conference Hall, will also discuss and analyze the future development of computer displays, the integrated circuits, communications, information appliances and software during the five-day discussions.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, H.K., MACAU, M'LAND CHINA MASS MEDIA REP. VISIT GUANGZHOU
DOC.DATELINE: Macau, Dec. 16 (CNA) (By Jen Jung-hong and Ed Chen)

TEXT.P: Representatives of mass media from Taiwan, Hong Kong, Macau and mainland China visited Guangzhou and Zhungshan cities in Guangdong province Saturday after attending a seminar on the current media development in Taiwan, Hong Kong, Macau and mainland China held at Macau.

Chen Chia-ling, president of Shih Hsin University and concurrently head of the Taiwan media delegation, said that after making a visit to Guangzhou and Zhungshan, the tour will help the people in Taiwan have a better understanding of mainland China, thus helping alleviate cross-strait barriers.
Some 50 delegates visited the hometown of Dr. Sun Yat-sen, founder of the Republic of China, at Zhungshan.
Sun was born in 1866 at Village Tsuihen, Zhungshan County, Guangzhou.
They visited the Guangzhou Press Country Club and the Kuangzhou Daily News Group.
They also visited factories invested in by Taiwan businessmen in Dongguan before returning to Macau Sunday afternoon. Members of the Taiwan delegation will return to Taiwan Sunday night.

DOC.HEADLINE: EARTHQUAKE HITS ILAN

TEXT.P: An earthquake of magnitude 5.3 on the Richter scale rattled Ilan in northeast Taiwan Sunday morning. No casualties or property losses were reported, weathermen said.
An official of the Central Weather Bureau said that the epicenter of the earthquake, which occurred at 9:05 am, was located 56.9 kilometers east of Suao.
Southern Suao registered the quake as magnitude 3, while it registered 2 to l in Ilan, Suao, Taroko, Techi in Taichung, Taipei, Taoyuan, Hualien and Wuku, Taipei County.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR EXTENDS APPRECIATION FOR INDONESIAN LABORERS

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou thanked Indonesian laborers for their contributions to Taiwan and wished them a happy new year during Eid al-Fitr celebrations at the Taipei Grand Mosque Sunday.
The event marked the end of the Muslim fasting month of Ramadan as well as the start of the new year in Indonesia.
More than 50,000 Muslims celebrated the end of the month-long Ramadan in mosques in Taipei, Chungli, Taichung, Tainan and Kaohsiung.
Indonesian laborers made up the majority of the hundreds of Muslims gathering at the Taipei Grand Mosque to celebrate the new year.
The popular mayor, though not a Muslim himself, donned a jannah cap to greet Indonesian laborers and spoke a bit of Indonesian -- drawing cheers from the crowd.

Ma pointed out that there are 36,000 foreign laborers in Taipei and among them, 20,000 are Indonesian laborers who contribute much to the construction and household assistance of the city, adding that if all of them took the same day off, one fourth of Taipei City would be paralyzed.
Ma also said that foreign laborers as well as their local counterparts will benefit from a NT$300 million (US$8.69 million) labor foundation established by the Taipei City Government.

If foreign laborers are improperly treated by their employers, Ma said, they will be able to hire attorneys through the assistance of the foundation, adding that foreign laborers should receive the same humanitarian treatment as any other local workers.

DOC.HEADLINE: RESUMPTION OF CROSS-STRAIT TALKS RELIES ON MAINLAND CHINA: OFFICIALS

TEXT.P: Mainland China holds the key to restarting cross-strait dialogue, ranking officials with the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Sunday.

Despite repeated displays of goodwill by ranking Republic of China government officials toward mainland China, including President Chen Shui-bian after Taiwan's general elections on Dec. 1, Beijing has not responded in kind, said the MAC officials.

President Chen has said Taiwan and mainland China should first put aside their disputes to engage in economic and cultural integration. Stressing that Taiwan will continue improving bilateral ties, he also said that the "one China" principle is negotiable and urged leaders in Taipei and Beijing to use their creativity and wisdom to iron out a definition for the "one China" principle acceptable to both sides.

President Chen had also pointed out in his inaugural address in May 2000 that he would not promote the insertion of the "two-states" model as stated by former President Lee Teng-hui into the Constitution, as long as Beijing is willing to renounce the use of force against Taiwan.

The "two-states" model was put forward by Lee in July 1999 and resulted in the cessation of institutional negotiations between the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and its mainland Chinese counterpart -- the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), which marked its 10th anniversary on Sunday.
The SEF and ARATS were intermediary bodies set up by Taipei and Beijing to deal with two-way exchanges in the absence of official contacts between the two sides.

MAC Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen, Taiwan's top mainland China policy-maker, recently called on Beijing leaders to accept President Chen's goodwill to create the feasibility of rekindling bilateral negotiations.
MAC Vice Chairman Lin Chong-pin has also said publicly that it is possible for Taiwan and the mainland to resume dialogue this coming spring and that the two sides should grab the opportunity.

Despite Taiwan's efforts, the MAC officials said, decades-old historical and political problems between the two sides cannot be resolved by one-sided goodwill alone. Worse still, problems related to cross-strait ties became major election issues again in the recently concluded polls, further complicating bilateral relations, they noted.

As Taiwan has fully displayed its willingness to resume dialogue with the mainland, the MAC officials called on Beijing to respond favorably and reopen bilateral talks with Taipei as soon as possible to help protect the interests of the people on both sides of the strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT WILL NOT BLOCK GOVERNMENT'S BUDGET: KMT LAWMAKER

TEXT.P: Kuomintang (KMT) lawmakers will not block the government's 2002 budget and would rather let the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) bear the responsibility for it, KMT whip at the Legislative Yuan Lee Cheng-tsung said Sunday.

On the eve of a meeting of KMT lawmakers over the government's budget, Lee said the KMT does not intend to block the budget, and has not specific plan to cut any government agency's budget; rather, it will let the budget pass as intact as possible and let the DPP take the full political responsibility for it.
Party lawmakers will cooperate on the 2002 budget and, in general, the party will follow the schedule worked out by the opposition and ruling parties.

Given that the DPP has emerged as the largest party at the legislature after the Dec. 1 general elections, there is a common sense within the KMT that the party should stay out of the DPP's way to avoid being blamed for its failure.

Although some KMT lawmakers threatened to cut the budget of the Ministry of Justice in retaliation for what they called its discrimination against KMT candidates in its crackdown on vote-buying during the general elections, the party will not fault the ministry or slash its budget as long as it can account for its act before the election, Lee said.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOV'T TO PROMOTE CROSS-STRAIT TRADE COOPERATION: MAC CHAIRWOMAN

TEXT.P: The government will continue to promote trade and economic cooperation between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, Tsai Ing-wen, the nation's top planner on mainland China policy, said in a speech Saturday in the United States.
The chairwoman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) made the remarks Saturday on the West Coast of the United States to overseas Chinese. The MAC released the content of her speech Sunday.
She said that the government's mainland policy is to uphold the nation's security and dignity as its top priority and will continue to promote peace and stability in cross-strait relations.

She also said that both sides should create favorable conditions for solving political disputes and that to revive normal dialogue, the government will also continue to take the initiative to create opportunities for contacts.

Tsai said differences between the mainland and Taiwan have been deeply rooted over time. She dismissed the ideas proffered by some politicians that cross-strait relations have soured since the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) took the helm of the nation.

On the nation's mainland policy, Tsai said that President Chen Shui-bian has sought to seek to forge a national consensus since he took office, pointing to the convening of a cross-party task force last year and an economic development advisory conference this year -- both of which have contributed to forging national agreement.

Tsai also said that the president openly declared that Taiwan's mainland policy would remain unchanged after the legislative elections. She continued: "We would also like to see a positive response from mainland China by hearing it say that its policy toward Taiwan will remain unchanged" so that cross-strait relations will not be changed by the results of parliamentary elections in Taiwan.
The DPP became the largest party after collecting 87 seats in the 225-seat legislature. The Kuomintang lost its grip on the legislature after garnering only 68 seats.

On preconditions set by the mainland on reopening cross-strait dialogue, Tsai said that both sides will have to face political reality in the end, but as there is no current environment or conditions for both sides to solve political disputes, "We believe that both sides should actively create an atmosphere favorable to solve the problems." She said this atmosphere will be created through the building of mutual trust, goodwill, cooperation and dialogue.
She said that the continued trade, economic, and social exchanges will form the basis of nurturing such mutual trust.

Tsai said that cross-strait issues are highly complicated and that because of its complicity, though the international community is always concerned with the cross-strait situation, it could hardly comprehend the core of the issue.

Tsai said that as Beijing tries to raise cross-strait issues in the international community and has deterred other countries from becoming involved in the issue, "We are obliged to help others to correctly and deeply understand the nature and development of cross-strait relations, so that the international community can help protect the peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait and the entire Asia-Pacific region. (By Lilian Wu) EDNITEM ZCZC CEP013 12-16-01 FIGHT OVER SENUIO CITIZENS' ALLOWANCE TO BE STAGED AT LEGISLATURE

Taipei, Dec. 16 (CNA) A NT$16 billion (US$463.76 million) budget for special allowances for senior citizens is likely to draw the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the opposition into an acrimonious debate in the Legislative Yuan Wednesday.
The DPP has vowed to push through the quasi-pension budget proposal, while the largest opposition party Kuomintang (KMT) insists that any government financial assistance be legislated first.

Lee Cheng-chong, KMT whip in the Legislative Yuan, said Sunday a "legal basis" is necessary for every government outlay. "The KMT," he added, "will consult other (opposition) parties on how to address the issue."
His People First Party counterpart, Chou Hsi-wei, said such consultations are necessary. He added his party could not tolerate a squeeze in the social welfare budget by the allowances for the aged.

A bill for the allowances, promised by President Chen Shui-bian during his 2000 presidential campaign, was rejected by the KMT-led opposition at the legislature earlier this year. The opposition claimed the bill was ill-thought, criticizing it as a policy designed to solicit votes for the ruling party in the Dec. 1 legislative elections.

In order to make good on President Chen's campaign promise, the Executive Yuan had the budget for the allowances included in the planned expenditures of the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) for 2002, pledging to implement it by decree, if necessary.

The stage is all set for the mid-week clash on the floor in the Legislative Yuan, where the DPP, riding on its stunning victory in the elections, is ready to railroad the MOI budget. The opposition, however, still holds the legislative majority.

Whether the allowances -- NT$3,000 a month to each of an estimated 400,000 people over 65 years of age -- will be issued depends in large part on how well the opposition can coordinate efforts to block the MOI budget request.

DOC.HEADLINE: N. KOREA CAPTURES 13TH ASIAN WOMEN'S FOOTBALL CHAMPION

TEXT.P: North Korea blanked Japan 2-0 to capture the title of the 13th Asian Women's Football Championship Tournament which ended Sunday in Taipei.
Neither North Korea nor Japan scored goal at the first half round and North Korea scored two goals at the second half to break the stalemated situation.
The third place went to defending title mainland China after it whitewashed South Korea 8-0.

A total of 14 teams representing Japan, Malaysia, Hong Kong, India, Thailand, North Korea, South Korea, Singapore, Vietnam, Uzbekistan, the Philippines and host Chinese Taipei took part in the 12-day competitions which began Dec. 4.
Chinese Taipei was eliminated by South Korea in the elimination game which ended Dec. 12.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CHAIRMAN OPTIMISTIC ABOUT TAIWAN'S POLITICAL REFORM

TEXT.P: Frank Hsieh, chairman of Taiwan's ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), said here Saturday that he is optimistic about Taiwan's political reform.

Addressing some 1,000 overseas Taiwanese living in the greater Los Angeles area at a dinner party, Hsieh emphasized the stability in Taiwan's political situation and pointed out that the ruling party will be able to make good on its reform promises.

After the legislative elections on Dec. 1, Hsieh said, the people have regained confidence in the DPP government, to which they attributed the political stability Taiwan needs most to weather the current economic woes. "All indications are that things are going well," Hsieh pointed out, "and I believe we will be able to carry on our political reform in stability."

One indication is a recovery in the stock market in the wake of the elections, Hsieh said. All fundamentals of the economy have since shown improvements. Foreign investors are also optimistic about Taiwan's economic future.

In particular, Hsieh said, the DPP victory in the legislative elections has strengthened President Chen Shui-bian's hands in implementing his promised reform. The DPP became the largest party in the Legislative Yuan by winning 87 seats in the 225-member legislature.
Hsieh explained the government plan to reform Taiwan's financial, legislative and administrative systems in his speech, titled "The Post-election Development of Taiwan's Political Situation."

He said the best way to eliminate corruption and reduce waste of financial resources is to privatize government-run enterprises. Other reforms include the downsizing of the legislature and a streamlined administration.

Turning to Taiwan's relations with mainland China, Hsieh said he is "quite optimistic" about the ties across the Taiwan Strait. However, he said Beijing leaders' failure to understand Taiwan's democratic system and its "mainstream of public opinion" remains the biggest obstacle to improved cross-strait relations. He referred to the DPP election success that signals the rejection by the electorate of Beijing's "one country, two systems" approach to the solution of the problem of Taiwan.

Beijing's oft-repeated formula for China's reunification is totally unacceptable to the people of Taiwan, Hsieh said. The People's Republic of China applied that formula in 1997 to Hong Kong, relegating the former British crown colony to a special administrative district, where its chief executive Tung Chee-hwa must take orders from Beijing. (by Chu Lu-sheng, eh)

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND SON-IN-LAW BECOMES ROC CONSCRIPT AT AGE 37

TEXT.P: A mainland Chinese man who married a woman from Taiwan several years ago was conscripted in October into the Republic of China's armed forces for two years' of compulsory military service after he obtained ROC citizenship.

Wang Shaojie, 37, from northeastern China, reported to the Chengkungling New Recruit Training Center located in central Taiwan two months ago to begin his military service in Taiwan, making him the first mainland Chinese citizen to do so after the ROC government in February of this year amended the statutes governing people's relations across the Taiwan Strait.

Wang, who ran his own small restaurant in the northeastern Chinese city of Shenyang before coming to Taiwan to become a "Taiwanese son-in-law," has reportedly received better treatment than the average conscript due to the fact that he is almost twice as old as most new recruits.

He could have avoided having to do his military service if the ROC government had not amended the cross-strait statutes in February raising the maximum conscription age for ROC citizens from 35 years old to 40 years old.
Wang was granted ROC citizenship in December of last year after he had applied for permanent resident's status in Taiwan.
Wang's wife, a young woman from Yuanlin, central Taiwan, went to Shenyang several years ago to open a wedding gown salon and met Wang there.
The couple, who have two children, now run a hot pot restaurant in Yuanlin with the help of Wang's Taiwanese in-laws.

Just one week after reporting to the Chengkungling base, Wang checked into a military hospital for high blood pressure, an illness which he had never had before. His in-laws then sought the help of a legislator in an attempt to allow Chang to carry out his military service in a non-military capacity.
Chang now works from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. at the Yuanlin Township Administration Office as an alternative conscript.

He seems comfortable with his current life in Taiwan -- carrying out his two-year military service during the day while minding his restaurant and spending quality time with his Taiwan family in the evening.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC LIAISON OFFICES TO BEGIN RECEIVING M'LAND TOURIST APPLICATIONS

TEXT.P: Republic of China liaison offices overseas will begin receiving applications Dec. 20 by mainland Chinese citizens for tourist visits to Taiwan, the Bureau of Immigration reported Monday.
The Executive Yuan passed a bill in late November formally allowing mainland Chinese tourists to come to Taiwan for leisure trips beginning Jan. 2, 2002.
Under the initiative, Taiwan will allow on a trial basis a limited number of mainland Chinese citizens to travel from any spot outside the Chinese mainland to Taiwan for tourist visits.

According to Tseng Wen-chang, commissioner of the Bureau of Immigration, the plan will allow a maximum of 1,000 mainland Chinese citizens to visit Taiwan each day for tourism purposes, with the period of stay per trip being no longer than 10 days.
Initially, according to Tseng, only mainland Chinese citizens who are studying abroad or are permanent residents of a foreign country will be allowed to apply for tourist visits.

Under the pilot plan, Taiwan-based travel agencies sponsoring mainland Chinese tourists to Taiwan will have to deposit an NT$1 million cash guarantee to the government before handling any such business to make sure that they will be able to take responsibility in the event of any irregularities, including tourists absconding or overstaying their visas, as well as any accidents.
The plan will be further liberalized in the future depending on how well the initial stage is carried out and on how cross-strait relations develop, Tseng said.

Premier Chang Chun-hsiung announced Oct. 20, 2000 that visitors from mainland China would be able to take leisure trips to Taiwan beginning July 2001 as part of the ROC government's efforts to address the cross-strait political impasse.

The plan, however, was not implemented as scheduled, and it had remained unclear when it would be put into practice until the Executive Yuan passed the pilot plan Nov. 23, paving the way for the actual implementation of the initiative.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES DOWN BY 0.6 PERCENT ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) fell 0.6 percent Monday due to profit-taking and institutional selling.

The TAIEX weighted price index, the market's key barometer, dropped 30.58 points to close at 5,456.15. The bourse opened higher at 5,502.04 and then fluctuated between 5,535.75 and 5,413.97 during the day's trading.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANCER REMAINS TOP KILLER IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Cancer remained the top killer in Taiwan in 2000, with an average of 86 citizens dying from the disease each day, the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) reported Monday.
If deaths due to cancer were excluded, the average lifespan of Republic of China citizens would be 3.31 years longer, officials from the MOI Statistics Department said.

The figures showed that cancer deaths reduced the average lifespan of an average Taiwan male from 76.45 years to 72.67 years and reduced the average lifespan of an average Taiwan female from 81.21 years to 78.44 years.
The top ten killers in Taiwan in 2000 were cancer, strokes, heart disease, accidents, diabetes, chronic liver disease, kidney disease, pneumonia, suicide and lung disease, in that order.

The number of deaths due to cancer, strokes, diabetes, kidney disease and suicide each rose last year over the 1999 levels, while the number of deaths caused by accidents, heart disease and pneumonia each declined, the officials quoted the MOI tallies as indicating.
Meanwhile, the year 2000 represented the third straight year that suicide was among the top 10 causes of death in Taiwan.

The MOI tallies showed that those between 15 years old and 44 years old were mostly likely to commit suicide. MOI officials said the high suicide rate in 2000 might be related to last year's domestic economic recession.
In 2000, a total of 2,471 people in Taiwan committed suicide, or an average of seven people per day, up 8.33 percent over the average in 1999.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S INFO-HARDWARE PRODUCTION SAID TO GROW 9.4 PERCENT IN 2002

TEXT.P: Taiwan's information industry hardware production is expected to experience 9.4 percent growth next year despite negative growth in production value this year, an adviser of the Institute for Information Industry (III) said Monday.

Wang Sheng-hung, adviser of the III's Market Intelligence Center (MIC), said that Taiwan's information industry hardware production ranked fourth in the world this year, ahead of Great Britain's and behind the United States', Japan's and mainland China's.

However, Taiwan is the only country among the top five nations in information industry hardware production that recorded negative growth this year, thanks to the global economic slump and especially the sluggish U.S. economy.

Wang noted that U.S. consumer confidence suffered a blow in the wake of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks on America. Noting that the U.S. market makes up 40 percent of the world's information market, Wang said Taiwan's hardware industry has been significantly affected, experiencing negative growth, of 9.2 percent, for the first time ever this year.

But with the U.S. military campaign against Afghanistan drawing to an end and with the expected shopping spree during the Christmas holidays, Wang predicted that Taiwan's information hardware production for next year will hit US$46.69 billion for a growth of 9.4 percent, or slightly less than the peak growth rate in 2000.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAGNITUDE 6.7 QUAKE RATTLES TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A strong earthquake measuring magnitude 6.7 on the open-ended Richter scale jolted eastern Taiwan Tuesday at 12:02 p.m., the Central Weather Bureau said.
The temblor struck 139.5 kilometers east of Hsiulin, Hualien County, at a depth of 32.2 kilometers. No property damage or casualties were immediately reported.
The earthquake, which was felt around the island, had an intensity of 4 in Ilan and Suao and an intensity of 3 in Taipei and Hualien.
Many buildings in Taipei shook for a few minutes due to the quake, and the Taipei Rapid Transit Corp. shut down all rapid transit lines for five to 10 minutes to carry out safety checks.

Meanwhile, high-tech manufacturers in the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park reported that their operations were largely unaffected by the quake, while Taiwan Power Co. reported that there was no disruption in power supply in Hsinchu, where the quake had an intensity of 3.

Wafer chip factories in the Hsinchu park have been designed to largely cope with earthquakes of more than magnitude 7. After the disastrous magnitude 7.3 earthquake that struck Taiwan Sept. 12 1999, most manufacturers in the park stepped up the anti-earthquake design of their buildings.
