DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT PRESIDES OVER COMMISSION CEREMONY OF 1ST F-16 FIGHTER WING

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian presided over a ceremony marking the commissioning of the nation's first F-16 fighter wing into service held Tuesday at Chiayi Air Base in southern Taiwan.

After viewing 24 F-16 fighters roar overhead in six groups in combat formation flying at an altitude of 1,000 feet and at a speed of 300 nautical miles, the president inspected 18 F-16 fighters on the ground as well as more than 300 military personnel from within a grand marshal limousine.

The president also boarded one of the F-16 fighters to learn more about the war plane, which is equipped with 20-mm cannons, AIM-7M radar guided missiles, AIM-9M air-to-air missiles, harpoon missiles and the LANIRTN (low-altitude navigation and infrared targeting for night) pod.

The Chiayi Air Base spokesman said the maximum speed of the F-16 is Mach 2, with a maximum thrust of 23,770 pounds, while the search range of the radar is 80 nautical miles, enabling the fighter to carry out anti-air, anti-sea and anti-blockade missions.

President Chen said he was gratified to preside over the commissioning of the 455th tactical combat aircraft wing, adding that nine years passed between the initial signing of contracts and the formal commissioning of the wing, which marks the deployment of a new generation of fighter jets forming a modernized force that can maintain air superiority in the Taiwan Strait.

The president also said the air force buildup is for the purpose of national survival and development, stressing that Taiwan has no intention of engaging in an arms race with mainland China. The buildup aims to establish a stable strategic situation in the Taiwan Strait, he said, pointing out that one must have a sufficient defensive capability to prevent wars from taking place.

The Republic of China Air Force purchased 120 single-seat F-16 Fighting Falcons from the United States and 30 of the twin-seat version to carry out mid-altitude offshore interception missions. The first batch of the advanced fighters arrived at Chiayi Air Base in April 1997.
Reports said the second F-16 fighter wing will be commissioned in Hualien, eastern Taiwan, in 2002.

Together with the 60 Mirage 2000-5s fighter jets that the ROC purchased from France and the 130 locally-built indigenous defense fighters, these advanced fighters form the backbone of the island's modernized air force.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA WORKING ON SUPERVISORY MECHANISM FOR SEMICONDUCTOR INDUSTRY

TEXT.P: Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Chen Ruey-long said Tuesday that his ministry will work out a supervisory mechanism with related government agencies and the semiconductor industry to regulate Taiwan semiconductor manufacturers' investments in mainland China in the future.

Referring to the yet to be lifted restrictions on the semiconductor sector's investments in eight-inch wafer foundries in mainland China, Chen said that he expects the government and the industry to reach consensus on such a mechanism before the end of this month.

Since the government has agreed to adopt a more open policy in terms of Taiwan businesspeople's investments in mainland China, the semiconductor sector is calling on the authorities concerned to at least lift the ban on eight-inch wafer foundry investments across the Taiwan Strait.

The government is reluctant to allow the semiconductor sector to shift their investments to mainland China for fear of weakening Taiwan's competitiveness. At a meeting last week, the government and the industry reached consensus that an effective supervisory mechanism should be established before lifting the ban.

Regarding the supervisory mechanism, the Taiwan Semiconductor Industry Association (TSIA) has proposed that the government only allow investments in foundries of eight-inch wafers or of lower technological levels. As for related businesses such as IC designing and packaging, the association feels they should be taken off the control list.

In order that Taiwan businesspeople maintain their roots in Taiwan, the TSIA suggests that government permission to make investments on the mainland only be given to those engaged in semiconductor R&D, design, packaging, testing, and manufacturing equipment and materials. Businesspeople in other sectors should not be allowed to invest in the semiconductor or IC manufacturing sector in mainland China, according to the TSIA.

TSIA Secretary-General Chen Wen-hsien said that the semiconductor sector also agreed that the corporate net assets of the investors should be under supervision of the authorities. Also, if an industrial group makes the investment, only the net assets of the semiconductor department will be under supervision.
The domestic electronics industry is keen on exploring mainland China's rapidly developing market, especially when local authorities in mainland China are offering attractive incentives.

Morris Chang, chairman of the Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp. (TSMC), said Monday that for mid- and long-term planning, Taiwan's semiconductor manufacturers must start their deployments in mainland China.

Chang said that the TSMC will carry on its 12-inch wafer foundry projects in Taiwan, adding that in the meantime, it will gradually phase out production of eight-inch chips. While the TSMC has no imminent 12-inch wafer foundry investment projects in mainland China, any investment plan in mainland China will only involve shifting existing production facilities there.

As Taiwan's strategic industry, the IC industry grossed total revenue amounting to NT$115.4 billion in the third quarter of this year. In the manufacturing sector, foundries and DRAMs made up around 90 percent of Taiwan's IC manufacturing business, according to statistics released by the TSIA.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES 2.3 PERCENT LOWER ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) closed 2.3 percent lower due to the weakness of the local currency, with the benchmark weighted price index shedding 126.96 points to close at 5,329.19.

Buoyed by the surge on Wall Street and European markets, the bourse opened at the day's highest point at 5,588.45 and then drifted downward due to heavy selling of electrical stocks. The bourse hit the day's low at 5,309.38

A total of 5.42 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT&140.80 billion (US$4.18 billion), compared with the previous trading session which saw 5.06 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$140.43 billion (US$4.05 billion).

All eight major stock categories lost ground, with plastics and chemicals dropping the most at 5.8 percent, followed by paper and pulp shares at 5.5 percent, textile issues at 4.9 percent, cement stocks at 4.8 percent, foodstuffs issues at 3.7 percent, construction shares at 2.6 percent, and banking and insurance and electrical issues at 1.9 percent, respectively.
Losers outnumbered gainers 501 to 114, with 33 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAL, DELTA TO SHARE ROUTES IN UNITED STATES NEXT YEAR

TEXT.P: China Airlines (CAL) announced Tuesday that it will begin code-sharing services on cross-Pacific routes with the United States-based Delta Airlines early next year.
Executives of the two aviation companies signed the cooperation accord Monday in Atlanta, where Delta is headquartered.
CAL said the two sides will discuss issues on cargo, passenger services and computer reservations in the coming months before launching joint operations in spring.

Under the terms of the agreement, CAL passengers from Taiwan can proceed from Los Angeles and San Francisco to Atlanta, Dallas, Cincinnati, Tampa and Salt Lake City on Delta flights. At the same time, CAL will also provide code-sharing flight services for Delta passengers from six U. S. cities, including New York and Atlanta to Taipei.
CAL, Taiwan's largest carrier, operates 56 airplanes and flies to 50 cities in 21 countries.

Meanwhile, the Taipei-based Chinese-language Liberty Times newspaper reported that CAL is expected to open air passenger services between Taipei and New Delhi in the near term, after more than two years of negotiations to break into the Indian market.
According to the report, CAL has confirmed that it is planning to conduct passenger flight services on the Taipei-New Delhi route next spring.

The move represents a fresh breakthrough for CAL in its negotiations with the Indian authorities over the past decade, the report said. CAL started a cargo flight service three times per week from Taiwan to India in Nov. 1999.
The report said CAL and the Indian authorities may sign a formal accord probably early next year on the new air links.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG MAYOR TO SEEK RE-ELECTION

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh said Tuesday that he will seek re-election, adding that sponsoring the 2010 Asian Games will be one of the major long-term goals of the city.
Hsieh did not disclose whether he would seek to retain his post as chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party.
Hsieh said that Kaohsiung will also vie for the sponsorship of the 2007 Universiade, adding that the National Council on Physical Fitness and Sports has provisionally agreed to the idea.
Hsieh said he has asked municipal bureaus to set a timetable for Kaohsiung's short-term and long-term goals and have prime construction and development plans follow that schedule.
Kaohsiung is Taiwan's second-largest city.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market dropped sharply on Tuesday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization weighed Index futures for December fell 93 points to close at 5,360, with 10,630 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for next January dropped 75 points to finish at 5,361, with 11,701 contract transactions. TAIEX Index futures for next March dropped 12 points to finish at 5,421, with three contract transactions. The TAIEX Index futures for next June dropped 248 points to finish at 5,405, with seven contract transactions. The TAIEX Index futures remained unchanged at 5,529 for next September, with one contract transaction.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 5,453 for December, 5,436 for next January, 5,433 for next March, 5,653 for next June, and 5,529 for next September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mixed.
December TE futures moved up 5.8 points to close at 274.8, with 2,695 contract transactions, while TE futures for next January fell four points to finish at 271, with 3,466 contracts traded.

No transactions were reported for other months. December TF future lost 22.2 points to finish at 809.8 with 3,422 contract transactions, while TF futures for next January lost 12.8 points to close at 827, with 4,295 contracts traded, TF futures for next March lost 4.6 points to finish at 835.4, with three contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: N.T. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar was down NT$0.127 against the greenback on the Taipei foreign exchange market Tuesday, closing at NT$34.707.
The local currency opened Tuesday at NT$34.630 and was traded between NT$34.585 and NT$34.728.
Interbank U.S. dollar trading totaled US$865 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC DONATES US $ 150,000 FOR TO OAS FUND FOR BORDER STABILITY
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 17 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Chen Chien-jen, the Republic of China's representative to the United States, will call on Caesar Gaviria, secretary-general of the Organization of American States (OAS), Tuesday to donate US$150,000 to Guatemala and Belize on behalf of the ROC government.
According to a news release by the ROC representative office Monday, the donation will help maintain peace between the two nations, that have had border disputes in the past.

The news release said that the Guatemala foreign minister and the vice foreign minister of Belize will lead a delegation to Washington D.C. In addition to attending the donation ceremony, they will also attend a ministerial meeting sponsored by the OAS between the two countries on border disputes.

The OAS, based in Washington D.C., seeks to solve disputes over land among its members through peaceful means. It established the OAS Fund for Peace, accepting donations from member states and other nations that are concerned with the affairs of Central and South America to enhance political stability and regional cooperation in the western hemisphere.

The news release said that though the ROC is not a member of the OAS, it has formal diplomatic relations with many countries of the organization in Central America and the Caribbean, and has always maintained good exchanges with the OAS.

The OAS said in a news release in June that five OAS members and five observers donated more than US$350,000 for the OAS Fund for Peace, including the United States and Mexico, which donated US$50,000 collectively, and Canada, which donated 50,000 Canadian dollars.
Denmark and Spain, who are OAS observers, each donated US$100,000 and Britain and Israel donated US$25,000 and US$20,000 respectively.
The news release said that the fund collected more than US$500,000 in one year. All 35 nations in America are OAS members.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN WANTS TO HOLD TALKS WITH KMT, DPP CHIEFS

TEXT.P: Presidential Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun visited leaders of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP) Tuesday to express President Chen Shui-bian's intention of holding talks with the leaders of the two parties.
During his meeting with KMT Secretary-General Lin Fong-cheng, Yu transmitted Chen's sincerity to exchange views on pressing affairs with KMT Chairman Lien Chan.
Lin said that he would convey Chen's intention to Lien who is now in Japan.
According to Lin, Chen wants to discuss with the KMT chairman matters related to legislative reform, governmental reorganization, economic development and political stabilization.

Lin told Yu that the KMT will respect the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP) right to form the Cabinet since the DPP replaced the KMT as the largest party in the 225-seat Legislative Yuan in the Dec. 1 legislative elections.
He also said that the KMT would play its role as a faithful opposition party and would support the DPP's bills and policies that will benefit the country and the people.

However, Lin noted that the KMT will not join any organizations which are beyond the constitutional framework, such as the "national stabilization alliance" proposed by Chen, and added that KMT members will not join the Cabinet.
Yu also paid a visit to PFP Secretary-General Chung Jung-chi to indicate Chen's hope of holding talks with PFP Chairman James Soong.

Chung told the media afterwards that the PFP will respect the DPP's right to appoint personnel, but stressed that there is no urgent need for the PFP to discuss with the DPP over appointments of government personnel at present.

Regarding the responses of the KMT and the PFP on Chen's intentions, Kuo Yao-chi, director of the Public Affairs Office under the Presidential Office, said that they will respect the decisions of the two opposition parties and added that they will continue to call on the two parties.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUTOBIOGRAPHY OF NOTED CHINESE WOMAN AUTHOR TRANSLATED INTO ENGLISH
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Dec. 17 (CNA) (By David Wang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: "A Woman Soldier's Own Story," the autobiography of veteran Chinese female author Xie Bingying (1906-2000), has been translated into English and published recently by Columbia University Press.

"In lyrical, flowing prose," the Publishers Weekly said, "this absorbing autobiography interweaves politics, family relations and romance as it chronicles an extraordinary woman's struggle to free herself from traditional Chinese society."

When translating and compiling the English version of "A Woman Soldier's Own Story," Xie's daughter, Lily Chia Brissman, and her American husband Barry Brissman, combined the two autobiographies that Xie wrote in 1936 and 1946.

"Her personal struggle to define herself within the larger context of political change in China early in the last century is a poignant testament of determination and a striking story of one woman's journey from old China into the new world," the Library Journal commented.

A native of the mainland Chinese province of Henan, Xie fought during the 1920s and 1930s to free herself from the constraints of ancient Chinese tradition by fleeing her hometown and joining the army and at the same time writing.
Xie moved to Taiwan in 1949 in a cross-strait exodus from mainland China under the lead of the Republic of China government.
During her decades of life in Taiwan, she taught Chinese writing at National Cheng Kung University in Tainan, southern Taiwan, and continued to write.
Throughout her 94-year life, Xie had 60 books published. She moved to the United States in her later years and passed away last year in San Francisco.

DOC.HEADLINE: HANG SENG ALLOWED TO OPEN REPRESENTATIVE OFFICE IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Finance approved Tuesday the establishment of a representative office in Taipei by the Hong Kong-based Hang Seng Bank, bringing the total number to 17 of such offices owned by foreign banks in Taiwan.
Hang Seng was the fourth bank from Hong Kong to open a representative office in Taiwan, following in the steps of the Hongkong and Shanghai Banking Corporation Limited and two other banks.

The ministry said Hang Seng's decision to set up a representative office in Taipei was due to Taiwan's strategic location in the Asia-Pacific region and aimed at enhancing its ties with the local banking and business communities.
According to a 2001 directory published by Reed Businesses Information Ltd., Heng Seng has assets of US$56.86 billion, ranking as the world's 138-largest bank.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING MAY CONTINUE BOYCOTT AFTER TAIPEI'S WTO ENTRY: SCHOLAR

TEXT.P: Due to the delicate situation across the Taiwan Strait, mainland China may continue boycotting Taiwan after the island enters the World Trade Organization (WTO) Jan. 1, 2002, an expert warned Tuesday.

Kao Chang, a senior researcher at the Chunghua Institution for Economic Research, said the mainland may also pick on Taiwan's name in the world trade regulatory body and seek to prevent Taiwan from taking part in multilateral trade negotiations under the WTO framework, including rejecting two-way talks with Taiwan and blocking Taiwan's presence in the international community.
Taiwan applied to join the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade -- the predecessor of the WTO -- in 1990 under the name of "Separate Customs Territory of Taiwan, Penghu, Kinmen, and Matsu."

In the face of these possibilities, Kao called on the government to work out countermeasures. He issued the warning in a keynote speech on the future of cross-strait economic exchanges sponsored by the Mainland Affairs Council.

As to the impact of WTO membership on both Taiwan and mainland China, Kao said Taiwan should be wary of the effects of the influx of mainland Chinese capital and the opening of the local market to foreign imports, as well as the mainland's magnetism to Taiwan businesses and greater competition between the two sides.
However, he also contended that cross-strait trade and commercial ties will be further enhanced and that two-way economic integration will also be boosted.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO PROTECT STEEL INDUSTRY INTERESTS

TEXT.P: Taiwan economic officials are attending a meeting of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) in Paris in an effort to further protect the interests of the domestic steel industry.

Michael Wei, deputy director-general of the Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) and officials of the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) responsible for the steel industry are participating in the OECD meeting that began the previous day to work out a mechanism to stabilize the global steel market.

The meeting took on added importance upon the announcement that the United States is expected to launch Clause 201 of its trade act to further protect its own steel industry, which further disturbed the already turbulent steel market, a BOFT official said in Taipei.
The official noted that the United States is the third-largest market for Taiwan's steel products behind mainland China and Japan by absorbing 30 percent of the island's steel exports per year.
Since the U.S. government took a number of anti-dumping measures last year, Taiwan's steel exports to the United States have decreased significantly, he said.

He noted that the European Union and Japan have begun to fight against Clause 201, with the E.U. saying it will not exclude the possibility of sending the issue to the World Trade Organization for arbitration.
Taiwan, which has also expressed its opposition to Clause 201 to the U.S. authorities, has begun to divert its steel exports this year from the United States to mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: DIRECT SALES IN TAIWAN GROW RAPIDLY

TEXT.P: Sales in Taiwan's direct selling industry reached NT$38 billion (US$1.09 billion) last year and the figure is still growing, an official of the Republic of China Direct Selling Association said Tuesday.

Liu Min-hsiung, president of the association, said that according to Fair Trade Commission statistics, more than 2.83 million people in Taiwan are involved in direct selling, which he said has contributed "significantly" to Taiwan's economy and has helped resolve the unemployment problem.
Liu added that sales of the 29 firms that belong to the association totaled NT$25.3 billion, accounting for 66 percent of the total revenue generated in the industry.

DOC.HEADLINE: EDITORS' NOTE: CNA WILL SUSPEND ITS CEP SERVICE ON DEC. 25,
BEIJING CENSORS BOOKS USED BY TAIWANESE SCHOOLS IN MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Textbooks used by two Taiwanese schools in mainland China have been censored by Beijing authorities, education officials in Taiwan said Tuesday.
Parts of the books considered politically incorrect by the Beijing authorities have either been deleted or forbidden for use in the schools.

The political differences between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait stems from Beijing's refusal to consider the Republic of China as a state and its abhorrence of any idea that boosts Taiwan's political identity.
As a result, the name of any organization or agency whose title contains the words "national," "central" or any other word suggesting ROC sovereignty has been deleted from the books.

The Beijing authorities even took offense at the name of Taiwan's National Institute for Compilation, whose title appears routinely at the end of government-approved test books, and ordered the back cover to be torn off.
The ROC flag is also considered taboo and cannot appear in any textbooks used by Taiwanese schools set up in the mainland.

Taiwan's description of the civil war between the Chinese communists and the nationalist and the ROC's 1949 relocation to Taiwan after losing the civil war is also offensive to the Beijing authorities, who have ordered it revised to the effect that the ROC was replaced by the People's Republic of China in 1949, implying that the ROC ceased to exist as a state from that time on.
And introductory courses on Taiwan's geography, history and society in elementary schools and junior high schools are forbidden, as Beijing sees them as encouraging Taiwan independence.
The students have to use the atlas published by the Beijing authorities during their courses in geography.

The two -- one in Dongguan, Guangdong Province, the other in Kunshan, near Shanghai City -- have appealed against Beijing's decision, but admitted that they will have no choice but to accept the censorship if their appeal is rejected.
Courses forbidden in mainland China will be taught when students return to Taiwan for summer or winter vacations, according to the education officials.
They also said they are weighing the possibility of compiling textbooks exclusively for Taiwanese schools in mainland China in order to accommodate Beijing's concerns.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA, MITAC GROUP FORGE ALLIANCE

TEXT.P: The Central News Agency (CNA) and the MiTAC-Synnex Group entered into a strategic alliance Tuesday to offer speedy corporate news and commercial and industrial information services in Chinese to domestic and global enterprises.

CNA (http://www.cna.com.tw/) President Bill Wang and MiTAC-Synnex Group Chairman Matthew Miao inked the agreement on the alliance on behalf of their respective organizations, witnessed by Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Chen Ruey-long and Deputy Director-General of the Government Information Office Lee Cher-jean.
Vice President Annette Lu telegraphed her congratulations on the CNA-MiTAC partnership.

Under the agreement, CNA and iPRnews (http://www.iprnews.com.tw) -- an offshoot of the MiTAC-Synnex Group -- will cooperate in expanding their information services through the Internet to directly provide corporate news and financial and stock information.
Speaking at the ceremony, Chen said the CNA-MiTAC partnership can serve as a model for cooperation between the mass media and the information technology industry.
Using CNA's news network, private enterprises can obtain fast, complete and comprehensive corporate, financial and stock market news, Chen said.
He noted that the Ministry of Economic Affairs acquires much of its news information via CNA reports.
With its fast and accurate news reporting, CNA makes a good partner for business cooperation, Chen added.
Wang said that CNA, the first Taiwan media organization to computerize its news reporting system, has always tried to upgrade its services to its customers.

This CNA-iPRnews cooperation will definitely further upgrade CNA's services to its global customers with the aid of Internet technology and networks that bypass slower and more time-consuming methods of news transmission, Wang added.

MiTAC-Synnex Group Chairman and CEO Matthew Miao said the release of corporate news has a huge impact on investors' rights and interests. All media and financial/stock markets require open and instantaneous access to information, he noted.
Miao continued that from the corporation's point of view, efficiently and effectively released corporate news will maximize public relations coverage.
Miao added that the partnership allows Taiwan's corporations a better chance to expose themselves globally, which will increase their competitiveness and enhance their public image.

To celebrate the inauguration of the CNA-iPRnews cooperation, iPRnews announced that all clients will enjoy a "free trial" period. News will be delivered through CNA's news network and can be "expressly mailed" to the terminals of media wishing to try the service, iPRnews said.
iPRnews urged potential clients to take the opportunity to experience the "best and most effective" news distribution network.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINA, TAIWAN TO BECOME OECD OBSERVERS: JAPANESE DAILY
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Dec. 18 (CNA) (By Mike Chang & Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: Both mainland China and Taiwan will become observers in the Paris-based Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) in January next year, Japan's Sankei Shimbun said Tuesday.

The paper quoted a "reliable source" in Paris as saying that Taiwan will join the OECD's competition policy committee, while mainland China will join the organization's science and technology committee.
The source added that a formal decision on the matter will be made at the OECD's council meeting Dec. 20.
According to the report, the applications for mainland China and Taiwan to become observers were discussed by the OECD's committee on cooperative relations of non-member countries Dec. 14.
Of the 30 OECD members, only Japan and South Korea are full members from Asia, while Hong Kong and Singapore are observers.
Mainland China has recently become a full member of the World Trade Organization and Taiwan's membership will become effective Jan. 1 next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: CBC TO ISSUE NT$ 200 BANK NOTE

TEXT.P: The Central Bank of China (CBC) will introduce a NT$200 bank note on Jan. 2 next year, a CBC official said Tuesday.

Tsai Yen-shu, deputy director general of the CBC's Issue Department, said the new bank note, colored green with an image of former President Chiang Kai-shek on one side and a picture of the Presidential Office on the other, has several anti-counterfeit measures incorporated into its design.
He added that the front of the note will also bear pictures representing the educational and land reforms that Chiang contributed to Taiwan society.
He also noted that the Taiwan Broadcasting Co. will organize an event Dec. 23 in Hsinchu, northern Taiwan, to demonstrate ways to recognize fake money.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT MIGHT MEET WITH PFP CHAIRMAN: PFP OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: People First Party (PFP) Secretary-General David Chung said Tuesday that he met with President Chen Shui-bian's chief of staff Yu Shyi-kung Tuesday to discuss the possibility of talks between the president and PFP Chairman James Soong.

Chung said the meeting was requested by Yu last week, but added that no date for a Chen-Soong meeting had yet been set and that although Soong is willing to meet with the president, there is no urgency in the matter.

Chung quoted Yu as saying that Chen telephoned Soong on Dec. 1 to express his willingness to cooperate with Soong on laying down major national policies, reforming the Legislative Yuan, streamlining the government, developing the economy and stabilizing the political landscape. He also said he would not exclude other issues from the agenda.

Chung went on to say that in light of the unwelcome effects of a secret meeting between the two leaders in July, Yu suggested that any future meeting between the two should be arranged through their chiefs of staff.

When news of the July meeting came to light, Soong was plagued by rumors that he was colluding secretly with Chen to the detriment of Soong's political ally -- the opposition Kuomintang, at that time the leading party at the legislature.

However, Chung said, Soong did not see any urgency for a meeting with the president, given that the main opposition parties have agreed to respect Chen's power to assemble a Cabinet after his party won the Dec. 1 general elections, while the domestic economy, riding on a sudden surge in stock prices, has recovered slightly since the elections.
Furthermore, Chung added, Soong is busy trying to build consensus among newly elected PFP legislators on policy issues.

DOC.HEADLINE: HARVARD MEDICAL PH.D. RETURNS TO CAMPUS AS ENTOMOLOGY FRESHMAN

TEXT.P: A local physician who received his doctorate from Harvard University and who is almost twice as old as most college freshmen, returned to school this fall as a freshman in the Department of Entomology of National Taiwan University (NTU).

47-year-old Chen Chia-chen seemed to be "a fish in his own pond" when he began attending classes at the entomology department, even though he was a freshman beginning at the bottom of the academic ladder.
"It is almost like a dream come true, as I have wanted to study insects since I was very young," said Chen recently.

Chen, who has practiced in Taiwan over the past few years, began thinking of giving up his practice last year after suffering severe burns in an explosion in his laboratory. His interest in starting again in another field was rekindled several months ago while helping his high-school son with his homework.
He took the courageous step of preparing for the hard-fought Joint College Entrance Examination this summer, winning entry to the prestigious NTU.

Chen has been a role model for his much-younger peers in his department over the past two months. He is never late for class, never leaves early and completes tests as fast as a machine, according to his classmates.

Chen takes his entomology studies seriously, saying that he will finish the four-year university course, continue to seek higher-level research in this field and hopefully obtain master and doctoral degrees.

DOC.HEADLINE: INCLUSION OF `TAIWAN' ON ROC PASSPORTS BEING STUDIED: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Republic of China Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Tuesday that the government has not yet decided whether to include the word "Taiwan" on Republic of China passports.

Replying to a question raised by New Party Legislator Fung Hu-hsiang, Chang said that the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) has been studying the issue, as travelers have complained that some foreign countries, especially those in Africa and Europe, have mistaken them for citizens of the People's Republic of China.
He noted that the issue is still being studied by MOFA and added that it will be handled in line with international practice. He also made clear that the name of the country will not be altered.
The premier stressed that the inclusion of "Taiwan" on ROC passports would be designed to help foreign governments distinguish ROC passports from those of the PRC.

Some opposition lawmakers said they would oppose the move, which they described as an attempt by the Democratic Progressive Party administration to change the name of the country from the ROC to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT DELAYS DEPARTURE FOR GAMBIA

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu has not headed for Gambia Tuesday as scheduled, a public affairs official at the Presidential Office said Tuesday evening.
Kuo Yao-chi, director of the presidential Public Affairs Office, cited problems with a flight transfer in an unannounced country on Lu's way to Gambia as the reason for her postponed departure.
Kuo refused to elaborate on the reasons and did not say whether the trip has been rescheduled, referring journalists' questions to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.
However, staff at the Foreign Ministry also declined to offer any explanation.

A ministry spokeswoman had announced Lu's itinerary the day before, saying that the vice president would make a transit stop in a western European state. She did not reveal the name of the country in question, as doing so would have elicited an immediate protest from Beijing, especially in light of Lu's often vociferous criticism of the communist regime.
Lu is supposed to arrive in Gambia Dec. 20 for the inauguration of re-elected President Yahya Jammeh Dec. 21.

During her stay in Gambia, she is expected to hold talks with Gambian leaders and inspect the ROC Embassy and agricultural projects being implemented under cooperation agreements between the two countries, according to anonymous officials at the Foreign Ministry.
She is supposed to leave Gambia Dec. 22 and return to Taipei Dec. 24 or 25 by way of the same European country, the official added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC MINISTER URGES INTERNATIONAL COOPERATION TO COUNTER CRIME

TEXT.P: Republic of China Minister of Foreign Affairs Tien Hung-mao stressed Tuesday the importance of international cooperation to counter crime.
He made the remarks while accompanying a group of foreign envoys and representatives of quasi-official foreign organizations to a display by a special security squad.
Tien said that squad was established to ensure the safety of society and the security of foreign residents in Taiwan.
As intercontinental crime has become rampant, the minister said, all countries should strength mutual cooperation to eradicate crime.
He said the international community has heightened awareness of the need for international cooperation to combat terrorism following the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks on the United States.
The squad's display, Tien said, demonstrated the ROC government's ability to fight crime.

DOC.HEADLINE: CSBC NEARS BANKRUPTCY, URGES EMPLOYEES TO SUPPORT RECONSTRUCTION

TEXT.P: Executives of Taiwan's almost-bankrupt state-run China Shipbuilding Corp. (CSBC) urged its employees Tuesday to "support a company reconstruction plan."

The CSBC, with capital of NT$11 billion (US$317 million) and some 5,000 employees, has accumulated losses of NT$10.56 billion as of this month and might be declared bankrupt by the end of the month, a company official said.
He added that the reconstruction plan will include layoffs and salary cuts.

The CSBC plans to lay off 2,500 employees and cut salaries by 35 percent for the remaining personnel as part of its reconstruction plan. It has presented the plan to the Commission of National Corporations (CNC) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, in the hope of getting more funding from the government to help the company survive.
Unsurprisingly, however, the plan encountered strong opposition from the employees, who promised to stage protests.

The official noted that the CSBC had originally asked to borrow money from other state companies such as Taiwan Sugar Corp. and Taiwan Salt Industrial Corp., but was rejected by the CNC, which maintains that it may favor the closure of the shipyard if it does not try to improve its financial situation and accelerate its reconstruction plan.
A CNC official said the Cabinet is expected to appropriate NT$6 billion for the CSBC in January next year if it implements the reconstruction plan at the end of this month.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT LAUDS TAIWAN'S OPENING TO MAINLAND CHINESE TOURISTS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian lauded Tuesday the government's decision to open Taiwan to mainland Chinese tourists as a breakthrough in peaceful exchanges with the mainland.

In a conference of the so-called "nine leaders" of his government and the Democratic Progressive Party, the president said the opening, to take effect Jan. 1 on a trial basis, marks a great step forward in the island's ties with the mainland.
His statement was disclosed after the conference by Chou I-jen, secretary-general of the Executive Yuan.

Chou also quoted the president as instructing the Executive Yuan to follow the examples of other World Trade Organization (WTO) member states when deciding upon the size of the island's WTO representative office.
The president was quoted as saying that the WTO representative office will be an important bridgehead for the island in its attempts to enter international society.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Dec. 19, or the 5th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1036: Chinese poet Su Tung-po is born.
1154: Henry II accedes to the throne of England.
1741: Vitus Bering, the Danish navigator and explorer who in 1728 sailed through the Bering Strait while exploring a route around Siberia to China, dies of scurvy at the age of 60.
1793: French troops under Napoleon Bonaparte capture Toulon.
1842: The United States recognizes the independence of Hawaii.
1932: The third plenary session of the fourth Central Committee of the ruling Kuomintang approves the convening of an assembly that will meet regularly and which will give the public a voice in governmental affairs.
1941: Adolf Hitler dismisses his chief of staff and takes personal command of the German army after military setbacks.
1946: War breaks out in Indochina as Ho Chi Minh's troops launch widespread attacks against the French.
1950: General Dwight D. Eisenhower is named by the North Atlantic Council as Supreme Commander for the Allied Powers, Europe.
1965: Charles de Gaulle defeats Francois Mitterand in the French presidential election runoff.
1969: President Apollo Milton Obote of Uganda is shot and injured. He would later be overthrown by the Ugandan army in 1971.
1972: The Apollo 17 spacecraft splashes down on target in the Pacific Ocean, bringing to an end the United States' Apollo program of landing men on the moon.
1980: The States-General of the Netherlands approves the selling of two submarines to the Republic of China.
1984: Britain and mainland China sign an agreement determining the fate of Hong Kong after a 99-year lease of the territory to Britain expires in 1997. The joint declaration signed by British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and mainland Chinese Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang spells out the terms for Hong Kong's return to Chinese sovereignty on July 1, 1997.
1985: U.S. Sen. Edward Kennedy announces that he will not run in the 1988 presidential campaign.
1988: Indian Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi visits Beijing.
1990: The first stock exchange on the Chinese mainland opens in Shanghai.
1990: Albanian authorities formally recognize the country's first non-Communist party.
1991: Mikhail Gorbachev resigns as president of the United Soviet Socialist Republic, a country that effectively ceased to exist on Dec. 12 of the same year.
1992: The Kuomintang wins 53.02 percent of the popular vote and the Democratic Progressive Party gets 31.03 percent in the elections for the Second Legislative Yuan.
1996: The ceiling on foreign institutional investments on the Taiwan Stock Exchange is raised from US$400 million to US$600 million.
1997: A Singapore SilkAir Boeing 737-300 airliner crashes near Palembang in Indonesia, killing all 104 people on board.
1997: South Korea's newly elected president, Kim Dae-jung, proposes dialogue with North Korea as a step toward reconciliation.
1999: Chen Shui-bian calls on voters to support the DPP's Chen-Lu ticket in the March 18 presidential election and says he will do what he can to finish off the KMT's "black gold" dealings and to distribute the money held by the KMT to the populace.
1999: Macau is formally handed over to mainland China at midnight after 442 years of Portuguese colonial rule.
2000: Peter Banko, managing director Taiwan and country manager of the Bank of America, is elected as the new president of the American Chamber of Commerce (AmCham) in Taipei.
Confucius: "Read and learn everything, but suspend your judgment on anything of which you are in doubt; for the rest, be careful in what you say: in that way you will give few occasions for men to criticize what you say. Mix with the world and see everything, but keep away and do not meddle with anything that may bring you into trouble; for the rest, be careful in what you do: in that way you will have few occasions for self-reproach."

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMICS MINISTRY DOESN'T SUPPORT CCP-TAIWAN BUSINESS LINKS: LIN

TEXT.P: The Republic of China Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) "does not encourage" mainland China-based Taiwan enterprises to join the ranks of the Chinese Communist Party (CCP), Economic Affairs Minister Lin Hsin-yi said Wednesday.

Fielding questions at the Legislative Yuan, Lin admitted that the alleged incorporation of CCP cells into the Shenzhen-based offshoot of Taiwan's Hon Hai Precision Industry Co. "is an issue that should be faced squarely and tackled."

Lin said the MOEA will keep in close contact with the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) to gain a deeper understanding of the alleged CCP "infiltration" into Taiwan-financed business and industrial operations on the Chinese mainland.

Lin made the remarks in response to a question raised by Legislator Chiu Chui-chen from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party. Chiu claimed that the CCP is aggressively absorbing mainland China-based Taiwan business people to organize CCP branch operations in an attempt to sharpen the CCP's "united front" overture toward Taiwan and its people.

Chiu asked Lin whether he knows how many Taiwan companies have made investments in mainland China, further questioning what the government would do if all the Taiwan firms operating on the mainland became "communized" and their staff returned to Taiwan to vote in major elections.

According to Lin, Taiwan capital equivalent to US$19.4 billion has been channeled into mainland China to finance or invest in more than 20,000 companies, although mainland Chinese authorities put the figure at around US$45 billion.

Lin admitted that the alleged CCP involvement in Taiwan companies on the mainland "is not a good thing." He however pointed out that as far as he knows, the number of people who work at Taiwan firms on the mainland and organize CCP operations is "very small," adding that their political activities are seen as not having a major impact on the operations of the mainland-based Taiwan companies.

Meanwhile, the MAC said that it is probing the alleged CCP operations in Hon Hai's Shenzhen affiliate Foxconn and that it will determine whether ROC statutes governing people's relations across the Taiwan Strait have been violated after it gains a better understanding of the situation.
It was learned that Foxconn is an overseas holding company registered in a third country.
Foxconn, established in Shenzhen in 1988 with a workforce of 38,000 people, is expected to post an export trade of US$2.4 billion this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES TWO PERCENT LOWER ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) fell two percent due to heavy selling Wednesday, with the TAIEX weighted price index, the market's key barometer, dropping 107.23 points to close at 5,221.96.
Buoyed by a surge on Wall Street, the bourse opened higher at 5,391.31, hitting a high of 5,402.65 and a low of 5,211.98 during the day's trading.

A total of 4.1 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$115.09 billion (US$3.31 billion), compared with the previous trading session which saw 5.42 billion shares change hands on a market turnover of NT$140.80 billion (US$4.18 billion).

All eight major stock categories lost ground, with construction stocks moving down the most at 5.9 percent, followed by bank and insurance shares at 5.7 percent, foodstuff stocks at 5.1 percent, plastics and chemical shares at 5.0 percent, pulp and paper issues at 4.9 percent, textile shares at 4.5 percent, cement issues at 4.0 percent, and electrical stocks at 0.7 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 543 to 79 with 28 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC V.P. DEPARTING FOR GAMBIA WEDNESDAY

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu is scheduled to depart for Gambia Wednesday to attend the inauguration of reelected Gambian President Yahya Jammeh Dec. 21 on behalf of President Chen Shui-bian.

Lu, to be flanked by Vice Foreign Affairs Minister Chiu Jong-nan and several other Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) officials, will make a transit stop at the international airport near Paris before heading to Gambia, MOFA officials said.

Lu, who studied law at Harvard Law School and was elected the first female vice president of the Republic of China last year, will deliver a speech in a farewell ceremony at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport Wednesday evening.
President Chen offered his personal felicitations to Jammeh on Oct. 22 upon the reelection of the Gambian president, who garnered an overwhelming 52.96 percent of the vote.

During her stay in Gambia, Lu is expected to hold talks with Gambian leaders as well as inspect the ROC Embassy and agricultural projects being implemented under cooperation agreements between the two countries, according to MOFA officials.

Lu is also returning the invitation to the country by Gambian Vice President Isatou Njie-Saidy, who was one of the four female vice presidents of countries that are diplomatic allies of the ROC to travel to Taiwan to attend the inauguration of President Chen and Vice President Lu on May 20, 2000.

The vice president was originally scheduled to depart from Taiwan on Tuesday, but the departure was postponed because of reported problems related to a scheduled transit stop in a European country which Beijing objected to.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMIC GROWTH PREDICTED TO BE AROUND 3.08 PERCENT NEXT YEAR

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economic growth this year will be negative 1.89 percent, down from an earlier prediction of 2.38 percent, but should return to around 3.08 percent next year, an economic research institute said Wednesday.

Kuan Chung-min, director of the Institute of Economics of Academia Sinica, the nation's highest research organization, made the remarks during a press conference on Taiwan's economic outlook for 2002.

Kuan predicted that the economy will hit the bottom in the fourth quarter of this year and will achieve positive growth in the first quarter next year, ending the recession of the past three consecutive quarters.

However, he went on, as the unemployment rate and bad loans in financial institutions are still high, the economic rebound will be modest. Kuan further predicted economic growth in the four quarters of next year at 1.04 percent, 2.39 percent, 4.58 percent and 4.16 percent, respectively.
He cautioned, however, that unemployment will exceed 5 percent -- far more than the figure predicted by the government.

Kuan noted that Taiwan's economic development has undergone transformation and that low economic growth, or even no growth, will be a trend, adding that the most worrisome thing next year will be unemployment.

He said that the large number of jobless due to economic transformation will have a hard time finding news jobs and that unemployment will increase dramatically to between 5 percent and 6 percent compared to the 2 percent to 3 percent of past years.

He noted that the Council for Economic Planning and Development under the Executive Yuan predicted that the agricultural sector will bear the brunt of the fallout after Taiwan's entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO) and that 100,000 people in the sector will be released into the job market over the next five years.
He said that as these people will be mostly in their 40s or older, with relatively low education levels, it will be difficult for them to find new jobs.

In terms of the service sector, the government will be more open to foreigners after WTO entry and Kuan predicted that mergers of local financial institutions will become more fierce, resulting in middle- or high-ranking officials in local financial institutions facing pressure of being replaced by their foreign counterparts.

He said that as white-collar workers are mostly in their 40s or older and have reached the time of life when they have the heaviest financial burden regarding family support, their unemployment will be particularly detrimental.

His colleague, Wu Chung-shu, said on the same occasion that Taiwan's exports next year will not be as good as in the past, but as exports of electrical and information products in recent months have shown signs of picking up, the worst should be over.
Although exports are picking up, weak domestic demand due to the rising unemployment and the bad loan situation will make it difficult for the economy to recover.

Consumer growth will be 3.21 percent, a far cry from the past growth of between 6 percent and 7 percent, mainly due to the high unemployment. Private investment will have modest growth of 2.06 percent after experiencing negative growth of 23.12 percent this year, he predicted.
Overall, he concluded, the economic situation is not very optimistic next year, but export growth will be more solid, stimulating a modest recovery.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC ATTACHES GREAT IMPORTANCE TO WTO REPRESENTATION IN GENEVA

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's delegation to the World Trade Organization (WTO) will be a permanent representation on a scale and status similar to those of other WTO member countries, sources from the Executive Yuan said Wednesday.

In a closed-door, nine-member meeting of the Presidential Office, the Executive Yuan and the ruling Democratic Progressive Party held late Tuesday, President Chen Shui-bian was quoted as saying that the establishment of the ROC delegation at WTO headquarters in Geneva should not be scrimped because of financial considerations and that hopefully the delegation will be formally inaugurated Jan. 1, 2002, the day Taiwan becomes a full member of the world trade regulatory body.
Taiwan finished its application process Nov. 11, when a WTO ministerial conference in Doha, Qatar, approved its admittance, ending the country's 12-year pursuit of WTO membership.

According to Chiou I-jen, secretary-general of the Executive Yuan, Tuesday's meeting did not discuss who will be appointed the ROC's first head delegate to the WTO or the line-up of the ROC delegation.

The meeting, however, decided that the inaugural ROC delegation will comprise 16 members, including a head representative, two deputy representatives and six officials from the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA), three officials from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, two officials from the Council of Agriculture, one official from the Ministry of Finance and one "alternative" official to be appointed by the top representative for the ad hoc mission.
Basically, the ROC's WTO delegation will be a 36-member diplomatic operation overseas, which will be allocated an annual budget of NT$200 million (US$5.8 million), according to Chiou.
It was undecided whether the delegation will be located at the existing MOEA office in Geneva or whether it will be based at another location, Chiou said.

He noted that based on the WTO formula, Taiwan will seek to join other international organizations in the future, including the World Intellectual Property Rights Organization, the World Customs Organization, the International Standards Organization and the Organization of Economic Cooperation and Development.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA SHIPBUILDING FACING FINANCIAL CRISIS

TEXT.P: The state-run China Shipbuilding Corp. (CSC) is facing serious financial crisis, and the management is calling on the employees to support a "company readjustment" -- layoffs and salary cuts.

A company spokesman said Tuesday that CSC's operational losses have amounted to NT$10.5 billion against its capital investment of NT$11 billion and that the company is facing imminent bankruptcy if no emergency measures are taken.
A representative of the workers union said meanwhile that the employees had not received their salaries for December.

The company spokesman said that management has promised to pay the employees just one-third of their monthly salaries Dec. 20. In the meantime, he went on, the company is trying to borrow money from other state enterprises. Employees will be able to receive their salaries on regular pay days, he said, but only if CSC can borrow money from the Taiwan Sugar Corp. (TSC) and the Taiwan Salt Industrial Corp. (TSIC).

TSC and TSIC are among the few state-run enterprises still making money. In order to improve the financial structure of the state enterprises, the Ministry of Economic Affairs has instructed six loss-making state-run enterprises to submit readjustment programs and to improve their operations before the ministry will grant any rescue packages.

In addition to the CSC, the Aerospace Industrial Development Corp., the Tang Eng Iron Works, Co. Ltd., the Kaohsiung Ammonium Sulfate Co., Ltd., the Taiwan Agricultural and Industrial Development Corp., and the Taiwan Machinery Manufacturing Corp. are also required to submit readjustment programs.

The CSC management recently submitted a draft of it readjustment program to the Ministry of Economic affairs, hoping that the Executive Yuan will set aside a rescue fund to help the company carry out its slimming program.
CSC has proposed reducing its staff by 47 percent, from over 5,000 to less than 2,800, while the survivors will face a 35 percent salary cut starting next year.

While the workers union is reluctant to agree to the program, the company management is in a dilemma. The Economics Ministry requires CSC to submit a list of staff members who agree to take early retirements before granting the company a special rescue fund. On the other hand, the program is not finalized because the management has had difficulty persuading 2,500 employees sign the early retirement agreement.

CSC Vice President Liu Wu-hsien said that the CSC management has decided to submit a list of people who will be laid off to the Commission of National Corporations under the Economics Ministry next week to manifest the company's determination to implement its readjustment program. The ministry may then agree to have TSC and TSIC lend money to CSC.

He said that the Executive Yuan has agreed to set aside NT$9 billion as a CSC special pension fund and another NT$6 billion for CSC reinvestment projects next year. However, CSC is required to implement the readjustment program before the end of December.

CSC was set up in July 1973 with two shipyards each in Kaohsiung and Keelung. The company had its glory days in the 1980s and early 1990s. However, it has suffered serious losses in recent years amid the recession.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO FINANCIAL HOLDING COMPANIES ESTABLISHED IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Taiwan's first two financial holding companies were established Wednesday, marking a milestone in the island's financial reform.
The Hua Nan Financial Holdings Co. started operations after receiving a license delivered in person by Minister of Finance Yen Ching-chang.
Yen said that the recent enactment of the financial holding company law enables financial institutions to engage in businesses previously beyond their areas of operation.
Late last month, the Ministry of Finance approved the applications by six financial groups to set up holding companies.
Yen noted that the financial reforms being carried out by his ministry will not only improve the structure of grassroots financial institutions, but will also provide a mechanism for mergers.
He predicted that Taiwan's financial institutions will become bigger in scale and more transparent in operations while attaching more importance to professionalism.
Later, the minister visited the Fubon Financial Holding Co. to present a business license that was received by the firm's chairman, Yu Cheng.
The Hua Nan Financial Holdings Co. was formed by the Hua Nan Commercial Bank and Yung Chang Securities Co. Total assets of the group top NT$1,230 billion (US$35.14 billion).

The Fubon Financial Holding Co. was established by the Fubon Insurance Co., the Fubon Commercial Bank, the Fubon Securities and the Fubon Life Insurance Co. Total assets amount to NT$451 billion (US$12.88 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCAL MUSICIANS TO GIVE CONCERT IN MEMORY OF LOCAL COMPOSER

TEXT.P: Local musicians will give a concert at the National Concert Hall on New Year's Day, 2002 in memory of the late composer Hsu Chang-houei (1929-2001).

Hsu is remembered as a pioneer local composer. As founder of the Music Creative Group in Taiwan and a co-founder of the Asian Composers League, he made great contributions to the development of local music composition and international exchanges.

Hsu's compositions have been played by domestic as well as international symphony orchestras. The orchestra of the National Taipei Academy of Arts will play Hsu's "The Chinese Festivities" and "Chang-O Flees to the Moon" in the New Year's Day concert.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CAN BECOME GLOBAL LOGISTICS CENTER: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Taiwan enjoys an edge in terms of geography, transport and trade in its plan to become a global logistics center in Asia, an economic official said Wednesday.

Ho Mei-yueh, vice chairwoman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, made the remarks when she attended a two-day seminar on global logistics that gathered freight forwarders from Taipei, Beijing, Hong Kong and Macau.

Ho noted that Taiwan has an international port within 53 hours sailing time of five other major harbors in the Asia-Pacific region and that the island is within an average of two hours and 55 minutes flying time of seven major cities in the western Pacific.

Ho said that Kaohsiung port in the south of Taiwan and Keelung port in the north can handle large commercial ships, adding that Kaohsiung port ranked fourth in terms of the world's container ports in 2000, while the volume of container handling grew by 6.3 percent from the previous year.

She also said that cross-Taiwan Strait relations have become closer, with the amount of Taiwan investment in the mainland approved for 2000 totaling more than US$2.6 billion. As of June this year, Taiwan investment in the mainland reached US$1.3 billion, while the government has also expanded the functions of Taiwan's offshore transshipment center this year so that goods shipped from Fuzhou and Xiamen in the mainland can be stored in bonded warehouses in Kaohsiung and processed for transshipment to third countries.
The seminar has been held in rotation in Hong Kong, Macau, Taipei and Beijing every year since its inauguration in 1998. This is the first time Taiwan has sponsored the event.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN AS FREE AS BRITAIN, JAPAN, GERMANY: HUMAN RIGHTS REPORT

TEXT.P: The Republic of China is a "free nation" with its rate of freedom on a level similar to 30 other "free nations" including Britain, France, Japan and Germany, according to a recent report on world human rights.
In its annual report, the Washington-based Freedom House ranked 86 out of 192 nations and areas around the world as "free" nations, 58 as "partly free" nations and 48 as "not free" nations.

On a 13-level ranking scale (the smaller the number of levels the better), 29 countries were listed as top-level free nations. Most nations in this group were in central and northern Europe, North America and the Caribbean.
Thirty countries and areas were included in the second-best level area, including Taiwan, Britain, France, Germany, Japan, Poland, Hungary and Panama.
Ten nations were on the lowest level, including Afghanistan, Myanmar, Cuba, Iraq, North Korea, Libya, Saudi Arabia, Sudan, Syria and Turkmenistan.
Seven nations in this group are Islamic countries, the report pointed out.
Mainland China was ranked on the 12th level together with nine other nations, including Laos, Vietnam and Somalia.
Hong Kong and Macau, meanwhile, were considered as "free areas."
Besides the 10 nations on level 13, the worst places in the world in terms of human rights are Tibet which is ruled by communist China, and Chechnya which is ruled by Russia, according to the report.
Worldwide, 2.54 billion people live in 86 free nations, forming just over 41 percent of the global population -- the highest proportion since the survey began in 1981.

DOC.HEADLINE: DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA COUNCIL HONORS ROC DIPLOMAT
DOC.DATELINE: Washington D.C. Dec. 18 (CNA) (By Sherman Pan & Ed Chen)

TEXT.P: The Council of the District of Columbia Tuesday declared Dec. 18 as "Jack K.C. Chiang Day" in Washington, D.C.

The council made the declaration to honor Chiang, formerly a section chief at the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in Washington and now director of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Seattle, for his contributions to relations between Taipei and Washington.

Chiang served as chief of the Servicing Section at the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in Washington from August, 1998, where he established good relations with overseas Chinese communities and Washington. He assumed his duties in Seattle last month.

Chiang, who returned to Washington, D.C. from Seattle Tuesday to receive the honor, thanked Council Speaker Linda Cropp and all the councilmen for their commendation and said that "his heart is still in Washington, D.C." He added his hope that the United States will continue to strengthen relations with Taiwan.
The Council of District of Columbia has also adopted resolutions to honor Oct. 10 -- Republic of China National Day -- many times over the years.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACADEMIA SINICA FORECASTS MINUS 1.89% ECONOMIC GROWTH FOR 2001

TEXT.P: The Academia Sinica's Institute of Economics announced Wednesday that it had adjusted downward an earlier forecast for the Republic of China's economic growth in 2001 from 2.38 percent to minus 1.89 percent.

In a report on the nation's economic prospects, the institute said that the domestic economy is expected to bottom out in the fourth quarter of this year and that 3.08 percent economic growth can be expected for the coming year.
The institute forecast the economic growth rates in the four quarters of next year at 1.04 percent, 2.39 percent, 4.58 percent and 4.16 percent, respectively.

Also that day, the International Monetary Fund (IMF) released its World Economic Outlook report in which Taiwan was listed 28th among 29 advanced economies in terms of real GDP (gross domestic product) growth.
The IMF report indicates that with GDP growth of minus 2.2 percent, Taiwan's real GDP growth in 2001 was far behind the average of 5.6 percent among the developing economies in Asia.

For the coming year, the IMF predicts that Taiwan's real GDP will grow by 0.7 percent, lower than most Asian economies. It further predicted that among Taiwan's major trading partners and competitors, the United States will attain growth of 0.7 percent, mainland China will grow 6.8 percent, Japan will grow 0.1 percent, Hong Kong will grow 1 percent, and South Korea will grow 3.2 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Dec. 20, or the 6th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1852: British troops annex Pegu, lower Burma, during a war with Burma.
1913: Taiwan's North-South Railway Trunk Line is completed.
1921: Mahathir Mohamad, Malaysian prime minister, is born.
1927: Kim Young-sam, former president of South Korea, is born.
1922: Fourteen republics of Russia form the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics.
1924: Adolf Hitler is paroled after serving eight months of a prison sentence after being convicted of high treason.
1928: Britain recognizes the government of the Republic of China.
1941: The Flying Tigers, flown by U.S. Air Force volunteers, shoot down four Japanese planes in their first encounter near Kunming in southwest China.
1944: Young Chinese students begin to enter training camps in response to a call to join the armed forces and fight against Japan.
1945: Soviet troops move an estimated US$2 billion-worth of machinery from Manchuria to the Soviet Union.
1950: Fu Shih-nien, president of National Taiwan University, dies of a stroke at the age of 55. He collapses while answering interpellations at the Taiwan Provincial Assembly.
1968: John Steinbeck, the American novelist who won the Nobel Prize for literature for books such as "The Grapes of Wrath" and "East of Eden," dies at the age of 66.
1960: The Viet Cong, the armed wing of the National Liberation Front, is founded in South Vietnam.
1968: The ROC chooses 26 new members of the National Assembly and the Legislative Yuan from among 52 candidates.
1971: President Agha Mohammed Yahya Khan resigns after Pakistan losses control over East Pakistan, now Bangladesh.
1973: Spanish Premier Luis Carrero Blanco is killed when assassins bomb his car in Madrid, Spain.
1981: The Kuangfu River Tunnel in Taitung is formally open to traffic, becoming the first railway tunnel under a river in Taiwan.
1982: Arthur Rubinstein, Russian-born American pianist, dies at the age of 95 in Geneva.
1986: Some 30,000 students march for democracy through the streets of Shanghai in mainland China's largest demonstration since the Cultural Revolution.
1988: The first batch of five mainland Chinese students, who are studying in the United States, arrive in Taipei for a visit.
1989: Some 12,000 U.S. troops join 12,000 already in Panama to unseat Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega as head of that country.
1991: President Boris Yeltsin announces that Russia wants to join the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO).
1994: Mexico lowers the peso's trading floor, triggering a drastic devaluation.
1997: South Korean President Kim Dae-jung pardons Chun Doo-hwan and Roh Tae-woo, two former military dictators who had tried to kill him when he was a dissident.
1998: Nkem Chukwu of Houston, Texas, becomes the first woman to give birth to eight live babies.
1999: The Wang Kuang-ying Library, dedicated to a public-spirited ROC man who collected garbage for 35 years and used the money he earned to buy books and donate them to the local and overseas institutions, is inaugurated in Taipei.
1999: ROC President Lee Teng-hui tells visiting U.S. Congresswoman Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) that the ROC's ultimate goal of seeking peaceful reunification with mainland China remains unchanged.
2000: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian says when receiving a seven-member Japanese parliamentary delegation that maintaining peace across the Taiwan Strait is in the common interest of the ROC, Japan and the United States.
Confucius: "Now, if in your conversation you give few occasions for men to criticize you, and in your conduct you have few occasions for self-reproach, you cannot help getting preferment."

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADIAN GOV'T WON'T COMMIT TO HELPING TAIWAN GAIN WHO ADMISSION

TEXT.P: Canada's foreign minister refused to commit the Canadian government to helping democratic Taiwan join the World Health Organization (WHO) when recently challenged on the subject.

Foreign Affairs Minister John Manley invoked Canada's long-standing "one China" policy to reject a request by Member of Parliament Svend Robinson on Dec. 10 that Canada "recognize reality and support Taiwan's participation in the World Health Organization and other international bodies."

"We recognize one China and we recognize the need for the government elected in Taiwan to work within the context of a policy, which is held in common by most countries, of recognizing a single China," Manley said.
Manley shunned another request from the New Democratic Party member of parliament to lift Canada's visa requirement for visitors from Taiwan.

Robinson said the 23 million people of "the independent sovereign state of Taiwan" were recently admitted into the WTO and, at the start of December, participated in vigorous national elections which led to a "historic victory by President Chen Shui-bian's Democratic Progressive Party (DPP)."

Manley pointed out that Robinson was quite right in depicting Taiwan as a lively democracy, saying that "it was a very vigorous election campaign with a very interesting result for everyone observing it."

Robinson was in Taiwan in late November to observe Taiwan's legislative as well as county and city chief elections held Dec. 1. The DPP won the largest number of seats in the Republic of China Legislative Yuan.
After returning to Canada, he issued a statement in Parliament congratulating President Chen and the DPP for their "impressive victory" and praising Taiwan for the vitality of its democracy.
"It is time now for the international community to welcome Taiwan as an international sovereign state, which includes granting it membership in the World Health Organization," he said.

"As well, the Canadian government should end its kowtowing to the mainland regarding its visa policies for visits to Canada by government officials from Taiwan, such as the recently proposed visit by the minister of health, and remove the visa requirement for Taiwanese visitors to Canada," Robinson said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES RALLY ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) rallied Thursday after dropping for three consecutive days, with the benchmark weighted price index rising 87.14 points to close at 5,309.10.
Market turnover amounted to NT$1,01.18 billion (US$2.90 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: EX HIGHER-UP KICKS OFF `PEACE-OF-MIND TASK' BY SELLING BOXED LUNCHES

TEXT.P: Former Control Yuan President Chen Li-an, who had also served as defense minister and Kuomintang deputy secretary-general, kicked off his ambitious "Peace-of-Mind Task" Thursday by selling reasonably-priced boxed lunches.
Chen announced the launch of his undertaking aimed at helping the people of Taiwan lead better lives amid economic distress, using the motto "no fear, always at ease."

The son of the late Republic of China Vice President Chen Cheng said that of the various planned aspects of the "Peace-of-Mind Task," the selling of boxed lunches should be the most pragmatic as well as the easiest in terms of participants in the undertaking achieving their goals.
A devout Buddhist, Chen's lunch boxes are all vegetarian, initially being offered only in Taipei City during lunch time mainly to office workers.

"It's not easy to make vegetarian meals tasty and economic," Chen said, adding that his strategy team, made up mainly of members from the staff of the Chen Cheng Cultural and Educational Foundation, have seen to it that through a centrally-controlled production line and distribution network, the vegetarian lunch boxes are both enjoyable and affordable at NT$60 (US$1.74).

Since the undertaking is designed to help regular people economically, the foundation recruited 22 unemployed people from the files of the Council of Labor Affairs, hiring them to be workers at the boxed lunch operation.
The foundation then signed contracts with 50 physically-challenged people, helping them to retail the vegetarian boxed lunches.
Chen estimated that initially, the boxed lunch enterprise will create job opportunities for 500 to 1,000 people.

According to Chiu Ching-liang, one of the contracted physically-challenged members, he makes a net profit of NT$10 from each boxed lunch sold. If he can manage to sell 50 lunch boxes each noon, he will make more than NT$10,000 per month -- an income which he says is "not bad" for a person who originally sold lottery tickets on the street.

Currently, the boxed lunches are available at 50 distribution points around Taipei, Chen said, adding that the operation will be expanded to other cities and counties in northern Taiwan if the program turns out to be a success in Taipei City.

When asked about the "trivial" and "moderate" scale of the boxed lunch enterprise as compared to his high-level background, Chen, who lost his bid for the Republic of China presidency to Lee Teng-hui in the 1996 election, said "making boxed lunches is not an easy task at all."

To help start the boxed lunch operation, Chen personally pitched in, getting to know the prices of the needed ingredients, such as rice and vegetables, as well as becoming familiar with GMP (a government-imposed quality standard for manufactured products) and the sanitary standards for ready-to-serve foods.
"Now, I have finally come to realize how shallow officials are in terms of their perception of things," Chen said.

Chen's pragmatism has already begun to inspire people. An unemployed 40-something man who had never in his life thought about being out of a job until this year, said that "if Chen can sell boxed lunches, why can't I drive a taxi cab?"
You can do anything once you cast aside the notion of "face," Chen told the man.

Pointing out that there are probably many things in the past that he should have done that he didn't and that he must therefore bear some responsibility for the problems Taiwan society is now facing, he said that the "Peace-of-Mind Task" is merely "a 65-year-old retired official's atonement."
Chen vowed to carry out the undertaking successfully, saying that he hopes the lunch box enterprise is just the starting point.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES UP 1.7 PERCENT ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taipei Stock Exchange rallied Thursday on the strength of bargain hunting in electrical stocks after falling for three consecutive days.

The TAIEX benchmark weighted price index rose 87. 14 points, or 1.7 percent, to finish at 5,309.10. The bourse opened low at 5,199.47, hitting a low of 5,142.83 during the day's trading before finishing at its highest point.

A total of 3.54 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$101.18 billion (US$2.90 billion), compared with the previous trading session which saw 4.1 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$115.09 billion (US$3.30 billion).

Three out of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with plastics and chemical stocks moving up the most at 3.8 percent, followed by electrical issues at 2.2 percent, and textile shares at 1.7 percent.

The five other major stock categories lost ground, with construction stocks moving down the most at 3.0 percent, followed by bank and insurance stocks at 1.0 percent, cement stocks at 0.6 percent, and foodstuff shares and pulp and paper issues, both at 0.3 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 373 to 203, with 72 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: CITY AND COUNTY CHIEFS SWORN IN

TEXT.P: Twenty-one city and county chiefs from around Taiwan were sworn in at official ceremonies Thursday, vowing to better serve the local people and to deliver on their campaign promises.

Among the new local chiefs, two are females. In terms of party affiliation, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) each have nine positions, and the People First Party (PFP) has one position, while two of the positions are occupied by independents.
The six county magistrates who succeeded in their reelection bids and were sworn in are as follows:

Yunlin County Magistrate Chang Rong-wei (KMT),
Pingtung County Magistrate Su Chia-chuan (DPP),
Penghu County Magistrate Lai Feng-wei (KMT).
Meanwhile, the 15 newly-elected city and county chiefs who were sworn in are as follows:

Chiayi City Mayor Chen Li-chen (Ind.),
