DOC.HEADLINE: SUSPENSION OF TAIWAN-HONG KONG AIR TRAFFIC NOT PROBABLE: MAC HEAD

TEXT.P: Air links between Taiwan and Hong Kong will not stop after the aviation agreement between the two expires at the end of the year, said Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen, Thursday.
Tsai said the probability of a suspension of air traffic was "zero," adding that officials are currently addressing the issue.
Local media has reported that air services between Taiwan and Hong Kong could be disrupted when the aviation accord expires at the end of the year as a result of Beijing's interference.

Fielding questions at the Legislative Yuan, Tsai said there is no possibility for the Taiwan-Hong Kong air links to be disrupted, adding that she would not comment further until details of the issue had been hammered out.

Under the current Taiwan-Hong Kong aviation pact signed in 1996, the two sides must review the agreement every five years. When the pact expired June 12 this year, the two sides failed to meet to review the accord, although they agreed to extend it to the end of this year.

Although the pact's new expiration date is drawing near, sources close to the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) said that the agency has still not been able to prepare an agenda for negotiations.

The CAA, under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, is responsible for arranging technical details for talks, but since Hong Kong reverted to mainland Chinese rule in July 1997, the MAC, which charts Taiwan's policy toward mainland China, has taken charge of issues related to Hong Kong, including civil aviation affairs.

At present, Taiwan and Hong Kong are each allowed to operate 121 flights between the two destinations per week. Of Taiwan's quota, China Airlines accounts for 105 flights and EVA Airways operates the remaining 16 flights.
On the Hong Kong side, Cathay Pacific Airways accounts for 100 flights and Dragonair is allowed to operate 21 flights.

Both EVA and Dragonair hope that the aviation accord can be revised to allow them to operate more flights as the demand for Taiwan-Hong Kong flight services has continued to rise, despite the current economic downturn.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market rose on Thursday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization weighed Index futures for next January rose 85.00 points to close at 5,285.00, with 18,097 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for next February gained 37.00 points to finish at 5,281, with 23 contract transactions. TAIEX Index futures for next March rose 44.00 points to finish at 5,250, with 13 contract transactions.

Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mixed.
TE futures for next January moved up seven points to close at 276, with 4,897 contract transactions, while TE futures for next February fell 1.6 points to finish at 273, with two contracts traded.

No transactions were reported for other months. TF future for next January lost 8.2 points to finish at 761 with 4,587 contract transactions, while TF futures for next February rose 11.8 points to close at 757.4, with seven contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

Interbank U.S. dollar trading totaled US$788 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO TAIWAN BUSINESSMEN ON MAINLAND HAVE JOINED CPC: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The government is not aware of any Taiwan businessmen who have invested in mainland China that have joined the Communist Party of China (CPC), Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Chen Ruey-rong said Thursday.

Chen made the remarks when fielding questions in the Legislative Yuan during which legislator Chiu Chui-chen of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party expressed concern over the establishment of CPC operations in Taiwan-financed companies on the mainland.

Chiu claimed that the Shenzhen-based branch of Taiwan's Hon Hai Precision Industry Co. has established a CPC cell. He also said that even well-known companies like Formosa Plastics and President Enterprises have organized CPC branches in their mainland Chinese operations.

Chiu said that the situation has become a serious problem and wondered what would happen if Taiwan nationals joined the CPC and then returned to Taiwan -- they could then vote for political candidates on the island with similar views.
Vice Minister Chen replied by saying that the CPC is still an illegal organization in Taiwan and that if Taiwan businessmen join the CPC they will be violating ROC statutes.
But he said that as far as he knows, only mainland staff of Hon Hai's Shenzhen affiliate, Foxconn, have joined the CPC and that no Taiwan businessmen have joined.
Foxconn, established in Shenzhen in 1988 with a workforce of 38,000 people, is reported to be an overseas holding company registered in a third country.

Chen also said that mainland authorities should concentrate more on protecting the well-being of Taiwan businessmen and their investments, not trying to push their political views on Taiwan nationals.

Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Hsin-yi had said the previous day that reports of Taiwan businessmen joining the CPC were unfounded and that there was no attempt by the CPC to infiltrate Taiwan-financed businesses and industrial operations in mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: SENIOR CITIZENS MAY BE GRANTED MONTHLY STIPEND STARTING 2002

TEXT.P: Senior citizens may be getting a NT$3,000 monthly stipend from the government if opposition parties can agree on how the program is to be implemented.

The Health, Environment and Social Welfare Committee of the Legislative Yuan Wednesday approved the NT$16 billion budget proposal for the senior citizen stipend program to be carried out in fiscal 2002. However, legislators of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party insisted that a senior citizen stipend provisional act should first be adopted before the stipend program is implemented.

Tsai Huang-lang, secretary-general of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), said that the Executive Yuan could decide on the implementation of the program with the Senior Citizen Welfare Law as its legal basis.

Tsai suggested that political parties in the Legislative Yuan settle the issue through negotiations in the plenary meeting scheduled for mid-January. If consensus is reached, the program would then be in force retroactive from Jan. 1, he added.

Around 440,000 senior citizens are expected to be covered by the program. A senior citizen, defined as a person 65 years of age or older, with an annual income of NT$500,000 or more, or in possession of real assets worth NT$5 million or more, would not be entitled to the payments, according to Minister of the Interior Chang Po-ya.
Chang guaranteed that the financial sources have been secured to implement the stipend program for the next four years until 2005, when the government starts the senior citizen annuity program.

According to the Executive Yuan's budget planning, the NT$16 billion set aside for the senior citizen stipend program in 2002 will come mostly from budget cuts in various ministries and departments of the Executive Yuan.

The senior citizen annuity was a campaign promise of the ruling party. It has given rise to much controversy and the government's financial ability to support the program has been questioned by opposition politicians.

In the past years, elderly residents in some of the DPP-governed cities and counties were granted living allowances. However, most of these welfare programs were carried out only for a short period of time because of financial constraints of the domestic administrations.

The elderly population has continued to rise in Taiwan over the past decade. In 1989, senior citizens numbered 1.2 million, representing 6 percent of Taiwan's overall population. As of the end of September, 2000, the number rose to 1.9 million, representing 8.6 percent of the population.

As Taiwan is entering the group nations considered to be senior societies, the government has made economic security and protection of the elderly a major goal in its social welfare planning. A national senior citizen annuity program is being planned and is expected to be implemented starting 2005.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN EXPECTED TO BECOME OECD OBSERVER IN JANUARY

TEXT.P: Taiwan is expected to become an observer in the Paris-based Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) in January, economics officials said Thursday.

The OECD council meeting is scheduled to make the announcement Thursday night (Taipei time), formally ushering Taiwan into the OECD's Competition Law and Policy Committee as an observer, effective from January, FTC officials said.
Taiwan has been endeavoring to join the OECD Competition Law and Policy Committee since 1995, competing with major rivals including New Zealand and Australia, for entrance.
Mainland China is also expected to become an OECD observer next month, joining the organization's Science and Technology Committee.
Reports said Taiwan's and mainland China's applications were discussed by the OECD's Committee on Cooperative Relations of non-member countries Dec. 14.

The OECD, known as a "rich men's club," is an association of 30 nations mainly in Western Europe, North America and the Pacific working to promote the economic and social welfare of its members, and coordinating efforts to aid developing countries.
Of its 30 members, only Japan and South Korea are full members from Asia, while Hong Kong and Singapore are observers.
Mainland China has recently become a full member of the World Trade Organization and Taiwan's membership will become effective Jan. 1.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. CONGRESS PASSES BILL SUPPORTING ROC'S WHO OBSERVER STATUS
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 19 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: The U.S. Congress passed a bill Wednesday requiring President George W. Bush's administration to come up with a plan to help Taiwan obtain observer status in the World Health Organization (WHO).

The representatives passed the bill without objection after Republican representative from New York Benjamin Gilman, who is chairman of the Committee on International Relations, and Tom Lantos, a California Democrat, called for support for the bill.
The bill is aimed to amend a similar bill signed by President Bush in May.
The original bill requiring the administration to help Taiwan get observer status by May, 2001 was signed into law by President Bush when the WHO annual summit in Geneva had already concluded.
Wednesday's bill changes the date from May. 2001 to May, 2002.

It also adds to the original bill a mention of President Bush's promise to Sen. Frank Murkowski, made in a letter dated May 11 to the Alaska Republican, that the United States "should find opportunities for Taiwan's voice to be heard in international organizations in order to make a contribution, even if membership is not possible."

Furthermore, the new bill also points to Secretary of Health and Human Services Tommy Thompson's statement on May 16 to the effect that the U.S. administration supports Taiwan's participation in the activities of the WHO.
This bill, which was introduced by Rep. Sherrod Brown, a Democrat from Ohio, will now be referred to the Senate for debate before going on to the president for his signature.
Taipei, riding on Congress' support, is calling on the Bush administration to follow its promise with concrete plans to support Taipei's bid for observer status at the next WHO summit.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. EXPERT WARNS OF MAINLAND CHINESE AIR FORCE MODERNIZATION
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 19 (CNA) (By Nelson Chung and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: The mainland Chinese air force could overwhelm a single carrier's defenses if that is all the United States could send to aid Taiwan in the event of an armed conflict in the Taiwan Strait, a U.S. expert on mainland military developments warned in a recently published article.

Richard D. Fisher Jr., a senior fellow at the Jamestown Foundation, a Washington-based think tank, wrote in the most recent issue of Jamestown's China Brief that it is therefore "correct" for the Pentagon to call for an increased U.S. military presence in the Western Pacific region in its September 2001 Quadrennial Review.

By 2005, Fisher wrote, the People's Liberation Army Air Force (PLAAF) will pose a much more formidable threat to Taiwan and to U.S. forces in Asia. It could help destroy Taiwan's defenses in a large pre-emptive strike when coordinated with massive missile strikes, he added.

"Ongoing PLAAF modernization makes necessary appropriate U.S. measures to ensure the deterrence of conflict in the Taiwan Strait," Fisher wrote, because "absent countervailing actions by Taiwan and the United States, by 2005 the PLA Air Force could begin to gain superiority" in the Taiwan Strait.

Fisher wrote that according to newspaper reports, the PLAAF sent its new Sukhoi Su-30MKK fighter jets out to the mid-line of the Taiwan Strait in early November as if to intimidate Taiwan before the island's Dec. 1 legislative elections.

He went on to write that it is important to watch the PLAAF because in any future conflict, a short-range ballistic missile might carry only a 1,000 pound warhead once, but a strike fighter like the Russian-made Su-30MKK can carry about 17,000 pounds over scores of missions.
"A war's outcome will depend on the PLA's ability to secure and exploit effective air superiority in the Taiwan theater of operations," he wrote.

Fisher attributed the drive behind the PLAAF's modernization to the growing political goal identified by Beijing leaders to "build a modern PLA capable of playing a key role in forcing unification with Taiwan under Beijing's terms."

Quoting recent reports, Fisher wrote that the PLAAF could acquire between 300 and 400 modern multi-role fighters by 2005 that are capable of all-weather attack missions with modern precision-guided weapons. These aircraft could include 100 Su-30MKKs and hundreds of indigenously built Chengdu J-10 fighters, he added.
In terms of airborne forces, Fisher quoted reports that suggest that the 15th Airborne Army might be substantially expanded to a force that exceeds 50,000 men.

"The danger is that such a force could prove instrumental in either scaring Taiwan into submission, or, if used correctly, could deliver the final blow needed to force Taiwan's surrender," Fisher wrote.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BUSINESSMEN WHO JOIN CPC WILL BE PUNISHED: MAC CHIEF

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen said Thursday that if Taiwan businessmen in mainland China are found to have joined the Communist Party of China (CPC), they will be liable to heavy punishment in Taiwan.
Speaking at a Legislative Yuan committee meeting, Tsai noted that a communist cell was set up in the Taiwan-financed Foxconn group in Shenzhen for locally employed workers last week.
However, she described it as "an individual case."
Tsai said that the government will keep a close watch on the development and work out appropriate countermeasures.
If Taiwan businessmen on the mainland are found to have joined the CPC, she went on, "it would be a serious matter."
The government's reaction to such businessmen would be reflected when any of their future investment applications are submitted for government screening, Tsai continued.

She pointed out that according to the statute governing relations between the people of Taiwan and mainland China, Taiwan businessmen are liable to fines of up to NT$500,000 (US$14,200) if they join the CPC.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAGAZINE NAMES TSMC LEADING COMPANY IN TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Dec. 20 (CNA) (By Stanley Cheung and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: A recent survey published by the Far Eastern Economic Review on the leaders, products and services of 208 companies in Asia listed Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. as the leading company in Taiwan.

The rest of the top-10 Taiwan companies are Formosa Plastics, Evergreen Marine, EVA Airways, United Microelectronics, Chinatrust Commercial Bank, Hon Hai Precision Industry, Nan Ya Plastics, Taiwan Cellular and Formosa Chemicals and Fiber, in that order.
The list appears in the latest issue of the Hong Kong-based magazine and is based on an annual survey conducted among the magazine's readers by ACNielsen.

The readers also named Woolworth's as the leading company in Australia, Mass Transit Railway in Hong Kong, Infosys Technologies in India, Astra International in Indonesia, Toyota Motor in Japan, Genting in Malaysia, Jollibee Foods in the Philippines, Singapore Airlines in Singapore, Samsung in South Korea and Charoen Pokphand Group in Thailand.
Globally, the magazine's readers named the top-10 companies as Microsoft, General Electric, Nokia, McDonald's, IBM, Coca-Cola, Visa International, Intel, Walt Disney and Nestle, in that order.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW ASIA-PACIFIC CABLE NETWORK LAUNCHED

TEXT.P: A consortium of leading telecommunication companies launched services Thursday on the Asia Pacific Cable Network 2 (APCN 2), the world's first Asian submarine ring system.

The APCN 2 System comprises 19,000 km of cable connecting mainland China, Taiwan, Hong Kong, Japan, Korea, Malaysia, the Philippines and Singapore. Consortium members have invested over US$1 billion in the project, which uses the most advanced fiber-optic technology deploying state-of-the-art technology.

The major investors in the system include Cable & Wireless, China Telecom, China Unicom, Chunghwa Telecom, Concert, Global One, Japan Telecom, KDDI, KT, KPN, Metromedia Fibre Network Services, NTT Com, NCIC, PLDT, Reach, StarHub, SingTel, Taiwan Fixed Network, Teleglobe, Telekom Malaysia and Williams Communications.

Rab Paramothayan, management committee chairman for the APCN 2 System, said: "In addition to providing intra-Asian connectivity, APCN 2 will also provide seamless interconnection with other major Trans-Pacific cable networks that provide connectivity to the United States."

NEC Corporation is the exclusive contractor of the system supply for APCN 2, and its Vice President Kentaro Oka said: "We are delighted to have contributed to this milestone project through the supply of cutting-edge technology."

APCN 2 is a fully diverse system, which will provide cost effective services to multinational customers across the region. It is designed as a self-healing network, which means that customers' services can be protected by using alternative paths or routing when required.

The system will initially offer 80 Gbit/s of capacity, which will be upgraded to 160 Gbit/s in 2002 to meet the burgeoning demand for bandwidth in the region. Further upgrades will be implemented in accordance with demand.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET RESHUFFLE TO BRING REFORM, DEVELOPMENT: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday that he has been maintaining a low profile and monitoring the situation since the Dec. 1 elections so that next year's Cabinet reshuffle can bring about a turning point for national reform and establish a foundation for economic development.

In a meeting with visiting U.S. Representative Robert Wexler, Chen said that although the ruling Democratic Progressive Party had good results in the elections -- becoming the largest party in the Legislative Yuan for the first time -- he was neither excited nor proud, but rather even more humble because the people gave the party a chance that it should treasure.

Chen told the Florida Democrat that he is confident in the future and that he believes cross-Taiwan Strait relations will become even more stable, the economy will continue to develop and various democratic reforms will be promoted and completed.

The president said that the U.S. government and Congress can play the role of cross-strait stabilizer, balancer and "messenger of peace." The ROC government supports the development of a constructive relationship between the United States and mainland China but hopes that such a development will not affect or sacrifice Taiwan's interests.
Chen thanked Wexler, who is a member of the House International Relations Committee, for his long-time support of the Republic of China's bid to participate in various international organizations.

After Taiwan officially becomes a World Trade Organization member next year, the island hopes to become an observer in the World Health Organization and ultimately a member in the United Nations, the president added.

Wexler arrived in Taiwan Tuesday for a four-day visit, his first trip to Taiwan. He has called on U.S. President George W. Bush to continue selling arms to Taiwan and to support the island's bid for membership in international organizations.

DOC.HEADLINE: NSB CHIEF SAYS NO BUGS DISCOVERED IN GOVERNMENT OFFICES

TEXT.P: National Security Bureau (NSB) Director-General Tsai Chao-ming said Thursday after a thorough search that his bureau did not discover any eavesdropping equipment in the offices of either the Ministry of Foreign Affairs or the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC).

Tsai said that the two government agencies asked his bureau to conduct electronic counter-surveillance after suspicions were raised that their premises were bugged. He added that it was "reasonable" to suspect mainland China of doing the bugging.
However, the MAC stated in a news release that the search was "a routine protective measure" that, contrary to media reports, was not carried out as a result of suspicions of bugging.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC NATIONALS IN ARGENTINA SAFE: FOREIGN MINISTRY
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 20 (CNA) (By Oscar Chung and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: Republic of China nationals and diplomatic personnel in Argentina are safe from the riots there, which have abated, a spokeswoman for the ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs said Thursday.

Meanwhile, the ROC representative office in Argentina reported that most businessmen from Taiwan live in Buenos Aires, the South American nation's capital city, while most of the rioting has occurred in nearby cities and provinces.

Austerity measures introduced by Argentine Economy Minister Domingo Cavallo, such as a monthly cap on savings withdrawals, have drawn widespread anger that led to protests and looting, prompting President Fernando de la Rua to impose a 30-day state of emergency to restore order.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S ECONOMY NEXT YEAR MAY GROW 3 PERCENT: RESEARCHER

TEXT.P: The president of the Taiwan Research Institute (TRI) predicted Thursday that the island's real economic growth rate next year is likely to reach 3 percent.

Liu Tai-ying made the remarks after attending a symposium on Taiwan's entry into the World Trade Organization, which was jointly sponsored by the TRI and the Cabinet-level Research, Development and Evaluation Commission.
Liu noted that various economic indices at home and abroad have begun rising -- especially the leading index for the U.S. economy -- and added that stock markets around the world are also recovering.

He admitted that it is difficult to make a precise prediction amid the recent large-scale fluctuations of the world economy, but went on to say that he has become more optimistic about Taiwan's economic performance than he was a few weeks ago.

Early this month, the TRI said that Taiwan's economy would register a significant recovery in the second half of next year, predicting a growth of 3.97 percent for the July-December period of 2002 and 2.24 percent for the whole year of 2002.
Regarding the devaluation of Taiwan's currency against the greenback, Liu said that the value of the new Taiwan dollar is unlikely to drop to the level of NT$35 to the U.S. dollar.
The exchange rate on the Taipei foreign exchange for the day was NT$34.756, down NT$0.029 from the preceding day.
The researcher attributed the recent rise of the local stock market to the recovery of the global stock markets, the loosening of capital in Taiwan and the island's lowest interest rates in a decade.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC AMBASSADOR: SENEGAL WELCOMES VISIT BY ROC VP
DOC.DATELINE: Dakar, Senegal, Dec. 19 (CNA) (By Tzou Ming-jhie & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: The relationship between Senegal and the Republic of China is stable and if ROC Vice President Annette Lu visits Dakar on her way to Gambia, she will get an enthusiastic welcome, ROC ambassador to Dakar Tou Chen-seng said Wednesday.

Tou denounced as groundless speculation reports in a Taiwan newspaper that ties between Dakar and Taipei could be in danger after the country, which is usually the gateway to Gambia, was deliberately skipped by Lu on her way to the Gambian president's inauguration.

The reports said that instead of flying to Gambia from Senegal, Lu tried to make her way to Western Europe, but had to delay her trip for one day because of the diplomatic red tape surrounding her transit stop in the unnamed Western European country.
Tou said Senegal President Abdoulaye Wade is very friendly toward the ROC. He visited Taipei in July, and struck up a "firm personal friendship" with ROC President Chen Shui-bian.

Senegal Prime Minister Moustapha Niasse and Foreign Minister Jacques Baudin also set great store on their country's friendship with the ROC and Tou added that the relationship between Dakar and Taipei is even better than it was before the presidential elections in March 2000.

The ambassador said the agricultural cooperation between the two countries is the best witness of the steadfast friendship and added that Taiwan's technical mission has created an "agricultural miracle" in the West African country by turning it from a rice importer to a rice exporter with Taiwan's advanced rice-cultivation technology.
Lu was scheduled to leave Taipei on Tuesday night for the Gambian capital of Banjul, but was forced to make a last-minute postponement.

As a result, she left Taipei a day later and was expected to board a chartered plane in Paris Thursday for Banjul, where she will attend the Dec. 21 inauguration of Gambia's re-elected President Yahya Jammeh.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, MAINLAND CHINA TO SIGN NEW OIL EXPLORATION AGREEMENT

TEXT.P: Taiwan's state-run Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) and the China National Offshore Oil Corp. (CNOOC) of mainland China will cooperate to drill for undersea oil in the Chaoshan area off the southeastern mainland coast, a CPC official said Thursday.

The official told reporters that CNOOC President Wei Liucheng is scheduled to come to Taipei next month to sign a cooperation agreement, under the terms of which the two firms will set up a joint company to be registered in a third country.
Initial capital for test drilling will be US$10 million, to be shared equally by the two sides.
The cooperation pact is also subject to approval by the governments of the two sides.
CPC began cooperating in oil exploration with CNOOC in March 1998 through its subsidiary firm -- Overseas Petroleum Investment Corp. (OPIC).

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WELCOMES OECD DECISION ON OBSERVER STATUS

TEXT.P: The Fair Trade Commission (FTC) under the Executive Yuan announced Thursday that the island has been admitted by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) as an observer to its Competition Law and Policy Committee.

The move signifies international confirmation of Taiwan's efforts to ensure fair trade practices on the island and marks a another major breakthrough in Taiwan's international economic ties after it won the admittance to World Trade Organization, the FTC said in a press release.

Observer status at the Competition Law and Policy Committee will pay the way for the island's bids for similar status at other OECD committees and its ultimate full membership of the OECD, according to FTC officials.

The status will offer Taiwan a valuable glimpse into the process through which international fair trade criteria are made and therefore bring its own trade practices into harmony with international standards, the officials added.

Taiwan has been endeavoring to join the OECD Competition Law and Policy Committee since 1998, but its application had been rejected on political grounds until earlier this year and in July, Taiwan's request was primarily approved.

Taiwan has in fact been closely associated with the OECD in recent years and the FTC has co-sponsored international symposia on competition strategy three years in a row. Officials from Thailand, Vietnam, Malaysia, the Philippines, Indonesia, Singapore and Hong Kong were invited to exchange views in these symposia.
Taiwan's co-sponsorship has helped make the country a model of fair trading in Southeast Asia, the officials said.
The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) also lauded OECD observer status as a valuable chance for the island to tout its achievements in ensuring fair trade.
MOEA officials noted that mainland China was also granted observer status to the OECD's Science and Technology Committee that day.
Reports said Taiwan's and mainland China's applications were discussed Dec. 14 by the OECD Committee on Cooperative Relations of non-member countries.

The OECD, known as the "rich men's club," is an association of 30 nations mainly in Western Europe, North America and the Pacific working to promote the economic and social welfare of its members and coordinating efforts to aid developing countries. Of its 30 members, Japan and South Korea are the only full Asian members, while Hong Kong and Singapore are observers.
Taiwan will join the ranks of five other OECD observers, namely Russia, Argentine, Israel, Brazil and Lithuania.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Dec. 21, or the 7th day of the 11th month of Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1620: Pilgrims on the ship Mayflower come ashore at Plymouth, Massachusetts.
1804: Mohammed Ali Jinnah, founder and first governor-general of Pakistan, is born.
1817: Governor Lachlan Macquarie formally adopts the name "Australia" for the British colony located on the continent with the same present-day name.
1876: Joseph Stalin, Soviet leader, is born.
1898: Scientists Pierre Curie and Marie Curie discover radium.
1901: The "Ching Yi Pao," a newspaper founded by Liang Chi-chao, who together with Kang Yu-wei initiated a reform movement in 1898, ceases publishing after the 100th issue.
1930: Hwang Thu-sui, Taiwan's first sculptor, dies at the age of 35.
1935: Walt Disney's "Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs" premieres in the United States.
1940: F. Scott Fitzgerald, the American author who chronicled the Jazz Age in books such as "Tender is the Night" and "The Great Gatsby," dies at the age of 44.
1945: George Smith Patton Jr., the U.S. general who led the Third Army's sweep across France and into Germany during World War II, dies in a car crash at the age of 60.
1958: Charles de Gaulle is elected president of France after a new constitution is adopted, marking the beginning of the Fifth Republic.
1968: The Apollo 8 spacecraft, as a part of the United States' Apollo program to land men on the moon, is launched.
1971: Hsieh Kuan-sheng, president of the Judicial Yuan, dies in Taipei.
1971: Kurt Waldheim, an Austrian diplomat who later become president, is chosen to be the secretary-general of the United Nations on his birthday.
1972: East and West Germany sign a treaty ending more than two decades of enmity.
1975: The convention of the World Chinese Language Education Association opens in Taipei.
1975: Oil ministers from 12 countries are taken hostage after terrorists raid an OPEC meeting in Vienna, Austria.
1975: The Executive Yuan announces that Taiwan's economy grew by 2.8 percent in 1975, with a GNP of US$14.4 billion and per capita income of US$700.
1988: Soviet cosmonauts Musa Manarov and Vladimir Titov return to earth after a record 365 days in space.
1988: A Pan American jumbo jet crashes in the Scottish border town of Lockerbie, killing all 258 people on board.
1990: The building of the ROC Navy's first missile frigate begins at the Kaohsiung shipyard of the China Shipbuilding Corp.
1991: The ruling Kuomintang wins 71 percent of the vote and 254 of the 325 seats in elections for the Second National Assembly.
1995: Under an agreement signed between Israel and the PLO in September 1995, Israeli troops withdraw from Bethlehem, ending their 28 years of occupation.
1998: Beijing sentences mainland Chinese dissidents Xu Wenli and Wang Youcai to prison terms of more than 10 years each for trying to register the China Democracy Party.
1999: Taiwan is listed as the 12th-most important maritime country in the world for the year.
2000: Taiwan's non-profit Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) announces the development of a commercial software package, dubbed Fast Local Alignment for Gigabases (FLAG), allowing rapid genomic DNA searches and comparisons.
Confucius: "Uphold the cause of the just and put down every cause that is unjust, and the people will submit. But uphold the cause of the unjust and put down every cause that is just, then the people will not submit."

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC V.P. WARMLY RECEIVED IN GAMBIA
DOC.DATELINE: Banjul, Gambia, Dec. 20 (CNA) (By M.J. Tzou and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu, at the head of a special Republic of China diplomatic delegation, arrived in Banjul Thursday to a red-carpet welcome by the Gambian government.

Lu and her entourage, which includes Vice Foreign Affairs Minister Chiu Jong-nan, flew via Paris to Gambia to attend on behalf of President Chen Shui-bian the inauguration of reelected Gambian President Yahya Jammeh slated for Friday.
Gambian Vice President Isatou Njie-Saidy met Lu in person at the airport, where Lu and the ROC delegation were honored with a military salute.

Limousines escorted by a police motorcade then took them to their hotel from the airport. Huge crowds of local villagers and students welcomed the ROC guests by waving small flags and banners of the ROC on both sides of the road.

Lu met with President Jammeh in the evening to present him with a copy of her credentials regarding her current mission in Banjul. She said she is confident that bilateral relations between Gambia and Taiwan will be further bolstered under the leadership of Jammeh during his new term in office.

President Chen offered his personal felicitations to Jammeh on Oct. 22 upon the reelection of the Gambian president, who garnered an overwhelming 52.96 percent of the vote in the country's November presidential election.

Jammeh staged a coup as a military officer in 1994, overthrowing the corrupt Gambian regime of the time. He then ran in the 1997 presidential race in his capacity as a civilian and was elected with a large mandate from the voters.

To mark Jammeh's reelection and the unique way of voting in Gambia, namely the use of marbles as ballots, Lu presented Jammeh with a box of 1.5 million marbles as a gift. Lu said that Gambia's use of marbles to vote reflects "fairness and transparency" and democratic ways which she said should be emulated by other African countries.

During her stay in Gambia, Lu is expected to hold talks with Gambian leaders as well as inspect the ROC Embassy and agricultural projects being implemented under cooperation agreements between the two countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOUR TAIWANESE SUPERMARKETS IN ARGENTINA LOOTED, ONE OWNER INJURED
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Dec. 21 (CNA) (By Oscar Chung and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Four Taiwanese supermarkets in Argentina were looted during rioting that began Wednesday, and one of the supermarket owners reportedly suffered injuries to the ears, Republic of China diplomatic sources in Buenos Aires said Friday.
The four Taiwanese-owned supermarkets were reportedly stormed and emptied by looters and jobless rioters, whom Argentine riot police responded to with tear gas and rubber bullets.
One owner, whose Chinese name is Ho Er-hui, suffered cuts on his ears during the looting, part of the worst rioting in Argentina in a decade.

As of Thursday, the rioting had left at least 22 people dead and 200 injured in Argentina. President Fernando De la Rua resigned after two turbulent years in power, his government crumbling as demonstrators across Argentina battled police to protest the country's lengthy period of economic woes.

Officials from the Republic of China Representative Office in Buenos Aires said it will take time to determine whether other ROC citizens or expatriates have also been injured or have experienced damage to their property.

According to the ROC officials, Ho and his wife emigrated to Argentina some 20 years ago, taking over operations of the supermarket located in a neighborhood on the outskirts of Buenos Aires only three weeks ago. A crying Ho said that "all is gone" after the looters ransacked and cleared out the store.

Wang Yu-yuan, the ROC's top representative in Argentina, said he has already asked Argentina's chief police officer to provide stepped-up protection for ROC citizens and expatriates so as to prevent them from being further hurt during the unrest.

Meanwhile, reports from Taiwan's southern port city of Kaohsiung quoted officials from an association of Taiwan ocean-going squid fishing boats as saying that squid fishing operations near Argentine waters -- the largest squid fishing ground for Taiwan squid fishing boats -- remained unaffected by the unrest in the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE YUAN APPROVES WORKPLACE GENDER EQUALITY BILL

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan Friday morning approved the Workplace Gender Equality Bill after the third reading, with the new law effective as of March 8, 2002.

The new law states that employees should be treated equally in terms of salary, promotions and assignments. It also requires employers to take measures to eliminate sexual harassment in the workplace.

With the implementation of the new law, an employee, whether male or female, who has worked for an establishment with 30 employees or more for at least one year may request an unpaid leave of up to two years before his or her child turns three years old in order to take care of the child.
Employees with children under the age of three may also request a reduction in their work hours of up to one hour per day or adjustments to their work schedule.

Since 1990, women's organizations and other lobbying groups have dedicated much effort toward promoting gender equality in the workplace. The first version of the bill was drafted by the women's organization Awakening Foundation and other civil groups in 1990.

In the past decade, different versions of the draft by the authorities and the private sector were discussed by the Executive Yuan. The Cabinet passed a draft of the Workplace Gender Equality Bill in March 1999.

A spokeswoman of the Awakening Foundation said Friday that the new bill was approved after the relentless efforts of many people. Despite the fact that 45 percent of females in Taiwan are employed, women in Taiwan still face work-related inequalities, she added.

The spokeswoman stressed the importance of both employees and employers having a full understanding of the new bill. She also called for related government agencies to work out supplementary measures so that the new law can be effectively enforced.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES 3.8 PERCENT LOWER ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) closed 3.8 percent lower Friday due to heavy selling triggered mainly by a sharp decline in the new Taiwan dollar.
The TAIEX weighted price index, the market's key barometer, shed 199.86 points to close at 5,109.24.
The bourse opened at 5,209.27 and dropped to the day's low of 5,090.55 before gaining a little momentum by closing.

A total of 3.57 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$109.25 billion (US$3.13 billion), compared with the previous trading session, which saw 3.54 billion shares change hands on a market turnover of NT$101.18 billion (US$2.90 billion).

All eight major stock categories lost ground, with banking stocks dropping the most at 4.7 percent, followed by electrical and electronics shares at 3.9 percent, paper issues at 3.7 percent, construction shares at 3.4 percent, plastics and chemical shares at 3.2 percent, cement stocks at 3.1 percent, foodstuff issues at 3 percent and textile stocks at 2.6 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 512 to 88, with 47 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: FINANCE MINISTER CALLS ON STOCK EXCHANGE TO IMPROVE COMPETITIVENESS

TEXT.P: Finance Minister Yen Ching-chang said Friday that the Taiwan Stock Exchange Corp. (TSEC) should improve its competitiveness through further internationalization and liberalization and better auditing.

Speaking on the TSEC's 40th founding anniversary, Yen said that the stock market has effectively channeled savings into investment. Since its inception in 1961, he said, the TSEC has served as a window on Taiwan's economic development and has been the nucleus of the direct financing system.
The minister said that the TSEC, which started with only NT$10 million in capital investment and less than 100 staff, has developed into an efficient operation.

As of the end of November, the number of listed companies totaled 585 and the market value of listed shares amounted to NT$8.1 trillion, accounting for 80 percent of the nation's GDP (gross domestic product), he added.

The minister said that as Taiwan's stock market continues to expand, the various securities products provided by the TSEC include stocks, beneficiary certificates, warrants, Taiwan depository receipts and bonds.

There are around 1,000 brokers and their branches around the island and the number of investors is nearing 7 million, representing one-third of Taiwan's population. The daily average turnover value in the past 11 months was NT$68.8 billion, according to the minister.

Yen noted that the financial authorities are constantly reviewing the operations of the stock market. In the past four decades, the government has adopted a series of incentive measures to encourage more companies with good performance to apply for listing and to help the TSEC develop a wide variety of securities products.

The minister said that in order to improve their international competitiveness, stock markets all over the world are using new technologies to integrate their operations while also seeking international alliances.
The domestic stock market should also reinforce its structure and improve its services to meet the challenges ahead, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT VISITS STAR PITCHER

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian paid a personal visit Friday to former Seibu star pitcher Kuo Tai-yuan, who recently underwent surgery to have tumorous tissue removed from his liver.
Chen was making good on a promise he made in November to visit Kuo at home to offer his greetings to the pitcher who has made extraordinary contributions to Taiwan baseball.

Kuo, a native of Taiwan who retired from Japan's Seibu Lions professional baseball team in 1997, was diagnosed at the Taipei Veterans General Hospital in September this year and traveled to Japan to have the liver surgery.
Kuo was said to be pleased by Chen's visit and told the president that he is convalescing well.

Chen for his part said he admires Kuo for his outstanding performance over the years. The two men also exchanged views on ways to reinvigorate Taiwan baseball and improve its strength in international competition.

Chao Shih-chiang, president of the Naluwan Co. baseball agency and himself a former star player, accompanied Chen on the visit and said tongue in cheek that Kuo's speed of delivery has "much regressed" -- down from 150-odd kph to a "mere" 140 kph.
Chen also offered his respects to Kuo for his refusal to adopt Japanese citizenship, despite playing in that country for so many years.

Kuo, who used to be nicknamed the "Orient Express" for his pitching speed, returned to Taiwan with his wife and children in 1997 after retiring from Seibu Lions. His wife, Chang Chun-tsu, is a model-turned-actress.

Kuo, 40, joined the Seibu Lions in 1985 after representing Taiwan in many regional and international baseball contests. He played a leading role in helping Taiwan win a bronze medal at the 1984 Los Angeles Olympic Games.
During his nearly 13 years with Seibu, Kuo recorded 117 wins, 68 losses and 18 reliefs. During the period, Seibu won eight Pacific League championships.
Kuo set many outstanding records during his heyday, including pitching a no-hitter, no-run perfect game in 1985. He has won many awards, including a Pacific League MVP award in 1991.
He decided to retire because of his age and an old wound to his right hand, which had affected his performance in his last two seasons in Seibu.
Kuo earned more than 1 billion yen during his stint with Seibu Lions.

DOC.HEADLINE: JOB SEEKERS IN TAIWAN INTERESTED IN OPPORTUNITIES IN MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Most job seekers in Taiwan would be willing to accept company assignments in mainland China and some have great interest in opportunities across the Taiwan Strait, according to a survey conducted by 104 Job Bank.

The online recruiting service center recently conducted a survey among job seekers and executives of industrial companies in Taiwan, the results of which show that more job seekers are inclined to accept job assignments in mainland China, recognizing the fact that many Taiwanese companies have invested there.

The results indicate that companies involved in traditional manufacturing industries in general are keen to invest in the mainland, as are electronics and information-related industries that are looking to improve their competitiveness. The service sector may also increase its investment there once Taiwan joins the World Trade Organization (WTO) next month, according to the survey results.

Sixty percent of the job seekers who responded to the Job Bank survey said they would accept assignments in mainland China, while about 20 percent said that they are unsure and 17.2 percent said they would not work in the mainland.

Among those showing great interest in mainland job opportunities, many said they hope to improve their resumes with their "mainland experience," while others said they would expect to find job fulfillment and better chances of promotion.
