DOC.HEADLINE: ILAN DETENTION CENTER SENDS BACK 534 MAINLAND CHINESE ILLEGALS
DOC.DATELINE: Ilan, northeastern Taiwan, Dec. 21 (CNA) (By Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: A detention center in Ilan County for illegal immigrants from mainland China deported 534 inmates this year, an increase of 133 over the previous year, a spokesman for the center said Friday.
The spokesman added that the deportations took place in ten separate groups this year. Last year, the center departed nine batches totaling 401 people.

There are some 200 illegal immigrants detained at the center, the spokesman went on. He expressed hope that agencies on both sides of the Taiwan Strait concerned with cross-strait relations will consult as soon as possible to get all the detainees deported to the mainland by the end of this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA RULES ON AGRICULTURAL INVESTMENT IN MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: The domestic agriculture sector will be prohibited from investing in certain agricultural items in mainland China, a Ministry of Economic Affairs Task Force Committee decided Friday.

The task force committee made up of government officials, scholars and industry representatives and presided over by Vice Economics Minister Chen Ruey-long and Council of Agriculture Vice Chairman Lin Kuo-ching, decided to remove a screening process on 921 items of agricultural products on a list of 1,268 general items that can be produced in the mainland through investment from Taiwan, while 347 items were put on a list of items that cannot be produced there via Taiwan investment.

The prohibited items include hogs, chickens and pond-raised fish. Lin said the committee made its decision on the grounds that such products could be resold to Taiwan once the island enters the World Trade Organization (WTO), harming the domestic agricultural sector. Mainland China is already a full WTO member, while Taiwan will become a member next month.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO REGISTER NEGATIVE 1.96% GROWTH THIS YEAR: REPORT

TEXT.P: The Chung Hua Institution for Economic Research Friday revised downward its estimate for Taiwan's real economic growth rate this year from negative 1.76 percent to negative 1.96 percent.

The institute also said that the island's economy will begin to recover in the second quarter of next year and added that it is likely to register negative 0.21 percent growth in the first quarter and to grow 0.81 percent in the second quarter.

It further said that if all Asian countries devalue their currencies to cope with the devaluation of the yen, Taiwan's export competitiveness will decline and its economic growth rate next year might drop from an original estimate of 2.36 percent to a mere 1 percent.

The institute said that if the recovery of the global economy is slow next year and all Asian countries devalue their currencies, exports of products and labor from Taiwan will decrease by NT$15 billion each quarter next year, which will lead to a substantial decline in the island's real economic growth rate.

DOC.HEADLINE: 165 TRAVEL AGENCIES APPROVED TO OFFER SERVICES TO MAINLAND TOURISTS

TEXT.P: The Tourism Bureau under the control of the Ministry of Transportation and Communications has approved 165 local travel agencies to offer services to tourists from mainland China, a tourism official said Friday.
A total of 258 travel agencies have applied to operate mainland Chinese tourist business, the official added.
The bureau will accept an average of 1,437 mainland Chinese tourist entry applications for screening per day, excluding Saturdays and Sundays, the official went on.
Of 165 travel agencies approved, 103 belong to the Taipei Association of Travel Agents, 41 to the Taiwan Provincial Association of Travel Agents and 21 to the Kaohsiung Association of Travel Agents.

The 103 travel agents in Taipei can submit 891 mainland applications per day, while the Taiwan Provincial Association of Travel Agents can submit 359 and the Kaohsiung Association of Travel Agents can submit 187.
The official said the quotas allocated to each association will be readjusted every three months.
According to an estimate made by local travel agents, the first batch of mainland tourists will arrive in Taiwan Jan. 5 if applications are submitted Jan. 2.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP'S LEGISLATIVE ELECTION WIN VOTED TOP DOMESTIC NEWS STORY OF 2001

TEXT.P: The Dec. 1 legislative elections that made the ruling Democratic Progressive Party the largest party in the Legislative Yuan for the first time was voted the year's most important news story in Taiwan.
Taiwan's successful bid to join the World Trade Organization and become the trade regulatory body's 144th member beginning Jan. 1 ranked second on the list of the top 10 domestic news events of 2001.
The list was compiled by the Central News Agency after a poll of editors in chief and news department directors of the country's domestic news organizations.
Other headline news stories rounding out the top-10 list in the order of their importance are:

-- The unusual frequency and behavior of the typhoons that struck the island this year, particularly typhoons Toraji and Nari that led to serious flooding in northern Taiwan and the flooding of the Taipei Mass Rapid Transit system.
-- The revoking of former Republic of China President and former Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lee Teng-hui's party membership for publicly criticizing the KMT and stumping for a rival party.
-- The plunge in annual imports and exports partially due to a slump in the global economy, leading to a predicted negative annual economic growth and a record 5 percent unemployment rate.

-- The government's adoption of an "active opening, effective management" policy toward Taiwanese investments in mainland China after a presidential Economic Development Advisory Conference was held in August, replacing the previous administration's "no haste, be patient" policy.
-- The government's announcement Feb. 4 to resume construction on the island's Fourth Nuclear Power Plant, after it halted the project Oct. 27 last year.

-- The mainland Chinese government's refusal to allow former ROC Vice President Li Yuan-zu to attend the 2001 Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum informal leadership summit in Shanghai on behalf of ROC President Chen Shui-bian, triggering vehement protests from the ROC government.

-- The government's implementation of direct trade, postal and transportation links between Taiwan's outlying Kinmen and Matsu islands and designated ports in mainland China, leading to the first direct sailing from ROC-held territory to the mainland in five decades on Jan. 2.
-- The indictment of former Minister of Education Yung Chaur-shin and 32 others after a prosecutorial investigation into an alleged scandal involving the Jin-Wen Group.

DOC.HEADLINE: AGENCIES DISPUTE CREDIT FOR GAINING TAIWAN'S OECD OBSERVER STATUS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's acceptance into the Organization of Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) as an observer is a feather in the government's cap, but two official organizations are at loggerheads over who deserves the credit for the diplomatic success.

Huang Chung-le, chairman of the Fair Trade Commission (FTC) blamed the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) Friday for trying to steal the limelight by jumping the gun and releasing the news of Taiwan's acceptance in the OECD ahead of the FTC.

In a news conference initially called to announce Taiwan's observer status at the OECD's Competition Law and Policy Committee, Huang cried foul over the economics ministry's late Thursday night news release.

Huang said his commission learned Tuesday that Taiwan's request to be an observer was to be granted Thursday, and consulted with the economics ministry that day on how to break the news simultaneously.

At that time, Huang said, the economics ministry agreed to give the FTC all the credit for having secured the status, and that both agencies would organize their own news conference to announce the news the day after the OECD's approval -- Friday.
To the surprise of the FTC, Huang said, the economics ministry broke the news to local media Thursday night, forcing the FTC to issue a news release of its own two hours later.

He angrily pointed to Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Chen Ruey-long and Director-General of the Board of Foreign Trade Wu Wen-ya as the culprits behind the move to beat the FTC to the punch in spite of the understanding between the FTC and the economics ministry.

Chen, however, denied Friday afternoon that his ministry was trying to monopolize the credit, saying Taiwan's acceptance had been achieved by the coordinated efforts of many government agencies, including the foreign ministry, the economics ministry and the FTC.
Chen said he didn't understand why the FTC issued its statement two hours later than the economics ministry.

Huang said his committee began to work for acceptance in the OECD in 1995, and formally presented application forms on June 19 of this year. He also said he had traveled to Paris on Oct. 18 to brief the OECD about Taiwan's laws concerning fair trade.

The FTC chairman said he had kept the entire affair as low-key as possible to avoid any interference from mainland China. Huang said that he has tried to do the right thing as a government official, but could not stand idly by as another government body shamelessly tried to take credit for the work of others.
"They have gone too far in trying to upstage the FTC," Huang said.

The FTC kept mum about the process because mainland China was simultaneously trying to join the OECD Science and Technology Committee, and the FTC didn't want to draw Beijing's attention to Taiwan's application, Huang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINA'S WTO ENTRY VOTED TOP MAINLAND NEWS STORY OF 2001

TEXT.P: Mainland China's accession to the World Trade Organization was voted the year's most important news story about mainland China by news editors in Taiwan.
Meanwhile, Beijing's winning bid to host the 2008 Olympic Games ranked second on the list of the top 10 mainland Chinese news events of 2001.
The list was compiled by the Central News Agency after a poll of editors in chief and news department directors of the country's domestic news organizations.
Other headline news stories rounding out the top-10 list in the order of their importance are:

-- The mid-air collision incident between a U.S. surveillance aircraft and a mainland Chinese fighter jet that led to heightened tension between Beijing and Washington, which was eventually alleviated after the U.S. government said it was "sorry."
-- The hosting of the 2001 Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum ministerial meeting and informal leadership summit in Shanghai.

-- The demand of the Taiwan Affairs Office under the mainland Chinese State Council for Taiwan to accept the "one China" principle and implement direct trade, postal and transport links between Taiwan-proper and mainland China after the Republic of China government implemented such direct links between its outlying islands of Kinmen and Matsu and designated ports on the mainland.
-- The declaration by mainland Chinese Vice Premier Qian Qichen that Beijing can "wait patiently" if Taipei were to agree to resolve the Taiwan issue under the "one China" principle.

-- The announcement by mainland Chinese President and Communist Party of China (CPC) General Secretary Jiang Zemin at the CPC's 80th anniversary celebrations that the heads of private companies will be allowed to join the party.

-- The announcement by Jiang after a summit meeting with U.S. President George W. Bush that mainland China was willing to fight terrorism with the United States and develop constructive cooperative relations.
-- The ratification of plans to carry out major infrastructure projects including a Qinghai-Tibet railroad at a meeting of the mainland Chinese National People's Congress.

-- The mainland government's declaration that it was against U.S. development of a National Missile Defense system in the wake of a visit by U.S. Assistant Secretary of State James Kelly to Beijing to exchange views on the issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: EDITORS' NOTE: CNA WILL SUSPEND ITS CEP SERVICE ON DEC. 25,
BEIJING SHOULD ACCEPT NEW REALITIES IN CROSS-STRAIT TIES: MAC CHIEF
DOC.DATELINE: Hualien, eastern Taiwan, Dec. 21 (CNA) (By Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: Mainland China must adapt its views on cross-Taiwan Strait relations to the changing reality reflected in the new political landscape after the Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP) impressive gains in the Legislative Yuan, said Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen Friday.

Speaking at a year-end news conference in Hualien, Tsai that the results of the Dec. 1 legislative elections indicated that the people of Taiwan want to pursue a stable cross-strait relationship on the basis of internal stability.
After the elections, the ruling DPP had collected 87 seats in the 225-seat lawmaking body to replace the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) as the largest party in the legislature.
Tsai said that the general circumstances and political structure surrounding the development of cross-strait developments are undergoing a fundamental change in the wake of the elections.
DPP policy leans toward independence for Taiwan, while the KMT ultimately seeks unification between Taiwan and the mainland.
Tsai said that she hoped that Beijing leaders will understand the significance of the results of the elections and face the changes pragmatically.
The MAC chief called on Beijing leaders to handle the cross-strait issue with a broader mind and to endeavor together with Taipei to elevate bilateral relations to a new level.

She urged an early resumption of bilateral talks, noting that normal dialogues and negotiations, as well as formal interactions, are required for the development of genuine and stable cross-strait relations.
Reviewing the government's policy toward the mainland over the past year, Tsai said that the government has been taking positive steps to promote cross-strait relations.

She pointed out that the "positive opening, effective management" policy announced by President Chen Shui-bian recently reflected the conclusions reached through consensus at the cross-party Economic Development Advisory Conference this past summer.
Taiwan and mainland China's entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO) will also affect the development of cross-strait relations, Tsai said.

In the future, she said that cross-strait economic and trade activities are expected to move toward normalization under the framework of the WTO. Tsai said she expects that the two sides will engage in more interactions and communications within the WTO framework.

She said that she believes the WTO memberships will provide an important opportunity for the two sides to improve their relations and to help stabilize the peace and stability across the Taiwan Strait.
Next year will be important for the mainland as there will be a change of top leadership in Beijing, Tsai said, adding that a smooth transition of power would benefit both sides of the strait.

Talking about her recent visit to the United States, the MAC chairwoman said the government's policy to maintain peace and stability across the Taiwan Strait has been widely accepted by the United States.

She said that the Chen administration has maintained open communications with the U.S. government and Congress and added that she had exchanged views with U.S. officials, congressmen and think-tank researchers during the recent trip.

Tsai said that maintaining peace and stability across the Taiwan Strait and in the Asia-Pacific area is in line with the interests of the United States. The consistency of the U.S. long-term policy toward mainland China and Taiwan remains unchanged at present, she said.
The issue of the so-called "1992 consensus," which refers to the "one China" principle whereby both sides of the Strait are free to define "China," was not discussed in the United States, Tsai said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TERRORIST ATTACKS ON AMERICA VOTED TOP GLOBAL NEWS STORY OF 2001

TEXT.P: The Sept. 11 terrorist attacks on America that led to the death of thousands of people and triggered a U.S.-led war against terrorism was voted the year's most important international news story by news editors in Taiwan.
Meanwhile, Beijing's winning bid to host the 2008 Olympic Games ranked second on the list of the top 10 international news events of 2001.
The list was compiled by the Central News Agency after a poll of editors in chief and news department directors of the country's domestic news organizations.
Other headline news stories rounding out the top-10 list in the order of their importance are:

-- The mid-air collision incident between a U.S. surveillance aircraft and a mainland Chinese fighter jet that led to heightened tension between Beijing and Washington, which was eventually alleviated after the U.S. government said it was "sorry."
-- The mapping and publishing of the human genome.

-- The U.S.-led coalition attacks on the Taliban regime in Afghanistan that toppled the government that harbored Osama bin Laden, the prime suspect behind the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks on America who is still on the run.

-- The announcement by Advanced Cell Technology, a Massachusetts-based company, that it had successfully cloned the first human embryo, leading to both the U.S. and the British governments to declare that they will not allow the cloning of humans despite support for stem-cell medical research.

-- The agreement among the leaders of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) to establish within 10 years an ASEAN-mainland China free trade zone that would be the largest trade area in the world with a combined population of 1.7 billion people.
-- The ousting of Filipino President Joseph Estrada and Indonesian President Abdurrahman Wahid for alleged corruption.
-- The outbreak of isolated anthrax incidents in the United States, triggering widespread fear.
-- The continued deterioration of the troubled world economy after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, adversely affecting the global airline industry.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESENTS 1.5 MILLION MARBLES TO GAMBIAN AS GIFT
DOC.DATELINE: Banjul, Gambia, Dec. 20 (CNA) (By Tzou Ming-jhie and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu presented the newly re-elected president of Gambia, Yahya Jammeh, with 1.5 million marbles as an inauguration gift Thursday in the capital city of Banjul.
The marbles are used as ballots in Gambia, with each candidate having his own box. Voters drop marbles into the boxes of the candidates they favor.
The marbles, with special colors and sizes, are difficult to fake, and can be used in the next elections, Jammeh explained.

There are no invalid votes when marbles are used in place of ballots, and the possibility of election irregularities is minimized, Jammeh said, adding that this is the system that was used when he was re-elected president Oct. 22.
Lu lauded the ingenuity of the Gambian people in making the marble -- which is used by children in games, or as weapons by some adults -- into ballots for use in democratic elections.
She exchanged views on a broad range of issues with Jammeh and presented him with a letter from ROC Presdient Chen Shui-bian.

According to a news release issued by Lu's entourage, Presdient Chen sent his personal greetings to Jammeh, and looks forward to much close ties with the west African country under Jammeh's leadership.
After an evening reception, Lu attended a dinner party hosted by ROC ambassador Lin Chun-yi.

Speaking at the party, Lu said her first day in the country has shown her that the country deserves its nickname of "the smiling coast," because all the people she met, no matter whether they were government officials or ordinary people, were all smiling -- a sign of the nation's energy and vision.
Lu said the close ties between Taiwan and Gambia make their peoples feel like family despite the geographical distance between them.
Lu left Taipei Wednesday night for the Gambian capital of Banjul via Paris and arrived Thursday.
She will attend President Yahya Jammeh's Dec. 21 inauguration.

During her stay in Gambia, Lu is expected to hold talks with Gambian leaders as well as inspect the ROC Embassy and agricultural projects being implemented under cooperation agreements between the two countries, according to Lu's entourage.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO ALLOW PRIVATE PRODUCTION OF LIQUORS, TOBACCO PRODUCTS

TEXT.P: Private companies will be allowed to manufacture liquor products beginning Jan. 1 and tobacco products beginning 2004, the Ministry of Finance announced Friday.

According to the new measures, companies can apply to manufacture a limited amount of alcohol products including rice wine, cooking wine, beer and distilled liquors and market them at the same time that a new wine and tobacco law goes into effect next year.
The government has always held a monopoly over the manufacturing of liquor and tobacco products through the Taiwan Tobacco and Wine Monopoly Bureau.

Manufacturers will be limited to producing an annual quota of 60,000 liters of beer, 40,000 liters of fruit-fermented wines, 20,000 liters of grain-fermented alcohol, 20,000 liters of other fermented liquors, 6,000 liters of distilled liquors, 20,000 liters of rice wine, 30,000 liters of cooking wine, 6,000 liters of other alcohols, or a mixed percentage of the various kinds of alcohols.
Private companies will not be allowed to manufacture pure alcohol.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPORT ORDERS DECLINED BY 11% IN NOVEMBER

TEXT.P: The money value of Taiwan's orders for exports stood at US$1.17 million in November, which is 11.15 percent smaller than last November, according to statistics released by the Ministry of Economic Affairs Friday.
Meanwhile, the industry production index stood at 120.85 in November, or 6.77 points smaller than the corresponding month last year. That brought the whole year index down by 7.68 points thus far.

DOC.HEADLINE: REVISED LAW ALLOWS FOREIGN WORKERS TO WORK IN TAIWAN FOR SIX YEARS

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan approved an amendment to the Employment Services Act Friday allowing foreign workers to work in Taiwan up to six years.
At present, blue-collar foreign workers are allowed to work in Taiwan for only three years.

However, workers are required to leave Taiwan for 40 days after their three-year contracts expire and come back to work under a new three-year contract. The move is designed to prevent them from applying for immigration.
The amendment forbids employers from discriminating against foreign employees on the ground of their marital status.

Employers are also banned from employing foreign workers who have come to Taiwan to work for other employers. Offenders are liable to fines between NT$150,000 to NT$750,000 for the first offense. Jail terms of up to three years and fines of up to NT$1.2 million will be handed down to offenders for second offenses.

The amendment states that when recruiting new foreign workers, employers should not keep the identity cards, work permits and other documents of the applicants without their consent. They are also not allowed to ask the workers to engage in illegal work.
At present, employers are required to put deposits equivalent to two months' wages for a foreign worker at the Council for Labor Affairs. The amendment abolishes this requirement.
The Employment Services Act was first promulgated in 1992.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SEMICONDUCTOR GIANT FACES SANCTION FOR INVESTMENT IN MAINLAND

TEXT.P: Hou Hai Precision Industry is facing the possibility of being fined between NT$1 million to NT$5 million per day, if it is found to have invested in mainland China without getting Taiwan authorities' approval, Vice Minster of Economic Affairs Chen Ruey-long said Friday.
The fine will be imposed daily until the company falls in line with the government's rules, Chen said.

He made the remarks after news reports from Beijing said Thursday that the Taiwan-based company will pour US$1 billion into the construction of a science-based industrial park, named after its mainland Chinese subsidiary, Foxconn, in Beijing.
Chen said he has no knowledge whether Hou Hai will asked for the approval of the economics ministry for its Foxconn project; if not, it will face being fined until it withdraw its investment.
Hou Hai raised eyebrows of government officials earlier this month for allowing Chinese Communists to set up a party office in its mainland Chinese subsidiary.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Dec. 22, or the 8th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1895: Using his newly discovered X-ray technology, German physicist Wilhelm Konrad Roentgen photographs his wife's hand to reveal the bones beneath the skin.
1905: The Ching court signs a treaty with Japan in Peking regarding Manchurian affairs, following Japan's victory over Russia in the Russo-Japanese War.
1907: The Ching government sets up the Directorate General of Railways and appoints Liang Shih-yu as the director-general.
1909: Korean Prime Minister Yi Wanyong, who agreed to a merger of Korea with Japan, is badly injured by assassins. Japan took complete control of Korea less than a year later.
1915: China's Ministry of Education sets up a training center to teach the phonetic annotation of the Chinese alphabet.
1936: Noted Chinese writer Yu Ta-fu visits Taiwan
1936: Madame Chiang Kai-shek, accompanied by W. H. Donald and T.V. Soong (Sung Tzu-wen), fly to Xian.
1938: Japanese Prime Minister Prince Konoye lays down a three-point guiding principle for the settlement of the Sino-Japanese conflict and the establishment of a "New Order in East Asia."
1942: U.S. heavy bomber planes bomb Japanese-occupied Rangoon, Burma.
1945: General George Marshall arrives in Chungking as U.S. President Truman's special envoy.
1945: The foreign ministers of the United States, Britain, and the Soviet Union hold a meeting in Moscow.
1961: James Davis becomes the first American soldier to die in Vietnam since America's involvement began in the Southeast Asian country.
1965: President Chiang Kai-shek issues a decree convoking an extraordinary session of the National Assembly in Taipei on Feb. 1, 1966.
1968: North Korea releases 82 crewmen of the U.S. intelligence ship Pueblo at the truce village of Panmunjom, 11 months after their capture off the North Korean coast.
1971: Austrian envoy Kurt Waldheim becomes the secretary-general of the United Nations.
1972: The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with Australia and New Zealand.
1976: Adm. Soong Chang-chih, chief of the general staff, presents citations to outstanding cadres and political warfare personnel.
1989: Civil war in Romania ends the 24-year-long reign of terror by Nicolae Ceausescu, who flees Bucharest with his wife Elena. Both were later executed.
1990: Lech Walesa becomes Poland's first popularly elected president.
1991: Dissident mainland Chinese astrophysicist Fang Li-chih visits Taipei.
1996: Chiang Hsiao-yung, the third son of late President Chiang Ching-kuo, dies of cancer in Taipei at the age of 49.
1997: Hong Kong authorities decide to destroy all chickens imported from mainland China after three people die of what is thought to be a strain of flu carried by poultry.
1999: Nasir Ahmed Sooro, listed as the world's tallest (236.2 cm) person by the Guinness Book of World Records, meets with the local press as he starts his four-month visit to Taiwan.
2000: The Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) says the Republic of China will fully open its livestock products market in 2005.
Confucius lesson for the day: "Treat people with seriousness and they will respect you. Let them see that you honor your parents and your prince, and are considerate of the welfare of those under you, and the people will be loyal to you. Advance those who excel in anything and educate the ignorant, and the people will exert themselves."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Saturday are as follows:
The China Times:
Workplace equality bill passed; Both parents are allowed to take unpaid maternity leave to take care of children aged under 3.
The United Daily News:
Equal Protection Employment Act passed; Working mothers can apply for unpaid maternity leave of up to two yars.
The Liberty Times:
Workplace gender equality bill passed; Unpaid maternity leave can be as long as two years.
The Taiwan Daily:
Taiwan caucus is expected to be formed in U.S. Congress in January.
The Central Daily News:
Ending 11 long years of struggle, the Legislative Yuan finally passes the Equal Protection Employment Act.
The China Post:
New sexual equality law slated to become a reality next March.
The Taiwan News:
Legislative Yuan passes workplace equality bill; Law requires employers to eliminate sexual harassment on job.
The Taipei Times:
Women receive equal protection in the workplace.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC V.P. ATTENDS INAUGURATION OF GAMBIAN PRESIDENT
DOC.DATELINE: Banjul, Gambia, Dec. 21 (CNA) (By M. J. Tzou and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu, on behalf of President Chen Shui-bian, attended the inauguration of reelected Gambian President Yahya Jammeh Friday held at an open-air gymnasium in the Gambian capital of Banjul.
More than 20,000 people attended the inauguration, including several heads of state from neighboring African countries and many special envoys from other countries.

In his inaugural speech, Jammeh vowed to continue to promote constitutional democracy in Gambia, manage the nation based on the principles of justice, transparency and humanitarianism, and lead Gambia to become a modernized nation that respects the rule of law, religious freedom and human rights.

Jammeh at the ceremony also announced an amnesty for former President Dauda Jawara, who is now living in self-exile in Britain after his government was toppled in the early 1990s, allowing the former ruler to return to his home country freely. Jammeh's announcement was met with thunderous applause.

President Chen offered his personal felicitations to Jammeh on Oct. 22 upon the reelection of the Gambian Presdient, who garnered an overwhelming 52.96 percent of the vote in the country's November presidential election.

Political observers from the United States, Canada and Europe witnessed the presidential election, which was held in two rounds of voting, and judged it to be a fair election that was "transparent and clean."

Jammeh staged a coup as a military officer in 1994, overthrowing the corrupt Gambian regime of the time. He then ran in the 1997 presidential race in his capacity as a civilian and was elected with a large mandate from the voters.

To mark Jammeh's reelection and the unique way of voting in Gambia, namely the use of marbles as ballots, Lu presented Jammeh with a box of 1.5 million marbles as a gift. Lu said that Gambia's use of marbles to vote reflects "fairness and transparency" as well as democratic ways which she said should be emulated by other African countries.
Meanwhile, Lu said she will not visit Senegal after her three-day visit in Gambia as she is scheduled to head back to Taiwan where President Chen is waiting for her for other official business.
Lu said she hopes to visit Senegal as soon as possible and dismissed rumors that there might be changes in the formal diplomatic relationship between the Republic of China and Senegal.
Lu, at the head of a special ROC diplomatic delegation, flew via Paris into Gambia Thursday, receiving a red-carpet welcome by the Gambian government upon arrival.

She and her entourage, which includes Vice Foreign Affairs Minister Chiu Jong-nan, are scheduled to leave Gambia Saturday for Taiwan, making a one-day stopover in Vienna and a transit stop at the Paris international airport enroute.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWANESE TEEN GOLFER WINS SINGAPORE JUNIOR CHAMPIONSHIPS
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, Dec. 22 (CNA) (By Sherman Wu and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: Thirteen-year-old Taiwanese golfer Tseng Ya-ni won the girls' division of the Singapore Island Country Club Junior Championships on Friday with a score of 228 over three rounds, five strokes ahead of the second-place finisher from Thailand.

An up-and-coming handicap eight player who won this year's Asia Pacific Junior Championships for her age group and who placed fifth at the San Diego Junior World Championships, Tseng carded a final-day score of five-over-par 77 and a 12-over-par overall score to win the title in the Girls' B Division for players aged 11 to 13.

On the par-five 11th hole in the opening round, Tseng delivered a 260-meter drive -- a respectable distance for a player in her age group, considering that she stands at only 162 centimeters tall and weighs 54 kilograms.

Tseng also wowed the crowd in the opening round by hitting a one-under-par 71 on the hilly golf course to lead the entire field of 150 men and women players at the Singapore Island Country Club invitational tournament by nine strokes.
However, a triple bogey on the sixth hole on her second day -- plus three birdies, four bogeys and two double bogeys -- set her back at 80 strokes for a two-round total of seven-over-par 151.
Tournament organizers at the San Diego Junior World Championships compared her swing to that of Tiger Woods, noting that the two share a similar style.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP CHAIRMAN LEAVES FOR U.S. VIA SOUTHEAST ASIA FOR PRIVATE TRIP

TEXT.P: People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong and his wife Chen Wan-shui left Taipei Saturday bound for San Francisco via Southeast Asia for a two-week private trip.
The main purpose of the trip is for a family reunion during the Christmas holiday season. Soong's son and grandchild live in San Francisco.

The PFP, founded by Soong last year, performed well in the Dec. 1 legislative elections, collecting 46 seats in the 225-seat Legislative Yuan, behind only the Democratic Progressive Party's 87 seats and the Kuomintang's 68 seats.
Despite Soong's absence, the PFP's reform plan and the transfer of the party's headquarters will proceed as scheduled under the direction of PFP Vice Chairman Chang Chao-hsiung.

DOC.HEADLINE: PUBLIC LEAST SATISFIED WITH PRESIDENT'S ECONOMIC PERFORMANCE: POLL

TEXT.P: The public is most satisfied with President Chen Shui-bian's dynamism and his crusade to eliminate criminal interests in politics and least satisfied with his performance on economic issues, according to an opinion poll released Saturday.

The telephone survey, conducted by Shih Hsin University on adults aged 20 or over and residing in one of the 23 cities and counties in the Taiwan area, sought to measure how the public rates Chen's first one-and-a-half years in office as well as the popularity of various Cabinet officials.

It was the fourth in a series of surveys by the university that includes opinion polls taken after Chen's first 100 days in office, after the conclusion of the Fourth Nuclear Power Plant incident that ended in an embarrassing about-face after the Cabinet's unilateral policy decision to scrap the project without first consulting the Legislative Yuan, and after the president's first year in office.

Of the 1,078 respondents in the most recent poll, 43.79 percent said that they are satisfied or very satisfied with Chen's on-the-job performance, indicating a gradual increase in his approval rating after hitting its lowest point at 32.8 percent following the Fourth Nuclear Power Plant incident which ended February this year.

Meanwhile, 46.48 percent of the respondents said that they are dissatisfied or very dissatisfied with the president's performance, citing the lack of concrete achievements and his failure to make good on certain campaign promises.
On a scale of zero to 100, with 100 being the best possible score, the respondents gave Chen an average of 63.41 points for his perceived performance.

The respondents gave Vice President Annette Lu a score of 58.46. Only 28.91 percent of the respondents said that they are satisfied or very satisfied with Lu's performance, while 44.35 percent of those polled said that they are dissatisfied or very dissatisfied with her performance.

Compared to the previous administration, 40.17 percent of the respondents said that they believe the current administration's performance is worse. Only 27.36 percent said that they think Chen's administration has been performing better than the previous administration.

The survey also noted that 82.96 percent of the respondents who said that they are members of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and 86.66 percent of those who are members of the Taiwan Solidarity Union expressed approval for Chen's performance, while only 18.81 percent of the respondents who are opposition Kuomintang members and 14.07 percent of those who are opposition People First Party members expressed approval.
None of the respondents who are opposition New Party members said that they are satisfied with the president's performance.
The margin of error for the survey was given to be plus or minus three percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: PUBLIC MOST SATISFIED WITH JUSTICE MINISTER'S PERFORMANCE: POLL

TEXT.P: The public is most satisfied with Minister of Justice Chen Ding-nan's performance and least satisfied with Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Hsin-yi's performance among all the Cabinet members, according to an opinion poll released Saturday.
Conducted by Shih Hsin University, the telephone survey sought to measure how the public rates the popularity of the various Cabinet officials.

The 1,078 respondents, aged 20 or above and residing in one of the 23 cities and counties in the Taiwan area, gave Chen an average score of 73.44 on a scale of zero to 100, with 100 being the best possible score.

Environmental Protection Administrator Hau Lung-bin received an average score of 69.46, making him the second-most popular Cabinet member. Minister of Education Ovid Tzeng ranked third with an average score of 65.94.

Premier Chang Chun-hsiung received an average score of 60. Of all the respondents, 41.84 percent said that they are satisfied with his performance, while 43.97 percent said that they are dissatisfied.
The margin of error for the survey was given to be plus or minus three percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWYER FOR CANADIAN FALUN GONG EXPLAINS LAWSUIT AGAINST DAILY

TEXT.P: Civil rights lawyer Rocco Galati said Friday that Canadian Falun Gong practitioners had been "very patient" before suing the Sing Tao Daily newspaper for libel, slander, negligence and incitement of hatred.
More than 150 Falun Gong practitioners filed a lawsuit Dec. 19 at the Province of Ontario's Supreme Court against the mass-circulation Chinese-language newspaper.
The main piece of evidence the plaintiffs presented to the court was a full-page spread from the Sept. 20 edition of the Sing Tao Daily entitled "Radical Religious Advocate Destroying the World."

The page carried photographs and commentary placing Falun Gong alongside such reportedly violent and doomsday religious cults as that of Aum Shinrikyo which released poison gas in a Tokyo subway several years ago, as well as comparing it to the terrorists who carried out the Sept. 11 attacks in the United States.

Shortly after the printing of the articles and photos, Falun Gong practitioners sent two separate letters to the Sing Tao Daily to complain about the slanderous reports. They later hired Galati to send another letter in October, but they said the daily failed on each occasion to respond satisfactorily.

As Canadian law regarding slander allows only a period of three months for the filing of a lawsuit from the date of the alleged infraction, the practitioners decided to file their suit Dec. 19, one day before the deadline in this case.
Galati told the press in Toronto Friday that the practitioners had been very patient and had given the Sing Tao Daily every opportunity to resolve the issue prior to filing the suit.

The Statement of Claim filed with the court states that the daily, "in publishing the expose, did engage in inciting hatred against an identifiable religious (spiritual) group which is contrary to the Criminal Code of Canada," and that the defendants "are parties and coconspirators in these hate crimes and crimes against humanity for which civil liabilities arise."

The 156 plaintiffs, including three from Hong Kong who had a photo of them meditating carried on the controversial page admitted as evidence, are each demanding general damage amounting to C$50,000, punitive damages amounting to C$20,000, a published front-page apology and retraction, and an injunction restraining the defendants from publishing any article about Falun Gong except the said apology.

Falun Gong was very popular in mainland China before 1999 when the Communist regime banned the movement and launched an all-out propaganda campaign and persecution against the spiritual and health movement allegedly due to fears that the number of practitioners had grown to outnumber the number of Chinese Communist Party (CCP) members.
Galati said Falun Gong is practiced in at least 53 countries around the world and that "only in China is it being targeted with persecution and propaganda."

"The entire world has condemned this persecution. The U.S. Congress and the European Parliament have passed resolutions (condemning the persecution). For the Sing Tao to stand on the side of this persecution is unacceptable," he added.

The filing of the lawsuit in Toronto came only nine days after the Superior Court of Quebec issued a court order that Les Presses Chinoises, a Chinese-language newspaper in Montreal, immediately stop publishing and circulating articles slanderous to Falun Gong.

DOC.HEADLINE: SCHOLARS NOTE POLARIZED RESULTS OF SURVEY ON PRESIDENT'S PERFORMANCE

TEXT.P: Local scholars said Saturday that a recent survey on President Chen Shui-bian's popularity indicates that public opinion is polarized along the lines of geography, party affiliation and ethnic background.

The telephone survey, conducted by Shih Hsin University on adults aged 20 or over and residing in one of the 23 cities and counties in the Taiwan area, sought to measure how the public rates Chen's first one-and-a-half years in office as well as the popularity of various Cabinet officials.

Soochow University political science professor Sheng Chih-jen said at a seminar that he is concerned by signs that the public's degree of support for Chen does not fluctuate with administrative successes or setbacks but rather remains divided over northern Taiwan-versus-southern Taiwan, pan-blue opposition-versus-pan-green parties, and Taiwan-born-versus-mainland-born differences.

Sheng added that the public appears to go by personal preferences instead of actual policy evaluations when rallying behind political figures, citing as an example the fact that Minister of the Interior Chang Po-ya received a relatively high popularity score of 64.86 on a zero-to-100 scale even as the survey respondents said they have the least understanding of her ministry's policies.

Similarly, Wu Tung-yeh, director of the American and European Institute at the National Chengchi University's Institute of International Relations, said that although the survey respondents expressed dissatisfaction with the president's and the Cabinet's economic performance, this attitude was not reflected in the outcome of the Dec. 1 legislative, county chief and mayoral elections that made Chen's party the largest party in the Legislative Yuan for the first time.

Tunghai University political science professor Fu Heng-teh said that the public's disapproval of Chen's economic performance indicates the need for a new Cabinet that is strong in financial and economic expertise.

Of the 1,078 survey respondents, 43.79 percent said that they are satisfied or very satisfied with Chen's on-the-job performance, while 46.48 percent said that they are dissatisfied or very dissatisfied, citing Chen's lack of concrete achievements and his failure to make good on certain campaign promises.
According to the survey, the public is most satisfied with Chen's dynamism and his crusade to eliminate criminal interests in politics and least satisfied with his performance on economic issues.

The survey also noted that 82.96 percent of the respondents who said that they are members of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and 86.66 percent of those who are members of the Taiwan Solidarity Union expressed approval for Chen's performance, while only 18.81 percent of the respondents who are opposition Kuomintang members and 14.07 percent of those who are opposition People First Party members expressed approval.
None of the respondents who are opposition New Party members said that they are satisfied with the president's performance.
The margin of error for the survey was given to be plus or minus three percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORKPLACE EQUALITY LAW A HARD FOUGHT VICTORY FOR WOMEN'S RIGHTS (I)

TEXT.P: "The legislation has finally arrived," said lawyer You Mei-nu after the president of the Legislative Yuan struck his mallet Friday confirming the passage of the Workplace Gender Equality Bill upon the third reading.

"It has been much harder than having a baby," said You, who was one of the several young but determined women attorneys-at-law who more than 10 years ago began to fight for working women's rights. You is now middle-aged and has a couple of children.

Since 1990, women's activist organizations and other lobbying groups have dedicated much effort toward promoting gender equality in the workplace on the grounds that despite the fact that 45 percent of females in Taiwan are employed, women in Taiwan still face work-related inequalities.
The public hearing for the first version of the bill, authored by four women lawyers, namely You Mei-nu, Tu Hsiu-jui, Chen Mei-ling and Pan Cheng-fen, was held at the Legislative Yuan in March 1989.

You, who with her friends grouped together to form the women's organization Awakening Foundation, said the passage of the new bill is a hard fought victory following the relentless efforts of many people over the past 13 years.

Foundation members were furious over Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall's mass dismissal in August 1987 of 57 female employees who were either over 30 years old or pregnant, an incident prompting the group of women lawyers to author a draft bill of equal opportunities and rights in October of the same year.
Over the past 12 years, although different versions of the draft by authorities and the private sector were discussed by the Executive Yuan, no concrete progress was made until recently.

To strengthen their appeal, members of Taipei women's organizations jointly launched a hell-raising demonstration in 1996 by marching hand-in-hand toward the Presidential Office, with female sanitary pads stuck to their heads. The marching "Kotex protesters" nearly scared to death the male police forces guarding the office.

According to You, Chen Shui-bian, then a lawyer-turned-legislator from the Democratic Progressive Party, contacted the women's organizations and offered his idea that an anti sexual harassment article be included in the bill, and it was.

The new law states that employees should be treated equally in terms of salary, promotions and assignments. It also requires employers to take measures to eliminate sexual harassment in the workplace.

With the implementation of the new law, an employee, whether male or female, who has worked for an establishment with 30 employees or more for at least one year may request an unpaid leave of up to two years before his or her child turns three years old in order to take care of the child.

Employees with children under the age of three may also request a reduction in their work hours of up to one hour per day or adjustments to their work schedule, according to the law. (to be continued...)

DOC.HEADLINE: WORKPLACE EQUALITY (II)

TEXT.P: Lai You-mei, chairwoman of the Awakening Foundation, welcomed the passage of the law, but added that the "challenges are just beginning."

The arrival of the law is just a reflection of the constitutional protection of equal rights. How to enable employers and employees to understand the power of the law and how to have it fully materialized are big challenges, Lai pointed out.

While applauding the passage of the bill into law, women's activist organizations said they think there are still some flaws, namely that only employees of establishments with 30 employees or more are qualified to request unpaid leave to care for their children under the age of 3 -- a regulation preventing many young parents who work for smaller enterprises from enjoying the same right.

Also, the women's activists said the law, scheduled to take effect March 8, 2002, does not provide a sufficient channel of complaint to those who feel they have been discriminated against nor does it provide for a proper supervisory mechanism to deal with those who fail to observe the law.
Last year, 841,000 women in Taiwan quit their jobs because of giving birth, according to a survey compiled by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).
In Taiwan, about one out of every five mothers quits work after giving birth for the first time.

The DGBAS also found that 50.3 percent of new mothers resumed their jobs after giving birth in 2000, marking the highest such percentage in recent years. It takes mothers an average of six years to return to the work place after giving birth, according to the survey.

The new law was met with mixed reactions from the industrial and business sector. Some corporate owners said that from now on, they will view male employees as more favorable than female ones as the new law will raise their overhead costs for employing females.

A woman clerk at a local bank surnamed Chen said she is worried that the new law allowing her to take up to two years' of leave to care for a child may lead to her being put at the top of a layoff list against a backdrop of the growing number of mergers and layoffs among banks.
"The chances are that when I returned to the bank after two years, I would find that I had been replaced," she noted.
Fortunately, some corporations in Taiwan have benefits that are better than those provided for in the new law.
Accton Technology, whose headquarters is located in the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park, has been known for its good treatment of female employees.

With the corporate motto of "we provide not just better benefits, we also provide stability, care and challenges," Accton is one of the very few companies in Taiwan that offers a NT$3,000 salary raise for employees who get married and also has two daycare centers located in the company to give employees peace of mind while working.
All female Accton employees are also entitled to a 10-month maternity leave each time they give birth, with the company paying 70 percent of the monthly salary during the leave.

Chang Kung Memorial Hospital in Kaohsiung, financed by the Formosa Plastics Group, is another example. The hospital has established a daycare center which is open to all the hospital's workers. Employees with children between one month old and six years old can bring their children to the center during their work time.
Taiwan IMB has for a long time allowed its female employees to take unpaid one-year maternity leaves, with the option of extending the period of leave to two years upon request.
HP Taiwan, meanwhile, allows its female employees to adjust their work schedules to cope with the demands of motherhood.

DOC.HEADLINE: ALISHAN FOREST RAILWAY RESUMES SERVICE
DOC.DATELINE: Chiayi, southern Taiwan, Dec. 22 (CNA) (By Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: The Alishan forest railway in Chiayi County, which was seriously damaged when Typhoon Nari swept the island in mid-September, resumed service Saturday.
In order to ensure restoration of the railway's normal operation before the end of the year, the Chiayi forest administration stepped up reconstruction efforts over the past three months.
A series of celebration activities were held to mark the resumption of the forest railway service and the 90th anniversary of the railway's inauguration.
Council of Agriculture Secretary-General Huang Chin-jung and other central and local government officials were invited to attend the celebration activities.

Alishan is the most famous scenic area close to Yushan National Park. Scenic areas there include Wufeng Memorial Park, Fenchi Lake and Juili. From these places, tourists can view the sunrise, a sea of clouds, monkey-shaped stones and divine trees.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN MOURNS PASSING OF FAMED WRITER

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian offered his condolences in person Saturday to the family of the late famed writer Lin Hai-yin, who died of illness in hospital Dec. 1 at the age of 83.

A memorial service was held at the Taiwan Cement Building Saturday morning with dozens of big names from Taiwan's literary circles attending to commerorate Lin, a writer-editor-publisher. The living room of Lin and her husband had been known as a "rendezvous point which most of time housed half of Taiwan's literary elite."

English literature professor Chi Pang-yuan, one of Lin's best friends, said during the service that Lin, with her natural talent and inherent good nature, was the luckiest and most blessed person she has ever known. Chi translated Lin's masterpieces, including the short stories "Memory of Peking" and "Gold Carp's Pleated Skirt" into English for publication in the United States.
"Memory of Peking," a story about life in Peking through the eyes of a young woman -- Lin herself -- was made into a movie by the Shanghai Motion Picture Co. in 1982.
Lin was born in the Japanese city of Osaka to a Taiwanese-Hakka father and a Taipei mother. She moved to Beijing with her parents during her formative years and lived there until the age of 25.

Lin and her writer husband Hsia Cheng-ying (who later became famous as the columnist Ho Fan) moved to Taiwan from Beijing in 1950 and opened the Pure Literature Publishing House, which discovered and nurtured many up-and-coming writers who later gained fame in Taiwan's literary circles.

DOC.DATELINE: Ilan, northeastern Taiwan, Dec. 23 (CNA) (By Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: A moderate earthquake measuring magnitude 5.7 on the Richter scale struck northeastern Taiwan Sunday morning, seismologists of the Central Weather Bureau said.
The temblor hit 114.9 kilometers southeastern of Suao, Ilan County, at a depth of 31.5 kilometers at 5:40 a.m. No casualties were reported.
The earthquake, which was not apparently felt elsewhere around the island, had an intensity of 2.0 in Ilan City and an intensity of 1.0 in Taipei County.

DOC.HEADLINE: DERAILMENT MARS REOPENING AND CELEBRATIONS FOR ALISHAN LINE

TEXT.P: A train derailed early Sunday on a section of the Alishan forest railway which had just been reopened after a three-month closure to repair damage caused by Typhoon Nari in September. Eight passengers were slightly injured in the incident.
The railway, which makes a steep climb up Ali Mountain and is popular with tourists, had resumed operations only the day before.
Chung Shui-lin, chief of the Chiayi forest administration, which operates the railway, said the derailment took place on a side route from the Alishan main railway station to Chushan.

About 400 passengers had boarded the train that left at 5:20 a.m. to make the journey to Chushan to view the sunrise. Part of the train left the tracks about 10 minutes after it pulled away from the station.

Passengers said they heard a loud grating sound as the train came to an abrupt stop. The first three carriages were left tilted at a nearly 45-degree angle. Passengers fearing that the entire train would come off the tracks jumped from some of the carriages.

After the incident, some of the passengers braved the cold -- minus 1.9 Celsius -- and continued to Chushan on foot; the others were taken back to Alishan by an eight-car service train which arrived about half-an-hour later, Chung said.
The injured passengers were treated in an Alishan clinic.
Three trains normally make morning runs on every holiday to Chushan. The train that derailed was the first run Sunday and the two other trains were canceled after the accident.
The disruption of railway services since the summer typhoon has dealt a serious blow to the economies of numerous hotels and restaurants on Alishan, a famous mountain resort.

The Chiayi forest administration had hoped to resume services on the 71.4 kilometer railway Saturday to coincide with the 90th anniversary of the railway's opening, but a collapse of the bed of a section Dec. 12 ended the possibility that the entire line could be reopened as planned.
However, a celebration marking the anniversary was held Saturday and services were resumed for the short run from Chiayi to Fenchi Lake.

The Chiayi forest administration brought out a 76-year-old steam locomotive to shuttle passengers for free on refurbished carriages between Peimen Station in Chiayi, the start of the route, and the next station of Chuchi as part of the celebration.

Passengers, nostalgic for the time when the puffing train was the only way to get to the top of Alishan, except by hiking, scrambled to take pictures of the vintage locomotive which, if pressed into service, could still make the trip up the 2,200 meter Alishan.

The refurbished and colorful train has only 10 seats in each carriage and comes equipped with karaoke facilities and closed-circuit television. Passengers wishing to make the full trip to Alishan -- with a modern locomotive -- pay around NT$1,000 one way.
A series of other celebration activities were held to mark the resumption of the forest railway service and the 90th anniversary of the railway's inauguration Saturday.
Council of Agriculture Secretary-General Huang Chin-jung and other central and local government officials attended the celebration activities.
The celebration drew some 3,000 visitors to Alishan, which has seen visitor numbers dwindle since the destructive typhoon last summer.

Alishan is the most famous scenic area close to Yushan National Park. Scenic areas there include Wufeng Memorial Park, Fenchi Lake and Juili. From these places, tourists can view the sunrise -- a sea of clouds -- monkey-shaped stones and old-growth trees.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION LEGISLATOR VOWS TO CUT 'UNREASONABLE ITEMS ' FROM BUDGET

TEXT.P: Proposed cuts in the Central Government's annual budget for next year are not deep enough and the People First Party (PFP) will have no reservation about cutting "unreasonable items," a PFP legislator said Sunday.

PFP legislator Liu Wen-hsiung said the overall review has focused on budgets for various government agencies, which account for between 75 percent and 80 percent of the total annual budget, which amounts to about NT$1.2 trillion (US$34.48 billion).

Liu said that listening to discussions over the last several weeks, he is concerned that the various agencies are not prepared to cut enough from their proposed budgets. Aside from the possibility that certain parts of the proposals may not conform to the law or that sections could overlap between agencies, the budgets are still too fat, he said.
The proposed cuts are between 0.2 percent and 0.5 percent, smaller than previous budget cuts over the past 10 years.

Liu said the average ratio of cuts in budgets was around 1.8 percent over the past 10 years, adding that the lowest rate was still 0.93 percent for the 2000 budget. This was the year after the disastrous earthquake on Sept. 21, 1999 which claimed 2,400 lives and caused widespread damage, particularly in central Taiwan.

In comparison, he noted that the proposed ratio of budget cuts in 12 committees screening the budgets this month has been between 0.2 percent and 0.5 percent, which is a significant drop from past cuts.

Liu said since the job market and economic growth rate in Taiwan next year are not expected to be good, if the budget cuts are so small then the financial situation can only worsen, particularly given that next year might be a lean year for government revenue.
He said if the trend continues, the result may be an incompetent opposition and an arrogant ruling party, and the people will be the ones to suffer.
He also said that the PFP, mandated by the people to monitor the government's expenditures, will cut "unreasonable items" from the budget after consultations with the ruling party.

Tsai Huang-liang, DPP party whip in the legislature, said that the ruling party will consult with the opposition parties in floor meetings, adding that the review of the budget should be pragmatic, and that one should not dogmatically follow the ratio of budget cuts in previous years as the benchmark for the upcoming year.

Noting that this is the first time that legislators have reviewed a budget after legislative elections, Tsai said they seem "listless" in reviewing the budget. He said that the legislators should show self-discipline and do their utmost to carefully review the budget.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT EXCHANGES TO CONTINUE: OUTGOING GIO OFFICIAL IN HK
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Dec. 23 (CNA) (By Lin Li-ming and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The outgoing chief of the Government Information Office's representative office in Hong Kong said she sees no big problem for continued cross-strait cooperation, although it will be more difficult for both sides to engage in political dialogues.
Chiang Su-hui, director of the Kwang Hwa Information and Cultural Center in Hong Kong, made the remarks when she was interviewed on cable TV in the former British colony Saturday.

Chiang said that she was optimistic about economic exchanges between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, noting that a lot of Taiwan businessmen have traveled to the mainland and that economic exchanges and cooperation will not be affected.

But she also said that the situation of Taiwan and Hong Kong is different, and that the "one country, two systems" formula will not apply to Taiwan, stressing that Beijing doesn't have to apply that formula for Taiwan.
She also said that mainland officials often take a tough stance in addressing issues concerning Taiwan, further alienating Taiwan people.
On the political dialogues, Chiang said that unless Taiwan accepts the "one China" principle cherished by the mainland, it will be difficult for both sides to engage in political dialogue.
Chiang will be leaving her post at the end of the year. Ping Lu, a noted columnist and novelist, will take over Jan. 1, 2002.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER ROC PRESIDENT'S VISIT TO JAPAN SAID A HEADACHE
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Dec. 23 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Ed Chen)

TEXT.P: Former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui's visit to Japan was a headache for the Japanese government, the Nihon Keizai newspaper quoted Foreign Minister Yukiko Tanaka as saying Sunday.

Nihon Keizai quoted pro-Beijing Foreign Minister Tanaka as reporting that Lee was indeed in need of regular medical attentions, and he still had some political influence -- although diminished -- but his visit to Japan was still something of a headache.

Tanaka spoke by telephone with Chinese Foreign Minister Tang Jiaxuan last May shortly after she assumed the foreign minister post and told him that Japan would not grant a visa for the former ROC president if he applies again.
Tanaka is the daughter of former Japan Prime Minister Kakuei Tanaka who established diplomatic relations with Beijing in 1972.
Yukiko's public remarks have drawn fierce criticism from the ruling Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) and the public.

Prime Minister Junichiro Kozumi said that Japan issued a visa for the former ROC president completely based on the independent judgment of the nation's interests, adding that the issue was discussed during the interpellation session of the parliament on May 9.
If the former ROC president applies for a visa again, the government's decision will be made after comprehensive consideration, Kozumi said.

However, an official from the Japanese Ministry of Foreign Affairs said Lee's visit to Japan was for medical treatment and if he wishes to apply again for the same purpose, Japan has no reason to refuse his visa application.

Former Japanese Foreign Minister Yohei Kono was against granting the former ROC president another visa so as not to offend Beijing. Under pressure from politicians and the media, former Japanese Prime Minister Yoshiro Mori eventually granted a visa for the former ROC head of state in April.
Diplomatic sources said said that as Lee is now a civilian like the general public, and it would be difficult for Japan to deny him a visa.

DOC.TEXT:

1921: Mahatma Gandhi is sworn in as chairman of India's Congress (I) Party, on a platform of non-cooperation.
1937: Japanese forces capture Hangchow in eastern China.
1943: President Roosevelt appoints Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower as supreme commander of the Allied Expeditionary Force preparing for the invasion of France.
1945: Pope Pius XII promotes Republic of China Bishop Tien Keng-hsin of Chingtao to cardinal, making him the first cardinal in East Asia.
1951: Libya declares independence.
1967: Communist China conducts its seventh nuclear test, detonating a small device in northeastern China.
1976: Takeo Fukuda organizes a new Japanese Cabinet.
1978: Local movie and television actor Ku Ming-lun jumps to his death from the top of a building.
1983: The Taipei City Fine Arts Museum formally opens to the public.
1992: President George Bush pardons former U.S. Defense Secretary Casper Weinberger and five other Reagan aides involved in the Iran-Contra affair.

1999: Gen. Joao Batista Figueiredo, the Brazilian military ruler who ended 20 years of military government by restoring civilian rule in 1985, dies at the age of 81.

He should be diligent in virtue and learning in order to profit from their lessons and example. In this way, he may become a man of real culture."

1936: Chang Hsueh-liang accompanies Republic of China Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek and Madame Chiang to Loyang, en route to Nanking, after mutinous warlords kidnapped Chiang and held him for 12 days.

1973: The 49-member Taipei City Council is sworn in. The council elects T.S. Lin as its speaker and Clement C.P. Chang as its deputy speaker.

DOC.HEADLINE: SMUGGLERS OF AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTS COULD FACE HEAVIER PENALTIES

TEXT.P: Those caught smuggling agricultural products into or out of Taiwan could face stiffer penalties in the future if an amendment approved Monday by the Legislative Yuan's Judicial Committee is passed into law.

The judicial committee approved an amendment to the Smuggling Control and Elimination Act compiled by the Executive Yuan to increase the maximum fine on agricultural product smugglers from the current level of NT$150,000 (US$4,348) to NT$3 million (US$87,000) and raise the maximum prison sentence from the present three years to five years.

The approved amendment, aimed at protecting Taiwan's agricultural sector, would also increase the maximum fine for repeat offenders from the current level of NT$300,000 (US$8,700) to NT$7 million (US$203,000) if passed into law.
The amendment also changes the wording of the current law from "convicted violators could also be fined in addition to receiving prison terms" to "imprisonment and fines for convicted violators."

The Executive Yuan recommended the amendment in a move to substantiate the conclusions reached in consensus by the presidential Economic Development Advisory Conference (EDAC) held in August to prevent smuggling from further undermining Taiwan's agricultural sector and its development.

The EDAC resolved that the punishment for agricultural product smugglers should be heavier in order to deter future smuggling, protect Taiwan's agricultural production and its marketing order, and protect farmers' interests.
The advisory conference also concluded that more severe penalties are needed to protect quarantine control of domestic animal and plant species, as well as Taiwan's overall economic development.

Legislator Tsai Huang-lang from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party said passage of the amendment is imperative as smuggling of agricultural products, particularly from mainland China to Taiwan, has been increasing over recent years with the further liberalization of private cross-strait exchanges.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S JOBLESS RATE MAKES FIRST FALL IN 13 MONTHS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's jobless rate in November was 5.28 percent, slightly down from the record 5.33 percent of the previous month, the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) said Monday.

The figure marks the first decline in 13 months since October 2000, though it is hardly a harbinger of economic rebound, DGBAS official Chen Chin-cheng said, adding that the jobless rate for next month will still be between 5.2 percent and 5.3 percent.

Chen said that job losses because of factory closures or downsizing increased to a record high of 268,000 for the 15th consecutive month, up 8,000 from the previous month, and that declines continue in the manufacturing industry.

But with Chinese New Year approaching, which falls on Feb. 12, 2002, the food service industry will see brisker business and the openings of several big shopping malls, as well as the harvesting season of certain agricultural products, will help the jobless situation, Chen said.

He said that overall, employment should rise before Chinese New Year, helping to stabilize the jobless rate. However, with Taiwan's entry into the World Trade Organization in January, 2002, it will not be possible to assess the true impact until March 2002, he said.
He said that the average jobless rate in the first 11 months was 4.52 percent and the jobless rate this year will be 4.57 percent.

Though the jobless rate in Taiwan showed an overall decline, 18 cities and counties have still registered a jobless rate of over 5 percent, with Hualien County the highest at 5.69 percent, followed by Taipei County (5.68 percent), and Taichung County (5.66 percent).
Legislator Lai Shyi-bao, in commenting on the first jobless decline in 13 months, said that the jobless rate could still be higher than 5 percent in the short term.
He cautioned against optimism over the decline, saying that judging from the domestic and international situations, it is still too early to say that it means the economy has hit bottom.

He noted that the overall international situation has yet to turn the corner to recovery, and when the economy of the United States will rebound remains to be seen. So, with domestic leading economic indexes showing no remarkable improvement, Lai said he could not say when the economy will bottom out.

A total of 3.00 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT&86.86 billion (US$4.05 billion), compared with the previous trading session which saw 3.57 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$109.25 billion (US$2.48 billion).

All but one major stock categories gained ground, with pulp and paper stocks moving up the most at 2.6 percent, followed by electrical shares 1.5 percent, construction issues at 1.2 percent, and cement, foodstuff, and textile stocks at 1.0 percent, respectively, and plastic and chemical stocks at 0.4 percent.
The only stock category that lost ground was bank and insurance stock, falling by 0.6 percent.
Gainers outnumbered loser 437 to 131, with 79 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: FEAR OF LOSING JOBS MOST CONCERNS TAIWAN PEOPLE: SURVEY

TEXT.P: Fear of losing their jobs most concerns residents of Taiwan and 85 percent said that finding a job has become difficult, according to a resent survey released Monday.
The poll, conducted by the mass-circulation newspaper United Daily News, telephoned 938 adults around the island Dec. 18-19. The survey had a margin of error of 3.2 percent.

The poll also found that nearly 89 percent of respondents complained about the economic sluggishness, and 49 percent said that they felt the pinch of hard times. Sixty-four percent complained that their lives are not what they used to be.

According to the survey, 1995 was a turning point for local people in terms of their feelings toward the nation's economy. In 1994, only 46 percent felt that the economy was bad and 34 percent said that finding a job was difficult.

In comparison, complaints about the economy have averaged around 76 percent since 1995 and hit a peak of 94 percent in 2000. A survey this year showed that nearly 89 percent of respondents said they felt the economy was in bad shape. Only 7 percent said that the economy is still doing well.

With the stalled economy, the impact on the lives of the average person has continued to become more evident. The figure for those satisfied with their lives hovered near 63 percent between 1996 and 1999, but dropped to 54 percent last year and slipped further to 48 percent this year.

Most of these polled were also pessimistic about their futures. Thirty-four percent believed that daily life over the next two or three years will be worse than now. Only 27 percent expected the future to be better.

Regarding employment, 31 percent of the 61 percent who are currently employed said that they are worried about the possibility of losing their jobs because of the poor economy. Thirty-four percent said that Taiwan's entry into the World Trade Organization could affect their jobs or incomes.
But 64 percent say that the success or failure of a person is up to the individual and 30 percent said that timing is more important than effort.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT CRIMES CHALLENGING TAIWAN'S LAW ENFORCEMENT

TEXT.P: Organized crime across the Taiwan Strait is becoming rampant and presents a formidable challenge to Taiwan's law enforcement, said Meng Wei-teh, an associate professor in public administration from the National Central Police University.

Cross-strait crimes are now seriously disturbing Taiwan's social order, hampering the island's economic development and posing a serious threat to Taiwan people's quality of life, personal safety and property, Meng said.

Meng said Taiwan and mainland China are separated only by a "ditch." He said that because the people from both sides are from the same race with almost identical languages and customs, crimes of all kinds can easily bridge the distance between the two. Meng mentioned crimes like goods' smuggling, drug trafficking, the sale of illegal weapons, smuggling of human cargo and hijacking.
Quoting tallies from the Criminal Investigation Bureau, Meng said the number of criminals who fled Taiwan to mainland China has risen yearly over last 10 years.

During that time, Taiwan law enforcement authorities have requested cooperation from mainland Chinese authorities to attempt to jointly apprehend 335 criminals wanted in Taiwan. Of that total, only 87 were caught while the remaining 74 percent remain fugitives, Meng said.

According to the Criminal Investigation Bureau, those Taiwan criminals, most of them prominent gangland figures, were found to have "remotely controlled" their cross-strait operations, including drug and weapons trafficking, smuggling of laborers and prostitutes from mainland China and shipping stolen cars from Taiwan.
Between Jan. 1 and Oct. 31 this year, 3,647 mainland Chinese people were nabbed by Taiwan law enforcement authorities for violating ROC laws.

Of the total, 1,150 mainlanders, or 31.5 percent, were arrested or repatriated for illegally working in Taiwan, 953 mainland women, or 26.1 percent, were apprehended while working in the sex trade, and 866 people, or 23.8 percent, were found to be illegal immigrants from mainland China.

Taiwan police have found that 47.8 percent, or 50.8 kilograms of the 106.4 kilograms of heroin confiscated in 1999, originated from mainland China, and 68 percent of the 1,214.5 kilograms of amphetamines seized the same year were from across the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: RESEARCH REPORT SAYS KAOHSIUNG NEEDS TO PROSPER ITS SERVICE SECTOR

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung has the potential to become an international city given its good resources for agricultural, industrial and business developments, but only as long as the public and private sectors can improve the service sector, according to a research report.
The Council for Economic Planning and Development recently entrusted the Chungshan Business Management Academic Research Society to prepare a report on urban development in metropolitan Kaohsiung.

The report indicated that Kaohsiung as a harbor city has the advantages in developing itself into a deep-sea fishery base. On the other hand, with the Linyuan petrochemical industrial zone and the steel mills of the China Steel Corp. in neighboring regions, Kaohsiung is an important industrial city in Taiwan and in Southeast Asia.
For further modernization and internationalization, the metropolis with 1.47 million people needs to boost its service sector, according to the report.

The report says that employees of the service sector accounted for 62.98 percent of the employed population in Kaohsiung in 1996. The percentage increased moderately to 65.44 percent in 1999. To compare with Taipei, Hong Kong and Singapore, Kaohsiung's service sector is less developed, it added.
