TEXT.P: Taipei Bank will be unable to introduce a new computerized national lottery on Jan. 10 as scheduled and will postpone the issuing date to approximately one week later, Taipei Bank President Jesse Y. Ding said Wednesday.

Ding said that his bank needs time to make the necessary preparations for taking on the task of managing a lottery, which he said will make Taipei Bank the only financial institution in the world to be in charge of a charity lottery where the majority of the profits will be used for public interest projects.
The computerized lottery numbers will be drawn twice a week. The top prize is NT$50 million (US$1.4 million) and will be rolled over each time no one wins the lottery.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT VISITS OUTLYING ISLAND OF WUCHIU

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian visited Wuchiu Wednesday and instructed the troops garrisoned on the tiny outlying island to remain on guard to prevent mainland Chinese infiltration.
Accompanied by Minister of National Defense Wu Shih-wen and Chief of the General Staff Gen. Tang Yao-ming, Chen was the first ROC president ever to visit Wuchiu during his term in office.

The president said that Wuchiu is strategically located between Kinmen and Matsu in the Taiwan Strait and serves as a forward post in the defense of Taiwan that can provide early warning on incoming aircraft.

Instructing the officers and soldiers stationed on the island to heighten their awareness and step up their combat readiness, Chen warned that mainland China has continued to refuse to renounce the option to use force against Taiwan and has diverted the results of its economic development into its military modernization efforts, allowing for large-scale advances in its overall fighting prowess.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CHIEF WELCOMES ELECTION COMPETITION

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Frank Hsieh said Wednesday that he welcomes the decision by Yao Chia-wen, former DPP chairman and now a member of the DPP Central Standing Committee, to run for election as party chairman.
Yao's participation indicates that the DPP is a democratic political party with many talented members, according to Hsieh.
Hsieh made the remarks to local reporters after attending a citation ceremony for environmental protection volunteers in Kaohsiung.

He pointed out that the DPP's Taiwan independence stance of the past is similar to those of the Taiwan Independent Party and the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), but he added that the party has altered its stance to maintain the status quo in line with mainstream public opinion.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI PROTESTS JAPANESE MINISTERS' REMARKS ON TAIWAN SOVEREIGNTY

TEXT.P: The Republic of China Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) Wednesday lodged a protest against the remarks of two Japanese cabinet ministers regarding Taiwan's sovereignty.
Japanese Foreign Minister Makiko Tanaka said in an interview with a Japanese daily Dec. 25 that, "In the future, Taiwan is going to be returned to China, like Hong Kong."

Later, Chief Cabinet Secretary Y. Fukuda said that the Japanese government's position on this issue has been stipulated in the 1972 Japan-mainland China joint statement -- "Taiwan is an inalienable part of the People's Republic of China and Japan understands and respects such a stand."

In response to the two Japanese ministers' remarks, MOFA Vice Minister Wu Tzu-dan summoned Shintaro Yamashita, director of the Taipei Office under the Japan Interchange Association, to the foreign ministry to lodge a protest.
Wu told Yamashita that Taiwan's situation is totally different from that of Hong Kong and stressed that Taipei insists on resolving cross-Taiwan Strait problems through peaceful negotiations.

He went on to say that Taipei is against the so-called "one country, two systems" formula proposed by Beijing and added that Taiwan will continue to strive for improvement of cross-strait relations with goodwill and sincerity.
Regarding the Japanese government's stand on the Taiwan issue, Wu said that the ROC has been an independent sovereign country since 1912.
He said that Taiwan and mainland China are now two separate political entities, pointing out the fact that the PRC's political jurisdiction has never reached Taiwan.
Wu delivered a memorandum to Yamashita, who promised to transmit it to the Japanese government.
Meanwhile, ROC Representative to Japan Lo Fu-chuan also delivered a letter of protest to the Japan Interchange Association in Tokyo.

The letter noted that the Republic of China on Taiwan is an independent sovereign country and its future will be decided by the 23 million people in Taiwan. It said that foreign officials are not allowed to interfere.

The Taiwan Benevolent Association in Japan also sent letters of protest to the prime minister's office, the foreign ministry and major Japanese news organizations, demanding that the Japanese foreign minister apologize to the people of Taiwan for her inappropriate remarks.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN INDEPENDENT ALLIANCE LODGES PROTEST AGAINST JAPAN'S FM

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Independent Alliance (TIA) Wednesday protested against comments made by Japanese Foreign Minister Yukiko Tanaka on Taiwan's future, a senior official of the TIA said.

Huang Chao-tang, chairman of the alliance, issued a written statement, charging that Tanaka was lacking in knowledge and common sense about history by having said Tuesday that the future of Taiwan will be like Hong Kong -- eventually coming under the control of mainland China.
Huang asked Tanaka to apologize to the Taiwan people since Tanaka's comments had seriously injured the rights and dignity of the people of Taiwan.
Being a foreign minister of Japan, Tanaka should bear the political responsibility for any comment made by her regarding another country, Huang said.
Tanaka's comments are an interference in the internal affairs of Taiwan, Huang went on, adding that this was the reason that he asked Tanaka to apologize to the people of Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: COL. PAN AI-CHU TO BECOME THIRD FEMALE MAJOR GENERAL IN ROC HISTORY

TEXT.P: Col. Pan Ai-chu, the new political warfare department director of the Military Intelligence Bureau (MIB) under the Ministry of National Defense (MND), will be promoted to the rank of major general Jan. 1, 2002, a spokesman from the MND announced Wednesday.

Pan, 46, will be the first Republic of China female officer to be promoted to major general in more than 40 years. She will become only the third female general in the country's military history. The two others were Chou Mei-yu and Chiang Yi-ying, who were promoted to major generals in 1958 and 1967, respectively.

"The promotion will be yet another symbol of gender equality in the ROC armed forces," Pan said several days ago on hearing the news of her promotion. She said that it also signifies the bright career prospects for women military officers in Taiwan.

Pan encouraged her comrades in the military to put aside the issue of sex and compete with their male peers on an equal footing. As a matter of fact, she said, the military has put much emphasis on gender equality in recent years. "I feel that female officers and non-commissioned officers can have brilliant careers just like their male comrades so long as they work hard," Pan said.

Military records show that Pan graduated from the political science department of the military-run Fuhsingkang College and has a master's degree from the school's Graduate Institute of Political Science.

Pan has also attended an MIB-sponsored graduate program. Pan was an outstanding student and ranked among the top three when she graduated from Fuhsingkang College. She worked for two years at the ROC Army's local-level political warfare units and then entered graduate school.

She joined the MIB's mainland affairs research department after obtaining her master's degree. Over the past 20-plus years, Pan has been involved in research of mainland Chinese intelligence and relevant information. She is now responsible for studying articles carried in major mainland Chinese magazines as well as collecting, compiling and analyzing information about the latest situation on the mainland.

Pan has received much acclaim from the government and military leadership for her analyses of mainland intelligence and suggestions on the development of relations across the Taiwan Strait, military sources said.

According to MIB sources, Pan's analytical reports were very useful during three critical periods -- the 1996 Taiwan Strait crisis, former President Lee Teng-hui's defining of cross-strait ties as a special "state-to-state" relationship in July 1999, and the 2000 presidential election which ushered in Taiwan's first peaceful transition of power between different political parties.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Dec. 27, or the 13th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1571: Johannes Kepler, German astronomer and mathematician, is born. Considered the founder of modern astronomy, he formulated three laws to clarify the theory that the planets revolve around the sun.
1822: Louis Pasteur, French chemist and bacteriologist who founded modern microbiology, is born. He invented the process of pasteurization and developed vaccines for anthrax, rabies and chicken cholera.
1831: Under the command of Capt. Robert Fitzroy, the Royal Navy's HMS Beagle sets sail from Devonport, England, on a five-year voyage of scientific exploration around the world.
1927: Leon Trotsky, Russian revolutionary theoretician, is expelled form the Soviet Communist Party for his opposition to the authoritarianism of Stalin and for his emphasis on world revolution.
1945: The International Monetary Fund is set up in Washington, D.C.
1949: Republic of China government troops evacuate Chengtu, the capital of Szechwan Province.
1949: Ahmed Sukarno, leader of the Indonesian Nationalist Party, returns to Batavia (Jakarta) after A.H.J. Lovink, representative of the Netherlands government, signed a protocol transferring sovereignty to an Indonesian delegation.
1958: More than 10,000 Tibetans die in armed resistance against Communist Chinese atrocities.
1959: Japanese Prime Minister Shegeru Yoshida visits Taipei.
1969: Egypt, Sudan and Libya agree to the formation of a political, economic and military alliance.
1972: Lester Pearson, the former Canadian prime minister who won the Nobel Peace Prize in 1957 for his part in settling the Suez crisis in 1956, dies at the age of 75.
1972: The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with Chad.
1975: Ten people are honored by the Young Entrepreneurs Association in Taipei for their inventions.
1975: The First International Children's Camp opens for two days of activities sponsored by the Camping Association of the Republic of China.
1975: The ROC's Vocational Assistance Commission for Retired Servicemen announces it had given aid to 251,563 former servicemen as of the end of November.
1976: Jacques Baumel, member of the National Assembly of France, arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1976: Dr. Charles E. Bishop, president of the University of Arkansas, and Rev. Malcolm Carron, president of the University of Detroit, arrive in Taipei for a weeklong visit.
1978: Some 10,000 people demonstrate at the airport when a delegation led by U.S. Deputy Secretary of State Warren Christopher arrives in Taipei for talks after the United States severed diplomatic relations with Taipei in favor of Beijing.
1979: Afghan President Hafizullah Amin is executed by the Soviets. Babrak Karmal, a former deputy prime minister in exile in Czechoslovakia, is installed in his place.
1980: Twenty-two supplementary members are elected to Taiwan's Control Yuan from among 54 candidates by members of the Taiwan Provincial Assembly, the Taipei City Council and the Kaohsiung City Council.
1987: The Taiwan Provincial Government issues its last lottery tickets.
1995: France stages the fifth in a series of nuclear weapon tests in the South Pacific.
1999: Vice President Lien Chan expresses his appreciation to Chinese-Japanese baseball star Sadaharu Oh for his active efforts after the devastating magnitude 7.3 earthquake hit Taiwan Sept. 21.
2000: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou says that the current political instability mainly results from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's failure to respect the Republic of China Constitution and its "one China" spirit.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Gentlemen, why should you be concerned at your present want of official position! The world has long been without the order and justice of good government; now God is going to make use of your teacher as a tocsin to awaken the world."

DOC.HEADLINE: CETRA ADJUSTS ITS OPERATIONS TO MEET NEW CHALLENGES

TEXT.P: The China External Trade Development Council (Cetra) will adjust its operations by shifting its focus from export-oriented business to diversified services in the export as well as import sectors, CETRA chairman Shea Jia-dong said Wednesday.
Shea said that the trade organization needs to find a new orientation in the face of mounting international competition.

Since its founding in 1970, the Cetra has been Taiwan's largest non-profit trade promoter. The 38 Cetra branch offices, design centers and trade centers overseas gather trade information, conduct market research, promote made-in-Taiwan products, organize exhibitions, and promote product and packaging designs.

In 1980, the Cetra-managed Taipei World Trade Center with convention facilities and display grounds was set up. In addition to leasing exhibition booths, the trade center provides venues for dozens of industrial exhibitions every year.
Shea said that in the coming year, the Cetra will seek to expand its display facilities to meet the increasing demand from exhibitors at home and from abroad.
Another important task for the trade promotion organization is to train more trade specialists for the government and the business community, according to Shea.

The Cetra set up the International Trade Institute in 1987 to train trade specialists well versed in foreign languages and the practices of international trade. The institute offers a two-year residential post-graduate international business administration program.

Shea said that the Cetra underwent a restructuring over the past several months and the workforce was cut by one tenth. The Cetra hopes to reduce its operational costs by NT$200 million in 2002, while looking for new sources of income, he added.

Shea disclosed that the Cetra will set aside NT$600 million of its capital to invest on the stock market. The former finance minister said that as a matter of fact, the Cetra has studied the feasibility of investing in stocks since the weighted price index of the Taiwan Stock Exchange dwindled to 4,000 points in mid September.

The other major categories posted losses, with foodstuff shares moving down the most at 2.6 percent, followed by textile issues at 2 percent, cement stocks at 1.8 percent, plastics and chemical shares at 1.7 percent, construction stocks and electrical shares, both at 1.5 percent, and pulp and paper issues at 1.3 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'RAINBOW ALLIANCE' FORMED TO PROMOTE MEDIA LIBERALIZATION

TEXT.P: Amid calls for a domestic television reform, a new alliance was formed Thursday to promote media liberalization, professionalism and democratization as well as to rid the media of political influences.

"The establishment of the Media Development Rainbow Alliance is aimed at boosting media impartiality, independence and balanced news reporting," said Chang Hsien-yao, one of the new alliance's founders.

Chang, who concurrently serves as director of the opposition People First Party's (PFP's) policy research center, and PFP Legislator Diane Lee jointly hosted a news conference explaining the alliance's major purposes and goals.

"One of the group's top goals is to invite President Chen Shui-bian and leaders of ruling and opposition parties to jointly sign an agreement on the ouster of political parties, government and military from airwave channels," said Chang.

He added that the alliance will also push amendments to Article 22 of the Broadcasting and Television Law and relevant provisions through the legislature to demand that the government sell its shares in Taiwan Television (TTV) and China Television System (CTS) to the public.

Other goals included promoting the legislation of a political party law that would ban political parties from controlling media management; pushing local terrestrial TV channels to trade their shares publicly on the stock exchange; and promoting the formation of a national media development commission.
Speaking on the same occasion, Legislator Diane Lee said the alliance's name bears special symbolic meanings.

"By designating our group as the Rainbow Alliance, we hope that local media would offer multidimensional, pluralistic, ingenious, inspiring and professional news services just like the colorfulness of rainbow," Lee explained.
The founders of the new alliance include some 20 elite members from media, literary and educational circles as well as legislators of different political stripes.

DOC.HEADLINE: COUNTERFEIT MONEY CHOSEN TOP HEADLINE MAKER BY CONSUMER FOUNDATION

TEXT.P: The Consumer Foundation, Chinese Taipei, announced Thursday that the counterfeit money problem and its serious consequences on consumer confidence was this year's top consumer-related news story.

A spokesman of the foundation said that the 29 members of the board, composed of scholars, university professors, physicians and architects, select the top 10 consumer-related news events at the end of each year.
The circulation of counterfeit New Taiwan dollar bills was selected because of the disturbance it caused to the monetary system and to consumer confidence.

Taiwan's entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO), effective from the beginning of next year, was chosen the second biggest consumer-related news story of the year in view of the impact on the domestic economy and the benefits to domestic consumers.

The third biggest story of the year chosen by the foundation was the panic buying of rice wine because of the expected price hike in the product after the monopolized domestic tobacco and wine market is opened to imports.

The spokesman said that other top consumer-related news headline makers for the year included credit card forgeries, the inauguration of a shopping mall before the obtaining of a business license, and the decline in business in the tourism sector since the tragic Sept. 11 terrorist attacks on America.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MUSEUM HOSTS EXHIBITION IN MEMORY OF JOSEPH NEEDHAM

TEXT.P: The National Taiwan Museum in Taipei is presenting an exhibition introducing the achievements of the late Dr. Joseph Needham (1900-1995) and the British scholar's contributions to Chinese and world civilization.

Dr. Needham, who passed away on March 24, 1995 at the age of 94, was assigned to China in 1942 to work as director of the Sino-British Cooperation Office. The four years in China was a decisive phase of the Cambridge academic's scholarly career.

In 1954, Dr. Needham put out the first book of his 16-volume monumental work -- Science and Civilization in China -- which provided the West with an insight into the achievements of traditional China and the important contributions made by China to science.

The exhibition co-sponsored by the British representative office in Taipei and the Joseph Needham Institute of Cambridge University features Dr. Needham's photos, notes and diary as well as some personal belongings.
The exhibition will run until March 17, 2002.

DOC.HEADLINE: ADJUSTMENT OF TAX REDISTRIBUTION RATIOS YET TO BE FINALIZED: PREMIER

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Finance (MOF) plan to adjust the allocation ratios of tax redistribution funds (TRF) for various cities and counties around the island has yet to be finalized, said Premier Chang Chun-hsiung Thursday.

Chang was responding to media reports that the MOF has drafted a plan to lower the TRF allocation ratio for the two special municipalities from the current 43 percent to 36.22 percent for fiscal 2003 and that the percentage for other cities and counties will be raised to 45.72 percent from the present 39 percent.

If the plan is put into force, the two special municipalities -- Taipei and Kaohsiung -- will see a decrease of NT$10.6 billion (US$302.86 million) in their total tax redistribution funds, while the country's other cities and counties will enjoy a NT$10.5 billion increase in redistribution funds.
The reports immediately caused a backlash from the Taipei and Kaohsiung city governments over the MOF-proposed adjustment plan.

Chang, who traveled to the central county of Taichung early in the morning to attend a post-Sept. 21, 1999 earthquake reconstruction promotion meeting, said he did ask the MOF to draft a TRF allocation ratio adjustment plan earlier this year to avert frequent squabbling among local governments over the issue of money.

"The MOF has not yet presented its draft plan to the Cabinet for approval," Chang said, adding that once the Cabinet receives the plan, relevant central government agencies will further discuss details with all local governments.
In Taipei, Minister of Finance Yen Ching-chang said his ministry is scheduled to discuss the issue with finance chiefs of city and county governments this Monday.
"Once the allocation ratios are settled, they will no longer be subject to annual adjustments as in the past," Yen said.

Acting on the premier's instruction, Yen said, the MOF has invited five scholars to work out the new TRF allocation formula after a careful evaluation of land acreage, population and tax revenues of various localities.
Yen urged Taipei and Kaohsiung municipal officials to examine whether the new formula is reasonable and fair, instead of simply complaining about the anticipated decrease in redistribution funds.

Lin Chuan, director-general of the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics, said once the new TRF allocation ratios are determined, the Cabinet will reimburse Taipei and Kaohsiung for their diminished redistribution funds by increasing their allocation ratios of central government grants to city and county governments.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PRODUCTS WIN PRESTIGIOUS DESIGN AWARDS

TEXT.P: A total of 16 products designed by Taiwanese companies received the prestigious iF and G-Mark awards this year, highlighting Taiwan's progress in transitioning from a manufacturing to a knowledge-based design industry, according to the China External Trade Development Council (CETRA).

CETRA, which selected 23 domestically designed products and entered them in the Industrie Forum (iF) Design Awards in Germany and the Good Design Award (G-Mark) in Japan, noted that the winning designs from Taiwan covered the range of telecommunications, entertainment, transportation, household and stationery products.
Winners of the iF awards have been invited to attend next March's CeBIT in Hannover, Germany, the world's largest trade show for information and telecommunication technology, according to CETRA.

The iF awards have been held since 1954 and attract over 1,800 entries from 30 different countries each year. The G-Mark has been presented annually since 1957 and receives over 2,000 entries each year.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FOREIGN MINISTRY DISCUSSING 'INAPPROPRIATE' REMARKS WITH JAPAN

TEXT.P: The Republic of China Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) will continue discussions with Japan over comments made by two Japanese officials that irked Taipei regarding Taiwan's future, a senior official said Thursday at a news conference.

MOFA spokeswoman Chang Siao-yue made the remarks in response to inquiries from Japanese reporters stationed in Taipei about possible subsequent developments after the ROC government lodged a formal protest with Tokyo over Japanese Foreign Minister Makiko Tanaka's and Chief Cabinet Secretary Yasuo Fukuda's recent remarks.
Japanese Foreign Minister Tanaka said in an interview with a Japanese daily Tuesday that she was hopeful that in the future, Taiwan would be returned to China, like Hong Kong.

Later, Fukuda said the Japanese government's position on the issue has been stated in the 1972 Tokyo-Beijing joint communique: "Taiwan is an inalienable part of the People's Republic of China and Japan understands and respect such a stand."

Chang said the Japanese government has made an initial response to Taipei's protest through the ROC representative office in Tokyo by reaffirming no change in its stance of hoping that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait can resolve their sovereignty disputes using peaceful, rational means.

In response to the two Japanese ministers' remarks, ROC Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Wu Tzu-dan summoned Shintaro Yamashita, director of the Taipei Office of the Japanese Interchange Association (JIA), to the foreign ministry Wednesday to lodge a protest.
Wu told Yamashita that Taiwan's situation is totally different from that of Hong Kong and stressed that Taipei insists on resolving cross-strait problems through peaceful negotiations.

He went on to say that Taipei is against the so-called "one country, two systems" unification formula proposed by Beijing and added that Taiwan will continue to strive for improvement of cross-strait relations with goodwill and sincerity.
Regarding the Japanese government's stand on the Taiwan issue, Wu said that the ROC has been an independent sovereign country since 1912.
Stressing that Taiwan and mainland China are now two separate political entities, Wu said the PRC's political jurisdiction has never reached Taiwan.
Wu delivered a memorandum to Yamashita, who promised to transmit it to the Japanese government.

Meanwhile, ROC Representative to Japan Lo Fu-chuan also delivered a letter of protest Wednesday to the Tokyo office of JIA, a semi-official organization authorized by the Japanese government to handle exchanges with the ROC in the absence of formal diplomatic ties.

The letter noted that the ROC on Taiwan is an independent sovereign country and its future will be decided by the 23 million people of Taiwan. It added that foreign officials are not allowed to interfere.
At Thursday's news conference, Chang reiterated that the ROC government has never agreed to the 1972 Tokyo-Beijing joint statement regarding Taiwan's status.
Chang urged Japanese officials to exercise caution and prudence in addressing the ROC-related issues. "Inappropriate remarks would affect the close and delicate Taiwan-Japanese relations," she added.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW U.S. ENVOY TO TAIPEI TO BEGIN DUTIES IN MARCH
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 26 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The new U.S. representative to the Republic of China will begin work in Taipei next March, a Bush administration official said Wednesday.

The official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said Secretary of State Colin Powell has decided to appoint Douglas Paal, a former senior Asia-Pacific affairs director under the White House National Security Council, as new head of the Taipei office of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT).
AIT is a quasi-official body authorized by the U.S. government to handle relations with the ROC in the absence of formal diplomatic ties.

As Paal has been out of public service for nine years, the official said, it is taking some time to complete the background check necessary for the posting. The official added, however, that Paal will be confirmed for the job.
Paal will succeed Raymond Burghardt as the new de facto U.S. ambassador to Taiwan. Burghardt has been named the new U.S. ambassador to Vietnam.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Dec. 28, or the 14th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1836: Spain recognizes Mexico's independence.
1856: Thomas Woodrow Wilson, American statesman and Democratic president (1913-21), is born.
1881: China's first telegraph line linking Tientsin and Shanghai is made available for public use.
1908: The most violent earthquake ever recorded in Europe destroys the city of Messina in Sicily, killing more than half of its 150,000 inhabitants and causing a giant tidal wave.
1912: City-run streetcars in San Francisco, California, begin operating.
1919: Feng Kuo-chang, a warlord who led the Chihli faction of the powerful Peiyang army during the first decade of the Republic of China, dies in Peking (Beijing) at the age of 62.
1923: Alexandre Gustave Eiffel, the French engineer who designed the 300-meter-high Eiffel Tower for the Paris Exhibition of 1889, dies at the age of 91.
1931: The ROC government is reformed, with Lin Sen made chairman.
1945: The Big Three Foreign Ministers' Conference in Moscow announces agreements on the establishment of a Commission and Allied Council for Japan, the ultimate establishment of a free Korea, and the withdrawal of Soviet and U.S. troops from China.
1950: Mainland Chinese troops cross the 38th parallel in Korea.
1962: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs declares that the border agreements signed between the Beijing regime and Outer Mongolia and Pakistan are illegal and non-binding for the Republic of China.
1966: Mainland China detonates its fifth atomic bomb.
1968: The ROC opens a telecommunications satellite earth station on Yangmingshan.
1971: Grand Justice Tien Chun-chin is appointed as president of the ROC's Judicial Yuan.
1972: The Republic of China's Embassy in Tokyo and the consulates-general in Osaka, Yokohama and Fukuoka are formally closed.
1974: The Republic of China-Bahamas Cultural and Economic Association is inaugurated in Taipei.
1974: The Republic of China suspends diplomatic relations with Gambia following the latter's recognition of the Peiping (Beijing) regime.
1976: The millionth visitor of the year to the Republic of China, Wilhelm Mulmann, professor of sociology and anthropology at the University of Heidleberg, Germany, and his wife are welcomed by officials of the Tourism Bureau.
1976: Education Minister Y.S. Tsiang presents a gold medal and citation to Yen Tjing-ling, board chairman of the Yue Loong Motors Co. Ltd., for his contribution to an industrial research center at National Taiwan University.
1987: The Development Bank of Shenzhen, the first private share-holding bank on the Chinese mainland, is inaugurated.
1988: The first instance of a baby born with Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome (AIDS) in Taiwan is recorded.
1993: A plane belonging to mainland China's Fujian Airlines is hijacked to Taiwan by Luo Chang-hua and his wife Wang Yu-ying in the 10th hijacking of the year.
1995: In Beijing, judges reject an appeal by dissident Wei Jingsheng, upholding his 14-year sentence on charges of trying to overthrow the Beijing government.
1995: Beijing names the committee responsible for steering Hong Kong through its transition from British colony to Chinese Special Administration Region in 1997.
1999: Taiwan changes the name of its representative office in Macau from Taipei Economic and Cultural Office to Taipei Economic and Cultural Center, Macau.
2000: The Formosa Plastics Group presents its first sedan -- the Formosa Magnus 2.0 -- which was manufactured via technical cooperation with South Korea's Daewoo Group.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Possession of power without generosity; courtesy without seriousness; mourning without grief -- I have no desire to look at such a state of things."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES UP BY 65.3 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) gained ground on Friday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving up 65.3 points to close at 5,398.28.
Market turnover amounted to NT$123.35 billion (US$3.52 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC CALLS FOR MORE COOPERATION FROM M'LAND IN REPATRIATING ILLEGALS

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) urged mainland China Friday to cooperate more closely with Taiwan in repatriating illegal mainland Chinese immigrants.
"We need greater mainland cooperation in sending back all captured illegal mainland immigrants," said MAC Vice Chairman Lin Chong-pin at a regular news conference.
Lin said mainland Chinese authorities should also strengthen their border control and adopt effective measures to prevent their people from stowing away on ships to Taiwan.
"Prevention of human smuggling is key to maintaining a normal exchange order between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait," Lin said.
With the assistance of the Red Cross Society on both sides of the strait, Lin said about 2,000 illegal mainland immigrants have been repatriated so far this year.
In the past two days, Lin said, more than 300 mainland stowaways were repatriated from the Republic of China-held frontline island of Matsu, which lies closer to the mainland than to Taiwan.
"With the Spring Festival drawing near, we hope to repatriate more illegal mainland immigrants so that they can spend the important traditional Chinese holiday with their families," Lin said.

According to Lin, over 800 illegal mainland immigrants are still being held at the three detention centers in Hsinchu, Ilan and Matsu. Meanwhile, 115 other illegal mainland immigrants are also waiting to be repatriated at various police bureaus around the island.
Lin said the MAC appreciates all the assistance offered by the Red Cross Society on both sides of the Taiwan Strait in the repatriation of mainland stowaways over the past years.

"We hope mainland China will continue cooperating with Taiwan in the repatriation of stowaways in accordance with the Kinmen Agreement signed by Taiwan's and mainland China's Red Cross Society in 1990," Lin said.

He said that in the coming year, the MAC, which charts Taiwan's policy toward the mainland, will actively push for resumption of dialogue and consultations between the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) on non-political practical issues arising from increased bilateral civilian exchanges, including the repatriation of illegal mainland immigrants and the cracking down on cross-strait smuggling and other criminal activities.
AEF and ARATS are quasi-official intermediary bodies authorized by their respective governments to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high and closed even higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 65.3 points to close at 5,398.28.
Encouraged by a continued rise in U.S. stock prices, the bourse opened at 5,372.85 and continued to go up. The index fluctuated between 5,408.15 and 5,307.38 during trading.

A total of 4.01 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$123.35 billion (US$3.52 billion), a decrease from the previous trading session which saw 4.92 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$160.19 billion (US$4.58 billion).

Three of the eight major stocks categories lost ground, with bank and insurance shares moving down the most at 3.1 percent, followed by pulp and paper issues at 0.4 percent, and plastics and chemical shares at 0.2 percent.

The other major categories posted gains, with electrical shares moving up the most at 2.4 percent, followed by construction stocks and foodstuff shares, both at 1.3 percent, cement stocks at 0.6 percent, and textile issues at 0.1 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 346 to 221, with 95 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market were generally higher Friday as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for next January moved up 118 points to close at 5,400, with 19,487 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for next February rose 94 points to close at 5,363, with 26 contract transactions, while next September futures lost 4 points to finish at 5,450, with only one contract traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 5,282 for next January, 5,269 for next February, 5,235 for next March, 5,497 for next June, and 5,454 for next September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, registered mixed results.

Next January TE futures moved up 8.3 points to close at 285.3 with 4,813 contract transactions, while next February TE futures increased 8.95 points to finish at 285.95, with nine contracts changing hands.
Next March TE futures rose 14.55 points to close at 283, with five contracts traded. No transactions were reported for other months.
Next January TF futures moved down 28 points to finish at 722, with 3,580 contract transactions, while next February TF futures decreased 15 points to close at 730, with 10 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEEFING UP UNDERWATER COMBAT CAPABILITY KEY TO ROC NAVY BUILDUP

TEXT.P: Building a submarine fleet to deter a possible mainland Chinese naval blockade should be one of the top goals of the Republic of China's military buildup, a senior Ministry of National Defense (MND) official said Friday.
Speaking at a seminar on submarines and Taiwan's naval defense, Chang Shih-po, an MND division chief in charge of logistic support affairs, said the Taiwan Strait will be a flashpoint in East Asia.
"As mainland China is likely to use its large submarine fleet to impose a blockade on Taiwan, we should beef up our anti-submarine combat capabilities," Chang explained.
He pointed out that mainland China has been expanding its navy and equipment in recent years.

In addition to beefing up its ocean-going naval fleet, Chang said, mainland China has also built up the world's third-largest submarine fleet and has continued to renovate relevant facilities and weaponry systems.

Noting that submarines offer the most lethal means of disrupting shipping services, Chang said Taiwan must upgrade its anti-submarine, anti-blockade capabilities to ensure smooth maritime traffic in its surrounding areas, which is crucial to the island's export-oriented economy.

Taiwan has traditionally relied on advanced countries for the supply of submarines and related weaponry systems, Chang went on, adding that since the United States has agreed to sell eight conventional diesel-powered submarines to Taiwan, the ROC military should take advantage of the opportunity to foster its own submarine design and manufacturing capabilities.

Chang further said that the ROC should seek to participate in the production of the eight conventional submarines the United States has agreed to sell. As the United States has long stopped production of diesel submarines, it may have to seek cooperation with other countries to fulfill its deal with Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: N.T. DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar appreciated NT$0.043 against the greenback on the Taipei foreign exchange market Friday, closing at NT$35.084.
The local currency opened Friday at NT$35.174 and was traded between NT$35.051 and NT$35.186.
Interbank U.S. dollar trading totaled US$669 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PEOPLE `MOST ASHAMED' ABOUT POLITICAL POWER STRUGGLES: SURVEY

TEXT.P: The people of Taiwan are "most ashamed" of power struggles between politicians and consider economic stability to be the key to Taiwan's prosperity, according to the results of a survey released Friday by the Common Wealth magazine.
The Chinese-language monthly conducted the survey among 1,069 people aged over 18 selected at random from around the island from Dec. 20-23.

Of the people who responded, 56 percent said they consider conflicts between political parties to be the most serious crisis facing Taiwan, while 37.9 percent said they consider provocative and manipulative tendencies of the media to be the most serious crisis and 25.4 percent said they are most worried about the decline of social values.
While mainland China is seen by many as a constant threat to Taiwan, 24.8 percent of the people said they are most concerned about the upswing of the mainland economy.

Forty-eight percent of the respondents said they are optimistic about Taiwan's future, against 26 percent who are pessimistic. A similar survey conducted a year ago showed that only 34.5 percent of the respondents were positive about the prospects at the time, while 37 percent were pessimistic.
According to a report on the survey results, the increased optimism is mainly because of the healthy development of Taiwan's democracy and justice system.

About 30 percent of the respondents said they have seen improvements in the justice system and 53 percent said that the crackdown on "black gold" politics has been effective since President Chen Shui-bian assumed office in May 2000.

According to the survey report, economic prosperity was chosen as the top priority by the poll respondents over the past four years, while political stability, personal security and administrative efficiency were also subjects of concern.
The survey results also show that 21 percent of the respondents wish to emigrate to escape the political chaos.
The United States and Canada are the favored destinations of 31 percent of those who want to get out of Taiwan, compared with 43 percent in a similar survey in December 2000.
The results also show that 21 percent would choose to emigrate to mainland China, compared to the previous year, when only 8.7 percent chose mainland China as their favored destination.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION LAWMAKERS TO TRIM NT $ 90.7 BILLION FROM 2002 FISCAL BUDGET

TEXT.P: Opposition alliance legislators tentatively decided Friday to insist that the Cabinet slash its fiscal 2002 budget by a further NT$90.7 billion (US$2.6 billion).

The opposition Kuomintang, People First Party and New Party lawmakers -- who together comprise the majority in the Legislative Yuan -- said that the Cabinet's estimate of government revenue for next year has been "seriously padded" and determined that expenditure will have to be adjusted if the budget is to be balanced.

Some of the items that the opposition lawmakers determined should be trimmed include the defense budget, the security personnel budget for former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui, personnel expenditures for the Ministry of the Interior and the budget for the largely superficial Taiwan Provincial Consultative Council.

However, ruling Democratic Progressive Party whip Tsai Huang-liang condemned the move and said that budget reviews should be conducted pragmatically item-by-item, with reasons given for each adjustment in accordance with each year's policy focus, instead of "irresponsibly" slashing the budget with one broad stroke.

Tsai said that his legislative caucus will consult the opposition parties before the budget undergoes its final review and added that lawmakers should not dogmatically follow the ratio of budget cuts in previous years as the benchmark for the upcoming year.

DOC.HEADLINE: MILITARY CHIEF STRESSES TRANSPARENCY IN PERSONNEL RESHUFFLE

TEXT.P: Chief of the General Staff Gen. Tang Yao-ming stressed Friday that transparency is the top operational guideline for military personnel reshuffles.
"No individual can single-handedly influence military personnel transfers or replacements," Tang said in response to press inquiries about a possible shakeup of the military brass in the near future.
Tang also said President Chen Shui-bian has so far not discussed any military personnel reshuffle plans with him.
"If President Chen brings up the issue with me, I would certainly request him to respect `military ethics' in any personnel reshuffle," said Tang.
Tang said he has on many occasions suggested to Chen that a two- or three-year tenure system be established for senior military positions.
"This is a practice widely adopted in advanced democratic countries," Tang said, adding that Chen supports his suggestion.

As the present Cabinet is expected to resign en masse before the inauguration of the new legislature in February 2002, speculation about various possible military personnel changes has been rife since the end of the Dec. 1 legislative elections.

Tang said that this speculation has smeared the military's clean image and he expressed worry that it might mislead other countries into perceiving that Taiwan's senior military officers are fond of power struggles and satisfying personal interests.
In reality, Tang said, most military officers and career soldiers are conscientious and harbor no grievances about their heavy workload.
"Unfounded speculation about personnel reshuffles is unfair and harmful to our military servicemen who have dedicated themselves to national service," Tang said.
Earlier in the day, at a seminar on the Republic of China's military buildup plan, Tang delivered a speech on the new direction of the country's military education.

Tang said Taiwan must invest generously in military education and take bold steps to rid the existing military educational system of obsolete practices or burdens in order to cultivate a new generation of military officers and talent.
Noting that the top goal of military education is to upgrade the quality of military cadres, Tang said military educational reform is critical to the ROC's ambitious military modernization plan.
In the face of the rapid development of information technology and the knowledge-based economy, Tang said Taiwan's military education must keep abreast of these prevailing trends.

"We must shed outdated shackles and use new thinking and new concepts in crafting a new military educational system for the new century in order to train a new generation of military cadres to meet the demand of the digital technology-characterized society," Tang said.

As Taiwan will become a formal member of the World Trade Organization at the beginning of the new year, Tang said, its military educational system must be compatible with general international trends.

Moreover, he continued, military educational institutions must strengthen cooperation and interaction with civilian educational and research institutions to make better use of the country's resources.
The military should also work out its special educational goals based on its own resources, unique features and demands, Tang added.

DOC.HEADLINE: CSC EMPLOYEES PROTEST AGAINST FORCED LAYOFFS

TEXT.P: The China Shipbuilding Corp. (CSC) will implement a "company re-adjustment" layoff program before the end of this year, despite resistance from those who will be forced into early retirement, a company spokesman said Friday.

Because the state-run enterprise's operational losses have accumulated to NT$10.5 billion in recent months, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) instructed the company to draft a "company re-adjustment program" -- a euphemism for personnel layoffs.
CSC then drafted a proposal to cut staff by 47 percent from over 5,000 to less than 2,800, while the survivors will face a 35 percent salary cut starting next year.
When the number of employees willing to accept early retirement failed to reach the target of 2,300, the CSC management made further selections based on performance and office attendance.

Many of those forced to retire questioned the fairness of the management. A total of 2,001 employees signed a petition to the Bureau of Labor Affairs of the Kaohsiung city government and representatives of the employees submitted the petition to the bureau Friday, hoping for a fair settlement.

The CSC spokesman said that 1,400 employees of the CSC's Kaohsiung shipyard and 900 employees of the Keelung shipyard will be laid off. Most of those on the layoff list have agreed to accept the pensions offered to them. As for the more-than 200 employees who refuse to be forced into early retirement, the Bureau of Labor Affairs should help find a settlement, he added.

According to the spokesman, the CSC management is compelled to carry out the layoffs because the MOEA requires the company to implement the program before it will grant CSC a special rescue fund, which will include money for the pensions, together with re-investment capital.

The Executive Yuan has agreed to set aside NT$9 billion as a CSC special pension fund. In order to improve the company operations, CSC has asked the Cabinet for another NT$6 billion for company reinvestment.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC CAN OBTAIN SUBMARINES THROUG VARIOUS CHANNELS: DEFENSE OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The Republic of China may add submarines to its defenses by combining purchases from overseas, working with foreign contractors through joint ventures, and building the vessels in Taiwan, a defense official said Thursday.

Chang Shih-po, an official in charge of military supplies at the Ministry of National Defense, pointed out in a symposium on "Submarines and security across the Taiwan Strait" that the ROC is a country heavily dependent on international trade, and open sea lanes are vital to its national security.
History is rifle with examples where blockades of shipping have been used to weaken an enemy or bring it to its knees, and submarines are an effective means to block shipping, Chang said.

Noting that Beijing has been aggressively building up its navy in recent years, Chang said the mainland has turned from a coastal navy to an ocean-faring one and now aspires to enhance its deep water capabilities.

In light of the fact that Beijing's navy boasts the world's third-largest submarine fleet, which is capable of blockading Taiwan, Chang said, it is urgent for the ROC to acquire a submarine deterrent to thwart any such attempts on Beijing's part.

Taipei has three options to acquire submarines, namely purchasing them from abroad, building them in cooperation with foreign contractors and building them on its own. Using the three options effectively will not only decrease the cost and shorten the time it takes to acquire the vessels, Chang said, but also boost the ROC's defense industry and improve defense technology.

Other scholars at the symposium said Washington's promise to sell eight diesel submarines to Taiwan provide the island a valuable chance to establish contacts with foreign defense contractors and develop its own submarine operations systems.
Taiwan has been denied this chance owing to its diplomatic isolation, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ASKS JAPANESE FOREIGN MINISTER TO RETRACT PRO-BEIJING REMARKS
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Dec. 28 (CNA) (By Amy Huang and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's representative to Japan demanded Friday that Japanese Foreign Minister Makiko Tanaka retract her remarks made Tuesday suggesting that she supported Taiwan's unification with mainland China using the formula applied to Hong Kong.

Lo Fu-chuan, who earlier lodged a protest to Japan for what he called Tanaka's interference in ROC domestic politics, demanded to know whether Tanaka's remarks signify a change in Tokyo's stance on the issue. Without taking sides, Tokyo has traditionally called for Taipei-Beijing issues to be handled through peaceful means.

Tanaka said Tuesday that she was hopeful that in the future, the Taiwan issue will turn out like Hong Kong. The former British colony reverted to mainland China in 1997 under a "one country, two systems" formula.

In his statement, Lo criticized Tanaka's remarks and expressed regret and indignation, stressing that the Republic of China on Taiwan is a sovereign nation, that Taiwan is not Hong Kong and that Taiwan's future must be decided by its 23 million residents.

Tanaka said at a news conference earlier Friday that when she said she hoped Taiwan could be like Hong Kong, she meant that the Hong Kong issue was resolved peacefully, and that she hopes the Taiwan issue will also be resolved through peaceful negotiations without the use of force.
Tokyo switched its diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing in 1972, when Tanaka's father was prime minister.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-HONG KONG AVIATION PACT RENEWED FOR SIX MONTHS

TEXT.P: Four private air carriers, two each from Taiwan and Hong Kong, exchanged memorandums of understanding Friday to renew the aviation pact between Taiwan and Hong Kong for another six months. The current agreement expires at the end of December.
The renewal means the 121 flights per week by each side between the two places will continue at least until the end of June.

This is the second time the pact has been renewed without being re-negotiated. It was renewed for six months before expiring June 12. The impasse stems from Taiwan's insistence to re-negotiate the pact by authorities of each side while Beijing insists on letting the four air carriers which fly the routes to make a deal on their own.
Taiwan denounced Beijing's refusal to open negotiations on the aviation pact as an attempt to debase the island.
More than four million passengers travel the Hong Kong-Taiwan route every year, which is three times the passenger load between Taiwan and the United States.
Taiwan is proposing to increase the flights by 49 per week, while Hong Kong wants an increase of 45 flights. No decision will be taken before negotiations are begun.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW ZEALAND VOLUNTEER HELPS CARE FOR ELDERLY TAIWAN PEOPLE

TEXT.P: Alan Hofet, a New Zealand national who traveled to Taiwan to work for an electric home appliances company 12 years ago, has dedicated himself to helping care for elderly Taiwan people on weekends and holidays.
Hofet, 35, said Friday that due to his longtime stay in Taiwan, he has been unable to take care of his own parents who are now in their 80s.
Therefore, Hofet said, he has turned his homesickness to dynamism to care for Taiwan's senior citizens.
Hofet recalled that he started with carrying heavy articles for elderly people he ran into on streets or leading them by hand on walks.
In the process, Hofet said he gradually found that some local elderly people need long-term assistance. In 1995, he began to help the elderly whenever he had free time.
At present, Hofet helps care for four elderly couples and a single senior citizen in Taipei County's Hsichi township on weekends.
Hofet said he has helped them clean their homes and make meals. Sometimes, he accompanies them to see doctors. Hofet said he also takes great pleasure in chatting with them.
"Voluntary services have enriched my life here," Hofet said, adding that he is gratified at seeing those elderly people lead more conformable lives with his assistance.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT WISHES ROC PEOPLE HAPPY NEW YEAR THROUGH E-CARD

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu wish the people of the Republic of China a happy new year in separate electronic greeting cards posted on the Presidential Office Web site, officials said.
According to the Presidential Public Affairs Office, the president and his wife also encourage the people to work together for Taiwan's growth and to create even more miracles.
Meanwhile, the vice president's greeting encourages the public to "treasure the present and innovate the future" while wishing for "love and peace" for all.
The e-cards can be viewed at www.president.gov.tw.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDEPENDENCE ACTIVISTS DEMAND JAPANESE APOLOGY FOR TANAKA'S REMARKS

TEXT.P: Scores of members of the Taiwan Independence Party (TAIP) staged a demonstration in front of the Kaohsiung Office of the Japanese Interchange Association (JIA) Friday to protest a Japanese official's remarks on Taiwan's future.

The demonstrators carried posters and banners protesting Japanese Foreign Minister Makiko Tanaka's recent remarks that she was hopeful that in the future, the Taiwan issue will turn out like Hong Kong. The former British colony reverted to mainland China's control in 1997 under a "one country, two systems" formula.

Lee Cheng-hsien, head of the TAIP chapter in the southern Taiwan port city, who led the demonstration, said Tanaka's remarks have seriously hurt the interests of the people of Taiwan, interfered with the island's domestic politics and undermined Taiwan's sovereign status.

Lee said Tanaka owes Taiwan's government and people an apology for her inappropriate statements, adding that Japanese Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi should also assume responsibility for his Cabinet member's improper remarks.

Stressing that Taiwan is an independent, sovereign state, Lee said Taiwan neither belongs to China nor to any other country. "Tanaka's remarks only betray her ignorance of Taiwan's history and the present situation across the Taiwan Strait," Lee lamented.

The demonstration ended after two JIA officials accepted the TAIP's protest letter. JIA is a quasi-official institution authorized by the Japanese government to handle exchanges with Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties.
The Republic of China government had already lodged a formal protest with Japan Wednesday over Tanaka's remarks.

On Friday, ROC Representative to Japan Lo Fu-chuan demanded that Tanaka retract her remarks made Tuesday suggesting that she supported Taiwan's unification with mainland China using the formula applied to Hong Kong.

Lo demanded to know whether Tanaka's remarks signify a change in Tokyo's stance on the issue. Without taking sides, Tokyo has traditionally called for Taipei-Beijing disputes to be resolved through peaceful means.

In his statement, Lo expressed regret and indignation at Tanaka's statement, stressing that the ROC on Taiwan is a sovereign nation, that Taiwan is not Hong Kong and that Taiwan's future must be decided by its 23 million residents.

Tanaka said at a news conference earlier Friday that when she said she hoped Taiwan could be like Hong Kong, she meant that the Hong Kong issue was resolved peacefully, and that she hopes the Taiwan issue will also be resolved through peaceful negotiations without the use of force.
Tokyo switched its diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing in 1972, when Tanaka's father was prime minister.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO EARTHQUAKES HIT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Taiwan was rattled by two earthquakes Friday, but no casualties or damage was reported, according to the Central Weather Bureau.

The first earthquake had a magnitude of 5.9 on the open end Richter Scale and occurred at 8:41 a.m. It was centered offshore 115.3 kilometers east of the Hualien seismological station in Hualien County.
It caused ground motion with an intensity of 3.0 on a scale from 1.0 to 7.0 in Ilan and Suao Harbor, and 2.0 in Hualien.

The second quake, with a magnitude of 4.6, took place at 6:40 p.m. The Central Weather Bureau determined that its epicenter was 1.4 kilometers east of its Tehchi seismological station in Taichung County.
The most violent ground motion prompted by the second quake was recorded in Tehchi and Hoping, in Hualien County, with an intensity of 3.0, the Central Weather Bureau said.
Ground motion with an intensity of 4.0 is capable of causing damage, and an intensity of 7.0 would cause destruction.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORLD TAIWANESE CONGRESS MEMBERS TO PREPARE FOR ANNUAL MEETING
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Dec. 27 (CNA) (By Chu Lu-sheng and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: Coordinating committee members and advisers of the World Taiwanese Congress (WTC) began arriving in Los Angeles Thursday to prepare for the group's second annual meeting to be held in Taipei in March.

The WTC is a Washington-based organization established last year to consolidate the powers of overseas Taiwanese communities to support the Republic of China government, to defend Taiwan's democracy and sovereignty, and to assist in the ROC government's international cultural exchanges.
Senior presidential adviser Yao Chia-wen is scheduled to attend the WTC working meetings slated for Jan. 4-6 to discuss Taiwan's current political situation.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DELEGATION TO BYPASS ARGENTINA ON TRADE MISSION

TEXT.P: A Taiwan trade promotion team scheduled to travel to Latin America in March will bypass Argentina owing to the chaotic situation unfolding in that country, according to an economics official Friday.
Instead, the team will visit Peru instead of Argentina. Its trips to Mexico, Brazil and Chile will remain unchanged, the official at the Ministry of Economic Affairs said.

Noting that the prospects for Argentina's economy are dim in the near future in light of the scarcity of hard currency and the surging unemployment in that country -- in addition to the presidential election in March -- officials said they are not sure the situation will stabilize before the trip by the Taiwan delegation in March.

The ministry's representative office in Argentina has been aware of the increased risk of doing business in Argentina over the last three years as the country's economy has been languishing. Many large companies have stopped paying their foreign debts, the official said.
The ministry also warned those in Taiwan doing business in Argentina to take into account the current political and economic situations in the country.

Many international trade fairs, slated to take place in Argentina next year, including an Asian trade fair scheduled for the first half of 2002, have either been canceled or postponed, the official said.
Taiwan regularly dispatches teams of trade officials and businessmen around the world to canvass business and investment for Taiwan.
In addition to the team going to Latin American, the Ministry of Economic Affairs will also send teams to Japan, the Middle East, Eastern Europe and the Commonwealth of Independent States next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: MERCY CORPS TO DISTRIBUTE TAIWAN'S RELIEF AID TO AFGHANISTAN

TEXT.P: A second shipment of humanitarian aid donated by the Republic of China to Afghan refugees will be distributed by the international charity, Mercy Corps, according to a statement released Friday by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

In the news release, the ministry said the US$2.5 million in relief goods are being transported in 41 shipping containers. The goods include rice, tents and blankets. The shipment to Afghanistan left Keelung Harbor Thursday and will be distributed to refugees in northern Afghanistan by Mercy Corps.
In addition to paying freight costs of US$237,000, the ROC government has also donated US$200,000 in cash to the Mercy Corps.
It is the second shipment of relief goods to Afghanistan from Taiwan.

The Mercy Corps, based in Portland, Oregon, is a private charitable organization founded in 1979 to aid refugees in Cambodia and now has expanded its operation to 73 countries around the world, according to the ministry.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Dec. 29, or the 15th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1808: Andrew Johnson, the 17th president of the United States, is born. He took over as president after Abraham Lincoln was assassinated.
1857: British and French troops take Canton, southern China.
1911: Dr. Sun Yat-sen is elected the first president of Asia's first democratic republic -- the Republic of China.
1921: The United States, Britain, France, Italy and Japan sign the Washington Treaty to limit naval armaments.
1924: John Davidson Rockefeller, an American oil magnate who amassed a great fortune through the Standard Oil Company, donates US$1 million to the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York.
1928: Chang Hsueh-liang pledges allegiance to the national government, thereby leading to the unification of China.
1931: The national government is reorganized, with Lin Sen as the new chairman.
1934: Japan renounces the Washington Treaty limiting naval armaments.
1938: Wang Ching-wei, who deserted the ROC government and left Chungking for Kunming on Dec. 18, issues a statement in Hanoi, Vietnam, advocating the termination of the War of Resistance against Japan and seeking peace with Japan.
1940: German bombers inflict the greatest damage on London since the Great Fire of 1666.
1948: The Executive Yuan appoints Chen Cheng as governor of the Taiwan Provincial Government.
1953: The Legislative Yuan revises the quorum for the National Assembly from the original one-half (1,523) to one-third (1,015) of the total number of members.
1968: The Yangtze River Bridge near Nanking, built by the Communist Chinese, is inaugurated.
1975: Some 100 scholars from Taiwan and abroad attend the Conference on Population and Economic Development. President Yen Chia-kan addresses the opening ceremony.
1980: Hsieh Kuo-cheng, Taiwan's so-called "father of baseball," dies at the age of 69.
1981: U.S. President Ronald Reagan announces a program of economic sanctions against the Soviet Union because of its alleged role in the imposition of martial law in Poland.
1981: Lee Tien-hui, who earned a mainland scholarship to study in the United States, defects and holds a press conference in Taipei.
1984: India's Congress-I Party, headed by Ragiv Gandhi, wins a landslide victory in India's general elections.
1986: Harold Macmillan, British politician, dies at the age of 92. As prime minister, he presided over the break-up of the British Empire.
1989: Vaclav Havel, a dissident Czechoslovakian philosopher, becomes the first elected non-Communist president without opposition.
1989: Thousands of Vietnamese refugees battle with riot police in Hong Kong.
1994: The first squadron of Ching-kuo indigenous defense fighters is officially commissioned, upgrading the combat ability of the ROC Air Force and demonstrating the initial results of local research and development.
1995: The Executive Yuan approves revised regulations governing the establishment of the Central News Agency.
1996: A peace accord is signed between the Guatemalan government and guerrilla leaders, ending 38 years of civil conflict and bringing Central America's last remaining and longest civil war to a close.
1999: Former ROC Minister of Education Lin Ching-chiang dies of respiratory failure at the age of 60.
2000: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung says that the government plans to spend NT$65.5 billion to create a total of 290,000 job opportunities within a year.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is the moral life of a neighborhood which constitutes its excellence. He is not an intelligent man, who, in choosing his residence, does not select a place with a moral surrounding."
