DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN THINK TANK TO BE INAUGURATED

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Think Tank, made up of scholars, industry leaders and government officials, is scheduled to be formally inaugurated Sunday to serve as a forum for public policy debates and policy formulation.

The group has already hosted eight forums over the past year with discussions ranging from government reform and financial reform to Taiwan's imminent official World Trade Organization entry on Jan. 1 of the new year.
According to the think tank, it will be a platform for dialogue between the government and the intellectuals of society that will host forums on various issues and offer feasible policy suggestions.
President Chen Shui-bian and Premier Chang Chun-hsiung are scheduled to attend the think tank's inauguration ceremony.

Think tank members include such heavyweights and supporters of the president as Taiwan Stock Exchange Chairman Lin Jong-shong, Land Bank of Taiwan Chairman Wea Chi-lin, Cathay Life Insurance Chairman Tsai Hong-tu, I-Mei Foods Chairman Kao Chih-shang, Evergreen Tokyu Chairman Lin Ming-cheng, Kinpo Electronics Chairman Hsu Sheng-hsiung, Jih Sun Group Chairman Chen Kuo-he, Mercuries and Associates CEO Chen He-tung, and Credit Suisse First Boston Taiwan Director Kung Chao-sheng.

Other think tank members are National Taiwan University College of Management Dean Ko Chen-en, National Security Council senior advisers Lin Chia-lung and Ko Cheng-heng, Cabinet Minister-without-Portfolio Hsu Chih-hsiung, Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park Administration Director-General James Lee and Taiwan Stock Exchange consultant Chen Hung-jung.

Consultants to the Taiwan Think Tank will include Presidential Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun, Council for Economic Planning and Development Chairman Chen Po-chih, Representative to Japan Lo Fu-chuan, Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh, National Palace Museum Director Tu Cheng-sheng, Presidential Adviser Byron Weng, National Taiwan University law professor Lee Hung-hsi, Cabinet Minister-without-Portfolio Hu Sheng-cheng, Taiwan Institute of Economic Research President Wu Rong-i, former Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Lin Yi-hsiung and Chi Mei Corp. Chairman Shi Wen-long.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S OIL PRODUCTS SUPPLIERS EXPECTING FIERCE COMPETITION

TEXT.P: With the liberalization of the oil products market starting next year, Taiwan's oil products suppliers are expecting fierce competition in the coming months, a spokesman of the Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) said Saturday.

The CPC is currently the biggest oil products supplier to domestic gas service stations, with around 1,600 gas stations around the island being supplied with CPC oil products. Formosa Petroleum Corp. (FPC) has contracts with 400 domestic gas service stations, while Taiwan's other gas service stations are supplied by imported products.

The Ministry of Economic Affairs announced this week that the domestic oil products market will be opened to imports starting next year. A total of 18 companies have submitted their applications to the ministry for wholesale licenses.
The giant international oil company Exxon-Mobil has partnered up with the Pan Overseas Corp. to supply gasoline to service stations in Taiwan.

A spokesman of the Pan Overseas Corp. said Friday that the company's newly built oil tanks at Taichung Harbor will be in use in two months and that the company will try to win supplying contracts from gas service stations around the island.
The gas service stations run by the CPC and FPC recently have launched a series of promotional campaigns, including offering discounts, holding lottery draws for sedans and giving away souvenirs.

Facing the impending fierce competition, some small gas stations have sought to improve their competitiveness by joining into alliances. More than 200 such gas service stations have signed contracts with the Taiwan-Up Alliance. The franchise will help the gas stations reduce their costs through joint procurement.
The Fair Trade Commission under the Executive Yuan announced last week that gas service stations are allowed to break their oil contracts and switch suppliers before the end of March, 2002.

The new measure will give oil supplying companies newly entering the Taiwan market a fair chance to compete. At the same, domestic gas service stations can expect more benefits from their suppliers, according to a spokesman of the commission.

DOC.HEADLINE: SCHOLARS CALL FOR REVISIONS TO LABOR STANDARDS LAW

TEXT.P: A group of local scholars urged the government Saturday to amend the Labor Standards Law to offer greater room and flexibility for employers and employees in negotiating working terms.

The academics made the appeal at a seminar on Taiwan's labor policy and labor-management disputes, sponsored by the opposition Kuomintang-affiliated National Policy Research Foundation and chaired by former Council of Labor Affairs Chairman Tsan Hou-sheng.
Chinese Culture University professor Yang Tung-hsuan said the Labor Standards Law is mainly designed to protect the rights and interests of the employee.

"But many provisions in the current law, enacted in 1984, are too rigid and strict on employers," Yang said, adding that some requirements, including demanding that employers pay for social insurance programs, would hinder local enterprises' competitiveness after Taiwan's accession to the World Trade Organization (WTO) at the beginning of 2002.

National Taiwan University professor Wu Chung-chi echoed Yang's words, saying that local companies must adjust their structures as well as their management and marketing strategies to cope with rapidly changing global economic trends after Taiwan's WTO entry.

"However, some existing Labor Standards Law provisions may hamper certain badly needed flexible adjustments," Wu said, adding that the law should be revised to ease restrictions on labor working terms.
By so doing, Wu said, employers and their employees will have greater room to negotiate commercially viable and mutually acceptable contracts.
Legislator-elect Chiu Yi, also an economist, said all labor-related laws should be made more flexible to allow labor and management to conduct rational consultations on working terms.

Chiu, a key member of the opposition People First Party, further said the Democratic Progressive Party government should refrain from manipulating the operations of various labor organizations so that labor unions can grow smoothly and become strong enough to negotiate with management on an equal footing to protect labor rights.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER URGES LAWMAKERS TO SUPPORT 2002 FISCAL BUDGET

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung urged lawmakers Saturday to support the 2002 fiscal budget, instead of slashing it, in order to help the government stimulate the economy by rolling out public projects.

Chang made his plea in response to the opposition legislative alliance's tentative decision made the previous day to trim the fiscal budget by a further NT$90.7 billion (US$2.6 billion) after accusing the Cabinet of "seriously padding" the projected government revenue for next year.

The premier said that his administration's efforts to promote public investments and create job opportunities would be dampened if a budget that was put together under already difficult circumstances was slashed even further.

Some of the items that the opposition lawmakers determined should be trimmed include the defense budget, the security personnel budget for former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui, personnel expenditures for the Ministry of the Interior and the budget for the largely superficial Taiwan Provincial Consultative Council.

Meanwhile, Chang said that the Ministry of Finance (MOF) will continue to coordinate and communicate with the heads of various cities and counties around the island on the ministry's plans to adjust the allocation ratios of tax redistribution funds.

Chang said that the draft proposal has yet to reach the Executive Yuan for approval and that he hopes the central and local governments can work together to tide over the difficult times for government finances by reaching an agreement on a mutually acceptable plan.

He was responding to media reports that the MOF has drafted a plan to lower the redistribution fund's allocation ratio for the two special municipalities from the current 43 percent to 36.22 percent for fiscal 2003 and that the percentage for other cities and counties will be raised to 45.72 percent from the present 39 percent.

If the plan is put into force, the two special municipalities -- Taipei and Kaohsiung -- will see a decrease of NT$10.6 billion (US$302 million) in their total tax redistribution funds, while other cities and counties will enjoy a NT$10.5 billion increase in redistribution funds.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA RECRUITING VOLUNTEERS TO WORK FOR ANTI-AIDS PROGRAM IN CHAD

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Saturday it will recruit volunteers with public health training backgrounds to work for an anti-AIDS program in the central African state of Chad.

MOFA officials said the ministry signed an agreement with Care France, a French charitable organization, in November, under which the Republic of China will offer a total of US$1.02 million over three years to finance an AIDS prevention and control program in Chad.

"The project is mainly aimed at establishing a nationwide comprehensive educational and publicity system in Chad in order to upgrade its people's awareness of the deadly disease and the major ways they can protect themselves from contracting AIDS, and to curb the spread of the disease," said a MOFA official.

To cultivate more diplomatic talent to facilitate Taiwan's participation in major international organizations and activities, the official said, the MOFA is cooperating with the Department of Health (DOH) in recruiting trained volunteers to work for the anti-AIDS program in Chad.

Those who have a bachelor degree or above in public health or who have participated in anti-AIDS field studies and can speak fluent French or English are welcome to register for the Chad program, the official said.
Registration will close Jan. 15. The MOFA and the DOH will jointly select qualified hopefuls to work in Chad for three months from February through mid-May 2002.
Hopefuls should e-mail their personal resumes to either the DOH Web site at yuchen@cdc.gov.tw or the MOFA address at unsec@mofa.gov.tw before the deadline.

DOC.HEADLINE: MEDICINE USING ANCIENT CHINESE RECIPE SAID GOOD FOR COLDS, CANCER

TEXT.P: An ancient Chinese recipe has been given new life in Newfoundland, Canada, as part of an alternative medicine for cancer sufferers and those with immune system diseases.

The product's name is "Ning," and it is being manufactured in the eastern Canadian province based on a recipe using Astragulus, a woody herb that grows in the mountains of Mongolia, according to Canada's national broadcaster.

The Canadian Broadcasting Corp. (CBC) said Friday that Ning is the brainchild of Xianging Chang and Robert Trenholm. Chang went to Newfoundland to pursue a master's degree in toxicology. She then joined up with Acta Herb to develop her research into Astragulus.

For years in China, the emperor and his family used Astragulus because they called it a superb herb tonic, the CBC quoted Chang as saying. He also noted that the herb has been used to treat people with kidney failure in China.

North Americans have been using Astragulus since the 1970s. But it has been used in tinctures and caplets, which Chang said are not very effective. The ancient Chinese infused the Astragulus root with warm water, much like a tea.

Chang uses an herbal distribution company in mainland China to farm the Astragulus. In Beijing, the active ingredients are dried into powder and packed into bags. Juice from sea buckthorn, a plant cultivated in Asia rich in vitamin A and vitamin C, is added to the mix.

In carrying out their research, Chang and Trenholm started experimenting with different formulas. One day, Trenholm began coming down with the flu and decided to take the concoction he had made that day. He said he was fine by the next day. Since then, the pair have stuck to that recipe.
However, Trenholm pointed out that the flavor may take some getting used to, saying that concoction has "a kind of rooty, earthy flavor to it with a citrus background."
Astragulus is good at boosting the immune system, Chang said, adding that the product works on everything from the common cold to asthma, arthritis and cancer.
"We have a lady who had asthma for five years and was using a puffer and some hormone products, but after she started taking this, she never needed the puffer again," Chang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SALE OF RED LABEL RICE WINE AT CURRENT PRICE ENDS DEC. 31

TEXT.P: The scene of people lining up to buy Red Label rice wine is expected to become a thing of the past as of Jan. 1, when the state-owned Taiwan Tobacco and Wine Board (TTWB) is set to hike the price of the popular kitchen staple more than fivefold.

According to the TTWB's latest figures, approximately 70 million bottles of Red Label rice wine, currently priced at NT$21 (US$0.60) per 0.6 liter bottle, have been sold over the past two months as consumers rush to stock up on the liquor, which is especially popular in the winter because it is a major ingredient in many Chinese hot stews.

Although the exact level of the price hike is not scheduled to be announced until the afternoon of the last day of this year, NT$90 (US$2.57) per bottle in taxes to be levied on the wine after Taiwan's World Trade Organization entry Jan. 1 will drive up the price to approximately NT$120 (US$3.42) per bottle.

The run on the liquor has led to record sales figures as people line up before TTWB distribution centers around the island to buy the wine, which began to be rationed at the end of last month such that each household can now only purchase a maximum of six bottles. Retail stores have also been having difficulty maintaining adequate supplies of the wine on their shelves due to the high demand.

According to the TTWB, all four of its production lines have been cranked into full gear, with the end result being that the number of bottles sold over the past two months actually exceeded the lines' maximum estimated total production capacity of 60 million bottles for that period by 10 million.

TTWB officials said that retailers can continue to sell Red Label rice wine produced before the end of this year after Jan. 1 but must do so at the current price. Stores found to be selling the wine at the new price will be fined NT$2,000 (US$57) per bottle sold, they warned, adding that any unsold bottles at the TTWB's own distribution centers by yearend will be rounded up to be repackaged under the new label that will replace the original one.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC LAWMAKERS DEMAND TANAKA APOLOGIZE FOR INAPPROPRIATE REMARKS
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Dec. 29 (CNA) (By Amy Huang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Three visiting Republic of China legislators demanded Saturday that Japanese Foreign Minister Makiko Tanaka apologize for her recent remarks on Taiwan's future.

The three female lawmakers from Taiwan's ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said they admire Tanaka's courage in pushing for bureaucratic reforms but regret her lack of international vision and knowledge about Taiwan's history and status.

The trio -- Tang Pi-o, Wang Li-ping and Chang Hsiu-chen -- said at a news conference that Tanaka owes the people of Taiwan an apology for her comment that she is hopeful that in the future, the Taiwan issue will turn out in a way similar to that of Hong Kong. The former British colony reverted to mainland China's rule in July 1997 under a "one country, two systems" formula.
Tang said Tanaka's remarks not only hurt the feelings of the people of Taiwan but also undermined Japan's national dignity.

Stressing that the future of Taiwan should be determined by the 23 million residents of the island in a democratic manner, Tang said Tanaka's statements marked a gross interference with Taiwan's domestic affairs and an infringement upon the ROC's sovereignty.
Moreover, Tang said, any issues between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should be resolved through peaceful consultations on an equal footing.
Tang reminded Tanaka never to forget that she is a Japanese foreign minister, not a mouthpiece of mainland China, whenever she addresses Taiwan-related issues.
Tang and her two colleagues arrived in Tokyo Friday night for a goodwill visit to promote parliamentary exchanges between the two countries.

"After our arrival, we decided to call an impromptu news conference this morning to voice our protests to the Japanese government over Tanaka's remarks and demand an apology from Tanaka herself," Tang said.
The ROC government already lodged a formal protest with Japan Wednesday over Tanaka's comments.

On Friday, ROC Representative to Japan Lo Fu-chuan demanded that Tanaka retract her remarks made Tuesday suggesting that she supported Taiwan's unification with mainland China using the formula applied to Hong Kong.

Lo demanded to know whether Tanaka's remarks signify a change in Tokyo's stance on the issue. Without taking sides, Tokyo has traditionally called for Taipei-Beijing disputes to be resolved through peaceful means.

In his statement, Lo expressed regret and indignation at Tanaka's statement, stressing that the ROC on Taiwan is a sovereign nation, that Taiwan is not Hong Kong and that Taiwan's future must be decided by its 23 million residents.

Tanaka said at a news conference earlier Friday that when she said she hopes Taiwan could be like Hong Kong, she meant that the Hong Kong issue was resolved peacefully, and that she hopes the Taiwan issue will also be resolved through peaceful negotiations without the use of force.
Tokyo switched its diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing in 1972, when Tanaka's father was prime minister.

DOC.HEADLINE: BOFT TO SET UP INTERNATIONAL TRADE OPPORTUNITY DATABANK

TEXT.P: The Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) has decided to make good use of trade information collected overseas and will establish a trade opportunity databank for use by Taiwan manufacturers.

BOFT officials said more than 100 overseas missions around the world each year collect valuable business information for Taiwan manufacturers to promote their trade overseas, adding that the missions have sent back 15,000 pieces of business information from July to November this year.

They said that such information will be sent to various business associations for Taiwan manufacturers. This is in contrast with past practices of directly channeling the information to the manufacturers, which risked having an adverse effect of creating cutthroat competition among the manufacturers.

Also, to prevent international groups from spreading fraudulent trade information or mainland Chinese manufacturers trying to cheat Taiwan manufactures with false orders, the China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) will also establish a databank of international groups known to have committed fraud for the reference of the domestic private sector.

In addition, as overseas manufacturers have complained that overseas credit checks are difficult to obtain, the CETRA and Export-Import Bank of the Republic of China will help domestic manufacturers check overseas company credit ratings to reduce the financial risk to the manufacturers.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BUSINESSMEN IN MAINLAND BECOMING AWARE OF POLITICAL RISKS (I)

TEXT.P: Beijing's censorship of text books used in Taiwanese schools in mainland China and the formation of Chinese Communist cells in Taiwanese corporations in mainland China have driven home to Taiwanese businessmen the political risk of doing business across the Taiwan Strait.
Their worries are deepening as their position as the powerhouses behind much of the economic development in the mainland is being eroded by the encroachment of multinational investors.

The first signs that Beijing was closing the political noose around the necks of Taiwan businessmen appeared last year when Lee Bingcai, deputy director of the Taiwan Affairs Office of the State Council, warned that Beijing authorities would not let Taiwan businessmen "make money in mainland China while supporting Taiwan independence at home."

Since then, several Taiwan corporations considered by Beijing to be supporters of Taiwan independence have seen their mainland Chinese subsidiaries harassed by local authorities under the pretext of account audits, fire safety inspections and others.

These moves have frightened Taiwan businessmen who operate in mainland China into staying out of politics in Taiwan. They have also bent over backward to stay out of political disputes between Taipei and Beijing after ties between them became strained over Beijing's claim that Taipei had reneged on its agreement to the "one China" principle.

A Taiwanese executive at a Taiwan-funded electronics company in Guangdong province, southern China, said Taiwan businessmen who ventured into mainland China because of the economic advantages there have failed to take into account the political risks that accompany their investments.

The risks, brought about by the five-decade political tussle between Taiwan and mainland China, include the potential for assets of Taiwan companies in mainland China to be commandeered or confiscated according to whichever way the current political wind is blowing over the Taiwan Strait.

Other concerns include the threat of open hostilities between the two and the ever-present negative reactions by Beijing to nearly all efforts of Taiwan to position itself in the international community. (MORE)

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BUSINESSMEN IN MAINLAND BECOMING AWARE OF POLITICAL RISKS (II)

TEXT.P: The Taiwanese executive, who has been posted to Guangdong for five years, said Taiwan businessmen have learned to refrain from getting embroiled in any controversial political issues after Lee's warning -- despite the fact that none of them have been forced to denounce in public any support for Taiwan independence that they may have.

Actually, most Taiwan businessmen operating in mainland China are investing there under the name of companies registered in countries other than Taiwan, such as Samoa, or the Virgin Islands, as a shield against political risks.

Another financial manager for a Taiwan-funded business in Guangdong province said the financial management of his company was based overseas, funneling into mainland China no more funds than are needed for a month at a time.
The advantage of having a financial base out of both Taiwan and mainland China is to transfer assets easily out of mainland China in case of trouble, he said.

Media reports that the Chinese Communist Party is penetrating into Taiwan companies in mainland China and is wooing Taiwan businessmen to join the party have become a hot topic of discussion among Taiwan businessmen in mainland China recently.
Chang Han-wen, president of the Taiwan Businessman's Association in Dongguan, Guangdong province, said he doubts any Taiwan businessmen will ever succumb to Beijing's lure.
Instead of improving business in mainland China, membership in the Chinese Communist Party will make things more difficult for Taiwan businessmen, Chang said.
Chiang Yan-hsiung, president of the same association in Shenzhen, Guangdong province, said most Taiwan businessmen have gone into mainland China on the basis of "all business, no politics."
Membership in the Chinese Communist Party would not necessarily help Taiwan businessmen in mainland China, Chiang said.
Many working for Taiwan companies' mainland subsidiaries are communists but they don't enjoy any privileges that are not afforded non-communists in the workplace, Chiang said.

Another Taiwan businessmen, identified only by his surname, Lin, dismissed the possibility of political risks, saying that Beijing's admittance into the World Trade Organization will force the country to adopt the rule of law.

He said that the days when good connections with the upper political crust made the difference in business circles will gradually disappear. Moreove, Taiwan businessmen will be shielded from political risks as will be the case with any other investor from another country.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT LEGISLATIVE CAUCUS ASKS GOV'T TO USE BUDGET FAIRLY

TEXT.P: The government must adhere to the budget as decided upon by the Legislative Yuan and not use the funds for any other purpose than how the money is to be allocated, a spokesman for the opposition Legislative caucus said Sunday.

Ho Chih-hui, representative of the KMT Legislative caucus, said that opposition parties have decided to cut NT$90.7 billion from the budget as it views this as political largesse needlessly added by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party government.
The government, therefore, should use the budget in accordance with decisions made by the Legislative Yuan, Ho said.
The Legislative Yuan is now screening national budget proposalfor fiscal 2002.

Ho said that the opposition parties have decided to cut the NT$90.7 billion from the budget because the amount earmarked by the government was not in accordance with the figures released by government agencies' projections.

He further pointed out that the budget as proposed by the government would result in a surplus of NT$200 billion. He said that the unrealistic revenue surplus was "false and empty." To prevent the government from using the extra money for purposes not authorized in the budget, the Legislature will adopt a resolution to prohibit the government from using the funds for other purposes, Ho said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CHARITY GIVES OUT US$1.78 BILLION TO U.S. TERRORIST VICTIMS
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Dec. 29 (CNA) (By Eric Tseng and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan-based charity, the Buddhist Compassionate Relief Tzu Chi Foundation, closed the last two of its three relief distribution centers in New York and New Jersey Friday after giving out US$1.78 million in aid to relatives and families of victims of the Sept. 11 attacks in New York.

A worker for Tzu Chi in New York said Saturday that families of the victims can now apply for grants from the foundation's New York branch office, although its has closed its relief distribution centers at the Chinese Benevolent Association of New York and the 94th Wharf.

The relief distribution center at the 94th Wharf opened on Sept. 19 and gave out US$1.36 million in aid to those affected in the Sept. 11 attacks on New York's World Trade Center before it closed Friday.
The distribution center in New Jersey opened on Sept. 18 and gave out US$263,650 before closing Friday.

Another center at the Chinese Benevolent Association of New York, which opened on Oct. 24 and closed on Nov. 30, gave out US$157,125 in relief to 815 persons, mainly overseas Chinese living near the World Trade Center, and having lost their jobs after the terrorist attacks.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN THINK TANK TO SERVE AS PLATFORM FOR DIALOGUE: PRESIDENT CHEN

TEXT.P: Taiwan must step up its pace in recruiting talent and the establishment of the Taiwan Think Tank is to serve as a platform for dialogue and integration between the government and the private sector, President Chen Shui-bian said Sunday.

Delivering a speech at the inauguration of the Taiwan Think Tank, a body composed of heavyweights from the government, industrial and academic sectors to provide the government with feasible policy suggestions, Chen said cultivating local talent and introducing foreign elites is Taiwan's top priority at present amid fierce global competition and severe challenges in ties with mainland China.

Taiwan Think Tank members include Taiwan Stock Exchange Chairman Lin Jong-shong, Land Bank of Taiwan Chairman Wea Chi-lin, Cathay Life Insurance Chairman Tsai Hong-tu and Credit Suisse First Boston Taiwan Director Kung Chao-sheng.

The president said he hopes the formation of the think tank will help forge an alliance between the government and the private sector and serve as a platform for dialogue and cooperation between the two sides in the current knowledge-based era.

Expressing his highest respect for the Taiwan Think Tank, Chen said independent and sound think tanks are indispensable partners of the government in formulating efficient policies. He called on all Taiwan's think tanks to play a role to bridge the government and the private sector in integrating talent and resources to help the government push for Taiwan's rapid progress and reform.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO DEAL WITH MAINLAND BASED ON WTO FRAMEWORK: MAC OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Taiwan will deal with mainland China based on parity and reciprocity after becoming a member of the World Trade Organization (WTO) on Tuesday, an official in charge of mainland affairs said Sunday.

Chen Ming-tung, vice chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), which is Taiwan's top mainland policy-making agency, said Taiwan will conduct exchanges with the mainland under the WTO framework and will respect all WTO arbitration.

Regarding a media report which cited ranking government officials as saying Taiwan will not open up its markets to mainland China in the short term, Chen was reluctant to comment and stressed only that "admissions of both sides to the WTO is just a beginning and that Taiwan will not create problems by bringing political issues into the international trade regulatory body."
The MAC vice chairman made the remarks at a seminar sponsored by the Taiwan Daily newspaper.
Local media has reported that Taiwan will not allow in mainland China's agricultural and service products for the time being after the island enters the WTO on Tuesday.

Taiwan was allowed to join the WTO on Jan. 1, 2002 as the world trade regulatory body's 144th member state at a ministerial meeting in Doha, Qatar in November. Mainland China entered the WTO in mid-December.

DOC.HEADLINE: VINCENT SIEW SAYS HE WILL NOT JOIN TAIWAN THINK TANK

TEXT.P: Former Premier Vincent Siew, who is now vice chairman of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT), stressed Sunday that he will not join the newly inaugurated Taiwan Think Tank.
The former premier made the remarks after attending the inaugural ceremony of the consultative group.
Siew said that Taiwan is developing into a multipurpose society and the establishment of more think tanks was good for the country.
He said that he just attended the ceremnony as a private individual, not as member of a political party.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO POLITICAL INTERFERENCE IN GIO EMBLEM CHANGING

TEXT.P: No political interference was encountered in the changing of the Goverment Information Office (GIO) emblem, Su Tzen-ping said Sunday.
Su, GIO director-general, ruled out political influence as a cause of the change, saying: "Actually, the new emblem was voted for by our staff."
"It was through democratic process," Su emphasized.
The old emblem shows a national flag of the Republic of China over a map of China, which the new one replaces with the acronym of GIO -- three letters crossed in the middle by a bridge.
Asked if the change symbolizes "de-sinicization," Su said that question never came under consideration and the bridge in the new emblem implies better communication to meet the need of "our time."

"We believe the bridge symbolizes better international communication and understanding," Su answered the press query at an inaugural ceremony for the Taiwan Think Tank at Far Eastern Plaza Hotel in Taipei.
The new emblem comes into use Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: BANKS IN TAIWAN GEARING UP FOR EURO SWITCH

TEXT.P: Banks in Taiwan are gearing up for the euro in cash, the single currency which will enter into general circulation in the 12-member European Union on Jan. 1.
All domestic and foreign banks are ready to deal with the introduction of euro banknotes and coins, a banking industry source said Sunday.
The new currency will arrive in Taiwan on Jan. 2, the source said. "The ICBC (International Commercial Bank of China)," he said, "will start selling and buying a day earlier, on New Year's Day."
Only the ICBC branch office at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport will exchange the cash euro Tuesday.

Starting Tuesday, euro banknotes and coins will circulate in all banks, post offices, shops and automatic transfer machines in Austria, Belgium, France, Finland, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, Portugal and Spain.

Three foreign banks in Taipei -- the Hong Kong and Shanghai Banking Corp., Citibank, N. A. and ABN AMRO Bank -- will change into the euro all European currencies their clients have in deposit, the source said.
Minister of Finance Yen Ching-chang described the euro switch as a factor conducive to world trade and the global financial market.

Eugenio Domingo Solans, an executive board member of the European Central Bank, said during a recent visit to Taipei that the single monetary unit will help Taiwan companies reduce risks of currency exchanges and make trips to the euro zone easier.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAID-OFF WORKERS TO CONTINUE SIT-IN PROTEST AGAINST CSC

TEXT.P: More workers laid off by the China Shipbuilding Corp.(CSC) will join in a sit-in in protest against summary dismissal Monday, the same day the debt-ridden state enterprise starts its cost-cutting restructuring.
The CSC has sacked over 2,400 workers and cut by 35 percent the pay for the remaining staff under its restructuring program.
"Come Monday, many of us will join ranks with those who started the sit-in in front of the CSC offices," a leader of a hastily formed group of laid-off workers said Sunday.
Dozens of sacked workers began the sit-in last week.
"It's going to be a long struggle," said the former work gang leader who spoke for the "Self-Help Alliance of Laid-Off Workers" under condition of anonymity.
He accused the management of "summary dismissal without transparency."
The dismissed workers should not "overreact," a CSC spokesman said. The restructuring will proceed as scheduled, he stressed.
Most of the laid-off workers have asked for their severance pay, which they can start collecting Tuesday, the spokesman added.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT LU GIVES EMPHASIS ON IDEA OF "ONE CHINESE RACE"

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said here Sunday that she believes all people of Chinese ancestry are willing to accept the idea of "one Chinese race."

Addressing a ceremony aimed at promoting traditional Chinese culture and arts, Lu said people of Chinese ancestry, "no matter whether they are in Taiwan or abroad," would be willing to accept the idea of "one Chinese race." She expressed the hope that people on Taiwan and the Chinese mainland, who have common Chinese racial and cultural connections, will work together for a bright and beautiful future.
Lu emphasized that the idea of "one Chinese race," or "one Chung Hwa" in Chinese, is a good basis for building a normal cross-strait relationship.
She hoped that Beijing would no longer insist on its "One China principle," which is not acceptable to the people of Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATURE TO ACT ON PARENT SUPPORT BILL

TEXT.P: People will be sent to jail or fined, if they fail to provide for their parents, according to a bill a Legislative Yuan committe will act on Monday.
New Party Legislator Lai Shih-bao, who initiated the bill, said Sunday his Judiciary Committee will start legislative action on the last day of the year.
If passed, the parent support act will make it mandatory for the court of law to sentence offenders to one year in prison or fine them not more than NT$200,000.
Over 150,000 people above 65 years of age in Taiwan are not sufficiently provided for, Lai said. Many of them have children, who do not want to support them, he added.
The bill is crafted to assure the unsupported elder citizens of a life with dignity they deserve in a society where filial piety is valued, Lai said.
Under the bill, the court may order employers to withhold the allowances for parents of their employees.
Legislator Tsai Huang-lang, Democratic Progressive whip at the Legislative Yuan, said his party supports the bill. "We are looking forward to its passage before the end of this session," he added.
The current session closes on Janaury 18.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANTI-JAPANESE SENTIMENT IN MAINLAND CHINA STILL HIGH

TEXT.P: A savage attack on actress Vickie Zhao Wei in Changsha reflects a high anti-Japanese sentiment in mainland China, according to media reports in Hong Kong Sunday.

Vickie Zhao Wei, who wore a mini-dress printed with Japan's naval ensign in a fashion show in New York early this month, was grabbed by the neck and poured with a small amount of human waste by a middle-aged man Friday evening when she was singing on stage in a live TV show in Changsha, capital of Hunan province in central China.

Scholars in Changsha and Hong Kong were quoted by the press as saying many people in mainland China became unhappy when they saw her picture taken in the fashion show, believing that she wore the dress to please the Japanese. The picture was reprinted recently by a mainland Chinese fashion magazine.

People in mainland China, particularly those in Changsha and Nanjing where hundreds of thousands were massacred by the Japanese invasion army at the end of 1937, still have hostile feeling against Japan, the Hong Kong press said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Dec. 31, or the 17th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1799: The Dutch Administration in Batavia (now Jakarta) takes over the Dutch East India Company's territories in Indonesia.
1879: Thomas A. Edison, American inventor, demonstrates for the first time his electric incandescent light at Menlo Park, New Jersey.
1880: George Marshall, U.S. Army general and statesman, is born. As secretary of state, he devised the Marshall Plan for post-war economic recovery in Europe.
1909: The Manhattan Bridge, a two-section suspension bridge, is opened to traffic in New York.
1915: Yuan Shih-kai, who promised to establish a republican government when he assumed the provisional presidency of the Republic of China, orders the restoration of the imperial system, with himself on the throne, beginning from 1916.
1919: The United States, Britain, and Japan sign an agreement on East Siberia.
1924: Dr. Sun Yat-sen, who had fallen ill earlier, arrives in Peking from Tientsin to hold talks with Tuan Chi-jui, provisional chief executive of the Peking-based government. While in Peking, Dr. Sun succumbed to liver cancer and died on March 25, 1925.
1946: U.S. President Harry S. Truman officially proclaims the end of World War II.
1946: Chiang Kai-shek reiterates the government's policy of continuing attempts to settle disputes with the communists by political means.
1946: Chang Hsueh-liang, the commander of the Northeastern Army who played a key role in the kidnapping of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek in Xian, is escorted to Taiwan and put under house arrest at the Chingshang hot spring in Hsinchu. The Xian Incident was a severe setback to Chiang's efforts to subjugate the communists.
1956: President Sukarno proclaims a state of siege in Sumatra, Indonesia.
1964: President Sukarno threatens to quit the United Nations if Malaysia is given a seat on the Security Council.
1971: Kurt Waldheim of Austria takes over as the United Nations secretary-general after U Thant retired.
1975: More than 1,600 foreign students present an autographed album to Premier Chiang Ching-kuo at a year-end meeting.
1976: Education Minister Y. S. Tsiang hosts a dinner to honor foreign students and visiting professors at the Chientan Youth Activity Center with more than 1,000 students and teachers from 30 countries attending.
1977: Cambodia breaks off diplomatic relations with Vietnam and suspends all air services between the two countries.
1979: The Sino-U.S. Mutual Defense Treaty against the Chinese communists in the area is ended.
1983: The United States deploys Cruise missiles and Pershing II missiles in Britain and West Germany.
1985: The Taipei World Trade Center is inaugurated.
1988: Indian Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi and Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto sign the first agreement between India and Pakistan in 16 years, agreeing not to attack each others' nuclear facilities.
1991: All senior delegates to the ROC's First National Assembly, Control Yuan, and Legislative Yuan retire from office.
1996: Taiwan Provincial Governor James Soong submits his resignation to Premier Lien Chan.
1997: Mohammed Rafiq Tarar becomes the ninth president of Pakistan.
1998: Finance ministers of the European Union announce definite rates for converting the currencies of the 11 nations due to launch the single euro currency on Jan. 1, 1999.
1999: President Lee Teng-hui calls for increased constructive dialogue between the two sides of the Taiwan Straits on an equal footing so as to contribute to peace and stability in the Asia-Pacific region.
2000: President Chen Shui-bian calls on Beijing leaders to try to break through the existing cross-strait stalemate with open-mindedness and forward-looking vision so as to jointly establish a mechanism for permanent peace and political integration of Taiwan and the mainland.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is only men of moral character who know how to love men or to hate men. If you fix your mind upon a moral life, you will be free from evil."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Monday are as follows:
The China Times:
Key criminal suspect arrested after gun fight.
The United Daily News:
Six ASEAN nations will mutually remove tariffs from the beginning of the new year.
The Liberty Times:
The newly formed Taiwan Thinktank expected to be President Chen Shui-bian's brain trust.
The Taiwan Daily:
City officials to present new tax redistribution fund proposals.
The Central Daily News:
KMT Chairman Lien Chan steps up recruiting talent into the party.
The China Post:
Taiwan Think Tank established under President Chen's push.
The Taiwan News:
President Chen inaugurates Taiwan Thinktank.
The Taipei Times:
President Chen helps create Taiwan Thinktank.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Jan. 1, or the 18th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
44BC: Julius Caesar, founder of the Roman Empire, introduces the Julian calendar.
1622: The papacy adopts Jan. 1 as the beginning of the new year, instead of March 25.
1814: Hung Siu-tsuen, Chinese leader of the Taiping rebellion, is born. He would proclaim himself emperor Jan. 1, 1851.
1863: U.S. President Abraham Lincoln issues the Emancipation Proclamation during the American Civil War, declaring the freedom of all slaves in the rebelling southern states.
1886: Britain annexes Upper Burma.
1901: The Commonwealth of Australia is established.
1912: The Republic of China is founded, with Dr. Sun Yat-sen as the first provisional president.
1912: The lunar calendar is officially replaced by the Gregorian calendar in China.
1916: Yuan Shih-kai, unmoved by the opposition of the Kuomintang, declares himself emperor and accepts congratulations from officials at the Hsinhua Palace in Beijing.
1923: The Union of Soviet Socialist Republics is proclaimed.
1927: The Nationalist government is established at Hankow in China.
1928: China's Nationalist government orders Chiang Kai-shek to continue the Northward Expedition.
1934: Republic of China government troops launch an all-out offensive against communist rebels in Fukien.
1942: A total of 26 nations, including the ROC, sign the "Joint Declaration of the United Nations" in Washington, D.C., affirming opposition to the Axis powers.
1947: The ROC government promulgates the ROC Constitution.
1949: ROC President Chiang Kai-shek, in a New Year's Day message to the nation, expresses his wish for a peaceful settlement to the nationalist-communist dispute.
1951: Taiwan's first man-made rain experiment is carried out at Sun-Moon Lake in Nantou County.
1951: Communist Chinese and North Korean forces break through U.N. lines at the 38th parallel dividing North and South Korea.
1966: U.S. Vice President Hubert H. Humphrey arrives in the ROC to confer with Chinese leaders.
1973: Dr. Edward Teller, known as "the father of the hydrogen bomb," arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1978: The Yuanshan cantilever bridge on the North-South Freeway is opened to traffic.
1979: The United States and Communist China set up diplomatic ties, 30 years after the founding of the People's Republic of China.
1988: Registrations for new newspapers in Taiwan begin, and restrictions on the number of pages per issue are relaxed.
1994: Communist Chinese authorities annul the double-track exchange rate system for the renminbi and stop issuing foreign exchange notes.
1995: The southern common market, an economic union of Brazil, Argentina, Uruguay and Paraguay, is formally established.
1999: Member nations of the European Union adopt the euro as their common currency.
2000: Premier Vincent Siew announces that Taiwan has weathered any threats posed by Y2K and has successfully marched into the new millennium.
2001: Renowned Taiwan musician and composer Hsu Tsang-houei dies of illness at Taipei's Veterans General Hospital at the age of 72.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Riches and honors are objects of men's desire; but if I cannot have them without leaving the path of duty, I would not have them. Poverty and a low position in life are objects of men's dislike; but if I cannot leave them without departing from the path of duty, I would not leave them."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES UP BY 152.96 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) gained ground on Monday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving up 152.96 points to close at 5,551.24.
Market turnover amounted to NT$140.48 billion (US$4.01 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high and closed even higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 152.96 points to close at 5,551.24.
The bourse opened at 5,481.07 and fluctuated between 5,583.82 and 5,477.53 during trading.

A total of 4.34 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$140.48 billion (US$4.01 billion), an increase from the previous trading session which saw 4.01 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$123.35 billion (US$3.52 billion).

All the eight major stock categories gained ground, with foodstuff shares moving up the most at 4.1 percent, followed by electrical stocks at 3.4 percent, plastics and chemical shares and construction stocks, both at 2.5 percent, cement stocks at 2.4 percent, textile issues at 2.3 percent, pulp and paper issues at 2 percent, and bank and insurance shares at 1.2 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 548 to 71, with 49 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market were higher Monday as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for next January moved up 198 points to close at 5,598, with 14,945 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for next February rose 226 points to close at 5,589, with 43 contract transactions, while next March futures surged 239 points to finish at 5,592, with six contracts traded.
Next June futures increased 84 points to close at 5,699, with five contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 5,400 for next January, 5,363 for next February, 5,353 for next March, 5,615 for next June, and 5,450 for next September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also higher.

Next January TE futures moved up 11.7 points to close at 297, with 3,386 contract transactions, while next February TE futures increased 10.05 points to finish at 296, with 12 contracts changing hands.
No transactions were reported for other months.
Next January TF futures moved up 11 points to finish at 733, with 3,065 contract transactions, while next February TF futures increased 11 points to close at 741, with three contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: SCHOLARS QUESTION SENSATIONALISTIC ETHICS IN CURRENT JOURNALISM

TEXT.P: Recent stories reported by the media in Taiwan show that sensationalism has become so pervasive that many analysts are wondering if the ethics of the media has slipped into the realm of yellow journalism.

Professor Yang Chih-hung, dean of the Journalism School of Ming Chuan University, said recently that "Next" magazine, a weekly serving a mishmash of sex, gossip and paparazzi-style "exposes," is having a negative knock-on effect on Taiwan's media ethics.

Yang said that the print and electronic media in Taiwan have resorted more and more to covering what passes as news with sensational embellishment since the appearance of "Next" magazine in late May 2001. Even the mainstream media have been dragged down to the level of pandering to the lowest denominator by the "contamination" of "Next," Yang contended.

The professor suggested that a media regulatory organization be created to monitor and discipline the media. As commercialization finds its way into reporting, ethics stand to suffer, according to the scholar.

Professor Lo Wen-hui of National Chengchi University said that local media is providing more coverage of gossip about celebrities because the public finds it entertaining. He said that he was not convinced that "Next" magazine should shoulder the blame for the current atmosphere in the media.

James Jin, chairman of the Magazine Business Association of Taipei, said that at the association's next board meeting on Jan. 4, 2002, he would raise the issue of self-discipline among magazine owners and editors.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOF ISSUES OPERATIONAL CERTIFICATES FOR 7 FINANCIAL HOLDING CO.

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Finance (MOF) issued operational certificates Monday to seven financial holding companies, the first batch of its kind in Taiwan.

The seven financial holding companies are the First Financial Holding Company, Taishin Financial Holding Company, E. Sun Financial Holding Company, Chiao Tung Financial Holding Company, Shin Kong Financial Holding Company, Jih Sun Financial Holding Company, and Fuh-Hwa Financial Holding Company.

The First Financial Holding Company topped the list of capital assets with NT$1,228 billion, followed in order by the Chiao Tung Financial Company, at NT$565.3 billion, Taishin Financial Holding Company, at NT$554 billion, Shin Kong Financial Holding Company, at NT$506.6 billion, E Sun Financial Holding Company, at NT$259.8 billion, Jih Sun Financial Holding Company, at NT$205.9 billion and Fuh-Hwa Financial Holding Company, at NT$67.5 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: GIO RELEASES NEW FILM ON NATIONAL ANTHEM

TEXT.P: The Government Information Office (GIO) released a new film Monday about the Republic of China's national anthem, featuring the vitality of the people in Taiwan.
Addressing the presentation ceremony, GIO Director-General Su Tzen-ping said the film will be shown to the public starting Tuesday, New Year's Day.

Instead of showing state-of-the-art weapons and uniformed armed forces, Su said, the film is a mixture of old documents and new shots to present Taiwan's past and the endeavors of its people. People from all walks of life -- such as school children, tea-picking girls, soldiers on disaster relief missions, factory workers and baseball players -- all appear in the film, he added.
The film aims to awaken a collective emotion of love for Taiwan through a connection between the past and the present.
The film was directed by Lin Cheng-sheng and the Su hailed him realizing a vivid crystallization of Taiwan's vigor.
Lin, only a junior high-school graduate, was given the Silver Bear Award for best director at this year's Berlin Film Festival.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SET TO EMBRACE WTO MEMBERSHIP DESPITE CHALLENGES (I)

TEXT.P: After over a decade of persistence, Taiwan will finally become a full member of the World Trade Organization (WTO) Jan. 1, 2002, and officials say that although there may be some stormy seas for several economic sectors, for the most part, WTO membership will be clear sailing in the long run for the island.

Individual consumers, in particular, will benefit most from the historic event. Nevertheless, WTO entry will certainly have an adverse impact on certain fields of the domestic economy, including agriculture, traditional industries, the automobile industry and even the information technology industry.
On the eve of the anticipated changes in Taiwan's economic landscape, many local people still have mixed feelings about the Taiwan's membership in the Geneva-based world trade regulatory body.

In an effort to allay public misgivings and suspicions about the possible negative impacts, Ho Mei-yueh, vice chairwoman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, said at a seminar Dec. 30 that WTO entry will enable Taiwan to trade with more than 140 other countries around the world on an equal footing.

Noting that Taiwan relies heavily on foreign trade, with the total amount of exports and imports exceeding the island's annual gross domestic product (GDP), Ho said WTO entry will help ensure equal trading status and benefits for Taiwan.
"In the past, our major trading partners didn't adopt discriminatory measures against us mainly because they thought that Taiwan would eventually become a WTO member," Ho explained.
After decades of operations, Ho said, the WTO has developed a comprehensive, binding mechanism for regulating international trading practices and resolving trade disputes.

"WTO accession will offer Taiwan a formal channel through which to consult with other members in forging new trade deals and settling trade disputes," Ho said, adding that the WTO mechanism will facilitate Taiwan's trade expansion and globalization.
More importantly, Ho said, WTO membership will allow Taiwan to have a say in the formulation of new international trade rules and regulations.

Because of mainland China's diplomatic embargo, Taiwan has been unable to join the United Nations. Ho said a seat in the WTO, which is known as the "economic United Nations," will be conducive to helping upgrade Taiwan's international profile.

Touching on the price Taiwan will have to pay for its WTO accession, Ho said that superficially, the island may lose a huge amount of tariff revenues as it must lower import duties on more than 5,000 agricultural and industrial items in the first year after entry.

"The impact, however, will be manageable," Ho said. "Among the products to be subject to tariff reductions, the average tariff rate for over 2,000 industrial items will be lowered by only 0.25 percentage points, from the current 6.03 percent to 5.78 percent."

Ho admitted that the imminent tariff cuts will have a greater impact on domestic farmers as the average customs duty rate for 3,000-plus agricultural items will be slashed from the present 21 percent to 14 percent.

As for traditional labor-intensive industries, Ho said, Taiwan secured assurances during the WTO negotiations process to protect its manufacturers in certain fields. For example, Taiwan is entitled, if necessary, to impose a 5 percent flexible hike on its tariff rate for ready-to-wear clothing. In addition, Taiwan will have a grace period of up to three years to implement a zero tariff policy on paper pulp and steel imports.

Taiwan began to allow compact car imports in 1997. The quota for compact car imports is set at 10,000 for 2002, with the tariff rate to be lowered from the current 30 percent to 29 percent. "The impact should be limited," Ho said. More than 9,900 foreign compact cars entered the Taiwan market this year.

In fact, Ho said, the market share of locally built automobiles has increased to 80 percent from 60 percent recorded before Taiwan opened its car market, thanks to domestic automakers' strenuous efforts toward presenting vehicles with styles and options catering especially to the tastes of local consumers. (To be continued)

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SET TO EMBRACE WTO MEMBERSHIP (II)

TEXT.P: Turning to the service sector, Ho said, Taiwan has agreed to ease restrictions on personnel and capital movements and use of land for foreign investors in all service-related fields.

Nevertheless, Ho said Republic of China nationals will still have niches in the domestic service markets. Despite opening the market, 70 percent of radio and television programs as well as 20 percent of cable TV programs must be produced in Taiwan.

For educational services, Ho said, chairmen of the boards and presidents of private schools must be ROC nationals and foreign members of the boards of trustees should not exceed one-third of the total. Although foreign advocates can from now on be partners of local legal firms, only lawyers with official ROC licenses can handle Taiwan-related legal cases.
Speaking on the same occasion, Minister of Finance Yen Ching-chang echoed Ho's optimistic views about Taiwan's capabilities to cope with the challenges that will come with membership in the WTO.

"During our 12-year struggle for WTO membership, local industries have for the most part undergone restructuring and have adjusted their business strategies in preparation for the challenges of more open markets," Yen said, adding that he is convinced that most local enterprises can withstand increased foreign competition in the wake of WTO entry.
As a matter of fact, Yen said, Taiwan companies would face new tests and challenges because of economic globalization and liberalization even if Taiwan had not been allowed to joint the WTO.

Yen pointed out that the WTO has only just begun to put forward regulations governing banking, insurance and securities services. To pave the way for its WTO accession, he said, Taiwan has gradually liberalized its financial service market since the mid-1980s. Over the past year-and-a-half, Yen said, Taiwan has finalized legislation of eight new statutes, including a merger law for financial institutions and a law regarding financial holding companies to facilitate restructuring and the rejuvenation of local financial services.
"My observation is that our local financial industry should have no difficulties dealing with WTO entry challenges," Yen said optimistically.

Moreover, Yen said, Taiwan's financial institutions will be able to branch out overseas under the WTO framework, breaking the current restraints resulting from the Beijing-imposed diplomatic isolation of the ROC.

"Although foreign institutions may have more financial products to offer, they must localize their products if they want to make a true impact on the Taiwan market," Yen said, adding that some foreign financial firms have forged strategic alliances with their local counterparts in preparation for entering the Taiwan market and even tapping the vast mainland Chinese market.

As for the sharp price hike for "red-label" rice wine because of WTO entry, Yen said this was the result of the Legislative Yuan's resolution allowing the price to be fixed indefinitely because the wine was considered a staple of every Chinese household, and should not be subject to market forces.

"Because of this, the price for "red-label" rice wine, which has been selling for NT$21 per 0.6-liter bottle for the past two decades, was distorted," Yen said, adding that the removal of the wine and tobacco monopoly system following WTO entry will allow market forces to determine the price of the wine in the future.

Council of Agriculture (COA) Chairman Chen Hsi-huang has never minced words on the WTO challenges for local farmers. With its small farming system, Chen said, Taiwan need not join the WTO from the viewpoint of agricultural development. "However, in this era of globalization, agricultural production should be an integral part of overall economic and social development."
In the past, Chen said, Taiwan placed more emphasis on agricultural production than on competitiveness and tended to offer government subsidies to cope with foreign competition.
In preparation for WTO entry, Chen said, Taiwan has set up several import relief funds to help cushion the impact on local farmers, as well as adjusting its agricultural development strategies.

"We still have significant leverage, including technological expertise and capital, and we'll continue enjoying a competitive edge in the sales of fresh vegetables and certain indigenous fruits," Chen said, adding that with new packaging and marketing strategies, many Taiwan-produced agricultural products can make their way into overseas markets. (To be continue)

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SET TO EMBRACE WTO MEMBERSHIP (III)

TEXT.P: For instance, Chen said, Taiwan was able to export more than 20 containers of garlic to Canada and the United States for the first time this year.
Wu Jung-yi, director of the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research, said he believes that Taiwan's farm produce will have a certain competitiveness in the world market.

"Nevertheless, it will still takes a while to adjust the strategy and structure of the sector," Wu said. "With entrepreneurship and technological innovation, I do not rule out the possibility that the island's agricultural production will account for 10 percent of its GDP in the future, as is the case currently in the Netherlands."
As Taiwan's agricultural population is aging and has poor adaptability, Wu said, the government should play an active role in helping the farming sector adapt itself to the severe tests lying ahead.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC REBUTS REPORTS ON MARKET CLOSURE TO CHINA AFTER WTO ENTRY

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) denied media reports Monday that Taiwan would not open its market to mainland China immediately after its formal entry to the World Trade Organization (WTO) Jan. 1, 2002.

"The reports are not true," said Fu Don-cheng, director of the MAC's Department of Economic Affairs. "On the contrary, the government will actively promote exchanges across the Taiwan Strait in the wake of our WTO accession."

Media reports quoted unidentified senior government officials as saying that Taiwan would not apply the same market-opening measures to mainland China following its WTO accession in an attempt to force Beijing to resume long-stalled cross-strait talks.

"The reports far deviate from reality," Fu said, adding that the MAC, which charts Taiwan's policy toward mainland China, would issue a formal statement after discussing the issue with other relevant government agencies.

Mainland China became a formal WTO member earlier this month. Under the WTO framework, mainland China would be entitled to demand negotiations with Taiwan should the island impose discriminating trade measures against it.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPANESE FOREIGN MINISTER CRITICIZED FOR PRO-BEIJING REMARKS
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Dec. 31 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: A Japanese foreign minister must follow the government's long-standing position calling for Taipei-Beijing issues to be resolved through peaceful means, a Japanese ruling Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) official said in a recent interview criticizing Foreign Minister Makiko Tanaka's pro-Beijing remarks made last Tuesday.

LDP Secretary-General Taku Yamasaki said in an interview aired on Fuji TV Sunday that diplomatic issues are very sensitive and should not involve comments that interfere with another country's domestic affairs.

Tanaka said Tuesday that she was hopeful that the Taiwan issue will turn out like Hong Kong in the future. The former British colony reverted to mainland China in 1997 under a "one country, two systems" formula.
The outspoken minister's remarks drew immediate protests from the Republic of China government and criticism from several major Japanese media.
Tokyo has traditionally refrained from taking sides on the Taiwan issue.

In a statement of protest, ROC representative to Japan Lo Fu-chuan stressed that the Republic of China on Taiwan is a sovereign nation whose future should be decided by its 23 million residents. He also demanded that Tanaka should retract her pro-Beijing remarks.

In an effort to clarify her comments, Tanaka explained at a news conference last Friday that when she said she hoped Taiwan could turn out like Hong Kong, she meant that the Hong Kong issue was resolved peacefully, and that she hopes the Taiwan issue will also be resolved through peaceful negotiations without the use of force.
Tokyo switched its diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing in 1972, when Tanaka's father was prime minister.

DOC.HEADLINE: STUDENTS IN TAIWAN, MAINLAND DIFFER ON BEIJING'S USE OF FORCE: SURVEY

TEXT.P: University students on both sides of the Taiwan Strait differ sharply in their view of Beijing's possible use of force against Taiwan, with 17 percent of those in Taiwan saying the event was unlikely, whereas 52 percent of mainland students saw it as a possiblity within 10 years, according to a survey released Sunday.
The poll was conducted by the National Chinese Congress of Cultures, a non-profit organization.

Dr. Kenneth Kuanling Fan, chairman of the organization, said that the group polled 2,000 students from 20 universities in Taiwan and another 400 from Peking University, Fudan University, Tsinghua University and Jiaotong University in mainland China through stratified random sampling from Dec. 17-29. A total of 1,741 responses from Taiwan and 232 from mainland China were received.

Fan said that the students had different views about the future development of cross-strait relations if agreement is not possible between the two. While 56.27 percent of the Taiwanese students believed that the status quo will remain, only 30.83 percent of the mainland students shared the same view. Only 16.96 percent of the Taiwanese students thought that Beijing would use force to take Taiwan within 10 years, while 52.5 percent of the mainland students believed that Beijing would resort to such action.

In the long run, 45.04 percent of the students in Taiwan believe the status quo can be maintained, but only 15.83 percent of the mainland students said this was possible. Just over 23 percent of the Taiwanese students see a future where the two sides of the Strait are unified while 22.8 percent envisioned an independent Taiwan.

However, more than half of the students who responded advocated some sort of unification between Taiwan and mainland China on an equal basis. Fifty-three percent of the Taiwanese students who responded supported such a formula. There was 58.33 percent support among the mainland students.
Referring to the question of direct cross-strait links, 54.04 percent of the Taiwanese students and 54.17 percent of the mainland students see it as being necessary.

Students on both sides aknowledge that the investment environment in mainland China is better than that of Taiwan. The survey results show that 53.41 percent of the Taiwanese students and 65.83 percent of the mainland students consider the investment environment in mainland China more favorable.

Since both Taiwan and mainland China have been admitted into the World Trade Organization (WTO), most students on both sides believe the authorities on both sides of the Strait will accelerate the realization of direct trade, direct transportation and direct investment. The survey showed that 55.98 percent of the Taiwanese students are positive about the development, and 53.33 percent of the mainland students have the same opinion.

Regarding a conditioned liberalization of tourist visas for mainland Chinese people, 76.38 percent of the Taiwanese students were in support of the idea and 81.67 percent of the mainland students welcomed such a decision.

As for the "no haste, be patient" policy of the Taiwanese authorities regarding investment in mainland China, only 23.45 percent of the Taiwanese students supported the continuation of the policy, compared with 53.98 percent who were against it. Among the mainland students, only 8.33 percent approved and 67.5 percent were against.
Dr. Fan said that it was the first time that the organization had conducted a survey among university students on both sides of the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: CYPRUS HOPES TO LURE YANGMING MARINE AND K SHIPPING TO ITS PORT
DOC.DATELINE: Ankara, Dec. 31 (CNA) (By Kuo Chuan-hsin and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Cyprus port authorities are seeking to lure the Taiwan-based Yangming Marine Transport Corp. to set up a transshipment hub at its southern port of Limassol, a Cyprus newspaper reported Monday.

The Cyprus Post, citing a ranking official of the Cyprus Port Administration, reported that port authorities are planning to invest millions of U. S. dollars to upgrade and enhance the port's facilities. The port is also planning to start 24-hour services in the near future, it said.

The daily newspaper said Yangming Marine, with seven ships and another, "K shipping company" with 13 vessels, are targets of the Cyprus Port Administration as part of its plan to establish a transshipment center in Limassol in the Eastern Mediterranean.

The official was also quoted as saying that both Yangming Marine and K are keen to create a transshipment hub in the Middle East by the coming spring. He also pointed out that the Cyprus port authorities will hold a seminar early next year in London to attract at least one of the two companies to ink a cooperation pact with it.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN PRESIDES OVER PROMOTION CEREMONY FOR NEW OFFICERS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Monday that military command and military administration will be integrated March 1, 2002 as part of the government's determination to streamline national defense.

Speaking at a senior military officers' promotion ceremony, Chen said although local society still has different views about the planned integration of the military command and administration, the policy will not be subject to further changes.
"I'm hopeful that all military servicemen will support the program and work wholeheartedly to make it work," Chen urged.

Currently, the military command structure runs directly from the General Staff Headquarters (GSH) to the Presidential Office, while matters of logistics are communicated between the GSH and the Ministry of National Defense (MND).
Under the new integration program, command will be taken care of by the defense ministry.

Noting that military nationalization is critical to the development of democracy, Chen said he was pleased that the military had maintained neutrality in the Dec. 1 elections for legislators and local government chiefs.
"This indicates that Taiwan's young democracy has gradually matured and that party politics has gradually taken root on the island," Chen said.
Three ROC Army major generals were promoted to lieutenant generals and 35 colonels in various military branches were promoted to major generals in Monday' ceremony.

President Chen said he took great pleasure in seeing Pan Ai-chu, director of the Political Warfare Department under the MND's Military Intelligence Bureau, become the Republic of China's first female major general in more than three decades at Monday' ceremony.
Chen said Pan's promotion shows the military's determination to promote sex equality.
